headline: Iran's Leader and Pope Seek Better Muslim-Christian Ties
abstract: Pope John Paul II, seeking to improve relations between Christianity and Islam, gives private audience to Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran; it is first papal encounter with Iranian head of state since days of Shah; photo (M)

headline: Math Book Salted With Brand Names Raises New Alarm
abstract: Article discusses controversy over textbook Mathematics: Applications and Connections and its including references to wide array of brand name consumer products, many of which appear in illustrations as well; textbook, published by McGraw-Hill Inc in 1995 and revised this year, is used in about 15 states, including California and Texas, and has been approved for use in New York City; spokesman for McGraw-Hill says that publisher received no payments from companies whose products appear in book; photo (M)

headline: INDIA LEADER PAYS VISIT TO PAKISTAN
abstract: Indian Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee, in unusual move, visits Pakistan and embraces Prime Min Nawaz Sharif; relations between them, while still tense and unpredictable, have taken turn for better in recent months; visit marks inauguration of bus service between New Delhi and Lahore; map; photos (M)

headline: A Bevy Of Bovine Tributes
abstract: Cows appear everywhere on World Wide Web, perhaps because of their ubiquitous and comforting presence in American consciousness, or maybe because many highly regarded computer-science programs are located in universities in middle of cow country, including Illinois, Wisconsin and Texas; photo (M)

headline: El Paso Energy to Buy Sonat, Creating Gas Pipeline Giant
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp agrees to buy rival Sonat Inc for $3.9 billion in stock and $1.9 billion in assumed debt, creating largest interstate natural gas pipeline company in United States; Sonat's pipelines provide gas to fast-growing markets in Southeast; bid comes month after Southern Co ends talks to buy El Paso (M)

headline: Want Your Own Talk Show? You Can Get One, on the Net
abstract: TalkNetRadio.com, Silicon Valley company, will provide Internet users with technology to start own radio talk shows from home that could be downloaded in real time by listeners on Web (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Intel Scraps I.D. Plan Over Privacy Concern  Intel, the dominant maker of computer chips, reversed a plan to activate an identifying signature in its next generation of products, capitulating to protests that the technology would compromise user privacy.    The company said it would modify the identification system in the Pentium III chips so that it was disabled unless the computer user voluntarily turned it on. Privacy groups had said they feared the I.D. system would mark a further erosion of anonymity on the Internet and allow marketers to collect detailed profiles of consumers. [Page A1.]

headline: In Japan, From a Lifetime Job to No Job at All
abstract: Japanese accustomed to lifetime employment are shocked by layoffs stemming from deep economic woes; Japan's 4.1 percent unemployment rate strikes blow to country's self-image and to social contract that has kept public complacent and one party in power for decades; jobless battle shame and despair, as well as challenge of finding work, and humiliation is even flaring into rare public anger; Takaharu Akimoto recalls disbelief at being asked to resign, seven years short of retirement; he is among older, higher-paid workers with particular problems finding new jobs; photo; graph; Government is going to great lengths to keep jobless figures from rising, providing generous subsidies to companies to keep workers (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are Up Nearly 1% on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose 0.93 percent in month ended Mar 15, to 1.83 billion shares; tables (S)

headline: Death Toll Rises in Sumatran Violence
abstract: Death toll from separatist violence in Aceh Province, Indonesia, has reached 16 and security forces are continuing house-to-house searches for suspected rebels (S)

headline: As Tough As, Well, Netting a Butterfly
abstract: Article describes dramatic fall 1998 upswing and recent flattening of futures prices as Chicago Mercantile Exchange traders charted 'millennium butterflies' for September and December 1999 and March 2000 based their on predictions about Year 2000 computer glitch; photo (M)

headline: Mexican Rebels, Showing Flair for Politics, Hold a Referendum
abstract: Mexico's Zapatista rebels hold nationwide referendum on proposals for peace with Govt; have organized balloting in every county; Govt responds with its own press campaign; Pres Ernesto Zedillo blames Zapatistas for holding up peace talks (M)

headline: SHARES CLIMB ON STOCK SPLIT AND BUYBACK PLAN
abstract: Shares of Wal-Mart Stores Inc climb after retailer says it will split its stock 2 for 1, and increase its share buyback program and its quarterly dividend (S)3

headline: DaimlerChrysler Abandons Talks About Buying Control of Nissan
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG abruptly breaks off talks to acquire controlling stake in Japan's troubled Nissan Motor; move follows Tokyo talks between chairman Jurgen Schrempp and Nissan president Yoshikazu Hanawa; Schrempp makes it clear that merger is too risky and that he is not simply holding out for more concessions (M)

headline: Aviall Is Considering Takeover by Nolan
abstract: Aviall Inc is considering friendly takeover bid from Nolan Acquisition Partners valued at more than $282 million (S)

headline: Low Hog Prices Hurt Agricultural Index
abstract: Agriculture Department reports index of prices paid farmers for their goods fell 2 percent in Dec from Nov and 6.7 percent from Dec 1997 (M)

headline: British Researchers on Animal Rights Death List
abstract: Animal rights extremists in Britain have threatened to kill 10 scientists who conduct medical testing on animals; Scotland Yard's special antiterror branch has separate data bank devoted to these fringe groups; they have safe houses, secret bank accounts, codes, Internet mailing lists and bomb-making instruction manuals; Prof Colin Blakemore, physiologist who has won awards for advances in treating vision problems, is on list of threatened scientists; he argues it is impossible to come up with any form of conventional medical treatment that has not at some point depended on research on animals; mail bomb was sent to his home; photo (M)

headline: Mexico Opponents See Politics in Clinton Visit
abstract: Pres Clinton is not scheduled to meet with any opposition figures during visit to Mexico, and they charge that he is taking sides before presidential election in 2000 (M)

headline: Campbell Sees Profit Slide After a Bad Season for Soup
abstract: Campbell Soup Co warns that its earnings in current quarter and fiscal year will be significantly lower than analysts' expectations because sales of soup were depressed by unusually warm weather in November and December; fiscal year results are expected to suffer (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: A Diamond Cartel May Be Forever; The Hereditary Leader of De Beers Pursues Post-Apartheid Growth
abstract: Interview with Nicholas Frank Oppenheimer, third generation of Oppenheimers to run De Beers; Oppenheimer, genial and open, does not mind saying that diamonds are intrinsically worthless or that a cartel is a cartel; expresses perplexity at antitrust laws in US, which he will not visit for fear of being subpoenaed in unresolved price-fixing case going back decades; is currently focusing on reorganization of De Beers-Anglo-Minorca consortium; denies that Oppenheimer families controls both De Beers and Anglo American Corp; graph; photos (M)

headline: CITIGROUP DROPPING PLANS TO ACQUIRE G-TECH UNIT
abstract: Justice Department says Citigroup will drop plan to acquire electronic benefit transfer businesss of Transactive Corp, to avert antitrust litigation; Transactive, G-Tech unit, is primary provider of electronic benefit services in three states, while Citigroup is chief contractor in 29 states (S)

headline: REPUBLIC BANKING'S SHARES RISE ON NEWS OF SALE
abstract: Shares of Republic Banking Corp of Florida rise almost 8 percent in reaction to announcement that it agreed to be bought by Union Planters Corp for $412 million in cash (S)

headline: In Choosing Nigeria Candidate, an Effort at Parity
abstract: Nigerian politicians press efforts to create parity and to heal deep wounds in nation's political soul as February 27 presidential elections near; many northerners are considering supporting southerner for post to correct injustice created in 1993, when northern-dominated military Govt annulled election apparently won by Moshood K Abiola, billionaire businessman from Yoruba southwest; map; photo (M)

headline: Vatican Seeks Mercy For Pope's Assailant
abstract: Vatican has let Italian Government know that it would favor clemency for Mehmet Ali Agca, Turkish gunman who tried to assassinate Pope John Paul II in 1981 (S)

headline: From Mud Packs to Millions
abstract: Marcia Kilgore, founder of spa and cosmetics company Bliss World, comments on its sale to LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton; photo (M)

headline: Police Abuses Start to Get Attention in China
abstract: Planned trial of seven police officers charged with summary execution of four farmers deemed troublemakers in Zhanlong, casts rare spotlight on widespread abuses by China's local police and on fledgling efforts to control them; state-owned law journals and newspapers now often publish exposes of torture and other forms of police brutality, although stories rarely seep into mainstream press; map; photo (M)

headline: Some H.M.O.'s Plan Limited Coverage for New Arthritis Drug
abstract: Arthritis sufferers who want to try Celebrex, anti-inflammatory drug newly approved by Food and Drug Administration, may have to pay for drug themselves; several of nation's largest insurers plan to limit coverage of the pill; Wellpoint Health Networks Inc and Aetna US Healthcare have restricted use; United Healthcare Corp has given drug lowest reimbursement it offers, while Kaiser Permanente is considering not covering drug; some insurers say Celebrex is much more expensive than generic brands, regarded by doctors to be equally effective (M)

headline: Bennett Harrison, 56, Urban Economist, Dies
abstract: Bennett Harrison, leading radical economist, vocal critic of United States economic policy and co-author of 1983 book The De-Industrialization of America, dies at age 56; photo (M)

headline: Oran Journal; Algeria's 'Train of Death' A Bit Safer, God Willing
abstract: Algerian paramilitary police officers are riding Train 1001 between Algiers and Oran in effort to cut down on attacks by Islamic rebels as it travels through Atlas Mountains; map; photo (M)

headline: Around-the-World Balloon Pilots Cheered on Return to Switzerland
abstract: Dr Bertrand Piccard and Brian Jones are cheered in Geneva, Switzerland, after returning from Egypt, where they completed first round-the-world balloon flight (S)

headline: Sears Settles Suit on Raising Of Its Credit Card Rates
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co to settle class-action suit charging it fraudulently raised annual interest rates on credit cards after promising not to; will pay $36 million in cash and issue store coupons worth $118 million to card holders; Sears, in separate development, says it will buy back up to $1.5 billion of its stock, about 9 percent of outstanding shares (M)

headline: Latest Israeli Candidate Has One Handicap
abstract: Azmi Bishara, Israeli Arab member of Parliament, says he will join race for Prime Minister, becoming first Arab to do so; says move is intended to thrust problems of Israel's one million Arab citizens onto agenda of campaign that has tended to ignore them; photo (M)

headline: No Agreement on Reducing Europe Farm Subsidies
abstract: European heads of state, meeting in Bonn, Germany, fail to agree on plans to reduce enormous farm subsidies; there are signs that once-sacred programs may soon be overhauled; German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who is in midst of six-month term as president of European Union, is pushing hard to scale back subsidies and production quotas for various farm products that help farmers but keep consumer prices artifically high; Germany contributes nearly $25 bilion a year to European Union, far more than any other country and more than twice what it gets back through economic or social programs; farm programs constitute nearly half European Union's $100 billion budget, and they are probably its most politically sensitive component; French Pres Jacques Chirac, whose country receives by far most farm support, is rejecting some of Schroder's basic ideas for reform--particularly his idea that individual governments should pay for more of their farm subsidies on their own; photo of Chirac (M)

headline: Santander Acquires Argentine Bank Stake
abstract: Banco Santander SA spends $179.6 million to acquire majority stake in Banco Rio de la Plata, Argentina's fourth-largest private bank by deposits (S)

headline: High-Profile Mexico Kidnapping: Puzzle With a Hint of Politics
abstract: Mexican authorities are unsure whether kidnapping of soccer star Jorge Campos Navarrete's father in Guerrero State was politically motivated; abduction comes during tense post-election standoff in state between gubernatorial candidate of Pres Ernesto Zedillo's ruling party, Rene Juarez Cisneros, who claims narrow victory, and leftist party, which disputes victory; Campos Navarrete appeared in commercials for Juarez; his father, Alvaro Campos Gonzalez, reportedly is friendly with governing party politicians (M)

headline: Libya Sets Date for Turning Over 2 Suspects in Lockerbie Bombing
abstract: Libya tells United Nations that it will hand over the two suspects in 1988 Lockerbie bombing for trial in Netherlands by April 6; appears to accept all the other conditions the US and Britain have said they want to see see met before they consider lifting economic sanctions against Libya; affirms opposition to all forms of terrorism, pledges cooperation with investigation, procedures and trial of suspects and offers to pay compensation to victims' families if they are convicted; photo (M)

headline: The Euro's Fickle Fingers Foil Many a Plan
abstract: Article on disappointing performance of European stock markets since introduction of euro, which was predicted to rise against dollar and other currencies; graph (M)

headline: Making Late-Course Adjustments to the Rest of Their Lives
abstract: John A Cutter article on adjustments faced by retirees; residents of Florida retirement community comment; most say they have little trouble filling days; photo (M)

headline: After 2d Day With Milosevic, Envoy Reports No Progress
abstract: US envoy Richard C Holbrooke, after meeting with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, says he has failed to win any change in Serbian leader's opposition to peace proposal for Kosovo (M)

headline: SEAGATE TO TAKE $50 MILLION CHARGE FOR REVAMPING
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc is expected to take third-quarter charge of $50 million to $60 million to pay for restructuring effort (S)

headline: People
abstract: Kathryn Ryan and Ellen Miller, executive vice presidents at Jordan McGrath Case & Partners/Euro RSCG Worldwide, are named co-directors of new Customer Insight Group (S)

headline: MIFFED AT EUROPE, U.S. RAISES TARIFFS FOR LUXURY GOODS
abstract: US heats up two politically contentious trade disputes with Europe, slapping 100 percent tariffs on $520 million in European products and threatening to ban Concorde from landing in US; tariffs imposed by Clinton Administration on luxury goods are part of six-year battle over trade in bananas; threat to ban Concorde is in bill passed overwhelmingly in House, in retaliation for European ruling that would ban many older American airplanes from landing in Europe; both battles are really about tensions that have erupted between US and Europe newly unified by common currency; Washington and European Union find themselves unable to resolve seemingly ordinary economic disputes, with each accusing other of defying World Trade Organization (M)

headline: KERR-MCGEE OUTLINES JOB REDUCTION MOVES
abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp plans to cut 525 jobs after completing its $2.44 billion acquisition of rival Oryx Energy Co, which is approved by shareholders (S)

headline: New-Media Shops Share Honors
abstract: CKS Partners, Ogilvy Interactive Worldwide and Wieden & Kennedy share top honors for new-media advertising at ceremony sponsored by One Club for Art and Copy (S)

headline: AIDS, the war that isn't over, gains some new marketing generals and unpaid foot soldiers.
abstract: Advertising column says Young & Rubicam, NY, is joining the American Foundation for AIDS Research, known as Amfar, in what is intended to be comprehensive, multimedia communications program; says goal is counter growing belief that AIDS is no longer as much as menace to public health as it seemed before introduction of treatments like protease inhibitor drugs (Advertising column) (M)

headline: In Disputed Move, Netanyahu Creates a National Security Council
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announces creation of American-style National Security Council to coordinate military and intelligence strategy; change, long urged by defense analysts, is now criticized as last-minute political maneuver by Government entering its final months in office; overshadowing substantive implications of move is Netanyahu's electoral battle against his former Defense Minister, Yitzhak Mordechai; Netanyahu's earlier effort to create council, on his first day in office in 1996, was blocked by Mordechai, who led fierce army opposition (M)

headline: In France, It's Zone Euro, Oui; Euroland, Non.
abstract: French Academy endorses 'zone euro' rather than 'euroland' as the way to name the 11 countries that are phasing out their national currencies in favor of the euro (S)

headline: E*TRADE RECEIVES S.E.C. APPROVAL TO START LINE OF FUNDS
abstract: E*Trade Group receives approval from Securities and Exchange Commission to start its own line of mutual funds, and company says it will establish its first fund, index fund attempting to mimic performance of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.72   5.34        3-month T-bills   4.50   4.49   5.04        6-month T-bills   4.62   4.62   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.91   3.90   3.73        10-yr. T-note   5.17   5.09   5.56        30-yr. T-bond   5.55   5.48   5.88        Telephone bd.   7.25   7.20   6.99        Municipal bds.   5.17   5.17   5.21          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: SEAGRAM TO SELL POLYGRAM ITC LIBRARY FOR $150 MILLION
abstract: Seagram Co agrees in principle to sell ITC library assets of Polygram Filmed Entertainment, unit of Universal Studios Inc, to Carlton Communications PLC of Britain for $150 million in cash (S)

headline: Iran's Leader and Pope Seek Better Muslim-Christian Ties
abstract: Pope John Paul II, seeking to improve relations between Christianity and Islam, gives private audience to Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran; it is first papal encounter with Iranian head of state since days of Shah; photo (M)

headline: Math Book Salted With Brand Names Raises New Alarm
abstract: Article discusses controversy over textbook Mathematics: Applications and Connections and its including references to wide array of brand name consumer products, many of which appear in illustrations as well; textbook, published by McGraw-Hill Inc in 1995 and revised this year, is used in about 15 states, including California and Texas, and has been approved for use in New York City; spokesman for McGraw-Hill says that publisher received no payments from companies whose products appear in book; photo (M)

headline: INDIA LEADER PAYS VISIT TO PAKISTAN
abstract: Indian Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee, in unusual move, visits Pakistan and embraces Prime Min Nawaz Sharif; relations between them, while still tense and unpredictable, have taken turn for better in recent months; visit marks inauguration of bus service between New Delhi and Lahore; map; photos (M)

headline: A Bevy Of Bovine Tributes
abstract: Cows appear everywhere on World Wide Web, perhaps because of their ubiquitous and comforting presence in American consciousness, or maybe because many highly regarded computer-science programs are located in universities in middle of cow country, including Illinois, Wisconsin and Texas; photo (M)

headline: El Paso Energy to Buy Sonat, Creating Gas Pipeline Giant
abstract: El Paso Energy Corp agrees to buy rival Sonat Inc for $3.9 billion in stock and $1.9 billion in assumed debt, creating largest interstate natural gas pipeline company in United States; Sonat's pipelines provide gas to fast-growing markets in Southeast; bid comes month after Southern Co ends talks to buy El Paso (M)

headline: Want Your Own Talk Show? You Can Get One, on the Net
abstract: TalkNetRadio.com, Silicon Valley company, will provide Internet users with technology to start own radio talk shows from home that could be downloaded in real time by listeners on Web (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Intel Scraps I.D. Plan Over Privacy Concern  Intel, the dominant maker of computer chips, reversed a plan to activate an identifying signature in its next generation of products, capitulating to protests that the technology would compromise user privacy.    The company said it would modify the identification system in the Pentium III chips so that it was disabled unless the computer user voluntarily turned it on. Privacy groups had said they feared the I.D. system would mark a further erosion of anonymity on the Internet and allow marketers to collect detailed profiles of consumers. [Page A1.]

headline: In Japan, From a Lifetime Job to No Job at All
abstract: Japanese accustomed to lifetime employment are shocked by layoffs stemming from deep economic woes; Japan's 4.1 percent unemployment rate strikes blow to country's self-image and to social contract that has kept public complacent and one party in power for decades; jobless battle shame and despair, as well as challenge of finding work, and humiliation is even flaring into rare public anger; Takaharu Akimoto recalls disbelief at being asked to resign, seven years short of retirement; he is among older, higher-paid workers with particular problems finding new jobs; photo; graph; Government is going to great lengths to keep jobless figures from rising, providing generous subsidies to companies to keep workers (M)

headline: Uncovered Short Positions Are Up Nearly 1% on Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers reports open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market rose 0.93 percent in month ended Mar 15, to 1.83 billion shares; tables (S)

headline: Death Toll Rises in Sumatran Violence
abstract: Death toll from separatist violence in Aceh Province, Indonesia, has reached 16 and security forces are continuing house-to-house searches for suspected rebels (S)

headline: Bristol-Myers Shifts Two Accounts
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co reassigns to roster agencies two accounts that had been handled by Intuition Group; Revitalique brand has been reassigned to Kaplan Thaler Group; billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million; Natural Instincts brand has been reassigned to Foote, Cone & Belding; billings estimated at $15 million (S)

headline: FRANKLIN RESOURCES TO CUT 7% OF WORK FORCE
abstract: Franklin Resources Inc will take $58 million charge to cut 7 percent of its work force; Franklin will eliminate about 560 jobs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stocks Lift Nasdaq to 3d Straight High  Propelled by a ravenous appetite among investors for technology shares, stocks soared, lifting the Nasdaq composite index to its third consecutive record and 11th since Thanksgiving. The Nasdaq jumped 43.22 points, or 2 percent, to 2,251.27.    The Dow Jones industrial average, helped by a strong performance from I.B.M., rose 126.92 points, or 1.4 percent, to 9,311.19. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 16.67 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,244.77, also a record. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as the yield of the 30-year issue rose to 5.20 percent. [Page C7.]

headline: A Brazilian Shot Heard Round the World
abstract: With Brazil as the fulcrum, the world's financial markets seesawed last week, plunging day after day, only to swing back up joyously on Friday, once the Brazilian Government decided to quit defending its currency, the real. Hoping the move will lead to falling interest rates, it will let the real float.

headline: Enthusiasm for New Currency Varies
abstract: Enthusiasm for new euro currency varies throughout participating European nations; although Helmut Kohl, former Chancellor of Germany, was probably Europe's most powerful and determined champion of euro, German Government agecnies are decidedly less enthusiastic; people in France, Italy and Spain have been somewhat more enthusiastic about euro; photo (M)

headline: Three Honored For Display Work
abstract: Point-of-Purchase Advertising Institute names Richard Leeds, Thomas Murphy Sr and Sol Berger to its hall of fame (S)

headline: Schroder Backs Design for a Vast Berlin Holocaust Memorial
abstract: Agreement is reached on Holocaust memorial in Berlin, Germany's new capital, after bitter debate; memorial will include vast field of stone pillars, 65-foot-high wall of books and research center for scholars; has been approved by Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder but still faces parliamentary review; blends longstanding proposls by New York architect Peter Eisenman with additions intended to satisfy new Govt of Social Democrats and Greens, who in 1998 opposed vast memorial, causing uproar (M)

headline: CALENERGY IN $236 MILLION GENERATOR DEAL WITH EL PASO
abstract: Calenergy Co to sell half of its interest in 14 generators to El Paso Energy Corp for $236.1 million in cash; El Paso will also cover $23.5 million in project costs for Calenergy's CE Generation unit, which operates 12 power plants and is building 2; sale will help satisfy requirements of regulators related to Calenergy's $2.95 bilion purchase of MidAmerican Energy Holding Co; Calenergy is also selling three geothermal projects to Caithness Energy LLC for $227 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Olivetti Races To Add Funds For a Heftier Telecom Bid
abstract: ROMEâ€”  Olivetti SpA, fighting fiercely to keep alive its takeover bid for Telecom Italia SpA, was scrambling Wednesday to raise about 23 trillion to 25 trillion lire ($13.5 billion to $14.7 billion) in additional funding, financial sources in Milan said.

headline: Ukrainian Seeks U.S. Asylum
abstract: Former Ukraine Prime Min Pavlo Lazarenko, who was detained as he tried to enter United States, seeks political asylum; faces corruption charges in Ukraine and claims he fears persecution by Pres Leonid Kuchma's Government (S)

headline: Trying to Get in Tune With the Digital Age; Recording Industry Seeks a Standard For Distributing Music on the Web
abstract: Recording industry, $12-billion-a-year business, is trying to catch up to Internet era; industry is trying to protect its franchise by developing uniform, industry-wide standard for digital distribution of music; task force of recording companies, software programmers and consumer electronics makers will begin work on project, called Secure Digital Music Initiative, aimed at making recordings available as pure digital information while letting only copyright owners choose how information can be disseminated; this is effort by major recording labels to stake out retail territory in one part of music business they do not control, even as their power is being challenged on Internet by home-recorded musicians, independent labels and countless mouse-wielding music fans; photos; chart (M)

headline: Serb View: A Victory
abstract: Serbian official news media portrays ambiguous outcome of Kosovo peace talks as considerable Serb victory, stand not disputed by foreign diplomats; Pres Slobodan Milosevic has had to make no irrevocable decisions, despite weeks of intense Western pressure (M)

headline: THE COMPLETE MASTERCOOK SUITE
abstract: Eric Asimov reviews The Complete Mastercook Suite, a CD-ROM cookbook; photo (M)

headline: Schroder's New Politics Tripped Up by Hesse Voters
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's coalition of Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens suffers sharp defeat in Hesse elections; opposition Christian Democrats win 44 percent of vote after campaign attacking Schroder's proposals for making citizenship easier for immigrants to obtain; Green vote plunges to 7 percent; Schroder's so-called Red-Green coalition had ruled state for eight years; his stumbling first three months in office clearly affected voted; photo (M)

headline: Trying to Beat the Clock
abstract: Alice Hector, Miami lawyer who lost primary custody of her children because of her long hours, quits her job as partner at Steel, Hector & Davis to set open her own firm, Hector & Harke, with three other lawyers; hopes to be able to leave work early a couple of afternoons a week to be with her two young girls; is appealing decision awarding their custody to her ex-husband, Robert Young (S)

headline: TCI's Cable Revenue Fell by 7% in 1998
abstract: AT&T Corp says cable television revenue at recently acquired Tele-Communications Inc fell 7 percent last year to $5.97 billion, from $6.42 billion in 1997, as it bought and sold cable systems to get better geographical clusters of customers; says TCI had 10.7 million cable customers at the end of 1998 and systems that reach 17.9 million homes (S)

headline: Trading Activity Surges at Charles Schwab
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp, nation's largest Internet broker, says average number of trades a day on which it earned a commission was 184,000 in January, up 144 percent from year earlier, as on-line trading soared; average daily number of on-line trades for month was 153,000; investors put $8.8 billion of net new assets into Schwab, bringing company's assets to $521 billion (S)

headline: Trickiest Divides Are Among Big Powers at Kosovo Talks
abstract: Hosts of Kosovo peace talks, Rambouillet, France, focus on their divisions; France and United States agree to compromise under which United Nations Security Council will be asked to 'endorse,' not 'authorize' deployment of NATO peacekeepers; more practical debate is over how quickly ethnic Albanian's Kosovo Liberation Army should be required to demobilize (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Comcast Buying Mediaone In a Deal Worth $53 Billion  Comcast plans to acquire Mediaone for $53 billion, creating the nation's third-largest cable television company.    The deal, however, has almost nothing to do with television. The reason for the combination is the cable industry's race with telephone companies to offer superfast access to the Internet. [Page A1.]

headline: Banana Talks With Europe Turn Nasty U.S.
abstract: United States and European Union are unable to agree on compromise in increasingly acerbic trade row over bananas; US, backed by Latin American countries, argues that Chiquita Brands International and Dole Food Co are illegally restrained from selling Latin American-grown bananas in Europe; World Trade Orgn panel ruled in 1997 that European import regulations favored Caribbean nations, many of them former European colonies; revised European banana trade policy went into effect Jan 1, but US claims European Union continues to violate international trade rules; photo (M)

headline: Banks in Ecuador Reopen After Week's Closing, but Taxi Strike Aggravates Tensions
abstract: Banks in Ecuador open for first time in over week, during which Government had kept them closed because of worsening financial crisis; strike by taxi drivers blocks roads and brings commerce and transport to near halt; taxi drivers are protesting tripling in gasoline prices, to over $3 gallon, announced by Pres Jamil Mahuad (M)

headline: CITIGROUP COMBINES 2 DIVISIONS IN DERIVATIVES REVAMPING
abstract: Citigroup Inc reorganizes its derivatives unit to combine businesses of its Citibank banking and Salomon Smith Barney brokerage divisions; group is headed by Narayan Prasad (S)

headline: Profit Plunges 69% at Seagram
abstract: The Seagram Company, said today that its second-quarter profit fell 69 percent because of box-office flops by its Universal Studios unit, including ''Meet Joe Black'' and ''Babe: Pig in the City.''    Profit before one-time items dropped to $18 million, or 5 cents a diluted share, compared with $58 million, or 17 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Seagram had forecast that it would earn 2 cents a share in the quarter ended Dec. 31. Revenue rose 11 percent, to $3.33 billion from $3.01 billion. Seagram, which is based in Montreal, reports in United States dollars.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: INVESTIGATION INTO DIANA CRASH ENDS -- Magistrates completed a 17-month investigation into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in a automobile crash that also killed her escort, Mohamed (Dodi) al-Fayed, and the driver, Henri Paul. There were no details on the findings or substance of the inquiry. A decision on whether to bring manslaughter or other charges against nine photographers and a motorcyclist accused of chasing the car is expected by May.     Craig R. Whitney (NYT)    RUSSIA: AGREEMENT IS REACHED WITH I.M.F. -- After meetings with the International Monetary Fund, First Deputy Prime Minister Yuri Maslyukov, left, said that the fund is ready to refinance its old loans to Russia, once it is satisfied Russia is sticking to its proposed 1999 budget. Russia, whose industrial production showed signs of recovery in late 1998, has been pressing for a reprieve on a $4.5 billion debt payment due later this year.   Celestine Bohlen (NYT)

headline: U.S. to Auction Debt 2 Days This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills, as well as a 52-week bill and a 12-day cash management bill that will be auctioned tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.54 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was 4.53 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 4.62 percent.

headline: Marvin Stone, 89, Packaging Executive
abstract: Marvin Stone, founder of Stone Container Corp, dies at age 89 (S)

headline: West's Bosnia Move May Hurt Kosovo Bid
abstract: United States and its allies are sending contradictory signals to Belgrade just before peace talks to Kosovo are due to resume, making it less likely that Pres Slobodan Milosevic will capitulate on American terms; Carlos Westendorp, Western envoy who essentially runs Bosnia, has fired elected Bosnian Serb President, Nikola Poplasen, and announced that strategic northern Bosnian town of Brcko is to be taken out of Bosnian Serb hands; unseating of elected official may increase Milosevic's anger with West; Western officials claim timing is coincidental; map (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks War Crimes Trial of Top Khmer Rouge Leaders
abstract: Clinton Administration, working to insure that two top Khmer Rouge defectors are put on trial for their roles in deaths of over million Cambodians in 1970's, is trying to organize international tribunal under United Nations auspices that would not be opposed by China and current Cambodian Government; US officials say one compromise would call for defectors, Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea, to be charged with crimes against humanity that occurred from 1975 to 1979, when Khmer Rouge under leadership of Pol Pot ruled Cambodia, and not for crimes that took place afterward; photos (M)

headline: SUPREME INTERNATIONAL AGREES TO ACQUIRE PERRY ELLIS
abstract: Supreme International Corp to acquire Perry Ellis International, which is privately held, for $75 million in cash (S)

headline: Edward Windsor, Prince, Will Take Sophie . . .
abstract: Buckinham Palace announces that Prince Edward, 34, Queen Elizabeth's youngest child, will wed Sophie Rhys-Jones, 33, this year; photo (M)

headline: German Reds and Greens Get the Blues
abstract: Tensions and turbulence persist within German Govt, 10 days after abrupt resigntion of Oskar Lafontaine as Finance Minister, which far from bringing calm seems only to have exacerbated divisions; situation has left fate of six-month-old governing coalition of Social Democrats and environmentalist Greens unclear since euphoria and bold ambitions that marked birth of country's first Red-Green Govt has vanished in pall of confusion (M)

headline: New Profits in Old Bottles; Companies Find Bonus in Drugs That Cure Several Ills
abstract: Article discusses how drug companies, in effort to stretch profits, are developing second and third uses for existing compounds; in one example, Glaxo Wellcome rolled out buproprion as Wellbutrin in February 1997 for depression; company reintroduces it as Zyban in April 1997 as anti-smoking drug; while drug companies need FDA approval before such alternate uses can be cited on drug's label, agency no longer frowns heavily on pharmaceutical companies' promoting ther medications for other uses without FDA approval; photo (M)

headline: Fueled by Market, Stock Funds Received $26.4 Billion in March
abstract: Trimtabs.com Investment Research says investors put about $26.4 billion into stock mutual funds in March, biggest monthly inflow since last April; Investment Company Institute says figure compares with $757.7 million in February, lowest number since August, when $11.6 billion was taken out (M)

headline: SEAGRAM TO REVAMP ITS SPIRITS AND WINES BUSINESS
abstract: Seagram Co will reorganize its spirits and wines business over next six months, shifting from regional and brand group structure to single, senior management team based in New York (S)

headline: Technology Issues Drag Down Indexes on Profit Taking
abstract: Nasdaq composite index drops 46.67 points, or 1.86 percent, to 2,463.42; Dow Jones industrial average declines 71.58 points, to 9,274.12; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index loses 11.01 points, to 1,261.99; graph; chart (M)

headline: Less Oversight Of Derivatives Is Supported By Greenspan
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan says that success of derivatives traded outside United States suggests that United States futures markets could operate with less Government oversight (S)

headline: Home Sales Up by 10.4%, Setting Record During 1998
abstract: Commerce Department reports sales of new homes surged to record in 1998; sales totaled 888,000, up 10.4 percent from year earlier and well above previous high of 819,000 set in 1977; in December, new single-family homes sold at seasonally adjusted annual rate of 978,000 units; Conference Board reports index of leading economic indicators rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December, following increases of half a percent in November and one-tenth of 1 percent in October; graph; chart (M)

headline: Trial Is Getting Under Way Today in Prozac Patent Lawsuit
abstract: Patent infringement trial in Indianapolis may determine when Americans can pay lower price for popular anti-depressant Prozac; Eli Lilly & Co is suing Barr Laboratories and Geneva Pharmaceuticals unit of Novartis AG, which filed applications with Food and Drug Administration to make generic versions of Prozac; Barr, in its application with FDA, claimed Lilly's patent is invalid in part because company did not disclose all relevant information about drug; Prozac's worldwide sales last year are expected to be $2.8 billion, almost one-third of Lilly's 1998 revenue; its sales of Prozac could drop as much as 75 percent if generic drug becomes available (M)

headline: United Air Faces Long Odds as It Pursues Merger
abstract: United Airlines' plan to acquire America West Airlines is expected to face obstacles from Justice Department, from its pilots, who own 25 percent of company and may find their seniority compromised in the deal, and from Continental Airlines, which has a marketing alliance with America West, owns 8 percent of its voting stock and has right of first refusal to buy the controlling stake now held by Texas Pacific Group; America West stock soars 18 percent, and there are some who believe a United deal is not so farfetched; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAY  Existing-Home Sales Dec.    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence Jan.    WEDNESDAY  None Dec.    THURSDAY  Weekly Jobless Claims  Durable Goods Orders Dec.    FRIDAY  G.D.P. 4th Qtr.

headline: Adviser's Guilty Plea Reinstated by Court
abstract: New York appeals court reinstates 1990 guilty plea of Donald C Carter; Carter pleaded guilty to overbilling clients of his proxy-solicitation business and filing bogus state tax return; he was sentenced to 16 to 48 months in prison and ordered to pay $50,000 fine and set up $1 million restitution fund; he also paid $1.75 million to New York State; Carter, who was released from prison in 1991, now contends he is innocent (S)

headline: Northrop Grumman to Restate Results for a Write-Off Loss
abstract: The Northrop Grumman Corp says it will restate its results for fourth quarter of 1998, taking a loss because of $30 million write-off associated with an investment in start-up rocket company Kistler Aerospace Corp; says it will report loss for fourth quarter of $3 million rather than net profit of $17 million it had announced in February (M)

headline: Omnicom to Acquire A Design Company
abstract: Omnicom Group agrees to buy Designory Inc (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Feb 14 article on Thomas S Monaghan's formation of lay support group for Roman Catholic executives, which misstated names of foundation and law firm that support group

headline: Chicago Executive Leaving Bozel
abstract: David Wojdyla to leave Bozell Worldwide to open his own agency (S)

headline: Lois to Reorganize Chicago Operations
abstract: Lois/USA, New York, to reorganize its operations in Chicago by spinning off part of an office there to form Chicago office for Fogarty Klein & Partners, agency owned by Lois/USA (Advertising column) (S)

headline: With German Craft Rules, It's Hard Just to Get to Work
abstract: Article on countless numbers of skilled Germans caught up in broad political battle over job protection and workplace flexibility in nation with some of strictest work rules in Europe, which have helped produce one of best-paid and most productive work forces in world; map (M)

headline: Milosevic Might Win From the Loss of Kosovo
abstract: Whispers about a face-saving Serbian loss to the world's most powerful military alliance began here long before NATO bombs started to fall on Yugoslavia.    The whispers -- reinforced earlier this week in interviews with well-placed officials in the regime of Slobodan Milosevic, with opposition leaders and with Belgrade residents -- all follow a similar line of Balkan logic. It goes like this:

headline: U.S. Proposes Easing U.N. Curbs on Iraq Oil
abstract: US proposes ending restrictions on how much oil Iraq can export to pay for relief supplies; acts under pressure from UN Security Council to alleviate suffering; State Department emphasizes that proposal is not lifting of sanctions (S)

headline: Mexican Gang Frees Soccer Star's Father
abstract: Kidnappers free Alvaro Campos Gonzalez, father of Mexican soccer star Jorge Campos Navarrete, reportedly after ransom is paid (S)

headline: India Accuses 4 of Plotting To Bomb U.S. Consulates
abstract: Indian police report foiling plot to bomb American consulates in Madras and Calcutta by arresting Bangladeshi man, Sayed Abu Nasir, and three alleged accomplices, Mohammed Gulab, Mohammed Nawab and Aga Khan; say other supects remain at large; say Nasir claims to have met Osama bin Laden, blamed for bombings of American embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, at terrorist training camp in Afghanistan, where he says he was chosen as agent by Pakistani intelligence officials; American counterterrorism experts probe case; United States intelligence officials say reports from India are overblown; photo (M)

headline: Intuit's Chief Urges Division of Microsoft
abstract: Intuit Inc chief executive William H Harris, testifying in Microsoft Corp antitrust trial, urges Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson to divide or limit Microsoft so that company cannot use its market-dominating Windows operating system to promote its other products; Microsoft lawyer John Warden opens his cross-examination of Harris by chastising him for offering such testimony without giving Microsoft any warning (M)

headline: As Kosovo Talks Continue, NATO Troop Plan Lags Badly
abstract: Clinton Administration and NATO officials say plans for using NATO troops, key element for an agreement in civil war in Kosovo, Serbia, lag far behind as peace talks progress in Rambouillet, France; how NATO force would be deployed and discussions over what authority it would have in Kosovo are far from final even though two-week deadline is set for talks; photo (M)

headline: Head to Head, Albright and Russia's Prime Minister Do Not See Eye to Eye
abstract: Russian Prime Min Yevgeny Primakov and Sec Madeleine Albright, in Moscow, sit down to dinner, nearly the 20th occasion they have done so during maturing of relationship between former spymaster and former university president; photo; Primakov describes recent trip to Siberia, making implicit suggestion that US should support him as best man to clean up Russia's huge problems; Albright, however, reportedly believes Primakov's formative work during cold war left indelible mark, and he continues to be suspicious of US (S)

headline: A man of more than one hat finds he likes an unconventional arrangement with Quaker State.
abstract: IT has long been said that anyone who represents himself or herself in court has a fool for a lawyer and a fool for a client. But the verdict may be somewhat different in the case of a marketing executive who has had himself for an agency and an agency executive who has had himself for a client.    That person is one and the same: William W. Tucker, managing partner at the Tucker Partnership, a New York agency with estimated billings of $40 million from such clients as Fordham University, the General Electric Company and the Quaker State Corporation.

headline: Hawaii Gas Station Deal
abstract: US Restaurant Properties Inc acquires 27 service station properties in Hawaii from Equilon Enterprises, joint venture between Shell Oil Co and Texaco Inc; deal includes former Texaco terminal property; sale was forced by Federal and state regulators concerned about anticompetitive effects of joint venture (S)

headline: Primakov Tries to Buy Time to Aid Yeltsin Case
abstract: Russian Prime Min Yevgeny Primakov tries to solidify Yeltsin Government's hold on power, by proposing new agreement with Communist-led Parliament; accord would remove cloud of impeachment hanging over Yeltsin, in name of political stability, and give Primakov time to fill top ranks of Kremlin with loyalists and to position himself to succeed Yeltsin (S)

headline: China Votes A U.N. Force Out of Balkans
abstract: United States and its principal allies press China to allow United Nations peacekeeping force in Macedonia to continue operating for at least few more weeks, despite Beijing's veto of resolution extending force's mandate (S)

headline: Ford Has Told Volvo It Is Interested in Buying Car Unit
abstract: Ford Motor Co tells Volvo AB that it would be interested in acquiring Volvo's car division if it were put for sale, but no formal offer has been made nor has Volvo expressed desire to open negotiations (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTEGRATED ELECTRICAL SERVICES INC.,  Houston, an electrical contractor, said it planned to acquire six electrical service companies with combined annual revenue of $43 million. The names of the companies and the purchase terms were not disclosed.    WIT CAPITAL GROUP INC., an on-line securities firm, said it plans an initial public stock offering in the second quarter of this year.

headline: Paris Boutiques Showcase Artists and Designers
abstract: PARISâ€”  While fashion designers often turn to art for inspiration, increasingly the fashion crowd is turning to the art world to add another dimension to its boutiques.

headline: IOC Reforms Olympic City Selection Rules
abstract: LAUSANNE, Switzerlandâ€”  In an effort to curb the corruption that has tarnished the selection process for Olympic host cities and sparked a winter of widespread discontent, the International Olympic Committee formally adopted a new system Thursday that curtails the direct contact its members will have with the six cities bidding for the 2006 Winter Games.

headline: Fitzgerald Regains Aruba Account
abstract: Aruba Tourism Authority returns its account to Fitzgerald & Co after dismissing agency two weeks ago (S)

headline: Massacres of Low-Born Touch Off a Crisis in India
abstract: India's eastern state of Bihar has nation's highest rates of illiteracy and poverty; untouchables, poorest of poor, have banded together under various leftist banners to agitate for higher wages, share of land and end to sexual exploitation of women; in response, both middle- and upper-cast landowners have struck back with terror tactics; in hamlet of Shanker Bigha, private army maintained by high-caste landowners massacred 22 villagers; in village of Narayanpur, 12 untouchables were massacred; bloodletting has set off crisis that has rocked state's poltical establishment and humbled national government coalition; police say they arrested 47 members of landowners' militia as well as dozens of members of leftist groups; human rights groups say police are tougher on leftists than on landowners' armies; photo; map (M)

headline: Albanian-Americans Rally To Voice Support for Raids
abstract: More than 3,000 Albanian-Americans march from UN headquarters to Yugoslav Mission in New York City in support for NATO's bombing campaign against Yugoslavia; photo (M)

headline: Gavin Relly, 72, Dies; Helped End Apartheid
abstract: Gavin W H Relly, retired chairman of Anglo American Corp, who in 1985 led delegation of business leaders to meet the banned African National Congress in Zambia, dies at age 72; photo (M)

headline: Lexmark Divides And Chooses
abstract: Lexmark International ends review for its advertising account, with billings estimated at $20 million; creative duties will be handled by Warwick Baker O'Neill and media duties will be handled by DeWitt Media; both parts of account had been at Grey Advertising (S)

headline: After Russian Lesson, Bond Prices Remain Stable in Latest Crisis
abstract: US bond prices remain stable despite Brazil's currency devaluation in contrast to aftermath of Russia's collapse in August; price of 30-year Treasury bond rises 1 6/32, to 101 28/32, and yield drops to 5.13 percent, from 5.20 percent on Jan 12; graph; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Brisk Store Sales Defy Usual January Doldrums
abstract: Goldman, Sachs retail composite index rose 7.4 percent in January, up from 4.5 percent in January 1998; increases, which exceed analysts' expectations by 2 percent to 3 percent, are particularly notable because they occurred across retail spectrum; chart (M)

headline: Treasury Sales List Is Confined to Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills, which will be held tomorrow, instead of the usual Monday, because of the Presidents' Day holiday today.

headline: DUPONT TO SELL OFF REST OF CONOCO TO SHAREHOLDERS
abstract: DuPont Co plans to sell off its 70 percent stake in Conoco Inc by end of third quarter (S)

headline: An Agency Clears the Way For 3-Bank Deal in France
abstract: French regulators approve $38 billion unsolicited offer made by Banque Nationale de Paris SA for Societe Generale SA and Paribas SA, clearing way for the creation of the world's biggest bank; analysts say decision could force Societe Generale to raise its own friendly offer for Paribas (M)

headline: Theft Report On Atom Data 'Unfounded,' China Says
abstract: Foreign Min Tang Jiaxuan denies charges, circulating within United States Government, that China's spies stole nuclear arms designs, news conference (M)

headline: HILTON IN TALKS TO ACQUIRE SUMMERFIELD SUITES CHAIN
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp is in talks to buy Patriot American Hospitality Inc's Summerfield Suites chain and several other hotels for as much as $1 billion; Hilton is also discussing equity investment of as much as $350 million in Patriot (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Government and Intel Reach Antitrust Settlement  The Federal Trade Commission reached a tentative settlement with Intel, the world's largest producer of computer chips, a day before opening arguments were set to begin in the Government's antitrust suit against Intel.    Although Government officials and Intel executives did not announce the precise terms of the proposed settlement, it does set out guidelines for when Intel has to disclose its technology to other companies. Intel's refusal to share technical details of its microprocessor chips with three companies was at the heart of the Government's complaint. [Page A1.]

headline: British Bookseller Plans Internet Service
abstract: W H Smith Group PLC, Britain's largest book retailer, to set up free Internet access service through venture with Microsoft Corp and British Telecommunications PLC; users will be able to buy books, music and videos; move counters free service begun by Dixons Group PLC (S)

headline: Olivetti Bid for Telecom Italia: High-Stakes Corporate Theater
abstract: Olivetti's hostile bid for its much larger rival, Telecom Italia, is fraught with risk; merger would unite Italy's two largest telephone companies; Telecom Italia remains bloated and inefficient company that has undergone three major management changes in last 18 months; deal will be very expensive, forcing Olivetti to sell assets to raise cash; tender offer will consist of cash, stocks and bonds worth $60 billion; Olivetti expects to make its offer through Tecnost SpA, separately traded Olivetti unit; Roberto Colaninno, Olivetti chairman, says he is motivated by fact that Telecom Italia faces threat of foreign takeover that would leave one of nation's industrial jewels in non-Italian hands; photos; chart (M)

headline: Forget the Oscars, Here Come the Webbys
abstract: International Academy of Digital Arts and Sciences announces 110 nominees for Webby Awards in 22 categories; Internet awards are creation of International Data Group, which formed academy; photo (M)

headline: A Balloonist's Adventurous Lineage
abstract: Article profiles Dr Bertrand Piccard on occasion of his completing balloon trip around world; photo (M)

headline: Turkey's Political Turmoil Deepens as National Election Nears
abstract: Turkey faces deep uncertainties; national election is approaching, Parliament is in open rebelion against political establishment, murderous terror attacks are being mounted against civilians and trial of Abdullah Ocalan, hated Kurdish guerrilla leader, is approaching; group of disgruntled members of Parliament vote to consider postponing April 18 election and debate other measures abhorrent to poltical and military elite (M)

headline: British Report Finds Racism Pervades Police
abstract: Long-awaited British Govt report says London's police force is riven with pernicious and institutionalized racism and suggests that its chief officers accept that conclusion as condition of keeping their commands; makes 70 recommendatons for changes in police practices to usher in fundamental transformation of race relations in Britain (M)

headline: Bogota Sees Drug War as Path to Peace
abstract: Colombia Pres Andres Pastrana says that ending civil war that has ravaged his country for nearly 40 years depends on rebels' willingness to help stamp out drug trafficking in areas they control; photo (M)

headline: $1.65 Billion Britain Fund
abstract: Nomura Co, Japanese investment bank, and Serco Group PLC, project management concern, agree to establish fund valued at $1.65 billion (US) to acquire pieces of Britain's public infrastructure; British Government is considering plan to involve private finance in managing and owning public businesses rather than privatizing them through share offering; fund will be known as Serco Nomura Infrastructure Fund (S)

headline: Fallon McElligott tries to shore up its New York operations with a new top management team.
abstract: Fallon McElligott is hoping that reconfigured management team will get its operations in New York back on track; in December, Fallon McElligott hired Jamie Barrett as creative director for New York office; Barrett completes four-person team of managers that also includes Alison Burns; Barrett comments (M)

headline: Switching to New Jobs, Endangering Savings
abstract: Challenger, Gray & Christmas study finds increasing number of baby boomers in middle of their careers have already made several job switches; says 41 percent of job seekers surveyed in 1997, with median age of 45, reported working at four or more places; warns multiple moves limit amount workers can build up in employer-run retirement savings plans; notes many job-changers who take distributions from plans fail to meet 60-day rollover deadline and lose substantial amount to taxes (M)/

headline: Retail Sales Climbed 7.6% In February
abstract: Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi's report for sales at stores open at least a year shows sales rose 7.6 percent in February, more than expected; Wal-Mart's sales rose 10.3 percent, topping industry leader's plan for 5 percent to 7 percent gain; sales rose 12 percent at the Gap; other sales figures noted; graph; chart (M)

headline: Seagram Division Consolidates Duties
abstract: Seagram Americas, unit of Seagram Co, consolidates media planning and buying responsibilities for all liquor brands except Absolut vodka at Mediacom unit of Grey Advertising; billings, which had been divided among several agencies, including Mediacom, are estimated at $46 million to $50 million (S)

headline: Ex-Official Urges Beijing to End Tiananmen 'Cover-Up'
abstract: Former Chinese official Bao Tong, in letter to China's leaders two months before 10th anniversary of crackdown on student protesters in Tiananmen Square, urges them to end 'cover up' and to renounce order that sent soldiers to disperse demonstrators, killing hundreds; Bao was jailed from 1989 to 1996 for sympathizing with protesters (M)

headline: South Africa Limps Out Of Bad Year For Police
abstract: This Christmas-New Year's season has not been kind to the South African police. But then, 1998 was not a very good year for them in general.    Colin Chauke, the mastermind of blood-soaked armored-car robberies and South Africa's most-wanted man, was not behind bars by Christmas as Bushie Engelbrecht, the country's most famous detective had, in a rash moment, promised he would be.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ASHLAND INC., -- Russell, Ky., said it would divide its wholly owned Ashland Chemical Co. into separate distribution and specialty chemicals businesses. The new divisions will be called Ashland Distribution Co. and Ashland Specialty Chemicals Co.    MBNA CORP., -- Wilmington, Del., a credit card company, agreed to buy the $103 million credit card portfolio of First Virginia Banks Inc., Falls Church, Va., for undisclosed terms.

headline: At Nicaragua Mudslide Site, Clinton's Aid Offer Falls Short of His Goal
abstract: Pres Clinton, in Nicaragua on first day of four-day tour of Central America, says US will provide additional $120 million to Nicaragua to build temporary shelters, repair roads, provide medical care and remove land mines that were uprooted by torrential rains and mudslides of Hurricane Mitch last Oct; Clinton's request for nearly $1 billion more for Central America is stalled in Congress in partisan dispute; map; photo (M)

headline: Cuba Attacks as 'Deceptive' Clinton's Easing of Embargo
abstract: Ricardo Alarcon, high-ranking Cuban official, denounces Pres Clinton's proposals to ease some restrictions in United States' embargo of Cuba; calls them 'deceptive maneuver' intended to deflect growing opposition around world to embargo; Alarcon says changes are meant to hide Clinton's rejection of bipartisan commmission in United States to review wisdom of 37-year-old embargo; Alarcon suggests that new proposal to let Americans other than family members send money to Cubans has sinister purpose; notes Cuban-Americans in Miami financed terrorist groups that have bombed hotels in Havana, among other things (M)

headline: SmithKline to Sell Off Units for $1.97 Billion
abstract: In a move to increase lagging earnings, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the world's eighth-largest drug company, announced yesterday that it would sell its clinical laboratories division and its pharmacy benefits management unit for $1.97 billion in cash and stock.    The company also said that it would cut 3,000 jobs from its worldwide work force, now about 58,000, by the end of 2002 and sell or close plants that are not essential to its core operations of pharmaceuticals and consumer products. The reorganization will result in a $1.2 billion charge over the next four years.

headline: Demeaning a Nobelist
abstract: Amartya Sen, Indian citizen and 1998 Nobel laureate in economics, is detained by Swiss immigration officials after arriving Zurich airport without a visa; mentions incident in speech to World Economic Forum in Davos, saying no one seems to pay attention to difficulty third-world citizens have in traveling; photo (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Cars, Sex and Stocks On One Web Site
abstract: Joseph Preston seeks to raise $7.5 million in stock offering for Efox.net, male-oriented electronic-commerce Web site focusing on women, cars, sports and stocks; adult-themed sites make money on Intenet, but they are risky business as far as financial community is concerned; photo (S)

headline: Some Foreign Funds Oppose Olivetti Bid
abstract: Standard Life Investments, one of Telecom Italia SpA's largest shareholders, and other investors say they oppose $58 billion hostile takeover offer for company by Olivetti because it would saddle company with debt and hamper growth; Standard Life is mounting campaign to persuade other shareholders to block takeover (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: STILL AWASH IN ILLEGAL ALCOHOL -- Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov acknowledged that a campaign to combat the production and sale of illegal alcohol had failed. Lax control over the alcohol market has cost the Government several billion dollars in lost revenues every year. Taxes on alcohol made up 30 percent of state revenues in Soviet times, but now account for less than 2 percent.   (AP)    BELGIUM: GIRDING FOR EUROPEAN VOTE -- The European Commission will resign in a vote scheduled for next Thursday only if two-thirds of the 626 legislators in the European Parliament vote their lack of confidence in it, the commission president, Jacques Santer, said. The vote comes after the Parliament refused to endorse the commission's budget report last month, citing allegations of mismanagement and fraud.   (NYT)

headline: Imperial Chemical's Sale of Unit Collapses
abstract: Imperial Chemical Industries acknowledges that $1 billion deal to sell its white pigment business to DuPont Co and NL Industries has collapsed, renewing analysts' concerns about British company's ability to reduce a mountain of debt; DuPont and NL Industries pulled out of deal because of undisclosed conditions set by American Federal Trade Commission (M)

headline: Snoopy and the 'Peanuts' gang will no longer be Metropolitan Life's main representatives.
abstract: Advertising column describes Metropolitan Life Insurance Co's new advertising campaign; it will feature actors representing its agents and customers, telling company's story, rather than Snoopy and other comic strip characters featured for last 15 years; Young & Rubicam is advertising agency; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.56   4.56   5.41        3-month T-bills   4.35   4.40   4.96        6-month T-bills   4.37   4.40   5.00        10-yr. T-infl.   3.76   3.76   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.82   4.79   5.54        30-yr. T-bond   5.25   5.24   5.85        Telephone bd.   6.91   6.91   7.28        Municipal bds.   5.12   5.13   5.19          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Kirch Group to Split Into Holding Companies
abstract: German media owner Leo Kirch details reorganization of his empire, opening way for possible sale of stakes to foreign investors; Kirch Group will split into three holding companies for film and television rights, pay-television and other assets under Kirch Foundation, formed in 1996 (S)

headline: Slate Drops Its On-Line Subscription Fee
abstract: Microsoft's on-line magazine, Slate, drops annual subscription fee after 10-month experiment; publisher Scott Moore holds fee restricts advertising potential; notes paid subscriptions for content have not grown on Web as expected; photos (M)a

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen rises for sixth consecutive session against US dollar as yields on Japanese bonds continue to surge; in New York, dollar declines to 111.21 yen, from 112.07 yen on Jan 4; graph; chart (S)

headline: Hill & Knowlton Buys Blanc & Otus
abstract: Hill & Knowlton acquires Blanc & Otus Public Relations; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Top Triarc Executives Halt Bid for Company
abstract: Triarc Cos chairman, Nelson Peltz, and president, Peter May, withdraw their offer to take company private for $18 a share, or $420 million; company says it will buy back up to 5.5 million shares at $16.25 to $18.25 a share in Dutch auction tender offer (M)

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Don't Be Shocked, But Money Isn't Everything
abstract: Jeffrey Nesteruk article his effort to minimize the place of money in his life while society grows ever more materialistic; drawing (M)

headline: High Expectations for Gas and Power Market Growth
abstract: WILL Latin America continue to provide significant opportunities for energy investors in light of the current economic troubles?

headline: Yahoo Said to Be Buying Geocities in Union of Top Sites
abstract: Yahoo Inc is expected to acquire Geocities Co, popular Internet site; executives will not comment on price that Yahoo will pay (M)

headline: NATO Strikes Go On as Serbs Step Up Campaign
abstract: Serbia withstands second round of NATO air assaults, and White House vows prolonged and severe attacks while Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia is reported to be defiantly stepping up his military campaign in Kosovo; Samuel R Berger, Pres Clinton's national security adviser, observes that Milosevic 'escalated today,' conceeding that despite NATO assault Milosevic's forces continue their sweep, burning ethnic Albanian villages in Kosovo and even sending 'some shelling' into Albania; Gen Wesley K Clark, NATO Supreme Commander, resolutely says that duration and severity of military campaign is up to Milosevic; on second day of NATO bombardment, cruise missiles and guided bombs rain down on targets that Pentagon officials describe as military and air depots and factories that have underpinned yearlong assault against Kosovo, southernmost province in Serbian republic; photos; map (M)

headline: GCI Group Adds Kamer-Singer
abstract: GCI Group, public relations arm of Grey Advertising, acquires Kamer-Singer & Associates; terms undisclosed; merged company will be renamed GCI Kamer-Singer (S)

headline: Down in the Valley, a Heated Economy Cools Just a Bit
abstract: Annual report of economic health of Silicon Valley shows some slowing of area's surging economy during 1998, in part because of Asian economic crisis; Silicon Valley added 19,400 jobs in 1998, compared with 62,000 in 1997, and exports from region declined for first time in eight years; figures are from 1999 Index of Silicon Valley, compiled by Joint Venture: Silicon Valley Network Inc, coalition of corporate and civic organizations; despite some signs of slowdown, there are still signs indicating that area reamins remarkably robust economic region; graph (M)

headline: Flat Screen, Fat Screen: Big Difference Is Cost
abstract: Q. What is the difference (besides price and size) between regular monitors and the new flat ones?    A. There are many complex issues involved, but perhaps the biggest difference between conventional desktop monitors and the new flat-panel displays is that they use different technologies to display images.

headline: SCHAWK AGREES TO ACQUIRE BRITISH IMAGING COMPANY
abstract: Schawk Inc acquires Wace Group PLC for $156 million (US) (S)

headline: Asia Regains Confidence As Its Stability Returns
abstract: Asia ends 1998 with shock at enormity of devastation wrought by econinic crisis, and relief that its storm-tossed markets and currencies finally regained their footing; photo (M)

headline: Philip Morris Plant Closing to Cost 1,400 Jobs
abstract: Philip Morris Inc says it is laying off 1,400 workers and closing its factory in Louisville, Ky; decision reflects growing decline in domestic demand for its cigarettes; closing will cost Philip Morris estimated $200 million before taxes, mostly to cover costs of severance pay (S)

headline: Productivity Set Fast Pace In Late 1998
abstract: The nation's productivity, the amount that a worker produces in an hour on the job, rose in the fourth quarter at an annual rate of 3.7 percent, giving the United States three years of robust improvement in labor efficiency, and suggesting that corporate America might indeed have become slightly more efficient after years of trying unsuccessfully to improve.    The newest quarterly number, announced yesterday by the Labor Department, is the biggest increase since the first quarter of 1996, when labor productivity rose by 4.2 percent, inaugurating the three-year period of hefty gains.

headline: Stemming the Tide of Touts on Those Stock Message Boards
abstract: Rise of Internet stock message boards leads to efforts on several fronts to rid them of people who use them to illegally tout stocks and spread false information; David M Schwartz, chief executive of Imaginon, has seen company's stock soar and slide on strength of postings on Yahoo Finance board and now posts his own messages there in an effort to squelch rumors about the company; photo; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Long View on Iraq: Patience in Containing the Ever-Deadlier Hussein
abstract: Tim Weiner analysis of policy of patient containment of Iraq now being advocated by some Clinton Administration officials; they point to success of 40-year containment of Russia; others warn that as time passes, Pres Saddam Hussein, now freed of United Nations weapons inspectors, can concentrate on building weapons to blackmail, terrorize and even attack his neighbors of US forces in Persian Gulf (M)

headline: NEWS WATCH
abstract: New program called The Signaler signals computer that someone is trying to get in touch, even if recipient is not on line; it was developed by NECS (S)

headline: Asthma Drug Is Approved, But Sepracor Shares Tumble
abstract: Sepracor Inc receives approval from Food and Drug Administration to begin marketing new inhalable drug named Xopenex for treatment of asthma; Sepracor shares fall $6.6875, to $111.5625 in Nasdaq trading on March 26 (M)

headline: Bridging a 'Generation Next' Gap
abstract: Profile of Dawn Hudson, new chief of marketing for Pepsi-Cola North America; she is confident that Pepsi's new slogan, which will be unveiled in March, will knit the brand back together; two-year-old 'Generation next' is widely maligned for conveying a hip image that alienated older Pepsi drinkers; photo (M)

headline: BMW Requests Subsidies
abstract: BMW AG, Germany's third-largest auto maker, says it will consider opening production sites away from Britain if British Government does not provide subsidies for Rover Group, BMW's unprofitable British unit; BMW wants subsidies for retooling factories (S)

headline: Foreign Stocks Are Down But Aren't Necessarily Out
abstract: Many investors are questioning value of overseas diversification after several years in which domestic stocks outperformed foreign markets; even some professional investors are shifting strategies; proponents of diversification say last few years have been atypical (M)

headline: NBC Discovers New Strategy In 'The 60's'
abstract: NBC, after selling tens of thousands of music CD's in conjunction with its recent miniseries The 60's and The Temptations, believes it has found new source of revenue for increasingly strained network television business: direct response sales of music through toll-free telephone numbers; network's movie department is picking some projects specifically for their potential to generate products that NBC can sell to its viewers; NBC believes it has found in music-oriented movies 'a new economic model' for network television business; at least three more music-oriented mini-series are in various stages of development at NBC; photo (M)

headline: E*Trade Acquiring Another Web Site
abstract: E*Trade Group acquires Clearstation Inc, financial World Wide Web site with 90,000 registered members, for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Canada, at U.N., Proposes a 'Third Way' to Deal With the Iraqis
abstract: Canada hopes to fill void between hardened Russian and American policies toward Iraq; Security Council begins discussing 'third way' proposed by Canada; Canada, with support of Brazil, this month's Council president, is calling for comprehensive assessments on status of Iraqi disarmament and on humanitarian situation in Iraq (M)

headline: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS NAMES FINANCIAL OFFICER
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp names James E Daley as its chief financial officer; he will fill position left vacant since Jody Grant resigned almost year ago (S)

headline: Albright to Meet Jordan's Heir
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright will meet with Crown Prince Abdullah, son and new successor to ailing King Hussein of Jordan, in Amman on January 28; courtesy call is intended to demonstrate importance US attaches to Jordan as pivotal ally (S)

headline: GERMAN TRAVEL GUIDE PUBLISHER BUYS A U.S. MAP MAKER
abstract: Langenscheidt KG, German publisher of Insight travel guides, acquires Hammond Inc, one of oldest American map companies; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Cellular Companies Agree To Make Networks Compatible
abstract: Two groups of cellular telephone companies and equipment makers agreed today to make wireless networks that use competing digital technologies work together.    The agreement would primarily affect networks in the United States and Europe. The Universal Wireless Communications Consortium and North American G.S.M. Alliance groups represent such companies as the AT&T Corporation, SBC Communications Inc., the Omnipoint Corporation, Lucent Technologies Inc. and Ericsson A.B.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Chicago Options Exchange Ends Merger Plan
abstract: Chicago Board Options Exchange abandons its planned merger with Pacific Stock Exchange, attributing decision to pressing technological issues and lingering antitrust questions (M)

headline: Deutsch Is Named Agency of the Year
abstract: Deutsch Inc is named agency of the year for 1998 by trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek (S)

headline: Midwest Shows Rise In Industrial Activity
abstract: Manufacturing activity in the Midwest picked up unexpectedly in December, helped by rising production and an increase in inventories.    The National Association of Purchasing Management-Chicago said today that its monthly index of regional manufacturing activity rose to 50.9 in December from 50.2 in November. Analysts had expected a reading of 49.7. An index above 50 means the number of manufacturers who said business improved was greater than the number of those who said it deteriorated.

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: ALLIED DOMECQ SPIRITS USA, Old Greenwich, Conn., named Paul R. Block senior vice president for marketing and chief marketing officer.    MERCANTILE INTERNATIONAL PETROLEUM INC., Cayman Islands, said its chairman, John Arthur Bray, had resigned. He remains chief executive of the company. Cameron O. Smith and Roger M. Widmann, both directors, also resigned.

headline: Outdated Maps at Heart of Satellite TV Dispute
abstract: Signal-coverage maps that unaccountably view world as flat, failing to account for mountain ranges or tall buildings, are at center of legal battle between broadcasters and satellite television industry; satellite transmission of network signals is allowed only in areas where local signals are poor; 750,000 viewers nationwide lost programming from CBS and Fox after Federal judge said Prime Time 24, contractor of DirecTV, violated law by illegally delivering network signals to homes in areas where coverage maps indicate customers can receive programming from local stations; photo (M)

headline: Downsizing Sound Files
abstract: Reader asks how a sound file in WAV format used in Windows Sound Recorded can be converted to the smaller MIDI format suitable for E-mail; such conversion is quite hard, or almost impossible (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Intel Reports Solid Earnings In Its Fourth Quarter  Buoyed by strong sales of its high-end microprocessors and increased operating efficiencies, Intel reported fourth-quarter financial results that substantially exceeded Wall Street analysts' estimates. But Intel advised analysts that sales for the first quarter of 1999 are likely to fall, following a normal seasonal pattern.

headline: Eritrea Says It Killed Hundreds In Routing Ethiopians on Border
abstract: Eritrea says it has repulsed Ethiopian troops after three-day battle along their disputed border, in fighting that cost lives of at least several hundred soldiers (M)

headline: Laguna San Ignacio Journal; Save the Whales? Mine the Salt? Mexican Standoff
abstract: Proposal by Mitsubishi Corp to build huge salt plant in partnership with Mexican Government in Laguna San Ignacio pits it against environmentalists seeking to protect gray whale's winter breeding grounds; both sides have launched sophisticated, global campaigns, with videos, Web sites, letter-writing drives and guided tours to promote its view; top scientists, recruited by both sides, are divided on issues; lagoon is part of biosphere reserve created by Mexico in 1988 as largest protected natural area in Latin America; map; photo (M)

headline: IN MY ... PURSE/ELLEN GALINSKY
