abstract: Contents of purse of Families and Work Institute president Ellen Galinsky described; photos (S)U

headline: Trade Deficit Rises, Setting Record Early
abstract: US trade deficit widens in November to $15.5 billion from $13.5 billion in October; deficit for first 11 months of 1998 is thus at $153.9 billion, exceeding 1987 record for full-year trade deficit; deficit is only 2 percent of gross domestic product in 1998, compared with 3.3 percent in 1987, and some forecasters believe the economy expanded at an annual rate of of at least 4 percent in fourth quarter; deficit is expected to grow, however, and further deterioration is seen as threat to economic expansion; exports fall by another 2 percent in November; imports of construction gear, machine tools and other capital equipment soars; rise in deficit is even worse than figures indicate because import prices have been falling in dollar terms as currencies in Asia and Latin America have weakened and world market for raw materials has plunged; graph (M)

headline: KOSOVO MASSACRE IS CALLED REVENGE
abstract: International monitors who discovered bodies of 45 ethnic Albanians in Racak, a village in Kosovo, conclude that attack on village and executions were carried out by Serbian forces in revenge for killing of four of their men; chronological report lists each body found at site, including two boys, and describes close-range gunshot wounds; massacre touched off latest Kosovo crisis; Milosevic regime now says US envoy William Walker may remain, but Clinton Administration says this is not enough, and demands Pres Milosevic reduce forces in Kosovo or face possible air strikes; German diplomat Berend Borchardt has given graphic account of scene of massacre, saying victims were 'humble peasants'; bodies were later taken to village mosque for burial, but 40 were removed by Serbian police for autopsies by Serbian doctors (M)

headline: Agencies Taking Donations for Refugees
abstract: List of agencies accepting contributions for Kosovo refugee assistance (S)

headline: Endesa of Spain Buys Repsol Stake
abstract: Endesa SA, Spain's biggest power company, buys 3.64 percent of Repsol SA, country's number 1 oil company, for 82.26 billion pesetas ($572 million), three months after Endesa signs alliance with Repsol's biggest shareholder, Gas Natural SDG SA; purchase means Endesa is likely to sell its stake in Compania Espanola de Petroleos SA, Spain's second-largest oil company and Repsol's competitor (S)

headline: To Forecast 1999, Don't Dwell on '98
abstract: Mark Hulbert comment suggests that most of factors that affected stock markets in 1998 have little or no significance for 1999

headline: SALE OF A BOTTLED WATER CALLED DASANI IS SET
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says it will begin selling bottled water called Dasani in United States and Canada this summer (S)9

headline: A Speech We'll Never Hear From Alan Greenspan
abstract: Richard W Stevenson article on what Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, might say to Senate Banking Committee about the state of the economy and monetary policy if he allowed himself to speak with perfect frankness--something he will never do (M)

headline: Disney and Hong Kong Confirm Talks on a Theme Park
abstract: Hong Kong and Walt Disney Co say they are in early negotiations about building theme park; Sir Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, says Disney and Hong Kong government will begin 'intensive negotiations' and hope to make final decision by end of June; adds first phase of Hong Kong Disneyland could be completed by 2005 if definitive agreement is reached (M)

headline: Guilt-Ridden Monitors Reflect on Pulling Out
abstract: 1,400 international monitors of Kosovo Verification Mission, evacuated before start of NATO bombing, are frustrated and guilt-ridden as they watch horrors unfold on Macedonian television; many express anger and frustration at their inactivity and powerlessness; some say it was mistake to pull entire mission out of Kosovo; feelings are heightened by unknown fates of 1,500 local staff members left behind, some of whom may have been shot to death for having associated with verification mission (M)

headline: MINDSPRING IS IN $245 MILLION DEAL WITH ICG
abstract: ICG Communications Inc sells most of Netcom's operations to Mindspring Enterprises Inc for $245 million in cash and stock; ICG acquired Netcom less than a year ago for $284 million (S)

headline: Keep Pollard Locked Up, Clinton Aides Recommend
abstract: Pres Clinton's national security advisers have reportedly recommended that he deny clemency to Jonathan Jay Pollard, American who spied for Israel; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright reportedly told White House there is no compelling foreign policy reason to release Pollard; opposition by CIA Dir George J Tenet and Defense Sec William Cohen noted; FBI is urging Atty Gen Janet Reno to oppose release of Pollard in her recommendation to White House (M)

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; Economy Class? What's That?
abstract: Keith G McWalter article on largess dispensed by corporations to increasing number of their white-collar workers; cites corporate-funded travel and entertainment; says benefits give business class derivative form of wealth and sophistication, threatening to squeeze out frugality, modesty and humility; drawing (M)

headline: How Far To Swing The Ax?
abstract: FOR the better part of two decades, the Federal budget deficit imposed tight limits on debates over tax policy. Republicans could not indulge their political and ideological desire to return more money to the people. Democrats were forced to support tax increases to maintain spending for the social programs they championed.    Now, with the advent of large and growing budget surpluses, the terms of the debate are being rewritten. No longer shackled by the demands of austerity, Republicans are pressing for a big tax cut this year, although they remain divided over the form and the size. The Clinton Administration is trying to thwart the Republican plan by demanding that Social Security and Medicare get first dibs on the surplus.

headline: Big Board Drops Its Lawsuit Against Amex
abstract: New York Stock Exchange withdraws its lawsuit against American Stock Exchange after Amex agrees to stop using ticker symbol 'Q' for its Nasdaq 100 Trust shares; Amex will use symbol 'QQQ' for the shares (S)

headline: '98 Heineken Net Up, But Outlook Drops Stock
abstract: Dutch brewer Heineken NV posts better-than-expected 1998 results, but stock falls sharply as company says pace of profit growth will slow in 1999; net profit in 1998 rose by 29 percent, to 981 million guilders ($485 million) (S)

headline: Grass on a Roof? No Problem. Just Don't Change Your Mind.
abstract: Katherine Whiteside reviews Complete Land Designer, garden design computer software program from Sierra; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY     None Reported    TUESDAY     Conectiv    Keyspan Enrgy

headline: CHUBB BUYS STAKE IN BRITISH INSURANCE COMPANY
abstract: Chubb Corp says its Federal Insurance Co unit has acquired 28 percent of Hiscox PLC for 89.9 million pounds ($146 million); says it bought shares from Trident Partnership LP (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.75   4.77   5.35        3-month T-bills   4.39   4.41   5.00        6-month T-bills   4.46   4.48   5.04        10-yr. T-infl.   3.91   3.89   3.69        10-yr. T-note   5.11   5.10   5.57        30-yr. T-bond   5.50   5.47   5.90        Telephone bd.   7.22   7.19   6.99        Municipal bds.   5.18   5.19   5.25          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: 70.20 Rise on Nasdaq Leads Gains Across the Board
abstract: Nasdaq composite index climbs 70.20 points, or nearly 3 percent, to 2,477.34; Dow Jones industrial average gains 81.10 points, or nearly nine-tenths of 1 percent, to close at 9,281.33; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 22.20 points, to 1,265.37; graph; chart (M)

headline: Arrest Uniting Europe's Kurds In Indignation
abstract: Overwhelming majority of estimated 850,000 Kurds living in Europe share outrage at arrest of Abdullah Ocalan, Kurdish rebel leader apprehended by Turkish agents; political divisions have long undermined scattered Kurds in their battle for homeland, and many of them do not support Ocalan's Kurdistan Workers Party; but fast-growing Kurdish diaspora in Europe has displayed ability to organize, communicate and act immediately after his arrest; Kurds in several European countries suggest that broad show of defiance reflects anger stronger than any internal Kurdish differences; Ocalan's movement has waged separatist war in southeastern Turkey that has left 30,000 dead; United States has defined Kurdistan Workers Party as terrorist organization and expressed quiet support for Ocalan's arrest and handover to Turkey; photo (M)

headline: Prodi the Front-Runner For EU Commission Job
abstract: BRUSSELSâ€”  Former Prime Minister Romano Prodi of Italy emerged late Wednesday as the front-runner for the post of president of the European Commission, following the resignation of all 20 members of the European executive in the face of a scathing anti-corruption report.

headline: Two Agencies Make Acquisitions
abstract: Arnold Communications Inc acquires Ingalls Moranville Advertising and Rockpile Interactive, two ad agencies in San Francisco; terms undisclosed; CMGI Inc acquires 2Can Media Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Judge Bars Anti-Abortion Militants Who Occupied Irish Clinic
abstract: Group of anti-abortion militants, including about 40 Americans, reignites highly emotional issue of abortion in Roman Catholic Ireland by forcing their way into Dublin family-planning clinic and occupying it for two hours; judge extends indefinitly an order prohibiting militants, including leader of American group, from picketing or trespassing at Irish Family Planning Assn office in center of city (M)

headline: Global Spots Planned For Ernst & Young
abstract: Ernst & Young LLP will begin running its first worldwide ads as part of $100 million marketing, public relations, sponsorship and events campaign; ads will be created by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications; previous agency was Grace & Rothschild (S)s

headline: MEAD HAS SOLD OFF $90 MILLION IN LAND AND OTHER ASSETS
abstract: Mead Corp says it has sold $90 million in assets, including its Mead Ink Products, and is ahead of its schedule for divesting itself of more than $100 million in assets by mid-1999 (S)

headline: Parmalat Plans to Buy A Dairy Products Rival
abstract: Parmalat SpA, world's largest dairy company, will buy diary unit of its main Italian rival, Cirio SpA, for 780 billion lire ($458 million) in cash and assumed debt; Parmalat also reports that second-half pretax profit rose 40 percent, to 273 billion lire (S)

headline: New Party Vying to Be in Middle of Israeli Politics
abstract: New political party in Israel, Center Party, holds inaugural gala; by Election Day on May 17, Center Party seeks to break traditional Israeli voting allegiances to the two major parties, Labor and Likud; Center Party is most readily siphoning votes from Likud's core constituency of Sephardim--Jews from North Africa and Middle East; many party members proclaim themselves both fed up with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, and thrilled with barrier-breaking candidacy of Iraqi-born Yitzhak Mordechai, former Defense Minister and first Sephardic immigrant to run for top office in country; photo (M)

headline: An Insurer Goes Against the Odds; Ace Bucks the Trend and Expands in Commercial Coverage
abstract: Ace Ltd, upstart insurer founded in Hamilton, Bermuda, is gambling that with its acquisition of much larger Cigna Corp's property and casualty business it can buck trend and expand its commercial coverage; property and casualty insurance has generated subpar profit margins last decade, but Brian Duperreault, chief executive of Ace, says he will run against wind as large commercial insurer using same strategies that made Ace top specialist in insuring against huge disasters with claims running into hundreds of millions of dollars; Cigna deal puts Ace head-to-head with American leader in commercial insurance, AIG, where Duperreault once worked; like AIG, Ace is known for finding new customers by moving into niches where competition is less fierce; photo; graph (M)

headline: People
abstract: Mylene Pollock is named chief creative officer at Long Haymes Carr, Winston-Salem, NC, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos, assuming duties from James P White, vice chairman and chief creative officer, now chief creative officer at another Interpublic agency; Max Caldwell is named chairman and chief executive at Banner McBride North America, NY; Alan Burgis is named to new post of executive vice president in account management department at Goldberg Moser O'Neill, San Francisco (Advertising column) (M)

headline: U.S. Now Tells of Much Deeper Damage by Pollard Than Thought
abstract: US defense and intelligence officials, adamant that Pres Clinton refuse Israel's requests that he grant clemency to spy Jonathan J Pollard, say Pollard did more damage to national security than public has been told; charge, in New Yorker magazine article, that Pollard gave Israel invaluable American secrets in exchange for payments of $50,000 and promises of $540,000 more (M)

headline: Parents Log On to Campus Life
abstract: Gettysburg College, Gettysburg, Pa, has taken high-speed Internet hookups in dormitories one step further by allowing students and parents access to an interactive Web-based system (www.gettysburg.edu) that tracks and links many aspects of college life; system, called College Navigation Project, offers way to link students to one another and to wide array of campus information, such as financial records, grades and course descriptions; many other colleges and universities are also using Internet technology to link systems, students and former students; photo of Gettysburg students using system (M)

headline: Led by I.B.M., Dow Closes 1.6% Lower
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 143.41 points, 1.6 percent, to 9120.67; Nasdaq composite index falls 5.84 points, to 2,338.88; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 9.97 points, to 1,225.19; graph; tables (M)

headline: Out of the Blue, Quiet Briton Wins Fame
abstract: Article profiles Brian Jones on occasion of his completing balloon trip around world; photo (M)

headline: Comedy Central Picks New Chief
abstract: Comedy Central cable channel names Larry Divney as president and chief executive, succeeding Douglas Herzog, who was hired at end of 1998 as president of Fox Entertainment (M)

headline: Abercrombie's Stock Looks Fashionable, Too
abstract: Stock price of specialty retailer Abercrombie & Fitch is booming, spurred by high expected earnings growth; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Maps Become Legal Issue in Alpine Cable Accident
abstract: Pentagon, more than year after Marine Corps jet hit alpine gondola cable that was not on crew's map, has not yet updated its maps; although Defense Department says it can operate safely with old maps, lawyer for victims' families says that changes in maps would complicate Government's legal defenses; ommission on map of Mount Cermis cable was major point for defense lawyers in court-martial of pilot Capt Richard J Ashby, who was acquitted; map (M)

headline: OXFORD HEALTH SEES PROFIT IN 2D HALF OF YEAR
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc says it might be profitable in second half of 1999 (S)9

headline: FRONTIER PLANS MOVES TO INCREASE ITS SHARE PRICE
abstract: Frontier Corp weighs spinning off operations, making acquisitions or creating tracking stock to raise its share price; will cut dividend 78 percent (S)

headline: The Secretary General Offers Implicit Endorsement of Raids
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan endorses NATO air strikes against Serbia; blames Yugoslavia's rejection of political settlement for resort to force; reprimands NATO for acting without Security Council authorization (M)

headline: Microsoft Shows a New Tape, and Raises Some New Questions
abstract: Microsoft Corp, trying to stop damage from disastrous week in court, plays new videotaped demonstration at antitrust trial; video shows senior executive James E Allchin performing live tests and then looking into camera and saying that he proved his point--that prototype Government program intended to separate Microsoft's Web browser from Windows operating system really does no such thing; to assure new tape would be viewed as credible, Government lawyer and Princeton professor, Dr Edward W Felten, along with his two students, were invited to come by at 8:30 PM to witness taping; but they were not permitted into room for two hours while Microsoft team unpacked boxes and set up computers, leading to angry concerns that something nefarious was under way; taping was not completed until after midnight (M)

headline: London Journal; A Right Honorable Briton? Hardly, It Turns Out
abstract: British commentators are mining Shakespeare and Greek tragedies to come up with parallels for fall of Jonathan Aitken, high-born former Cabinet minister who has admitted committing perjury during libel case; his marriage and his fortune are gone, and his likely future is in prison; photo (M)

headline: Hong Kong Court Tells 17 They Must Return to China
abstract: Hong Kong court tells 17 mainland residents they must return home and apply for resident visas; 17 are among 1,000 mainland Chinese who entered Hong Kong on temporary visas but now assert right to remain under recent court ruling that relaxed immigration laws; photo (M)

headline: Jordan King's Heir Reaffirms Stand for Peace and U.S. Ties
abstract: Crown Prince Abdullah, who will become King of Jordan upon the imminent death of his father, King Hussein, says that Jordan under his rule will remain committed to peace in Middle East and close relations with US, but wary of both Iran and Iraq; discusses his nuanced views of other regional diplomatic challenges, his strained relationship with his uncle, former Crown Prince Hassan, and his vision of the future of Jordanian monarchy; says his greatest immediate internal concern is to close family ranks behind him; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Order to Airbus
abstract: Spanair orders up to 45 Airbus planes worth as much as $2.2 billion as it prepares to expand service in Spain and rest of Europe (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH; Coupon Clippers Go on Line More and More, Report Says
abstract: Survey conducted by NPD Group finds that use of coupons delivered via Web is increasing; 87 percent of respondents who say they know about on-line coupons expect to use some or more of them in future; shoppers go to Web, print coupons out and present them at checkout register (S)

headline: Aetna to Allow Outside Reviews of Care Denials
abstract: Aetna US Healthcare says it will voluntarily allow its health plan members in 30 states to have outside reviews of decisions that deny them necessary or experimental care; program will take effect by June 30 (M)

headline: Albright Due at Kosovo Talks to Push Pacts on Forces
abstract: Clinton Administration says State Sec Madeleine K Albright will visit Kosovo peace conference, Rambouillet, France, to push delegates to forge military accords to end fighting; says she will propose internal security arrangements, including cut in Serbian troops and police forces, dissolution of ethnic Albanian rebel army and creation of new Kosovo police force; Serbian Pres Milan Milutinovic visits Serbian delegates; warns of guerrilla war if NATO bombs Serbia; photo (M)

headline: Screening Screenplays
abstract: J Sperling Reich letter on Jan 14 article on Internet sites for screenwriters notes site that uses screening process to weed out weaker offerings (S)

headline: No Fast Payments for Chinese Concern's Creditors
abstract: Chinese Government officials tell representatives of 150 international banks that liquidation of Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corp, or Gitic, will not begin for at least three months and that repayment of $4 billion will not occur anytime soon (S)

headline: Media Talk; Actor Sues Magazine Over Fashion Spread
abstract: Actor Dustin Hoffman is pressing lawsuit against Los Angeles magazine, which used his face in fashion spread in Mar 1997 issue; suit centers on area of law called right of publicity, which is supposed to give celebrities right to control manner and circumstances under which their name and image are used for commercial purposes; photo (S)

headline: An upstart tries to appeal to marketers that want to work beyond the realm of traditional agencies.
abstract: Artustry Partnership, new advertising agency bearing name with double meaning--'art' and 'industry'--is stepping up efforts to promote itself as offering advertisers two types of services--creative and strategic services to marketers that want to work outside realm of traditional agencies (M)

headline: Richards Awarded Excel Account
abstract: Excel Communications awards Richards Group the general market account for its 10-10-297 long-distance service, which had been handled by Ehrens Motion and Music; billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million (S)

headline: CANANDAIGUA BRANDS TO PURCHASE 7 WHISKY LABELS
abstract: Canandaigua Brands Inc acquires Black Velvet and six other Canadian whisky brands, as well as production facilities in Alberta and Quebec and bulk whisky inventories, from Diageo PLC for $185.5 million (S)

headline: Geocities Encourages Members To Make Their Web Pages Pay
abstract: People with home pages on Geocities are offered program that allows them to create links to commercial Web sites and earn commissions on purchases that result from visits to them (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Currencies: euro declines on concerns that European Central Bank's failure to raise interest rates is hindering recovery in 11-nation currency union; graphs (S)

headline: President's Reasons: Moral Revulsion and Weight of U.S. Interests
abstract: Pres Clinton, in televised speech, says his decision to authorize military strikes against Serbia was derived from moral revulsion at killing in Kosovo and calculated assessment of US interests in Balkans; says he acted only when he was certain that Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic would respond to nothing less than forceful military action; photo (M)

headline: Pitfalls and Benefits In the Home Office
abstract: A SELF-EMPLOYED publicist,  Shari L. Goldstein began building her business in the spring of 1996, when the older of her two sons turned 6. ''I started in a corner nook in my former husband's law office,'' Ms. Goldstein said. ''But it's a busy place, so I eventually rented a small office in Huntington,''  N.Y., near her home in Jericho on Long Island. ''Through word of mouth, the business developed.''    Later Ms. Goldstein, 40, like a growing number of entrepreneurs and consultants, moved her office to her home, giving herself the full array of tax traps and opportunities faced by the self-employed. The move occurred last September, when she and her husband were negotiating an amicable divorce; they agreed that he would get the law practice and she would get their home.

headline: Richard R. Shinn, Retired Metropolitan Life Chief, Dies at 81
abstract: Richard R Shinn, retired chairman of Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, dies at age 81; photo (M)

headline: NATO AUTHORIZES KOSOVO AIR RAIDS IF SERBS BAR TALKS
abstract: NATO allies authorize Sec Gen Javier Solana to order air strikes against military targets in Kosovo and elsewhere in Serbia unless Pres Slobodan Milosevic agrees by Feb 6 to start talks in France with Kosovo's ethnic Albanian leaders on autonomy for province; accelerate planning for possible emergency extraction of 1,020 Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe civilian observers; begin planning for possible peacekeeping force of 30,000 to 40,000 troops, including United States troops; NATO officials say strikes will not go ahead if Albanians refuse to talk or to stop attacking Serbs (M)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO SELL ITS STAKE IN TRASH HAULER
abstract: Republic Industries plans public sale of its stake in trash hauler Republic Services Inc after it fails to get tax-free status for distribution to shareholders (S)

headline: $104 Million Seagate Net Exceeds Forecast
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc earned $104 million in second quarter ended Jan 1, compared with loss before charges of $20.2 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 7.7 percent, to $1.8 billion from $1.67 billion (S)

headline: U.S. Weighs Its Reaction To Massacre In Kosovo
abstract: Clinton Administration struggles to explain how it will react to execution-style massacre of 45 ethnic Albanians by Serbian forces under control of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic; Pres Clinton condemns killings and calls them 'clear violation' of Serbs' cease-fire agreement with NATO; senior official says Administration is stopping short of calling Serbs in 'substantial noncompliance' with NATO agreement (M)

headline: U.S. Helped Turkey Find and Capture Kurd Rebel
abstract: US worked for four months to help Turkey arrest Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan; US diplomatic pressure backed by intelligence-gathering helped to put Ocalan in flight from safe haven in Syria, to persuade nation after nation to refuse him sanctuary, and to drive him into desperate search for city of refuge; US, like Turkey, considers Ocalan terrorist; he leads Kurdistan Workers Party, which has fought against Turkey for 15 years seeking autonomy for Kurdish people; 37,000 people have died in that fight (M)

headline: At Kennedy, a Day of Cancellations and Confusion
abstract: Catching a flight on American Airlines out of one of the area airports proved a little like playing lottery yesterday, with many passengers not discovering until they arrived at the counter whether their flight was among the lucky departures or not.     ''They haven't really let people know what's going on,'' said Darren Sharpe, a 27-year-old Australian standing around at Kennedy International Airport, waiting to embark on an extended vacation itinerary of American flights to Miami, New Orleans and the Caribbean. ''I'm trying to remain calm; you don't want to take it out on the people at the counter -- it's not their fault.''

headline: CBS SAYS IT HAS RAISED ITS STAKE IN SPORTSLINE TO 18%
abstract: The CBS Corporation said yesterday that it had increased its stake in Sportsline USA Inc. to 18 percent and extended its marketing accord with the on-line sports news company for five years. CBS had owned 12.5 percent of Sportsline as part of an alliance that began in March 1997. Under the agreement, which lasts until 2006, CBS receives warrants to buy more Sportsline common shares and may increase its stake to about 27 percent. CBS will also spend about $100 million to promote their joint Web site, cbs.sportsline.com. Sportsline rose $5.25, to $40.125, while CBS shares rose $1.0625, to $36.50.

headline: NEXTLINK TO EXPAND VIA WIRELESS LICENSES
abstract: Nextlink Communications Inc will spend $832.7 million to expand its local and long-distance fiber optic networks with wireless licenses; Nextlink will acquire WNP Communications Inc for $695 million in cash and stock; it will also pay $137.7 million for Nextel Communications Inc's 50 percent stake in Nextband, joint venture between Nextel and Nextlink that owns more than 40 wireless licenses (S)

headline: Preserving Medicare's Roots
abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on debate over Medicare's future; cites need to remind forgetful public that program was founded in part to ease burden on children of their parents' illnesses; opposes proposal to let affluent shop for private insurance; drawing (M)0

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: KING PRODUCTS INC.,  Canada, a maker of information kiosks and computerized directories, will develop and market multimedia products with Ascom Holding A.G., Switzerland's largest maker of telecommunications equipment, which agreed to pay $13 million (Canadian), or $8.6 million (United States), for 60 percent of King's stock.

headline: Brazil Increases a Key Interest Rate to 45%
abstract: Brazilian central bank raises its benchmark interest rate to 45 percent and grants its new president, Arminio Fraga, expanded powers to adjust rates in effort to head off surge of inflation and to stabilize country's battered currency; interest rate increase, from 39 percent, helps steady Brazilian currency, the real, in trading; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Forming Alliances in China
abstract: Microsoft Corp signs accords with at least nine companies operating in China, move that may help its new operating system gain market dominance there; companies, including Legend Holdings Ltd and Acer Inc, will develop television set-top boxes for Internet reception, other devices that will use operating system (S)

headline: NATO's Kosovo Bid Is Rebuffed by Serbs
abstract: Two NATO generals who flew to Belgrade to face down President Slobodan Milosevic on the issue of violence in Kosovo, the largely ethnic Albanian province in southern Serbia, failed to win any of the concessions they were seeking, Clinton Administration officials said.    Despite Mr. Milosevic's continuing defiance of a cease-fire in Kosovo, Administration officials said they did not favor immediate air attacks on Serbia. Still, they said they are aware that Mr. Milosevic is putting NATO's credibility to the test.

headline: Chroniclers of Collaboration; Historians Are in Demand to Study Corporate Ties to Nazis
abstract: Corporations hire historians and researchers to investigate their possible links to Nazis; Ford Motor Co, General Motor Co and Bertelsmann, have hired well-known academics to write their wartime histories or scour ancient file rooms worldwide for damaging or exculpatory information; at stake are hundreds of millions of dollars in settlements, potential public embarrassment, and even business complications; Deutsche Bank said recently that independent historians it had hired had found records confirming that bank helped finance building of Auschwitz death camp; Saul Friedlander, who has been hired by Bertelsmann to do research on publishing pro-Nazi and anti-Semitic books during World War II, comments; chart; photo (M)

headline: Rare, Delicate Books You Can Maul to Your Heart's Content
abstract: Octavo, company that puts rare books onto CD-ROM's, has built catalogue of dozen titles straddling popular and scholarly markets; has won digital rights from major libraries, including New York Public Library; chief executive Patrick Ames comments; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Leads Defeat of Pact On Genetically Altered Food  Attempts to forge the world's first global treaty to regulate trade in genetically modified products failed when the United States and five other big agricultural exporters rejected a proposal that had the support of the rest of the roughly 130 nations at the talks.

headline: New Program Is Introduced To Ease Use of Linux System
abstract: Free software movement takes its most significant step yet toward direct confrontation with Microsoft Corp by introducing software that gives powerful and free Linux operating system ease-of-use found on Windows and Macintosh computers; program, which is known as Gnome, for GNU Network Object Model Environment, is introduced at first Linux World computer exhibition, San Jose, Calif; announcement, which is made by Free Software Foundation and Red Hat Software Inc, Linux developer, serves as evidence of progress for Linux movement; but it also hints at internal tensions that have been building within GNU (M)

headline: Iraq Damage More Severe Than Reported, Pentagon Says
abstract: Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen Henry H Shelton, and commander of US forces in Persian Gulf, Gen Anthony C Zinni, say that US and British raids on Iraq that stopped three weeks ago caused more damage than initially reported (M)

headline: Ruling Backs Release of Microsoft Trial Material
abstract: Federal appeals court, ruling on suit by news organizations, finds all deposition transcripts and videotapes in Microsoft Corp antitrust trial must be made public under little-known 1913 law (M)

headline: 47 Suspected Militants in India Charged in Missionary's Death
abstract: Indian police charge 47 members of militant Hindu youth group with setting fire that killed Australian missionary Graham Staines and his sons Philip, 10, and Timothy, 6, as they slept inside van in remote tribal village of Orissa state; escalation in attacks on Christians spurs round of official condemnations; Prime Min Atal Behari Bajpayee says group, linked to his ruling party, will be punished if it was behind attack; many of attacks have occurred in tribal areas, where militants say Christians forcibly convert indigenous people, charge Christians deny; photo (M)

headline: Merger Adviser Buys a Business
abstract: Eric J Gleacher is severing ties with National Westminster Bank, which bought his merger boutique in 1995; Gleacher says he and his colleagues are taking business he sold to National Westminster for $135 million private in April; Bank of Scotland will own 9.9 percent of new firm, to be named Gleacher & Co; Gleacher will be chairman (S)

headline: How Jews Turn Houses Into Homes on West Bank
abstract: Hills around Eli, entrenched Jewish settlement on West Bank, is dotted for miles with scattering of mobile homes, evidence of continuing and willful expansion of Jewish presence in area; Palestinian leaders and American diplomats have criticized growth of settlements, particularly in rocky hills between Palestinian cities of Ramallah and Nablus; say expansion is carving out new Jewish communities, either by occupying new land or by turning makeshift communities into more established settlements by replacing trailers with houses; Israelis contend they are expanding settlements based on natural growth of 140 communities, and that settlements are theirs to expand until future is decided on final-status negotiations, which have not yet begun; photo; map (M)

headline: An alliance with Warner Brothers Online has an upstart Web development company feeling like the Road Runner.
abstract: Fortunecity.com signs deal with Warner Brothers Online to collaborate on community site for fans of Warner properties, which include cartoons, television programs and music groups; Acmecity.com, as development is known, makes use of Fortunecity's experience building on-line communities to both protect and profit from Warner's intellectual properties; Warner Brothers is giving fans plot of cyberspace in Acmecity for their own home pages and encourages them to use pictures, video and sound clips of their favorite Warner stars; drawing (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    TUESDAY     Becton Dickinson & Co    Cilcorp Inc    Foster Wheeler Corp    Knight Ridder Inc    Lee Enterprises Inc    Lexington Corporate Pptys Tr    Pogo Producing Co    Republic Group Inc    Rollins Inc    RPC Energy Svcs Inc    Shurgard Storage Ctrs Inc    Standard Pac Corp New    Standex Intl Corp    UGI Corp New    USLife Income Fd Inc    USX-Marathon Group

headline: Talk Media Names A Financial Officer
abstract: Talk Media, multimedia company founded by Tina Brown and Ron Galotti, hires Gerard A Fragetti as its chief financial officer (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Recent advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Wendy's founder wasn't a hit, except with customers.
abstract: Advertising column discusses Bates USA's hugely succcessful advertising campaign for Wendy's International using Wendy's founder, R David Thomas, as spokesman; notes that press was scornful when ads first appeared 10 years ago, but public took to them, finding Thomas likeable and believable; says Wendy's crucial franchise system, which pays portion of advertising, embraced campaign, and company has had decade of growth and profit; photo (M)

headline: Untangling Gridlock On the Union Pacific
abstract: Union Pacific Railroad is making progress toward untangling gridlock in Houston that backed up trains around nation as it becomes much more adept at managing nation's largest railroad; coping with crisis has taken line beyond tactical problem-solving to making basic changes in way it runs; changes include decentralization of control and creation of joint operating center in Houston with rival Burlington Northern Santa Fe; photos (M)

headline: Rivals Jockey For 2d Place Behind 'Today'
abstract: Experts say there can be no quick fix in morning television because people's viewing habits at that time of day are particularly hard to change; ABC learned this after moving its prime-time journalism star, Diane Sawyer, to Good Morning America; ratings changed very little; next move is expected to come from CBS, which hopes to persuade Bryant Gumbel to move to CBS This Morning, which is in third place; NBC's Today show continues to be hugely successful (M)

headline: Private Sector; Keeping Cool in a Pressure Cooker
abstract: Interview with Peter I Bijur, chairman and chief executive at Texaco Inc, who comments on plans to cut costs but not on speculation about whether company will seek a merger partner; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; Air Fares to Europe Are Cheap And May Stay Low for a While
abstract: Most major airlines aggressively cut fares to Europe, exceeding in many cases their previous winter sales; driving force behind discounting is overcapacity; airlines find themselves with too many seats to fill in slow winter season; American Airlines is expected to introduce bargain fares on both international and domestic flights, to try to lure back passengers; photo (M)

headline: Tony Blair Rides Triumphant, Either as a Visionary or as a Good Promoter
abstract: Britain's Prime Min Tony Blair, who has large majority in Parliament and ineffective opposition, presses 10-year project to revitalize Britain and make it Europe's leader but many Britons are raising questions; even though he is most popular Prime Minister in British history with wide public appeal, his Government has been criticized for engaging mostly in presentation, or 'spin,' while lacking real substance; photo (M)

headline: British Aerospace Deal Upsets European Arms Industry
abstract: British Aerospace PLC announces $9.5 billion stock deal for Marconi Electronics Systems unit of General Electric Co PLC, creating British colossus that will be one of world's biggest military contractors; new company will trail only Boeing Co and Lockheed Martin Corp; photo of Lord George Simpson of Marconi Electronics and Sir Richard Evans of British Aerospace (M)

headline: AMERICAN AXLE AGREES TO BUY COLFOR MANUFACTURING
abstract: American Axle & Manufacturing will buy closely-held auto-parts maker Colfor Manufacturing Inc for as much as $170 million in cash (S)

headline: BOEING TO SPEED UP JOB CUTS IN COMMERCIAL PLANE UNIT
abstract: Boeing Co says it will accelerate job cuts in its commercial airplane division because it is making more progress in cutting factory costs; 111,400-worker division is expected to have 93,700 employees by end of year (S)

headline: Allies Call Kosovo Rivals To Peace Talks in France
abstract: US, four Western European nations and Russia, in unusual show of unity, summon warring sides in Kosovo to peace conference in France on Feb 5, and suggest that if they did not reach agreement within two weeks, air strikes would follow; photo of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and British Foreign Sec Robin Cook at news conference in London (M)

headline: Mason Walsh Publisher, 86
abstract: Mason Walsh, former publisher of Arizona Republic and Phoenix Gazette, dies at age 86 (S)

headline: Harvesting the Electronic Garden
abstract: Gardeners turn to Internet for information, products and contacts; thousands of sites vie for attention and dollars of gardening consumers, changing way established companies do business and encouraging formation of alliances that offer more accessible and detailed information; photos (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    TURKEY: CRACKDOWN ON ISLAMISTS ORDERED -- Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, left, announced a nationwide crackdown on Islamist activity, saying he was instructing the police and judiciary to take legal action against any threats to the secular order. Past crackdowns in Turkey have led to prosecution of politicians and journalists deemed to have encouraged religious militancy.     (Reuters)    RUSSIA: U.S. HELP SOUGHT ON 'YEAR 2000' -- Russia said it needs up to $3 billion to tackle the Year 2000 computer problem -- six times its original estimate -- and appealed to the United States and NATO to help fix computers that control its nuclear weapons. While an errant missile launch brought on by a computer failure is considered highly unlikely, such snags could sabotage radar and telecommunications networks.   (AP)

headline: AT&T MAY CUT $45 MILLION FROM OFFER FOR SMARTALK
abstract: AT&T may cut as much as $45 million from its offer for Smartalk Teleservices Inc, because of Smartalk's slumping sales (S)

headline: What War Has Wrought: Sierra Leone's Sad State
abstract: Sierra Leone, ranked by United Nations as world's poorest nation, lies in ruins after eight years of civil war; is nation only in name; 440,000 people, about 10 percent of population, have fled to neighboring countries; Government authority has dissolved; Nigeria hopes to withdraw its troops, which currently lead West African peacekeeping force, leaving nation's northern and eastern regions in sway of rebels, who reportedly terrorize residents; map; photo (M)

headline: What Hath Drudge Wrought?
abstract: Partisan Web sites are becoming early warning systems for mainstream press; like talk radio, they are filled with freeform invective; they offer previews of coming attractions from places where conspiracy is king; most trace their beginnings to Matt Drudge, whose gossipy Web site first ran Monica Lewinsky story; photo (M)

headline: After Sex-Tape Attack on Prosecutor, Yeltsin Fires a 2d Aide
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin of Russia dismisses his chief of staff, Nikolai Bordyuzha; some see Bordyuzha as fall guy for Government's failure--so far, anyway--to force resignation of prosecutor general, Yuri Skuratov, who was seen in bed with two women in a videotape shown on national television; photo (M)

headline: A. Doak Barnett Dies; China Scholar, 77
abstract: Arthur Doak Barnett, leading scholar and government adviser on China, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Is Set to Auction Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.24 percent, and the rate on the six-month issue was 4.27 percent. In when-issued trading the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 4.56 percent.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CALENERGY CO., Omaha, a power plant developer, agreed to sell its stakes in three geothermal electricity projects to closely held Caithness Energy L.L.C., New York, for $277 million in cash and assumed debt.    SHOREWOOD PACKAGING CORP., New York, a printing and packaging company, said it is considering making a takeover offer for Field Group P.L.C. that would beat Chesapeake Corp.'s $:225.4 million ($321 million) bid for the British specialty packaging maker.

headline: New Gas Pipeline Planned
abstract: Coastal Corp to build 700-mile pipeline that would carry natural gas from Gulf of Mexico to southern Florida; first deliveries are scheduled for 2002 (S)

headline: Deutsche Telekom Earnings Climb 50%
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG reports earnings gain of 50 percent for second half of 1998; says profits rose 27 percent for all of 1998, to 2.15 billion euros, or $2.5 billion; in second half, profit rose to 1.15 billion euros, from 770 million euros a year earlier (M)

headline: Reaction to Offer From Microsoft Is Cool
abstract: State and Federal officials are dismissive of Microsoft Corp's proposal to settle its antitrust suit; two sides will meet for talks, at behest of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson; last time two sides tried to settle case, talks broke down after day and half; Microsoft is now offering to show flexibility in two broad areas raised in lawsuit: its restrictive contracts with Internet companies, and limits computer makers face in their ability to customize opening screen of Windows operating system; state and Federal officials want some form of reorganization of Microsoft; Justice Dept has not decided which sort of remedy it favors; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: 8 Killed in Explosion in China; Bomb Is Suspected
abstract: Explosion in Yizhang, in southeastern China, kills at least 8 people and injures more than 60; officials say cause of blast has not been determined, but local journalist says there is evidence that it was intentional, and one doctor says victims had nails in their wounds, suggesting possibility of homemade nail bomb; explosion is second this month in Hunan province, site of recent worker and farmer protests over corruption, unpaid wages and taxes (M)

headline: Clinton Says Milosevic Hurts Claim To Kosovo
abstract: Pres Clinton warns Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that he is jeopardizing his claim to keep Kosovo as province of Yugoslavia with his assault on ethnic Albanians; vows to pursue air attacks against Serbian targets in Yugoslavia until Milosevic ceases killing; makes his statement at State Dept ceremony to unveil portrait of former Sec of State Warren M Christopher; Clinton later rejects Milosevic's proposal to withdraw some of his forces from Kosovo in exchange for halt in allied bombing; photo (M)

headline: Bank and Insurer Merging in Denmark
abstract: Tryg-Baltica AS and Unidanmark AS set merger (S)

headline: Mastercard Renews World Cup Pact
abstract: Mastercard International renews its sponsorship of World Cup soccer tournament with Federation Internationale de Football Association in agreement that is estimated to total $140 million over four years for advertising, marketing promotion and sponsorship fees; sponsorship covers World Cup in 2002, with option to renew for 2006 at same price (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Clinton's budget plan on social needs will barely make a dent.
abstract: Economic Scene column on Pres Clinton's budget that includes dozens of new spending programs; says charges of extravagance are unconvincing; holds analysts believe that even if Congress passed Clinton's entire plan, relative size of Federal Government would continue to shrink; drawing (M)

headline: Group Running European Union Quits en Masse
abstract: Entire executive leadership of European Union, 20 highly paid members of powerful bureaucracy appointed by 15 member countries, resigns after independent panel accuses group of chronic cronyism and corruption; European Commission presient, Jacques Santer, announces move after he and his colleagues receive report; mass resignation is first since original European Economic Community was founded 42 years ago; it is outgrowth of increased power of European Parliament, whose investigations of alleged wrongdoing by bureaucracy led to appointment of panel at beginning of this year; new 626-member European Parliament will be elected in early June (M)

headline: People
abstract: Audrey Margolies is named to new position of associate publisher at Mirabella magazine (S)

headline: UNITED AMERICAN ENERGY PLANS TO BUY 2 POWER PROJECTS
abstract: United American Energy Corp to buy two electrical power projects for $181 million in separate deals; says equity financing is being provided by investment funds managed by Fox Paine & Co, which will pay $75 million for 44 percent stake in United American; says Duke Energy Corp's Duke Energy Power Services unit will increase its stake in United American to 25 percent by investing $25 million (S)

headline: NABORS INDUSTRIES IN DEAL FOR POOL ENERGY SERVICES
abstract: Nabors Industries will acquire Pool Energy Services Co for around $357 million in stock and $144 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: People
abstract: Scott Murray, director for client services at TFA/Leo Burnett Technology Group, Chicago, unit of Leo Burnett Co, is named to head new Austin, Tex, office of TFA/ Burnett as president; Jim D'Arcangelo is named to new post of senior vice president for marketing and business development at Media Metrix, NY unit of NPD Group (Advertising column) (S).

headline: Audio Book Club Agrees to Buy Rival
abstract: Audio Book Club Inc to acquire Audiobooks Direct, unit of Doubleday Direct Inc subsidiary of Bertelsmann AG, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Sony Says New Playstation Might Even Show Movies
abstract: Sony Corp announces plans for the next generation of Playstation, which will be released in early 2000. says graphics will come to life and that 3-D images will pop off the screen of the new console; new unit will have 300-megahertz, 128-bit processor (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., a maker of computer chips, announced that it would work with a unit of Security Dynamics Technologies Inc., based in Bedford, Mass., to develop chips that have built-in encryption capabilities to help prevent fraud.

headline: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN DELAYS SPINOFF OF MUTUAL FUNDS
abstract: Kansas City Southern Industries said the spinoff of its mutual funds unit, which includes the Janus Capital Corporation, would probably not occur until the fourth quarter of this year. The company, which also operates a railroad, said it had recently submitted a new plan to the Internal Revenue Service, requesting that the spinoff be ruled tax-free. The I.R.S. raised concerns about the company's original plan in the fourth quarter of last year, causing Kansas City Southern to withdraw the proposal and postpone the spinoff.

headline: The Real Fashion Victims Today Are Lolita's Age : Children and the Cult of Celebrity
abstract: PARISâ€”  COMMENTARY

headline: Today's Bill Sale Is Sole Auction Set by Treasury This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.46 percent and a six-month bill was 4.48 percent.

headline: Cendant Names Ernst & Young in Suit
abstract: Cendant Corp sues accounting firm of Ernst & Young LLP, contending that firm violated professional standards when it certified false financial statements of CUC International Inc, company that merged with HFS Inc to form Cendant in 1997; shares of Cendant have fallen 41 percent in last year as company was forced to restate three years of earnings; Ernst & Young says it was deceived itself by fraud that took place at Cendant (S)

headline: Economic Scene; New York blazes a trail on how to handle local-phone access.
abstract: Michael M Weinstein Economic Scene article hails New York State Public Service Commission's approach to opening local phone market to competition; cites its policy of sending squabbling lawyers from Bell Atlantic and long-distance carriers to sidelines while engineers and other technicians resolve technical disputes; notes Bell Atlantic continues to struggle to ease task of switching customers to competitors, with incentive that agency will back its bid to enter long-distance market when it succeeds; drawing (M)

headline: Arkansas Truck Tire Deal
abstract: Arkansas Best Corp agrees to pay $9 a share, total of $45.9 million, for 51 percent of Treadco Inc it does not already own (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices post their biggest decline in six weeks as record stockpiles indicate that production is outpacing demand; in New York, copper for May delivery falls 2.7 cents, to 62.45 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Yields at 3-Week Lows, With Favorable Inflation News Seen
abstract: Treasury bond prices rise for second day, pushing yields to lowest in almost three weeks; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 2/32, to 96 1/32; graphs (M)

headline: The History of Retirement, From Early Man to A.A.R.P.
abstract: Humorous article by Mary-Lou Weisman traces history of retirement, from Stone Age, when there were no old people, to 1999, as baby boomers threaten never to retire; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. Writer On Gay Topics Is Badly Beaten In an Irish City
abstract: Robert Drake, prominent American writer on gay themes, is in critical but stable condition in Dublin following Jan 31 assault by two men in Sligo; two men reportedly told police they beat Drake after he made sexual overtures to them; no arrests have been made (M)

headline: Account Review For ADT Security
abstract: ADT Security Services is undertaking review for its American advertising account, with billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: SALOMON SMITH BARNEY AND NIKKO SECURITIES IN DEAL
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney and Japan's Nikko Securities say their investment banking venture will open on March 1 after month's delay because of procedural problems; Standard & Poor's lowers Nikko Securities' counterparty rating to one notch above 'junk' status (S).

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Banking heavily on his name, Mario Gabelli is set to take his mutual fund operation public.
abstract: MARIO J. GABELLI plans to take his mutual fund company public this week after agreeing to cut his annual pay and to give his public shareholders first crack at his best investment ideas.     Both conditions allowed him to line up underwriters for the initial public offering, which is being viewed as an indicator of investor appetite for asset management companies. Money management firms have rebounded only modestly from last summer's selloff, causing several private ones, including Neuberger & Berman Inc. and Offitbank, to delay plans for public offerings.

headline: Tullamore Journal; Travelers' Tale: Irish Nomads Make Little Headway
abstract: Ireland's 40,000 nomads, formerly disparagingly called tinkers, are now politely called travelers; most have given up horsecarts and covered wagons of their ancestors for car-towed trailers; still have hard time finding regular jobs or adequate campsites; 2,000 live in illegal camps that lack normal facilities; Government has ordered local councils to provide adequate facilities within next five years; map; photo (M)

headline: M-G-M to Regain Film Distribution Rights
abstract: Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc says it will pay Warner Brothers $225 million to regain video distribution rights to MGM's film library; MGM sold rights in 1990 for 13 years (S)

headline: Accounting Is Questioned In Lawsuit Against iVillage
abstract: Joanne O'Rourke Hindman, former chief financial officer of iVillage Inc, a New York Internet service for women, files court documents accusing company of 'inappropriate' accounting practices, days before planned initial public offering of company; charges are made in connection with lawsuit filed in January by former employee Todd L Kenner, who contends that iVillage reneged on promise to give him stock options, a benefit that could prove valuable if offering, expected March 15, is successful; iVillage says it stands by its financial statements, which have been audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers (M)

headline: Linux Users Planning to Take Demands Straight to Microsoft
abstract: Proponents of Linux software operating system start Windows Refund Center, trying to get Microsoft to refund money they paid for Microsoft Windows, which is standard issue on most PC's (S)

headline: Older Students Bring New Life to Campuses
abstract: Thousands of senior citizens in United States are devoting their retirements to learning, and hundreds of colleges and universities are beginning to understand this burgeoning new market; colleges all across country are catering to retirees with broad array of academic programs, cultural offerings, community service initiatives and even housing options; estimated 300 colleges have such programs--known as Institutes for Learning in Retirement--and they serve more than 60,000 retirees; photo (M)

headline: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING TO SELL PEACHTREE UNIT
abstract: Automatic Data Processing Inc agrees to sell Peachtree Software Inc to Sage Group PLC for $145 million (S)

headline: Yeltsin's Trip Just Spotlights His Frailty
abstract: Boris N. Yeltsin's decision to attend the funeral of King Hussein of Jordan was supposed to be a vivid demonstration that the 68-year-old President is still capable of governing  Russia.    But the trip ended up as a showcase for Mr. Yeltsin's frailty, and it gave fresh ammunition to critics who say he is too ill to govern.

headline: Defying the Usual Wisdom, Inflation Holds Near Zero
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index rose 0.1 percent, Jan, continuing pattern of surprisingly mild inflation; index rose just 1.7 percent for 12 months through Jan; graph; table of consumer prices in key metropolitan areas (M)i

headline: Donaldson, Lufkin Makes A Move Up Merger Charts
abstract: Securities Data Co reports Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette now ranks third in dollar volume of worldwide merger and acquisition activity, far cry from its seventh-place showing this time last year; firm has been on hiring binge over last five years, expanding its banking staff almost fourfold and has aggressively wooed bankers from competitors (M)

headline: Equity and Convertible Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Careside Inc., Culver City, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.8 million shares. Fahnestock & Co.    Cerus Corp., Concord, Calif., 2 million shares. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.    Children's Place Retail Stores Inc., West Caldwell, N.J., 4 million shares. BT Alex. Brown.    Claimsnet.com Inc., Dallas, an initial public offering of 2.5 million shares. Cruttenden Roth Inc.    Critical Path, San Francisco, an initial public offering of 4.5 million shares. BancBoston Robertson Stephens.    El Dorado Bancshares Inc., Laguna Hills, Calif., an initial public offering of 2.4 million shares. Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.    Gen Trak Inc., Plymouth Meeting, Pa., an initial public offering of 650,000 units, each consisting of 2 common shares and 2 warrants. Barron Chase Securities.    Global Markets Access (GCA) Ltd., Hamilton, Bermuda, an initial public offering of 12 million shares, 17 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch/ Prudential Securities.    Infospace.com Inc., Redmond, Wash., 2.8 million. Hambrecht & Quist Inc.    International Smart Sourcing, Farmingdale, N.Y., an initial public offering of 1.3 million shares and warrants. Network 1.    Litronic Inc., Irvine, Calif., an initial public offering of 3 million shares. Bluestone Cap.    MKS Instruments Inc., Andover, Mass., an initial public offering of 6.5 million shares. NMS.    Pepsi Bottling Group Inc., Somers, N.Y., an initial public offering of 100 million shares, 85 million in the U.S. and Canada. Merrill Lynch & Co./Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.    PLX Technology Inc., Sunnyvale, Calif., an initial public offering of 3.3 million shares. Merrill Lynch & Co.    Priceline.com Inc., Stamford, Conn., an initial public offering of 10 million shares. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.    Trex Company, Winchester, Va., an initial public offering of 3.4 million shares. Schroder & Co.    Ziff-Davis Inc.--ZDNet Group, New York, an initial public offering of 10 million shares. Goldman Sachs & Co./Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette.    Source: MCM Corporatewatch.

headline: Business Travel; A rising number of airlines are making the case that a picture can be worth a thousand words.
abstract: Growing number of airlines are painting pictures on their planes; Austrian Airlines has 40-foot image of Johann Strauss on tail of some planes; characters from Pokemon, popular Japanese game and television cartoon series, decorate All Nippon Airways jets; Four Seasons hotel opens in Las Vegas, Nev, only luxury hotel on city's strip that does not have gambling casino; there is casino in 43-story tower that Four Seasons shares with Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino; Omni Ambassador East in Chicago wants to rent out for New Year's Eve 1999; hotel is asking $450,000 for two days and two nights; passengers should be aware that they are not entitled to compensation from airlines if winter storms result in canceled flights; photo (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Daniel Rejects A Takeover Bid
abstract: Daniel Industries, oilfield-equipment firm, says its board has rejected an unsolicited bid of about $267 million and hired an investment-banking firm to help it review its options; an unidentified company offered to buy Daniel for $15 a share (S)

headline: Japan Lowers Rates Again, And for Banks It's a Big Zero
abstract: Japan's central bank pushed overnight interest rates to the unprecedented level of effectively zero this week in one of its boldest attempts yet to invigorate the economy -- basically allowing Japanese banks to borrow free.    The Bank of Japan's move, which partly contributed today to a 5 percent surge in the Japanese stock market, represents a gamble that banks will use this borrowed money to increase their own lending to businesses and individuals. The hope is that such a move will stimulate spending and generate a recovery in the world's second-largest economy, which is stuck in the worst recession since World War II.

headline: Microsoft Official Defends Company's Strategy at Trial
abstract: Microsoft Corp senior vice president James Allchin, in antitrust trial, delivers forceful defense of company's actions in Internet software market, saying it has acted mainly in pursuit of 'Holy Grail of software development' by making its products more powerful, easier to use and seamlessly integrated (M)

headline: 4th-Quarter Slowing In British Economy
abstract: Britain reports growth in gross domestic product slowed to 0.2 percent in fourth quarter from third quarter and 1.6 percent from 1997 period (S)

headline: OLD KENT FINANCIAL PLANS TO BUY CFSB BANCORP
abstract: Old Kent Financial Corp says it will buy CFSB Bancorp Inc for $235 million in stock (S)

headline: Young and Single, and Wanting Some Tax Relief
abstract: LAST year's tax season was not a pretty one for Michael Grande. Oh, he faced no major hurdles, no unexpected penalties or audits; it's just that he ended up shelling out ''north of 20 grand.'' He had expected to pay about $18,000, but he is an active investor and had a good a year in the market.    Mr. Grande, who is single, makes upward of $100,000 a year in salary and bonuses; he contributes to his 401 (k) plan, now amounting to $100,000 spread among three mutual funds, and invests nearly $25,000 a year in stocks. So he has a substantial income that he has not offset with deductions. For example, he rents an apartment in Manhattan, so he can't claim a deduction on a mortgage.

headline: Tables Turn on a Filtering Site As It Is Temporarily Blocked
abstract: Surf Watch, which produces daily filtering updates that its customers can download, accidentally blocks Filtering Facts, Web site that advocates use of software filters in libraries to protect children from 'objectionable' material (S)

headline: Alcatel-Motorola Venture
abstract: Alcatel SA, Europe's No. 2 phone equipment maker, and Motorola Inc, No. 2 maker of cellular telephones, announce they will jointly develop and sell digital phone network equipment; also say they will develop so-called third-generation mobile phone equipment (S)

headline: U.S. Will Increase Oil Reserve For the First Time Since 1994
abstract: Clinton Administration is expected to announce that it plans to add oil to Strategic Petroleum Reserve for first time since 1994; move is aimed at shoring up nation's shrinking protection against oil emergencies; Government will take royalty payments for wells on Federal land in oil rather than money (M)

headline: When Do Artists Pack It In? Never
abstract: Doris Grumbach, 80-year-old novelist, writes that painters, writers, composers and sculptors work until they die, because for creative people, work is something that lasts as long as life (M)

headline: Making a Fortune, One Monster at a Time
abstract: J C Herz evaluates computer game Pokemon, in which participants raise and train monsters to fight; game is published by Nintendo and costs $29.95; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: MODERATES LEAD IN VOTE  Moderate candidates were leading in all 15 seats in Teheran and appeared to have routed hard-liners in most other races nationwide in Iran's first municipal elections, according to partial results. The outcome is seen as an endorsement of President Mohammad Khatami's efforts to ease the social and political restrictions imposed by the hard-liners in the Government. Final counts are expected by Friday. (AP)    IRAQ: OIL EXPORTS HURT BY U.S. RAID  About half of Iraq's oil exports are in jeopardy after American warplanes hit two communications centers that controlled the flow of oil through a key pipeline, an Iraqi official said. The damage is so extensive that it will take a ''long time'' to resume pumping oil through the pipeline to Turkey, said Hussein al-Fattal, head of operations for Iraq's Northern Oil Company. (AP)

headline: Ethnic Albanian Guerrillas Will Attend Talks on Kosovo
abstract: Members of the Kosovo Liberation Army, ethnic Albanian guerrilla force, say they will attend peace talks outside Paris and meet Serbian opponents at negotiating table; Kosovo's political leadership is also attending, but guerrillas' participation is seen as crucial to hopes of ending fighting; Jakup Krasniqi will lead delegation; photo of Albanians grieving for slain relatives (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bond Prices End Decline, But Stocks Continue to Fall  Bond prices rallied, ending a three-day slide that sent interest rates to their highest levels since August. But even with the rebound, interest rates remain high and continue to pose a threat to the outlook for the stock market.

headline: Group Dismisses Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Two New Zealand offices of Saatchi & Saatchi are dismissed by New Zealand Tourism Board in wake of political scandal that led to calls for resignation of Prime Min Jenny Shipley; at issue is Shipley's increase in budget for board, which prompted accusations that she plans to use agency's tourism campaign to help her re-election bid (S)

headline: Drug Tourism / In Laos, English Menus and New Opium Dens : Westerners Flock East for an 'Asian Trip'
abstract: VANG VIENG, Laosâ€”  With a ring of opium grease starting to bubble around the pinhole on the end of his pipe, the emaciated old man reclining on a pile of dirty white pillows nods slightly to signal the liquid will soon vaporize.

headline: Texaco Posts 80% Plunge in Earnings
abstract: Texaco Inc reports fourth-quarter earnings fell 80 percent; says earnings before special items fell to $92 million, from $472 million in 1997 quarter; special items gave Texaco final loss of $213 million, compared with net income of $623 million in 1997 period (M)

headline: The latest music form to find resurrection by mainstream marketers is swing, in all its glory.
abstract: Advertising column notes swing sounds are becoming music of choice in increasing number of campaigns for mainstream advertisers; television and radio commercials are reverberating with voices of vocalists like Louis Prima, Cab Calloway and Frank Sinatra, and with big-band sounds of 1930's and 1940's; photo (M)

headline: American Begins Return To Normal Flight Schedule
abstract: American Airlines is flying a 'virtually normal' schedule of flights for first time since pilots began sickout on Feb 6; airline and pilots' union continue talks over issue that began labor action: how fast nearly 2,000 junior crew members at American would be promoted as result of American's purchase of Reno Air in December, and how soon raises at Reno would take effect (M)

headline: John Atwood, Aviation Executive, Dies at 94
abstract: John Leland Atwood, engineer who rose through executive ranks at North American Aviation as it built P-51 Mustang, most powerful fighter plane of World War II, F-100 Super Sabre, first supersonic fighter, and Apollo capsule that took men to moon, died on March 5 at age 94; photo (M)

headline: Jury Rules That PBS Must Pay Video Distributor $47 Million
abstract: Federal jury in Los Angeles unanimously finds Public Broadcasting Service guilty of breach of contract and fraud in dealing with Michael Nesmith, former member of rock group The Monkees, and awards Nesmith and his video company, Pacific Arts Inc, nearly $47 million in compensatory and punitive damages; verdict is unusual because Nesmith was defendant in case, in which PBS sought to recover past royalties due from his company; jury rejected PBS claim while finding in favor of Nesmith's counterclaim; Nesmith spent much of 1980's buying home-video rights to PBS programs; photo (M)

headline: Seeing End of Sanctions, Burundi Breathes Easier
abstract: 200,000 people have been killed in Burundi since civil war broke out in 1993; strict economic sanctions imposed on nation by its neighbors in Aug 1996 have not worked out exactly as planned; sanctions most likely will be suspended in acknowledgment that they have outlived their usefulness and may be doing more harm than good to Burundi's fragile peace effort; map; photo (M)

headline: A Kosovo Family's Cry: 'Now We Have Nothing'
abstract: UN reports flow of refugees from Kosovo, Serbia, has exploded in recent days, with 60,000 reaching Albania and additional 150,000 on way; refugees tell harrowing tales of whole towns being ordered to flee by Serbian policemen and paramilitary units, people being robbed along way and stripped of identity documents and others executed; similarities of accounts seem to indicate that Serbian campaign is methodical, organized and systematic; map; photos (M)

headline: WINSLOEW FURNITURE IN DEAL TO BE BOUGHT
abstract: Winsloew Furniture Inc says it agreed to be acquired for about $223.5 million in cash by management group led by its chmn, Earl Powell (S)

headline: YAHOO TO OFFER CREDIT CARD SERVICES THROUGH BANK ONE
abstract: Yahoo Inc signs agreement with Bank One Corp and First Data Corp to offer credit card processing services to on-line stores featured on Yahoo's Web site; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Getting In on the Ground Floor In the Cyberpostage Market
abstract: Small businesses in San Francisco and Washington areas are testing security and reliability of electronic postage systems offered by two start-up companies, Stamps.com and E-Stamp Corp; they register financial information on line and then download and print encrypted, bar-code-line stamps; Pitney Bowes is also testing its on-line system; photo (M)

headline: DVD! No, Divx! No . . .
abstract: Letter by William L Plumb responds to Jan 28 article on Divx; says some of the information in article comes from groups and individuals who simply misunderstand what Divx-enhanced DVD disk is all about

headline: Chemical Maker Purchase
abstract: Tetra Technologies buys Cozinco Inc for $12 million (S)

headline: Move to End Quick Write-Offs Of Research in Acquisitions
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board rules that companies should no longer be able to immediately write off value of research acquired from other companies; decision is preliminary but significant because it could soon stop practice that is being used by increasing number of companies buying other businesses and that has recently raised concerns among Federal regulators; some companies have been able to recoup cost of merger by citing footnote in accounting rules that allows companies to write off cost of continuing research they acquire by immediately deducting amount from bottom line; board wants to require companies to put value of acquired research on their books as asset, which would be slowly written off over years, reducing future earnings (M)

headline: U.S. Says It Caught a Chinese Smuggler Seeking Gyroscopes That Can Guide Missiles
abstract: Federal agents in California arrest Yao Yi, Chinese citizen, and charge him with trying to obtain component vital to missile guidance systems; arrest sheds light on China's alleged effort to smuggle American technology to improve accuracy of its weapons (M)

headline: U.S. Used U.N. Team to Place Spy Device in Iraq, Aides Say
abstract: United States officials say that in March, in a last-ditch attempt to uncover Saddam Hussein's covert weapons and intelligence networks, US used United Nations inspection team to send an American spy into Baghdad to install highly sophisticated electronic eavesdropping shystem; say spy entered Iraq in guise of UN weapons inspector and left behind eavesdropping device; for nine months, device let US and a select few within UN inspection team monitor cell phones, walkie-talkies and other communications instruments used by military and intelligence officers who protect Pres Saddam Hussein and conceal Iraq's weapons; this operaation is at center of current furor over relationship between American intelligence agents and insepctors with UN Special Commission, which is supposed to be independent, and not pursue policy or intelligence goals of individual members; photos (L)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper prices rise 2.8 percent on expectations of further strength in US housing and construction industries; March contracts rise 1.85 cents a pound, to 68.45 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: When Old-Fashioned Is Good
abstract: Letter by Judy Rascoe, responding to Jan 28 article on new wireless telephone technology, says article should have recommended that people retain at least one telephone that operates off current from a phone jack

headline: Independent Booksellers Plan to Open On-Line Store
abstract: American Booksellers Association, trade association for independent booksellers, is creating national on-line store, Book Sense, to stave off fierce competition from Amazon.com and Barnesandnoble.com; store will feature all the standard functions of popular on-line sites, including a search engine, a stock of 1.5 million titles, credit card fulfillment, gift wrapping, distribution services and a best-seller list, but it will also allow individual stores to tailor Web pages to reflect their individuality with store reviews and features; independents' share of popular consumer book market has shrunk to about 17 percent today from 32 percent in 1991 (M)

headline: Wall Street's Banks Kept To Hierarchy During 1998
abstract: Major United States investment banks underwrote record $1.82 trillion in new stocks and bonds in 1998, up about 40 percent from 1997, despite near-shutdown of financial markets in third quarter; bond underwriting rose 44 percent, spurred by low interest rates; stock sales fell 10 percent, with market drying up in second half; investment banks advised companies on mergers and acquisitions valued at $2.5 trillion, up sharply from 1997; many firms are on course to match or exceed record 1997 earnings, but continue to see overall profit margins shrink; year's turmoil did not rock rankings of top investment banks; Merrill Lynch & Co, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co and Goldman Sachs & Co continued to dominate most lucrative businesses; table of top securities underwriters (M)

headline: 13 Are Killed By Firebomb At Busy Store In Istanbul
abstract: Thirteen people were killed and three others were wounded today in a bomb attack on a shopping center in an outlying section of Istanbul, police officials said.    No one claimed immediate responsibility.

headline: DHL AND U.S. POSTAL SERVICE TO MAKE DELIVERIES IN EUROPE
abstract: DHL Worldwide Express Inc to make deliveries in US and Europe with United State Postal Service, charging less than Federal Express or United Parcel Service (S)

headline: Top Central Bank Aide Resigns in Malaysia
abstract: Abdul Murad Khalid as resigned as assistant governor of Malaysia's central bank; no successor is named (S)

headline: Dairy Group to End Work With Burnett
abstract: Dairy Management Inc, which conducts advertising and promotional programs for American Dairy Association and National Dairy Council, and Leo Burnett Co are negotiating to end their relationship on advertising account with billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Serbs' Killing of 40 Albanians Ruled a Crime Against Humanity
abstract: Dr Helena Ranta says 40 ethnic Albanians who were killed in Racak, Serbia, in Jan were unarmed civilians; Ranta, head of Finnish forensic team that examined bodies, says their slaying amounts to crime against humanity (M)

headline: CMP MEDIA HIRES LAZARD FRERES TO HELP EXPLORE OPTIONS
abstract: CMP Media Inc, magazine company that owns seven magazines aimed at builders, users and sellers of technology, hires Lazard Freres & Co to explore its options, including a sale (S)

headline: Clinton and Latin Leaders Turn to Immigration
abstract: Pres Clinton and a group of Central American leaders declare that they will work among themselves and with United States to reach 'humane and permanent solutions' to problems of illegal immigration; declaration is issued at one-day meeting in Antigua, Guatemala, that focuses on reconstruction after a devastating autumn hurricane, development, trade and immigration; photo of Clinton and Latin leaders (M)

headline: Maker of Inexpensive PC's Reports a Flood of Orders
abstract: Richard Latman, head of Microworkz Computer, says company received orders for 50,000 of their $299 personal computer, called Webzter Jr; Webzter Jr uses Cyrix 300 MII chip and various off-brand components, and it does not include Microsoft Windows 98, industry-standard operating system that comes already loaded on most more expensive personal computers; Webzter Jr is being promoted primarily as Web-surfing device; company has profit margin of about $36 per PC; Latman claims aim is to put computers in hands of more children; photo (M)

headline: The Weather Channel's High-Profit Center
abstract: Weather Channel develops loyal following that has turned it into a cash machine for its owner, the privately owned Landmark Communications; its low-cost programming reaches 70 million homes; it generated an estimated $100 million in operating profits in 1998 on revenue of $200 million that came primarily from advertising, as well as from fees paid by cable operators; photos (M)

headline: Shortage of Accounting Students Raises Concern on Audit Quality
