abstract: Number of professionals in public accounting has remained almost unchanged in last decade, even as number of public companies has grown by almost 30 percent; public accountants play key role, acting as watchdogs for millions of American investors by reviewing financial reports of companies and giving independent, expert opinion on whether management's numbers are trustworthy; many college accounting majors are looking to Wall Street for more excitement and money; this raises concerns about decline in quality of auditors; profession's largest and most powerful group, National Conference of CPA Practitioners, proposes to make job more attractive by, in part, reducing requirements; some accountants and regulators adamantly oppose that plan; accounting firms find their corporate clients reluctant to pay more for their annual audits, so they cannot offer greater salaries to incoming accountants; photo; graph (M)

headline: THE CASTRO DOLLAR: A special report; In Cuba's New Dual Economy, Have-Nots Far Exceed Haves
abstract: Special report, The Castro Dollar, finds Cubans are struggling to survive in dual economy, fueled in large part by money flowing from US, island's arch enemy, 10 years after collapse of Soviet bloc and cutoff of lifeline of subsidies and aid; once egalitarian island has evolved into society of haves and have-nots, in which increasing numbers of people are turning to illegal schemes to make ends meet; many Cubans have abandoned state jobs and opened small businesses under new rules allowing self-employment in faint hope of earning more than they did from state; driving trend is simple reality, namely, that state-controlled wages have remained frozen while prices have risen dramatically since Soviet era ended; even though Govt continues to distribute rations of subsidized food and to provide free housing, medical care and education, most Cubans are unable to survive on salaries and pensions alone; more than 160,000 currently operate private businesses, spare rooms in houses can be rented and artisans can hawk wares to tourists; Govt has also established markets where farmers can sell produce left over after state is supplied with its quota; even so, island remains essentially Communist state; Jose Luis Rodriguez, Minister of Economy and Planning, says reforms are intended to allow some private employment without dropping commitment to Communism; says island will not revert to market economy; map; photos (L)

headline: U.S. Negotiator at the Kosovo Talks Visits Milosevic
abstract: US Amb Christopher R Hill, American negotiator at Kosovo peace talks in Rambouillet, France, visits Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade; repeatedly reiterates warning issued publicly by West that NATO will launch air strikes against Serbia if it fails to agree to presence of NATO-led ground force in Kosovo (M)

headline: Schools Turn Kosovo Into Civics Lesson
abstract: In schools around the country, a complicated lesson in geopolitics has suddenly sprung from the textbook onto the television screen. And like many of their parents, students are struggling to make sense of it.    Few had heard of Kosovo before NATO began air strikes on Wednesday. In interviews yesterday, the military assault and its historical background puzzled students at every grade level.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HENRY SCHEIN INC., Melville, N.Y., a distributor of medical supplies to doctors and dentists, said it had bought Heiland Group G.m.b.H., a German direct marketer of medical, dental and veterinary supplies. Financial terms were not disclosed.    TOWN AND COUNTRY FINE JEWELRY GROUP INC., Chelsea, Mass., a jewelry maker, said it had laid off 260 American workers, or 75 percent of its domestic work force, because of weak sales last fall.    NEWPARK RESOURCES INC., Metairie, La., an oilfield services company, said it had dismissed 100 employees, or 8 percent of its work force, and would lower capital spending from $60 million to $28 million.

headline: VENATOR GROUP GIVEN $400 MILLION CREDIT LINE
abstract: Venator Group Inc, top United States retailer of athletic shoes and clothing, says that it had received $400 million revolving line of credit in an amended agreement with its banks (S)

headline: New Head of Pocket Books
abstract: Simon & Schuster, unit of Pearson PLC, names Judith Curr, president and publisher of its Pocket Books division, effective April 12; Curr replaces Gina Centrello, who resigned (S)

headline: CHECKERS TO BUY RALLY'S HAMBURGERS
abstract: Checkers Drive-In Restaurants to buy Rally's Hamburgers Inc for $29.3 million in stock (S)

headline: U.S. Pollster For Opponent Of Netanyahu Is Burglarized
abstract: Break-in is reported at Washington offices of American polling firm advising Ehud Barak, leader of Israel's opposition Labor Party; this threatens to inject new venom into election campaign; candidates are exercising restraint while awaiting results of investigation by US authorities; there are strong suspicions that burglars were after material concerning Barak's campaign to unseat Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu in national elections on May 17; Stanley Greenberg, who heads polling firm, has worked for many Democratic politicians; photo (M)

headline: Mouse That Roared: European Parliament Stands Up
abstract: News analysis of abrupt resignation of entire executive leadership of 15-member European Union amid charges of fraud and gross mismanagement; resignation clearly reflects deeper malaise in which democratic accountability of organization's Brussels-based leadership has not grown, even though size and power of united Europe have expanded; underscores need for European leaders to pay greater attention to theme of democracy (M)

headline: CHIEF EXECUTIVE SAYS TELLABS IS NOT IN TAKEOVER TALKS
abstract: Tellabs Inc chief executive Michael J Birck says he is not in discussions to sell company (S)

headline: Panel Denies Amnesty for Four Officers in Steve Biko's Death
abstract: Four former police officers who say they accidentally killed anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko are denied amnesty by Truth and Reconciliation Commission; commission cites several reasons for decision, including belief that officers lied about Biko's detention and interrogation in 1977, during which he died of severe head injuries (M)

headline: U.S. Negotiators Depart, Frustrated by Milosevic's Hard Line
abstract: Senior US official says that Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic refused 'every opportunity' to avoid onslaught of NATO air power during negotiations with US envoy Richard C Holbrooke (M)

headline: Oh, Those Pesky Little Financial Details
abstract: Micron Technology's Dec 23 news release on its fiscal first quarter reports a figure for sales of semiconductor memory products that is 4.3 percent higher than the one shown on quarterly report, or 10-Q, filed with SEC on Jan 5; 10-Q also reports a 10 percent decline in megabits shipped that is not mentioned in news release; Micron's share price has risen 49 percent since news release; graph (M)

headline: Sears to Pay Fine of $60 Million In Bankruptcy Fraud Lawsuit
abstract: Ending a two-year criminal investigation into charges that it was trying to illegally collect debts from customers who had declared bankruptcy, Sears, Roebuck & Company agreed yesterday to plead guilty to one count of bankruptcy fraud and to pay a fine of $60 million.    The fine, which is subject to approval by the Federal District Court, would be the largest ever to be paid in a bankruptcy fraud case, according to the United States Attorney's office in Boston.

headline: MCI WORLDCOM WINS 4-YEAR GOVERNMENT PHONE CONTRACT
abstract: General Services Administration says MCI Worldcom Inc wins second of two contracts to provide Federal Government agencies with at least $750 million worth of phone services over four years; Sprint Corp won first contract in December and will also receive minimum revenue of $750 million (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Tax-subsidized savings may not work out as many hope.
abstract: Economic Scene column on tax-subsidized savings plans proposed in Pres Clinton's budget and legislation offered Sens Robert C Torricelli and Paul D Coverdell, which gives tax breaks on interest, dividends and capital gains; says these plans are politically deft, but are economically suspect; says Clinton's plan purports to increase savings of America's many nonsaving families, but no one knows how to make idea work in practice; many economists argue Torricelli's plan would provide little more than consumption holiday for higher-income families and do virtually nothing to achieve stated goal of rebuilding nation's low savings rate; drawing (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Pilots for American Airlines Defy a Back-to-Work Order  Pilots for American Airlines defied a Federal judge's order to end their sickout. Instead 2,400 pilots called in sick, forcing the carrier to cancel more than half its 2,250 flights.

headline: Searing Indictment
abstract: Guatemalan truth commission report blaming military for deaths of nearly 200,000 people in 36-year civil war surprised nearly everyone with bluntness and severity of its judgments and recommendations; weakens political standing of military high command and their civilian allies and leaves them open to prosecution; charge of genocide against groups of Mayan people is not covered by amnesty they were granted in 1996 (M)

headline: Ogden-Seagram Wet 'n Wild Deal
abstract: Ogden Corp acquires water park operator Wet 'n Wild Inc from Universal Studios subsidiary of Seagram Co for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Merging French Banks To Reduce Loan Volume
abstract: Societe Generale SA and Paribas SA, French banks merging to create Europe's second-biggest bank, plans to reduce their loans to corporate clients by more than 10 percent, freeing capital to make acquisitions (S)

headline: New Pension Plans Are Cash and Carry
abstract: New 'cash balance' pension plan is growing in popularity with large corporations trying to cope with increasingly mobile work force; portable plan appeals to younger employees who may not stay with company long enough to reap full benefits of traditional plan; benefits in plan build uniformly from year to year and are usually paid in lump sum, which can be rolled into individual retirement account and continue to grow (M)

headline: Commonhealth Unit Gets New Name
abstract: Commonwealth Direct is renamed Xchange Group; Matt Giegerich, president of Quantum Group, consumer health communications division of Commonwealth, is named to additional postion of president of Xchange; he succeeds Diana Long, who resigned; Jeff Ross is named to new position of vice president and managing director; Mark Kosak is named to new position of vice president and creative director (S)

headline: Jordanians Pay Tribute to Late King and His Heir
abstract: Thousands of Jordanians from desert camps, urban shacks and sleek modern villas made their way to the royal palace today to offer sympathy to King Abdullah and prayers for his late father, King Hussein.    Queen Noor, the widow of King Hussein, and other women in the royal family prayed separately for the first time at the King's grave.

headline: Notebook With Consumer Feel Will Be Aimed at Companies
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co presents its first laptop with a true consumer feel; HP Omnibook XE, which includes 266-megahertz Intel Pentium II processor, 4.1-gigabyte hard drive and 32 megabytes of RAM, will initially not be sold in any consumer retail stores, but will be marketed by Hewlett Packard through existing corporate channels and on the Web; photo of new laptop (S)

headline: U.S. and China Trying Hard For Breakthrough on Trade
abstract: United States and China are making crash effort to resolve issues that block China from joining World Trade Organization; Deputy Treas Sec Lawrence H Summers comments on effort after meeting with Prime Min Zhu Rongji, Beijing; United States wants accord that will lower China's tariffs and commit it to legally enforceable schedule for opening markets (M)

headline: Olivetti Renews Efforts to Buy Telecom Italia
abstract: Olivetti SpA approves some technical steps required by Italian stock market regulators for it to proceed with $60 billion hostile bid for Telecom Italia; Olivetti's moves, including raising new capital and selling communications business, are intended to overcome objections of regulators, who initially declared invalid earlier Olivetti bid for Telecom Italia, which is five times Olivetti's size; quickly resubmitting valid bid for Telecom Italia is crucial to Olivetti's strategy; under Italian takeover law, company cannot take defensive steps once valid offer has been made; it is unclear whether Olivetti's latest steps are sufficient to validate its bid; company has not raised its bid price of 10 euros a share, or $11, for all Telecom Italia voting stock, which comes as surprise to investors who expected pot to be sweetened (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: General Dynamics Bids For Rival Submarine Maker  General Dynamics, the nation's largest maker of nuclear-powered submarines, stunned the defense industry by making an unsolicited $1.4 billion bid for Newport News Shipbuilding, the No. 2 maker.

headline: SEMA GROUP ANNOUNCES AN ALLIANCE WITH BROADVISION
abstract: Sema Group PLC, Europe's second-largest computer services company, forms alliance with Broadvision Inc, Internet software company in Redwood City, Calif, to offer systems to telecommunications companies that will allow customers to pay bills and buy services through the Internet (S)

headline: Nissan Plans To Pay Off Unit's Debts
abstract: Nissan Motor Co, eager to resolve sticking point in merger talks with DaimlerChrysler AG, plans to announce that it is paying off debts at troubled subsidiary, Nissan Diesel Sales; Nissan wants to reach deal soon because credit rating agencies have been threatening to lower its rating; DaimlerChrysler co-chairman Robert J Eaton tells Associated Press at Geneva International Motor Show that his company will likely decide before end of March whether to take a stake in Nissan (M)

headline: Markets Up On Strength Of Blue Chips
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 121.26 points, to 9,324.58; Nasdaq composite index jumps 64.10 points, or 2.71 percent, to record 2,433.41; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 18.33 points, to 1,252.31; graph; tables (M)

headline: New York Life To Review Account
abstract: New York Life Insurance will review its account, which has been handled by TBWA/Chiat/Day; billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen surges on higher Japanese bond yields, which have doubled in last two months and increased investors demand for yen; in New York, dollar falls to 112.05 yen from 115.08; graph; chart (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ICF KAISER INTERNATIONAL INC.,  Fairfax, Va., an engineering and construction services company, said it planned to sell its consulting unit to the New York-based investment firm CM Equity Partners L.P., for $75 million to concentrate on its other businesses.

headline: Vice President For Siberia
abstract: Readers are asked to submit their stories about being offered promotions at work only to realize that they were being moved aside, not up

headline: With King Hussein Near Death, Power in Jordan Is Passed to Son
abstract: Jordanian Govt transfers full powers to 37-year-old Crown Prince Abdullah, with King Hussein unconscious and near death from cancer; he is sworn in as Regent by Prime Min Fayez Tarawneh after 22-member Cabinet votes unanimously to declare Hussein unfit; is invested with full constitutional powers of monarchy; transfer effectively ends 40-year reign of Hussein, who clung to power through wars, coups and assassination attempts; doctors say his lungs, liver and kidneys have failed and that he is being kept alive on respirator; photos (M)

headline: Exemplary, But Exhausted
abstract: Q. My boss often tells me I am his best worker. His praise is gratifying, and he backs it up with raises each year. But his attitude that I am irreplaceable makes it difficult for me to take any time off, even when I'm ill. I'm not the only talented worker in the office, but because I am given all the most challenging assignments, I'm the only one with experience doing them. How can I keep my boss's high regard from leaving me stuck at my desk?    A. Maybe your supervisor is an evil management genius, exploiting your work ethic at the expense of your personal life. But more likely, he just doesn't see the problem. ''It's easy for a boss to single in on one person they know they can depend on; it's not done  intentionally, but as a convenience,'' said Gerald E. Holmes, a director of media relations for General Motors who has held several supervisory positions there.

headline: With the Office Depot account, DeVito/Verdi will get a chance to play in the big leagues.
abstract: LITTLE more than a decade ago, Ellis Verdi was making cold calls for accounts from his Upper East Side apartment, where he had started an advertising agency with an Apple Macintosh and an extra phone line.     Today, his company, DeVito/Verdi, is considered one of New York's hot shops with $115 million in billings, 86 employees and a growing client base. With its winning in December of the $40 million-plus account for the Office Depot Inc. chain of office products superstores and a string of other smaller, but important assignments from major advertisers such as Seagram, Canon and Sony Electronics, the agency seems poised to become a national player in the $58 billion advertising business.

headline: Stock Markets, Facing Threats, Pursue Changes
abstract: Nation's biggest stock markets seek to form alliances with competitors that are grabbing growing share of America's booming stock-trading business; if transformation works as hoped, it could provide investors, big and small, with better service at lower prices; if plan goes awry, it could damage stock market whose strength and fairness have attracted foreign capital, fostered growth of new businesses, and provided opportunities for many millions of investors; New York Stock Exchange, where traders meet on central trading floor, might build or buy its own electronic trading network; Nasdaq market, electronic marketplace, is discussing alliances with private trading networks; largest such network, Instinet unit of Reuters Group PLC, is talking with Nasdaq and New York exchange about alternative ways to trade stocks (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Two Alliances Seek New Routes to Internet  Two separate industry alliances to be announced today share a similar goal: creating alternatives to the personal computer -- and to Microsoft's operating systems -- for access to the Internet.     In one announcement, I.B.M., Motorola, Sun Microsystems, Lucent and 10 other companies have agreed to create standards based on Sun's Java programming language to connect smart devices ranging from computers to dishwashers. In a separate deal, U S West and Network Computer plan to announce a schedule for trials of AT-TV, which will integrate the Internet, telephone and television. [Page C2.]

headline: Financier Stays Under The Radar
abstract: Carl C Icahn, financier who has made two attempts to shake up RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp over last four years, is strangely quiet despite recent threats of proxy battle to force company to split up its food and tobacco businesses; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Treasuries Rally Sharply On Policy Reversal by Japan
abstract: US bond prices rise sharply higher; price of 30-year bond rises 1 5/32, to 98 21/32; yield drops to 5.34 percent, from 5.42 percent on Feb 12; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Computer Games Venture Into the World of Gun, Bow and Big Game
abstract: Robert Westmoreland of Wal-Mart Stores Inc has been driving force behind phenomenal success of computer hunting games, led by Deer Hunter and Cabela's Big Game Hunter; Westmoreland is credited with prodding software industry to make hunting games and then promoting them heavily at Wal-Mart, nation's largest retailer; five of 20 top-selling computer games last year were low-cost hunting titles; their success is considered sure sign that personal computing is moving to the masses; audience for outdoor games, mainly male, is often older and less technophile than gamers have been in past; these games took off last year, as computers priced below $1,000 became commonplace and proportion of American households with computers rose to 50 percent; photo; chart (M)

headline: Patriot Set to Decide On Offers From Two
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc. is expected to make a decision tomorrow on whether to accept an offer made by the Hilton Hotels Corporation or one made by an investor group led by Apollo Real Estate Advisors, and the company appears to be leaning toward the Apollo bid, people close to the situation told Dow Jones.     The Dallas-based real estate investment trust will hold a conference call tomorrow to listen to final presentations from Hilton and the Apollo group, at which time a decision will be made, the person said.

headline: Former U.N. Arms Inspector Is Criticized by State Dept.
abstract: State Department suggests there is nothing surprising or new in Scott Ritter's disclosure that Central Intelligence Agency placed employees on United Nations weapons inspection team in Iraq and helped plan inspections; holds Ritter's book, Endgame, is misleading and helps Saddam Hussein's propaganda machine; Rolf Ekeus, former head of UN commission that conducted inspections, scores Ritter and book; rejects Ritter's speculation of tie between UN team sent to Iraq in 1996 and what may have been CIA-inspired coup attempt (M)

headline: Television spots for Legoland, a new theme park, promise more than the usual scenes of thrill rides.
abstract: yrticle on $15 million television advertising campaign by Asher & Partners for Legoland, Lego Group's $130 million theme park in California (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Banking legislation puts fiscal heavyweights in rival corners.
abstract: Continuing spat between Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin and Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan over modernizing bank regulations threatens to bury legislation that comes before House and Senate committees; they agree that laws that keep out securities and insurance markets should be scrapped; but they disagree how banks should be structured to handle their new responsibilities; photo (Economic Scene column) (M)

headline: 45 Die and 100 Are Hurt as Indonesian Muslims and Christians Riot
abstract: Four days of rioting between Muslims and Christians on Ambon island causes deaths of 45 people in worst violence in Indonesia since May; police say more than 100 people are injured, 88 houses destroyed and 3 mosques and 3 churches burned; night curfew is imposed, and 2,500 soldiers and police officers work to restore order; riots were set off by street argument; map (M)

headline: For First Time in War, E-Mail Plays a Vital Role
abstract: Conflict in Yugoslavia is first instance of warfare in which small but significant slice of population has Internet access, allowing creation of entire news network consisting of E-mail, chat rooms and bulletin boards; access is proving more reliable than uneven international telephone lines in communicating with concerned friends and relatives; is way for many who do not have satellite dishes to cope without depending on news from state-controlled media (M)

headline: Croatia Branded as Another Balkans Pariah
abstract: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe report condemns Croatian Government of Pres Franjo Tudjman for violating human rights and rights of minorities and disregarding rule of law (M)

headline: TENNECO TO SELL STAKE IN CONTAINERBOARD UNIT
abstract: Tenneco Inc to sell majority stake in its containerboard business, which will be renamed Packaging Corp of America, to Madison Dearborn Partners for $2.2 billion; will keep 45 percent stake (S)

headline: KERR-MCGEE TAKES CHARGE IN RESPONSE TO LOW OIL PRICES
abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp will take $250 million fourth-quarter charge to lower value of its oil and natural gas reserves in response to lower oil prices; company, which is buying Oryx Energy Co for $2.8 billion, also says it is rescinding $300 million stock repurchase program because of acquisition and that it will cut 1999 spending for combined company by 45 percent (S)

headline: 4 I.R.A. Gang Members Sentenced in Killing of Irish Detective
abstract: Four members of an Irish Republican Army gang are sentenced in Dublin to terms of 11 to 14 years for killing Gerry McCabe, an Irish detective, during robbery of a bank van in Adare, Ireland, in 1996; outrage is voiced in many quarters over decision by prosecutors to drop charges from murder and manslaughter, which they did because crucial witnesses had been intimidated and refused to repeat in court what they had told police (M)

headline: Big Chip Maker Warns on Jobs And Earnings
abstract: Advanced Micro Devices Inc says it will report significant loss for current quarter ended March 28 and will cut 300 jobs worldwide over next two quarters; warning comes after similar statement a month ago, when Advanced Micro said pricing pressures on microprocessors might leave it with loss for quarter, prompting two-day rout of technology-laden Nasdaq stock market (M)

headline: SALE OF 100 MILLION CASES OF NEW DIET COLA EXPECTED
abstract: Pepsico Inc expects to sell 100 million cases of its new Pepsi One diet cola in first year; cola, introducted in Oct, is maintaining 1.5 percent to 2 percent market share (S)

headline: The View From Calpers On Shareholder Proxies
abstract: California Public Employees Retirement System sets up Web site where investors can track how the fund intends to vote on shareholder proxies (S)

headline: I Like It Here. The House Is Paid For. I Think I'll Stay!
abstract: Joy Alter Hubel article notes majority of people tend to retire in place, remaining in or near homes; problems arise when requisites of suburban life are beyond older person's abilities; social service providers, noting many pockets in Nassau County, NY, and elsewhere where retirement-age adults account for more than half of population, see such naturally occuring retirement communities as tools for turning retirees into pressure groups working in own behalf; photo (M)l

headline: Microsoft's Counterattack To Focus on Rivals' Linkup
abstract: Microsoft Corp, whose antitrust trial resumes in April, is expected to present evidence suggesting that America Online plans to become a head-on challenger through the acquisition of Netscape Communications and agreement to buy and jointly develop technology with Sun Microsystems Inc; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said in December that deal might result in very significant change in playing field as far as the industry is concerned; Justice Department has approved Aemrica Online-Netscape-Sun pact (M)

headline: Mortgage Rates Are Lower
abstract: Interest rates on 30-year, fixed-rate mortgages fall for the week, to average of 6.78 percent (S)

headline: World Bank Cuts Off Loans to 2 Brazilian States
abstract: World Bank freezes $209 million in development loans to two Brazilian states locked in economic war with central Government, Minas Gerais and Rio Grande do Sul; move is clear bid to support beleaguered Government of Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso; Itamar Franco, governor of Minas Gerais, set off crisis by suspending payments on $13.5 billion of debt to federal government for 90 days; Gov Olivo Dutra of Rio Grande do Sul is paying his state's debt into escrow account; two staet governments claim they inherited deficit-ridden administrations after elections last October (M)

headline: Foie Gras and Chips, Anyone?; Internet Shopping Is (Sort of) Catching On in Europe
abstract: Europeans, who have age-old shopping habits, are just now warming to shopping on World Wide Web; on-line shopping accounted for just $1.2 billion of Europe's $1.9 trillion in retail sales last year, compared with $8 billion in on-line sales and $2.6 trillion in total sales in US; European on-line entrepreneurs have reasons to be optimistic; Internet use is rising in Europe as its cost falls, thanks in large part to deregulation of telecommunications; governments, troubled by Europe's lag behind North America, are pushing for more Internet use, and as result, on-line stores are spreading; American companies like IBM are actively promoting electronic commerce among their European customers; graph; photo (M)

headline: Looking Past Hussein, U.S. Is Peering at a Pretender
abstract: US officials meet with Sharif Ali bin al-Hussein, 42-year-old heir to throne of short-lived modern Iraqi monarchy, which ended in 1958; he lives in London, commands only a small movement and believes that a constitutional monarchy still has resonance in Iraq; photo (M)

headline: CLEAR CHANNEL AND JACOR PLAN TO SELL SEVERAL STATIONS
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc. and the Jacor Communications Company announced plans yesterday to divest themselves of $340 million worth of radio properties in an effort clear the way for regulatory approval for their $4.4 billion merger. The companies said they would sell or swap properties in Louisville, Ky., Tampa and Jacksonville, Fla., and Cleveland and Dayton, Ohio, for other radio properties plus $285 million in cash. Cox Radio Inc. said it had agreed to swap five  stations in Syracuse for a number of Clear Channel and Jacor properties in Louisville and Tampa. Also, the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation said it would acquire two radio stations in Tampa and one in Cleveland from Clear Channel for $122.5 million in cash.

headline: Leucadia Sells Green Stamp Unit
abstract: Leucadia National Corp sells Sperry & Hutchinson Co, which sells S&H Green Stamps to retailers; Leucadia does not disclose terms of transaction or identity of buyer; Imperial Bancorp agrees to sell Leucadia a 24 percent stake in Imperial Credit Industries for about $82 million (S)

headline: Top French Officials Cleared Over Blood With AIDS Virus
abstract: Special jury of French legislators and judges clears former Prime Min Laurent Fabius and former Social Affairs Min Georgina Dufoix of criminal negligence and manslaughter in deaths of hundreds of people who contracted AIDS in mid-1980's from tainted blood transfusions; convicts Edmond Herve, Health Minister under Dufoix, of negligence in two cases; rules he should have ordered untreated blood supplies destroyed when he learned of risk in 1985, instead of letting them be used for several more months; Herve comments; AIDS advocacy groups and patients score verdicts (M)

headline: AMERICAN EXPRESS TRAVEL UNIT FOR SMALLER COMPANIES
abstract: American Express Co forms division, American Express One, to handle travel arrangements for small to midsize companies; unit combines two of company's customer service units with recently acquired Travel One travel agency (S)

headline: COCA-COLA AGREES TO BUY HALF OF INCA KOLA PERU
abstract: Coca-Cola Co to buy half of Inca Kola Peru SA, its leading rival in Peru, and intends to market Inca Kola internationally; transaction could cost Coke up to $200 million; Coke also buys 20 percent stake in Jose R Lindley e Hijos SA, the Inca Kola bottler (S)

headline: Japan Signaling Its Intention To Keep Nissan Motor Going
abstract: Japanese Government sends clearest signal to date that ti will not allow struggling Nissan Motor Co to collapse; International Trade and Industry Minister Kaoru Yosano says Government will provide adequate assistance to Nissan and that he has not heard that company is having rouble raising funds; Japan Development Bank extends $700 million loan to company (M)

headline: I.M.F. Approves $460 Million Loan Installment for Indonesia
abstract: International Monetary Fund approves $460 million loan installment for Indonesia and increases its credit line by $1 billion as recession there deepens and private creditors refuse to invest in country; IMF approval comes after Indonesian Government finally agrees, after two-week delay, to close and seize banks that do not come up with workable reorganization plans; extra IMF money is designed to help Indonesia meet shortfall in budget and prevent millions more people from falling below poverty line (M)

headline: Laura Ashley Gets a New Chief Again
abstract: Laura Ashley Holdings names Pat Robertson, the television evangelist, as nonexecutive director and names Kwan Cheong Ng as chief executive; Ng replaces Victoria Egan, who has been in the job for only five months (S)

headline: Telecom Holders Grumble Over Olivetti Bid
abstract: Olivetti SpA has yet to begin its formal $60 billion bid for Italy's largest phone company, Telecom Italia, but large British and American investment funds are complaining that as biggest shareholders in target company they may be getting bad deal (M)

headline: Zeneca-Astra Deal Is Cleared by F.T.C.
abstract: Zeneca Group of Britain says it received approval from United States Federal Trade Commission to buy Astra, Sweden's biggest pharmaceuticals maker, for $35 billion in stock; merger received approval from European competition authorities on Mar 1; Zeneca wins approval after agreeing to relinquish its rights to certain anesthetic (S)

headline: ANCHOR GAMING IN $220 MILLION DEAL FOR POWERHOUSE
abstract: Anchor Gaming to acquire Powerhouse Technologies Inc for $220 million in stock and assumed debt of $60 million (S)

headline: Leading Recording Companies To Test On-Line Digital Sales
abstract: Five major recording companies and IBM say they will, for first time, begin to test selling albums as digital information transmitted over Internet; new system is intended to sell authorized recordings in medium where most of music, legitimately copied and otherwise, is now available free (M)

headline: The Euro: For U.S., Gains and Losses
abstract: Clinton Administration's public support for euro, new European currency, masks complex and unresolved issues for US; success of currency could over long run pose threat to dominance of dollar, world's primary reserve currency by possibly increasing borrowing costs for US; failure could endanger success made by Europe in melding diverse economies into single market and subduing historical animosities with help of economic engineering; US officials say Europe should not allow real challenges of monetary union to turn its attention inward since much of world still struggles to recover from shocks of financial crisis that began in Asia in 1998; are prodding European officials to make sure focus on getting euro started does not diminish their resolve to deal with Western Europe's chronic economic problems (M)

headline: SBC to Acquire Stake in Unit Of Williams
abstract: SBC Communications, trying to become national communications provider, to buy up to 10 percent of Williams Companies Inc's communications unit, which is building coast-to-coast fiber optic network; deal could be worth as much as $500 million and would be first significant investment in long-distance carrier by one of Bell local phone companies; while none of Bells are allowed to sell long-distance service in their core markets, Telecommunications Act of 1996 allows them to own up to 10 percent of long-distance operator (M)

headline: Ralph Lauren Buying Casual Clothing Retailer
abstract: Polo Ralph Lauren Corp acquires Club Monaco Inc, Canadian-based specialty retailer that sells designer lookalike casual apparel, for $52.5 million in cash; Polo Ralph Lauren chairman Ralph Lauren comments (M)

headline: CONFLICT IN THE BALKANS: THE OVERVIEW -- NATO Planes Step Up Attacks on Serb Troops; Allies Shifting the Focus to Halting Atrocities Reported in Kosovo
abstract: NATO warplanes brave bad weather, stepping up attacks on Yugoslav troops while allied officials repeatedly accuse Serbian forces of large-scale atrocities in Kosovo against ethnic Albanians; US and Britain commit additional aircraft; NATO Sec Gen Javier Solana says mission is shifting from neutralizing air defenses to stopping 'humanitarian catastrophe' taking place on ground; Pres Clinton voices support for decision to hit broader range of targets, including forces in field; says continuing Serbian repression underscores need for NATO to persevere; NATO mounts fifth straight night of bombing, including cruise missile attacks by B-52 bombers; Yugoslav state television insists repeatedly that American F-117 stealth fighter was shot down; Pres Slobodan Milosevic defiantly praises people and armed forces for defense of Serbia; stages rock concert celebration in downtown Belgrade to show solidarity with armed forces and to mark 10th anniversary of 1989 move to strip Kosovo of broad autonomy; Clinton Administration and NATO officials insist they have no intention of committing ground troops, as questions arise over course of action if air power fails to halt violence against Kosovo's Albanians; map; photos (M)

headline: Network Solutions Planning Stock Split and an Offering
abstract: Network Solutions Inc, which has temporary monopoly on distribution of Internet addresses, announces plan for both stock split and secondary offering of 4.58 million shares; moves will reduce its parent company's holdings below 50 percent and give Network Solutions greater flexibility to make acquisitions; proposed secondary offering, to take effect at close of business on Feb 26, would reduce ownership of parent company, Science Applications International Corp, to 45 percent from 72 percent (M)

headline: CISCO TO ACQUIRE 400 ACRES FOR NEW SILICON VALLEY SITE
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc acquires more than 400 acres in North Coyote Valley in San Jose, Calif, for new site that may house up to 20,000 employees; new location will be Cisco's largest business site, with about seven million square feet of office space (S)

headline: Balkan Rarity: A Peaceful Mixture of Ethnic Groups, All Looking to the West
abstract: Macedonia is only former Yugoslav republic that has peacefully retained ethnically mixed society, but war being waged at its borders in Kosovo is testing country's ability to keep itself intact; working in its favor is ambition to move toward Western-style democracy and widely shared dread of ending up like neighbors; photo (M)

headline: Schwab Lands Feet First on Net; Broker Leap-Frogs Rivals to Front of On-Line Trading
abstract: There are many brand-name banks and brokerage houses battling on the front lines of American investing. Only one of them,  the Charles Schwab Corporation, has made peace with the Internet.    Schwab, the quarter-century-old discount broker that has long cast itself as a Wall Street outsider, has converted most of its brokerage business to the Internet with an ease few analysts predicted. Moreover, it has quickly come to dominate the booming business of trading stocks on line. Its giant computing center in Phoenix handles almost a third of all Internet trading -- meaning that one in 20 stock trades in America passes through the Schwab system.

headline: Seeking That Fair Day's Pay
abstract: Experts offer advice to a reader who has taken on new titles and responsibilities at her job but is refused a raise because, she is told, the company would then have to give one to all her co-workers (M)

headline: Envoys Flock to Milosevic To Tackle Crisis He Created
abstract: Western diplomats flock to Serbia in effort to convince Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, to defuse Kosovo crisis by making relatively easy concessions that will let them avoid using force, which he doubts they are willing to do; say he has left himself room to maneuver and back down; cites his delay in expelling Amb William Walker, head of Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe monitoring mission (M)

headline: Yeltsin Is Back in Hospital, This Time With a Bleeding Ulcer
abstract: Russia's Pres Boris N Yeltsin is hospitalized with acute bleeding stomach ulcer, barely three weeks after doctors declared him fully recovered from pneumonia and exhaustion; ulcer is his third serious illness in three months; follows year in which health problems forced him into hospital twice and kept him away from Kremlin for months; photo (M)

headline: Research Efforts Win Recognition
abstract: Steel Alliance Washington trade organization that promotes the use of steel, takes top honors at the Advertising Research Foundation's fifth annual David Ogilvy Award ceremony for excellence in research; sharing the award for research that best supported successful campaign are GSD&M, part of Omnicom Group and Orem, Utah, office of Wirthlin Worldwide (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Repsol Denies Having Plans to Take Over YPF
abstract: Madrid-based Repsol SA denies report that it plans to take over the Argentine oil company YPF SA (S)

headline: Mexico's Drug Effort: Poor or Irrelevant?
abstract: As the Clinton Administration weighs its annual evaluation of Mexico's cooperation in fighting illegal drugs, officials say that to observe American law strictly in this matter would require risking the broader relationship with Mexico.  Article, page 6.

headline: PATRIOT AMERICAN SAID TO ACT TO FOIL HILTON BID
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc signs definitive agreement to accept $1 billion equity infusion from investor group led by Apollo Real Estate Advisors; pact is expected to foil counterproposal made by Hilton Hotels Corp (S)

headline: COLD PURSUIT: A special report; Mexican General Off-Limits To U.S. Agents in Drug Sting
abstract: Clinton Administration is criticized for ending US money-laundering investigation among drug traffickers in Mexico after it started to point at Defense Min Enrique Cervantes; William F Gately, former Customs agent who led undercover inquiry, questions decision to halt investigation; senior Administration officials deny that foreign policy influenced their decision; key targets of investigation and Customs and Administration officials involved in it noted; Gately photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: EX-PREMIER LOSES IMMUNITY -- Parliament voted to strip former Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko, left, of immunity from prosecution on corruption charges. Mr. Lazarenko, a member of Parliament, is accused of taking $2 million while a regional governor and as the top official in President Leonid Kuchma's administration. The Swiss have charged him with money laundering. In 1997, President Kuchma ousted Mr. Lazarenko, who denies any wrongdoing.   Michael Wines (NYT)    RUSSIA: EUROPEAN LEADERS IN MOSCOW -- European Commission President Jacques Santer and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany told President Boris N. Yeltsin that the European Union was ready to deepen ties if Russia opens its markets and continues to stabilize its economy.   (Reuters)

headline: Among Stock Funds, Small Is Beautiful
abstract: Study by Financial Research Corp finds that domestic stock funds with fewest total assets outperform average for their categories (S)

headline: Japanese Stocks Look Better From Afar
abstract: Stephanie Strom Portfolios, etc column on slow strengthening of Japan's Nikkei 225 stock index, which has risen almost 15.7 percent in 1999; graph (M)

headline: Brazil Pushes to Restore Financial Credibility
abstract: Brazilian Govt moves to restore financial credibility in wake of devaluation in which currency lost 40 percent of value (M)

headline: New Computer for Just $299? Well, Most of One, Anyway
abstract: Price of personal computers continues to fall; Microworkz Computer is offering computer for $299, but it is bare-bones machine missing monitor, floppy drive and CD-ROM drive (S)

headline: Big Board May Add Membership Seats
abstract: William R Johnson, president of New York Stock Exchange, says exchange may create memberships, as it prepares to open new floor for trading foreign shares and expand trading hours next year; exchange has had 1,366 seats since 1953; each seat gives holder right to trade stock and vote at stock exchange meetings; last sale of seat went for record $2.6 million on March 1 (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Discount Tire Co., Scottsdale, Ariz., to Cramer-Krasselt, Phoenix, as the first agency of record to handle its account. Billings have not been determined.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar futures jump 4 percent on big purchases by Iran and Tunisia that bolsters demand; in New York, sugar for March delivery rises 0.27 cent, to 6.92 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: An ARCO Push in Alaska
abstract: Atlantic Richfield Co will increase production in Alaska when its new Alpine field begins operating in mid-2000 (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:   Digital Lava Inc., Los Angeles, an initial offering of 1.2 million units, containing 2 shares of common stock and one warrant. Dirks & Co.

headline: LAUDA AIR PLANS TO BUY ABOUT 11 BOEING JETS
abstract: Austria's Lauda Air AG plans to add as many as 11 Boeing planes worth $519 million to its current fleet of 19, as it seeks to build up routes to Southeast Asia, where traffic is growing (S)

headline: ESSAY; Shakespeare Never Lost a Manuscript to a Computer Crash
abstract: Essay by Theodore Roszak says some of best literature was written with quill pen; says Bill Gates and others who seek to put computer in every classroom should realize that quality is in the mind, not the machine; says school administrators eager to wire every classroom, often at expense of hiring more teachers, should know that inforamtion is worthless if it is not informed by ideas, values and judgment; photo (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: MAN IN THE NEWS -- Paul Maritz; Microsoft's Star Antitrust Witness
abstract: Man in the News profile of Paul Maritz, who takes witness stand this week as highest-ranking Microsoft official scheduled to testify in company's antitrust trial: Maritz was executive who oversaw development of some of main Microsoft products at issue in trial; photo (M)

headline: P&G Consolidates All Clearasil Work
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co consolidates worldwide account for its Clearasil brand products at Grey Advertising; billings estimated at $40 million to $50 million (S)

headline: Crane Suit Against Coltec May Alter Merger Strategies
abstract: Fate of Crane Co's $1.7 billion unsolicited takeover bid for Coltec Industries rests largely in hands of courts; Crane sued Coltec in last-ditch effort to derail B F Goodrich's acquisition of company for $1.4 billion and assumption of debt; at issue is Coltec's 1995 promise to Crane to notify it of any potential suitors; Crane seeks stock-for-stock deal with Coltec in what is called pooling-of-interests transaction; such transactions are coming under increased scrutiny from regulators (M)

headline: BP Amoco Profit Off; Layoffs to Increase
abstract: BP Amoco PLC will accelerate its cost-cutting plan and dismiss 10,000 workers, up from 7,000 planned in August, after prolonged slump in oil prices causes 37 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit; profit falls to $875 million from $1.38 billion a year ago (S)

headline: Monitor Chief Calls Kosovo Close to Flare-Up
abstract: Senior general in charge of international monitors in Kosovo, Maj Gen John Drewienkiewicz, warns that province is perilously close to major conflagration, as two incidents nearly flare into violence; says unarmed monitors were barely able to separate would-be combatants, and he does not think they can continue with mission indefintely because place is hugely volatile; says scattered camps of Serbian forces and ethnic Albanian guerrillas are on alert; says only international military force can do job now (M)

headline: Lottery May Decide Competition in Internet Name System
abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, nonprofit board charged with opening the Internet's domain-name registration business to competition, is leaning toward an international lottery to pick the five companies that will get the first shot at ending the Government-sanctioned monopoly held by Network Solutions Inc; scores of companies around the world will eventually enter the domain-registration business, but board must decide a number of key issues before full-scale competition begins, among them how to structure three supporting organizations, including the crucial central group that will make recommendations on domain name and registration policies (M)

headline: February Pace of Home Resales Remained Near January Record
abstract: Home resales hover close to record level in February, topping annual rate of five million sales for third consecutive month as affordable mortgages and plentiful jobs stoke demand; resales fall four-tenths of percent, to annual rate of 5.02 million houses; home resales are closely watched gauge of economic growth because previously owned houses account for 85 percent of all homes on market (S)

headline: Newspaper Ads Up 6.3% for the Year
abstract: Newspaper Association of America says spending on newspaper advertising in 1998 rose 6.3 percent from 1997, to $43.9 billion, in line with expectations; national advertising grew 7.7 percent, to $5.7 billion; retail advertising gained 5.7 percent, to $20.3 billion; classified advertising climbed 6.6 percent, to $17.9 billion (S)

headline: Pentagon Sees Risk in Going Into Kosovo
abstract: Senior Pentagon officials express concerns about sending American troops to Kosovo, Serbia, interviews; are worried about casualties, lack of strategy for quickly removing peacekeepers and about whether United States can spare troops; concerns are echoed at House hearing, after Clinton Administration describes plan to send up to 4,000 American ground troops; Pres Clinton, apparently heeding military warnings, has not committed troops, even as United States diplomats at Rambouillet, France, peace talks push for US role (M)

headline: Secret Tape of Plotter's Confession Deepens the Mystery of a Political Murder in Mexico
abstract: Compelling new piece of evidence implicates Raul Salinas, brother of former Mexican Pres Carlos Salinas de Gortari, in 1994 assassination of Jose Francisco Ruiz Massieu, ruling party's No 2 official; sensational trial of Raul Salinas has taken so many bizarre turns that it has done little to dispel notion that Mexico's high and mighty enjoy impunity; new evidence is tape recording of very first interrogation of Jorge Rodriguez Gonzalez, who organized killing and is serving 37-year jail sentence as accomplice to murder; Rodriguez Gonzalez affirms repeatedly that it was Raul Salinas who gave orders to 'eliminate' Ruiz Massieu, fast-rising politician; he also says that Raul Salinas Lozano, father of Raul and Carlos, also approved killing of Ruiz Massieu, who was his former son-in-law; chart showing principals in case; photos (L)

headline: Saab Posts Profit For Second Half
abstract: Saab Automobile AB reports net income was 391 million kronor ($49.6 million) in second half, compared with loss of 1.272 billion kronor in same period year earlier (S)

headline: 17 Syllables to Share, And a Captive Audience
abstract: Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson begins session of Microsoft Corp antitrust trial by reading haiku alternatives to Microsoft's error message; they are part of fictitious article circulating on Internet that purports to announce that Sony has come up with new operating system (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.36   5.51        3-month T-bills   4.24   4.19   5.02        6-month T-bills   4.27   4.26   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.78   3.80   3.67        10-yr. T-note   4.61   4.68   5.68        30-yr. T-bond   5.07   5.13   5.96        Telephone bd.   6.78   6.78   7.27        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.16   5.23          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Trimark in Accord With Broadcast.com
abstract: Trimark Holdings Inc agrees to license its movies to Broadcast.com and to swap $$3.2 million in stock; Trimark produces and distributes movies; Broadcast.com broadcasts programming over Internet (S)

headline: King Hussein Back Home; Despite Joy, Jordan Frets
abstract: King Hussein returns to tumultous welcome in Jordan after six months of cancer treatment in United States; weighs naming one of his sons to replace his brother, Crown Prince Hassan, as his designated successor; photo (M)

headline: Legislators In Brazil Are Leaving Ruling Party
abstract: Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil may face more fractious second term as raft of newly elected members of Congress switch parties just before taking office; some deputies leave ruling party to join smaller party in which they could hold more sway; they promise more critical stance twward Cardoso's proposals; several legislators have left Cardoso's party for party of Itamar Franco, Governor of their state, who is in middle of battle of nerves with Cardoso regarding his state's debt to Federal Government (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Computer Shares Decline, Sending Nasdaq Plunging  Shares of computer-related companies fell sharply, sending the Nasdaq composite index down 3.34 percent, its biggest loss in morethan five months. Shares of on-line brokerage firms also plunged after temporary shutdowns for the second consecutive day in the processing system at E*Trade and after the Attorney General of New York said he was investigating the ability of on-line brokers to process large numbers of trades. The Nasdaq lost 83.34 points, its third-biggest point drop ever, closing at 2,410.07.

headline: Ford Buys Volvo Car Unit in Bid To Lift Profile of Luxury Models
abstract: Ford Motor Co agrees to buy car operations of Volvo AB of Sweden for $6.45 billion, taking its biggest step toward becoming large-scale seller of high-profit luxury cars and more humble vehicles; sales of luxury cars are rising in United States and Europe; profits on less expensive cars have evaporated as manufacturers in South Korea and elsewhere flood markets in US with ever-cheaper cars; Ford's chief executive, Jacques A Nasser, says Ford's goal is to sell million luxury cars annually within several years, up from 200,000 luxury cars it now sells; Nasser and William C Ford Jr, Ford's chairman, say they are not planning any immediate changes to Volvo's current lineup of cars; Ford has increasingly emphasized same issues as Volvo in recent months--safety and environmental issues; photos; charts (M)

headline: Microsoft's Profit Up 75% In Quarter
abstract: Microsoft Corp reports 75 percent gain in earnings in second fiscal 1999 quarter ended Dec 31, far exceeding most optimistic projections of Wall Street analysts; reports earnings of $1.98 billion, up from $1.13 billion in year-earlier period; says revenue rose nearly 38 percent, to $4.94 billion, over $3.585 billion reported in second quarter of fiscal year 1998; Microsoft officials remain cautious in their outlook; chart (M)

headline: Consumer Digital Camera Breaks the Pixel Barrier
abstract: Fuji Photo Film USA introduces the first pocket-size digital camera that captures more than two million picture elements, or two megapixels, per image; model, Fuji MX-2700, will cost 'well under $1,000' when it becomes available in April or May; camera photo (S)

headline: U.S. Offers Saudi Arabia New Weapons
abstract: United States Defense Sec William S Cohen, touring region to solidify anti-Iraqi sentiment among friendly Arab government, offers to sell Saudi Arabia sophisticated air-to-air missiles to help shore up its defenses against Iraq, meeting with Prince Sultan bin Abd al-Aziz; Iraq charges US pressures and blackmails Arabs (M)

headline: Gauges Return to Plus Column on Strong Earnings Reports
abstract: Stocks close higher, lifting major averages back into plus territory for year, after some strong quarterly earnings reports are issued; Dow Jones industrial average rises 82.65 points, or nine-tenths of percent, to close at 9,203.32; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index increases 8.79 points, to 1,233.98; graphs (M)

headline: Asian Stocks Take a Rest From a Dizzying Rally
abstract: Asian stock markets register mixture of modest gains and losses, after a week of powerful gains; analysts seem relieved, since many were alarmed by growing disparity between rising markets and Asia's still-sinking economies; US dollar settles at 110.93 yen, down from 111.04; it is up slightly against euro, which fell to 1.15540 from $1.16700; graph (M)

headline: H & R BLOCK DROPS CREDIT CARD OPERATION
abstract: H & R Block Inc says it will sell its credit card unit to Providian Financial Corp and leave credit card business; Providian will buy $181 million portfolio of Webcard Visa cards (S)

headline: Most Pilots at American Are Now Back In the Cockpit
abstract: Overwhelming majority of American Airlines pilots, pressured by Federal judge's contempt citation, return to work, alleviating delays for passengers and allowing airline to make major strides toward returning to normal; American says it expects to fly nearly all of its 2,250 scheduled flights; airline officials say that beginning next month it will reduce number of scheduled flights by few dozen each day because of concerns that many pilots will not agree to work overtime (M)

headline: NBC and 24/7 In Marketing Deal
abstract: NBC and 24/7 Media Inc, New York, Web advertising company, sign three-year agreement to collaborate on television and Internet marketing plans for local advertisers (Advertising column) (S)

headline: Quarterback Club Honors Visa Spot
abstract: NFL Quarterback Club names humorous commercial featuring Jerry Rice and Steve Young of San Francisco 49ers as best football-themed commercial of 1998; spot was created for Visa USA by BBDO New York (S)

headline: Canary Wharf Offering Raises $:551 Million
abstract: Canary Wharf Group PLC raises 551 million pounds ($904 million) in its initial share sale (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HEIDELBERGER DRUCKMASCHINEN A.G.,  Heidelberg, Germany, a maker of printing machinery, confirmed that it was in talks to buy Eastman Kodak Co.'s copier business, valued at about $200 million.    VAIL RESORTS INC.,  Avon, Colo., a mountain ski resort operator, agreed to acquire the Grand Teton Lodge Co., which operates lodges in Wyoming's Grand Teton National Park, from CSX Corp., Richmond, for about $50 million.    LUCENT TECHNOLOGIES CO.,  Murray Hill, N.J., the phone-equipment maker, acquired closely held Sybarus Technologies, Ottawa, a semiconductor designer, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Big Technology Issues Bolster Advance of S.& P. 500
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 13.13 points, to 9,291.11; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 4.37 points, to 1,243.77; Nasdaq composite index rises 31.30, to 2,404.92; graph; chart (M)

headline: U.S. HOPE IS SLIM AS TALKS RESTART ON KOSOVO CRISIS
abstract: Clinton Administration has only slim hope of success in second round of Kosovo peace talks in Paris; mood has shifted in Washington because of Albanians' refusal to sign accord so far, Serbia's refusal to countenance foreign troops in Kosovo and increasing violence there; Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright, who invested substantial personal capital in failed first round of negotiations, will not attend y latest round; talks are resuming as violence continues and even intensifies in Kosovo; it is unclear what Administration's strategy is to resolve conflict if, as many expect, talks end after several days (M)

headline: Albanian 'Nay' Puts Milosevic in Role of Yea-Sayer
abstract: Serbian officials and analysts say ethnic Albanians at Kosovo peace talks have taken pressure off Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia by failing to agree proposed settlement, allowing him to create at least temporary divisions within West; say Milosevic remains prepared to make deal, but will want in return an easing of country's economic and diplomatic isolation; say Serbian delegation's willingness to accept political arrangements for Kosovo, while objecting to presence of NATO troops to carry out deal, will enable Italians and Russians to argue that Serbs are moving toward deal and cannot now be punished; map; photo (M))

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Smoke-Free Snacks; RJR Nabisco's Spinoff Plan Takes a 180-Degree Turn
abstract: Market Place column on RJR Nabisco Holdings decision to split its food and tobacco businesses and sell its foreign tobacco company to Japan Tobacco; says investors are not impressed by decision, with RJR Nabisco shares finishing day up only 12.5 cents, at $28.75; holds investors essentially deemed per-share value created by separation of two businesses not worth much; says tepid reaction also reflects uncertainty around deal whose details will not be announced until sale of foreign tobacco operations is completed, probably not until next month at earliest; graphs; drawing (M)

headline: Business Travel; Some hotels offer to rent their entire operations to corporate partygoers to welcome the millennium.
abstract: Nation's hotels will not be filled exclusively with corporate partygoers to welcome in year 2000, but many hotel owners hope that will be the case; some hotels are offering to rent their entire operations; Starwood Hotels and Resorts plans to announce Web site designed by IBM that not only allows frequent guests to make reservations on line but also to customize the Web page; Peabody Hotel in Orlando, Fla, is offering guests reduced-rate physical checkups through arrangement with Institute for Corporate Wellness; Continental Airlines will begin daily nonstop service between Newark and Amsterdam beginning July 15; Continental and Chase Manhattan Bank will offer first co-branded debit card; users of card will earn frequent-flier miles on Continental (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Fall on China Debt Fears
abstract: Fears of debt crisis in China sweep through Hong Kong, punishing stock market and stirring fresh anxiety in city that seems to be recovering from Asia's economic distress; Hong Kong's benchmark Hang Seng index falls 437.79 points, or more than 4 percent, to 10,273.77; Hong Kong markets are worried that some China-linked companies might be burdened by huge, hidden debts; photo (M)

headline: Swiss Life Considers Deal
abstract: Swiss Life is in talks to buy Lloyd Continental (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: New Portal To 'Rich Media' To Make Debut
abstract: Snap LLC, Internet company partly owned by NBC, to offer portal for users with high-speed Internet links; Snap will be free guide and showcase for bandwith-intensive applications, like video clips and audio files, making them easier for users to find; will announce 20 alliances with content providers, distributors and advertisers (M)

headline: Savoring The Spice Of Urban Life
abstract: THIRTY years ago, Erba Food Products was struggling to get by, making kosher specialties in a tiny 2,000-square-foot factory within earshot of Yankee Stadium, and its prospects looked as limited as its market, New York's dwindling population of observant German Jews.    Today, Erba is booming. In its 75,000-square-foot plant in the Canarsie district of Brooklyn, the company's 100-odd employees pack kosher products from wines to soups to  salsas and barbecue sauces, half for the New York area and half for beyond.

headline: INTEL AND PICTURETEL IN PRODUCT-DEVELOPMENT PACT
abstract: Intel Corp to invest more than $30 million in Picturetel Corp as part of distribution and product-development deal; Intel will grant Picturetel, a maker of video-conference equipment, rights to sell its Proshare and Team Station video-conferencing phones (S)

headline: As Angola Erupts, Youths Fear Being Forced to Fight
abstract: Angolan youths are being required to register for draft as civil war heats up; fear possible resumption of use of press gangs to round up recruits; photo (M)

headline: American Topics : Calvin Klein Billboard Ignites New Foray in the Culture Wars
abstract: Anyone who believes that the end of President Bill Clinton's impeachment trial also marked the end of America's "culture wars" should think again.

headline: On the Lost Stealth Jet's Own Ground, Fighting Words and Empathy
abstract: Brig Gen William J Lake, commander at Holloman Air Force Base, home base of F-117 stealth bomber that crashed in Yugoslavia, defends plane as premier weapon system, but says it is neither invulnerable nor invisible; vows to send dozens more if asked (M)

headline: Buffett of Arabia? Well, Maybe
abstract: Article on Saudi Arabian Prince Walid bin Talal, who reportedly has amassed $14.2 billion business and investment empire; Prince Walid acknowledges that sources of early investments were commissions paid by other businesses; photo (M)

headline: Growing From a Tiny Wheelbase
abstract: THIS is a story about two bankrupt entrepreneurs and the tiny car that brought them back from the edge of ruin after they rescued it from obscurity. A hocked gold Rolex watch, an angel, a garage full of mothballed machinery and a Czech arms factory also play important roles.    From these, Steven J. Singer and Justus Bauschinger fashioned the Lilliput Motor Company in 1990. Lilliput, a small catalogue business specializing in nostalgic metal toys, grew steadily until it made $1 million in sales in 1996. Then the partners sold it to Genesis Direct, a New Jersey catalogue consolidator.

headline: T. C. Mann, 87, a Maker of U.S. Latin Policy
abstract: Thomas C Mann, US diplomat who was influential in Latin America policies, dies at age 87; photo (S)

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments in advertising industry (S)

headline: In Courtship of Airtouch, Heavy Dates and Hefty Stakes
abstract: Vodafone Group PLC's successful effort to woo Airtouch Communications Inc away from merging with Bell Atlantic has resulted in $60 billion Vodafone-Airtouch pact that would create world's largest wireless communications company; new powerhouse could become serious rival to telecommunications titans like AT&T and British Telecommunications; description of tense two-week period proceeding announcement, when sleep-deprived executives in four time zones communicated during all-night strategy sessions and telephone calls; photos; chart (M)

headline: Indonesia to Reduce Oil Production 4%
abstract: Government official says Indonesia, only Asian member of OPEC, is ready to cut crude oil production by 4 percent, or 34,000 barrels a day, in line with an agreement among OPEC members; Indonesia produces about 1.3 million barrels a day under the quota system; new production quota will be 1.246 million barrels a day (S)

headline: Review; The Lower End of 'High Definition'
abstract: Joel Brinkley describes Sony's new 34-inch high-definition television, which has traditional picture tube and sells for $9,000; says its life span is likely to be short, because several manufacturers have announced plans to begin selling similar models at half that price or less; photo (M)

headline: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION TO CUT 7% OF WORK FORCE
abstract: Mercantile Bancorporation plans to cut 7 percent of its work force, or 770 jobs, in 1999 as part of a revamping to improve profits (S)

headline: Russian Anger at U.S. Tempered by Need for Cash
abstract: Russia, stung by NATO's decision to carry out air strikes against Yugoslavia, suspends cooperation with Western alliance and denounces attack as an act of brazen aggression; Pres Boris N Yeltsin urges Pres Clinton not to go through with air strikes and makes impassioned television address carrying same message; Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov urges Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to reach accommodation on Kosovo issue; Russia announces that International Monetary Fund managing dir Michel Camdessus will arrive in Moscow for more talks (M)

headline: Frierson Mee Gets Coty Account
abstract: Coty Inc expands its agency roster by awarding Frierson Mee & Kraft the account for number of undisclosed new fragrance brands; billings estimated at $25 million (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SAFEWAY INC., Pleasanton, Calif., the food and drug retailer, filed a registration statement with the S.E.C. for the sale of 19.75 million shares of common stock held by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company.    CONCENTRIC NETWORK CORP., San Jose, Calif., a network services provider, filed with the S.E.C. to sell 2.5 million common shares, which would increase the number of outstanding shares by 16.5 percent, to 17.64 million.    PEPSICO INC., Purchase, N.Y., bought a Russian bottling plant from the Whitman Corporation, Rolling Meadows, Ill., which produces and distributes Pepsi-Cola, in a deal it valued at $25 million.

headline: IMC GLOBAL TO SELL DISTRIBUTION UNIT
abstract: IMC Global Inc to sell its IMC Agribusiness retail and wholesale distribution unit to Royster-Clark for $300 million; signs pact to supply phosphate and potash to Royster-Clark (S)

headline: Prospectus; Can a computer program figure out the market? A former analyst and a mathematician are betting that theirs can.
abstract: Intelligenesis Corp, founded by Ben Goertzel and Lisa S Pazer, has software program that combines elements of Internet with artificial intelligence technology to help figure out world financial markets; company hopes to supply its site to financial news services or other on-line information providers, in revenue-sharing arrangement; drawing (M)

headline: THE NEW EUROPE: United and Divided; Shiny, Prosperous 'Euroland' Has Some Cracks in Facade
abstract: Europe has two faces, light and dark, and they are evident on Germany's western and eastern borders as the continent crowns four decades of integration with the adoption of a single currency, the euro.    Here in Aachen, which lay in ruins in 1945, borders have ceased to exist. It has become usual for people who work in this western German city to live in Belgium and play a weekly tennis match in the Netherlands. The sweet whiff of prosperity seeps from Italian shoe stores, Spanish tapas bars, French croissanteries and English pottery shops that line the pedestrian shopping areas on all sides of the borders.

headline: Mexico's Central Bank Is Optimistic on Economy
abstract: Banco de Mexico officials say Mexico has already weathered worst blows of global economic crisis and is not likely to suffer severely from instability in Brazil; say economy grew by about 4.8 percent in 1998; will seek to bring inflation, which ended year at 18.6 percent, down to 13 percent in 1999 (M)

headline: S.& P. Downgrades 5 Large Chinese Banks
abstract: China International Trust and Investment Corp, China's biggest investment company, and Bank of Communications have their credit ratings cut to junk-bond rating by Standard & Poor's Corp as concern rises over quality of loans; Bank of China, China Construction Bank and Industrial and Commercial Bank of China are lowered even further, to lowest investment grade (S)

headline: NEC Plans to Eliminate 11,600 Jobs
abstract: NEC Corp sets broad restructuring that will cause elimination of 11,600 jobs, including 9,000 in Japan, most sweeping cuts ever by major Japanese company; plan could lead to sharp changes in NEC's strategic direction; NEC forecasts net loss of 150 billion yen ($1.3 billion) for fiscal year ending Mar 31, up from previous loss forecast of 35 billion yen; job cuts will come through attrition and early retirement over three years; NEC will write off about $1.6 billion of its $1.8 billion investment in Packard Bell NEC; will pay $450 million to buy 80 percent of Packard Bell's European operations, in yet another cash infusion for troubled unit; Bull SA, NEC's partner in Packard Bell, will take 20 percent stake in European business; NEC names Hajime Sasaki chairman; names Kouji Nishigaki president, replacing Hisashi Kaneko (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.00   4.80   5.84        3-month T-bills   4.45   4.42   5.19        6-month T-bills   4.53   4.42   5.20        10-yr. T-infl.   3.88   3.85   3.70        10-yr. T-note   4.65   4.64   5.74        30-yr. T-bond   5.09   5.08   5.92        Telephone bd.   6.75   6.75   7.15        Municipal bds.   5.16   5.16   5.25          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: I.M.F. Expected to Offer More Aid to Indonesia
abstract: International Monetary Fund official Hubert Neiss says he expects fund to approve more financial aid to Indonesia; notes nation needs more aid because it is not yet attracting private capital; lauds Indonesia's efforts to clean up ruined banking system (M)

headline: Debt of Consumers Climbed in January
abstract: Federal Reserve figures show that borrowing by United States consumers increased at faster pace in January as all categories of debt increased; borrowing rose by $14.7 billion, to $1.316 trillion, in January, after a revised increase of $3.1 billion in December; chart (S).

headline: British American Tobacco Will Buy Rothmans
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC plans to acquire Rothmans International for about $7.5 billion; deal would unite second- and fourth-largest tobacco companies in world and put British American within striking distance of Philip Morris Companies (M)

headline: South African Bank Buying Rest of Insurer
abstract: The Standard Bank Investment Corporation of South Africa said yesterday that it would pay 5.595 billion rand ($917 million) for control of the Liberty Life Group, creating one of the country's largest financial services companies.

headline: THE COMPLETE INTERACTIVE COOKBOOK
abstract: Eric Asimov reviews The Complete Interactive Cookbook; photo (M)

headline: U.S. JUDGE ORDERS PILOTS IN SICKOUT TO RETURN TO JOB
abstract: Federal Judge Joe Kendall orders American Airlines pilots to end disruptions that have grounded over 2,500 flights; pilots have been calling in sick in dispute over American's purchase of Reno Air; American expects most of its pilots to return to work, but will still have to cancel several hundred more flights; expects service to be back to normal by weekend; says affected passengers can reschedule flights without penalty or get refunds; Kendall chides both company, which sought court order, and Allied Pilots Association for not settling dispute on own; photo (M)

headline: Fleet Financial to Buy BankBoston in $16 Billion Stock Deal
abstract: Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire BankBoston Corp for $16 billion in a deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in country and the pre-eminent bank in New England; bank will be called Fleet Boston; Federal antitrust laws are expected to require large sales of bank branches in New England; acquisition will mostly likely involve a significant number of job cuts and layoffs through New England (M)

headline: Surfing in Circles And Loving It
abstract: Internet surfing using Web ring makes it easier for people with similar interests or hobbies to communicate with each other; Web rings are circles of Internet pages on various topics that are linked democratically, by their creators, as opposed to wider Web's more official and commercial tone; rings provide homespun displays of hobbies, obscure and common expertise and general camaraderie; more than 60,000 Web rings, including more than one million member sites, can be searched via Web Ring, which was purchased last month by Geocities, free home-page service; photos (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week consists of today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and an auction of two-year notes on Wednesday.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.43 percent and the rate on the six-month issue, 4.46 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 4.93 percent.

headline: Cambodia Town's 'Luck' Leaves Illness in Its Wake
abstract: 3,000 tons of industrial waste from Taiwan, dumped in field near Sihanoukville, Cambodia, has caused illness among poor villagers who regarded it as 'windfall' and used it to build tents, canopies and bedding and to store food; tests have determined that waste was contaminated with high levels of mercury and possibly hazardous mixture of other metals; Formosa Plastics Corp says it was unable to dump waste in Taiwan because of fear of public protests; photos (M)

headline: U.S.I.A. Says Hacker Killed Web Site and Damaged Computer
abstract: United States Information Agency says an outsider breached its Internet security, knocking out its Web site and forcing it to re-evaluate its computer protection; sabotage is second such incident in six months (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Brazil's currency continues to slide; graphs; table (S)

headline: If Microsoft Loses Suit, 19 States Plan to Seek a Radical Overhaul
abstract: If Microsoft Corp loses antitrust suit against it, 19 states that have joined Federal Government in landmark case will demand that company be revamped; states, as equal partners in suit, hold veto-like power over kinds of remedies Federal Government can recommend; option receiving most favor would force Microsoft to license source code for Windows operating system to several other companies, instantly creating competition in operating system business; many of states are eager to use provisions in their laws that would allow them to fine Microsoft for every antitrust violation 'incident,' although there is little if any case law to suggest how incident is defined in this context; in the end, remedy Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson imposes might or might not be based on recommendations of plaintiffs; state attorneys general, as elected officials, have motives not alwways same as those of Justice Department (M)

headline: A voice long familiar to football fans has made itself heard promoting a range of products lately.
abstract: Voice of John Facenda, late narrator for NFL Films, and voices that mimic his are heard in National Football League spots run during television broadcasts of playoff games and in commercials for AT&T, Tostitos tortilla chips and Sunny Delight juice drink and promotions for The Late Show With David Letterman; not everyone appreciates such exploitation of the dead (M)

headline: Chinese Company Delays Offering's Pricing
abstract: Shandong International Power Development Ltd, Chinese state-run power generator, delays pricing of its initial public offering by one business day; analysts have said that Goldman, Sachs & Co may be forced to lower Shandong's initial stock price, or shelve offering entirely, because investors are growing reluctant to put money in China; Southern Co has agreed to buy about 40 percent of Shandong's offering (S)

headline: California Utility Buying 16 Illinois Plants
abstract: Edison International to buy 16 Illinois power plants from Unicom Corp for $4.8 billion in cash (M)
