headline: Citigroup's 4th-Quarter Operating Earnings Plunged 27%
abstract: Citigroup says its fourth-quarter operating earnings plunged 27 percent, to $1.4 billion, from quarter a year earlier; for the year, Citigroup reports operating earnings of $6.3 billion on revenue of $49.8 billion; results for all of 1998 include many charges, including $703 million of previously announced $900 million charge related to eliminating 10,400 jobs; undisclosed but substantial number of job cuts will involve layoffs (M)

headline: For Many on West Bank, Resentments Linger
abstract: Many Palestinians on West Bank express mixed feelings over death of Jordan's King Hussein; some express sympathy while others voice anger at monarch who had checkered relationship with Palestinian national movement (S)

headline: Cardiff Journal; Mr., Make No Mistake, This Mrs. Is Decidedly Ms.
abstract: Liz Shankland, 35-year-old public relations executive in Cardiff, Wales, who married longtime love, Gerald Toms, causes controversy after taking out advertisement in local newspaper explaining reasons why she prefers to be called by maiden name; her situation underscores larger situation in Britain, where title 'Ms' has been resisted; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Trading Begins Smoothly As Euro Enters Markets  The euro had a nearly flawless debut in world markets as European financial institutions opened for business without a hitch and Europe's new single currency climbed in value against other major currencies.    In its first full day of trading, the euro opened at $1.17 and climbed to nearly $1.186 before falling back to about $1.18. Far from being unsettled by the uncertainty or technical glitches, the stock markets in Frankfurt, Paris, Milan and Madrid all jumped by 5 percent or more. But the reaction was much more subdued in the consumer marketplace, where there was little evidence of change. [Page A1.]

headline: Sapporo Journal; In a Winter Wonderland, a Big Bunny With Bugs
abstract: Japan's military annually transforms Sapporo's streets into museums of huge snow and ice sculptures for week-long snow festival; trucks in thousands of tons of snow from mountains for military and civilian artists; map; photo (M)

headline: As Arab League Urges Iraqis to Obey the U.N., They Walk Out of the Meeting
abstract: Iraqi delegation led by Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf walks out of Arab League meeting, Cairo, as Arab foreign ministers demand Iraq renounce 'provocations' against neighbors and comply with United Nations resolutions before economic sanctions are lifted; al-Sahaf blames Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Syria for anti-Iraq tone of statement, news conference; warns United States tries to use Arab stand as pretext for new attacks; photo (M)

headline: 2 Coke Bottlers In Japan Link
abstract: Coca-Cola Co has taken another step in its push to consolidate bottling operations in its second-most-profitable market, with Japanese bottlers Kinki Coca-Cola Bottling Co of Osaka and Chukyo Coca-Cola Bottling Co of Nagoya saying they will cooperate on production as Coca-Cola moves to cut costs (S)

headline: Greek Pride Is Stung By Capture Of Kurd
abstract: Greece has been nurturing deep identity crisis since Turkish security forces seized Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan in Nairobi, Kenya, where he had been hiding in Greek Embassy; Ocalan will be tried in Turkey on terrorism charges; Ocalan affair has provoked national conversation on shame, pride and Greek identity; photo (M)

headline: AMR Profit Drop Deepens Over Pilot Sickout
abstract: AMR Corp, parent of American Airlines, says financial problems resulting from 10-day sickout by pilots of American Airlines last month was worse than expected and that its first-quarter profit will be about half of Wall Street's expectations; says sickout will reduce its first-quarter sales by about $200 million to $225 million; Gerard J Arpey, AMR's chief financial officer, says sickout caused American to lose greater number of high-paying business travelers than airline had thought; also says action encouraged greater number of potential passengers to book their future travel on other airlines; photo (M)

headline: In Hong Kong, a Growing Sense That Tycoons Skew Competition
abstract: HONG KONGâ€”  On any morning, a typical resident here may wake up in an apartment developed by one of a handful of billionaire Hong Kong property owners, take a bus to work owned by one of the same tycoons, and make a mobile phone call along the way over a tycoon-owned network.

headline: Some Head South, And Some Head Back
abstract: Tens of thousands of retirees move to Florida, but for some of them the dream of Sunshine State turns out to be illusion that is costly financially and emotionally; decision to retire and move far from family, friends and other social support systems is often made without due consideration beforehand; sense of dislocation can be exacerbated by onset of old-age afflictions; growing number of retirees are returning home from Florida or relocating elsewhere; photos (M)

headline: Tel Aviv Journal; Battling Israel's Great Divide: A Schoolgirl Is Star
abstract: Tel Aviv Journal on film by Senyora Bar-David underscoring rift in Israel between Ashkenazi Jews of Central and Eastern European descent and Sephardic Jewish immigrants from North Africa and Arab countries, who suffer discrimination; subject of film is 17-year-old Elinor Nagar, Sephardic Jew who is enrolled in 25-year-old integration program aimed at giving such teen-agers shot at social mobility through education in quality high schools; Bar-David is graduate of program; photo (M)

headline: Manager Given Fine In Stock Fraud Case
abstract: Henry J Auwinger, branch manager for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co, to pay $10,000 to settle Securities and Exchange Commission's accusation that he failed to supervise broker Michael Oberholzer who defrauded four elderly customers of more than $300,000; in August, SEC accused Dean Witter Reynolds Inc--now unit of Morgan Stanley--and two Dean Witter branch managers of failing to look closely enough into California broker's activities (S)

headline: PARKER DRILLING AND SUPERIOR ENERGY CALL OFF MERGER
abstract: Parker Drilling Co and Superior Energy Services Inc agree to end merger agreement under which Parker was to acquire Superior (S)

headline: From a Coffin Maker, the Final Accessory
abstract: Article on White Light of Dallas, owned by Patrick J Fant, which sells personalized coffins; photo (M)

headline: A Winner And New Era Are Declared In Nigeria
abstract: Gen Olusegun Obasanjo is officially declared Nigeria's next President; pledges to foster democracy in country where years of corrupt military misrule have squandered vast oil wealth and restricted freedom of one in six Africans; won decisive victory with 63 percent of popular vote; rival Olu Falae seizes on reports of fraud and irregularities to dispute results (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.63   4.85   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.39   4.42   5.06        6-month T-bills   4.40   4.42   5.02        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.79   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.87   4.92   5.62        30-yr. T-bond   5.30   5.34   5.92        Telephone bd.   6.98   7.00   7.17        Municipal bds.   5.12   5.14   5.21          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Private E-Mail Greetings Are Made Public by Mistake
abstract: Hallmark Web site, which permits well-wishers to send private E-mail greetings to one another, had problem; company says it left file containing some private messages attached to site's publicly accessible search engine for period of eight weeks until it corrected problem earlier this month (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.88   4.74   5.52        3-month T-bills   4.48   4.46   4.94        6-month T-bills   4.49   4.48   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.91   3.89   3.68        10-yr. T-note   5.18   5.16   5.62        30-yr. T-bond   5.55   5.53   5.94        Telephone bd.   7.27   7.29   7.02        Municipal bds.   5.23   5.22   5.30          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Capturing That Screen
abstract: J D Biersdorfer replies to reader's question on how to use print screen option on personal computer to capture and modify screen image

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    SPAIN: 9 MORE BASQUES SEIZED -- The police arrested nine suspected activists of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. in nighttime raids, just hours after the rebels' military chief and his five top aides were captured in Paris. Spain said it still hoped that the rebels' unilateral cease-fire, which they have observed since September, would lead to a lasting peace.   Al Goodman (NYT)

headline: Mergers and acquisitions on Madison Avenue continue to be alive and well in the new year.
abstract: Mergers and acquisitions in advertising industry continue into new year; Integer Group acquires Stern Advertising; five top employees of Russek Advertising are joining Berenter Greenhouse & Webster; Russek closed on Dec 31; Ketchum in New York acquires Sheppard Associates; Foote, Cone & Belding acquires CM Partners; Draft Worldwide acquires three integrated-marketing shops in Belgium, Britain and Canada and data base management company in France; acquires Gingko Group Ltd in Toronto; Cordiant Communications Group PLC denies reports that it is being acquired by True North Communications (M)

headline: FOUNDING FAMILY OFFERS $520 MILLION FOR ST. JOHN KNITS
abstract: St John Knits Inc agrees to go private for $520 million under group led by company's founder; group including affiliate of Vestar Capital Partners, St John's chairman-chief executive Robert E Gray and his family will pay $30 a share for all shares Gray family does not already own, about 90 percent of the stock (S)

headline: Tough Controls Blamed for More Deaths on Border
abstract: American Civil Liberties Union and other American and Mexican human rights groups complain to Organization of American States that newly erected border fences and more vigorous enforcement by Border Patrol has spurred illegal immigrants to take dangerous routes to California through mountain passes and deserts, spurring surge in deaths; say Mexican diplomats have documented deaths of 360 immigrants along California border since 1994, when United States began crackdown (M)

headline: Surfing Their Way to the Holy Land
abstract: Virtual Jerusalem, expansive Internet site presenting Jewish news and culture, enables users to E-mail prayers to city's Western Wall; site creator Avi Moskowitz comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: New Protection Likely For Child Tax Credit
abstract: Pres Clinton and Repr Bill Archer, who heads House Ways and Means Committee, agree that a fix may be needed this year so that middle-class families seeking $500 tax credit for each child under 17 will not lose part of it by falling under alternative minimum tax (S)

headline: No Mixed Reviews Here
abstract: Susan French Ludwig letter on Jan 17 article on Kellogg Co's breakfast-in-a-box; recalls designing an imaginary ad campaign for such a product 30 years ago

headline: Russia Allows Trading In Bonds to Resume
abstract: Russia allows domestic bond trading to resume for first time since Government's August default, limiting annual yields to 120 percent to keep down future borrowing costs (S)

headline: CIENA IN TWO ACQUISITIONS FOR $980 MILLION
abstract: Ciena Corp, maker of equipment that increases capacity of phone networks, agrees to buy Lightera Networks Inc, maker of equipment that directs traffic on networks, and Omnia Communications Inc, whose products make it easier to carry both voice and data calls; Ciena will issue 20.6 million shares, valued at $552 million, for Lightera and 16 million shares, worth $429 million, for Omnia (S)

headline: TECHNOLOGY: Market Place; Dragon Systems, a Former Little Guy, Gets Ready for Market
abstract: Market Place column on speech-recognition software produced by Dragon Systems, company scheduled to sell shares to public in next few weeks; Dragon Naturally Speaking software converts words spoken conversationally into computer's microphone into words typed on computer's screen; Dragon Systems has balance-sheet strength and good products and young and extremely fluid market niche; potential problem is with large companies like IBM, Royal Philips Electronics and Microsoft, all of which are working on similar speech technology that they might try to bundle into their hardware; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Chancellor May Sell or Spin Off Some Units to Raise Share Value
abstract: Chancellor Media Corp, soon to be number 1 owner of radio stations in US, says it might sell or spin off all or part of its businesses to raise its share value to that of its biggest rivals; Chancellor has asked investment bank BT Alex Brown Inc to help it consider strategic options, including possible sale (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY; On-Line Smut Law Heads Into Court
abstract: American Civil Liberties Union and 15 other groups and businesses file lawsuit to overturn Child Online Protection Act, new Federal law intended to protect children from on-line smut; law was immediately challenged on constitutional grounds and has never gone into effect; law makes it crime for operator of commercial Web site to knowingly make available to those under 17 certain sexually explicit material; earlier attempt to limit children's access to on-line pornography was struck down by Supreme Court as so vague and broad that it violated First Amendment; supporters of new law say it is narrowly written enough to pass muster, but opponents say it would undercut not just free speech on line but Internet commerce of various sorts; photo (M)

headline: BP AMOCO BEGINS REORGANIZATION WITH JOB CUTS
abstract: BP Amoco PLC begins revamping that includes 2,475 job cuts in Texas, Alaska and Canada, and closing of New Orleans and Denver offices, which together employ 600 workers (S)

headline: POMEROY COMPUTER SERVICE BUSINESS TO GO PUBLIC
abstract: Pomeroy Computer Resources Inc has split off its service business into new subsidiary that plans to go public through initial stock sale; Pomeroy Computer will retain controlling stake in unit, Pomeroy Select Integration Solutions Inc (S)/

headline: Virginia Utility May Buy a Gas Company
abstract: Dominion Resources Inc, owner of Virginia's largest electric utility, is reportedly negotitating purchase of Consolidated Natural Gas Co (S)

headline: COLTEC DOWN, GOODRICH UP AS DEAL IS STUDIED
abstract: B F Goodrich Co says Federal Trade Commission is seeking more information on its $1.86 billion purchase of Coltec Inc, sign that deal is under close scrutiny; deal would unite two major makers of landing gear in United States (S)

headline: Telefonica Estimates Profit
abstract: Telefonica SA says fourth-quarter profit rose 12 percent, to 54.2 billion pesetas ($359 million) from 48.3 billion in year-earlier period (S)6

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction of reference the The Great Gatsby in Jan 3 article about investing in bond marketg

headline: French Your Way 2.0
abstract: Eric Nagourney evaluates French Your Way 2.0 on CD-ROM from Random House/Syracuse Language Systems--$69.95; photo (M)

headline: Omaha Oracle Taps a Medium Of Wall Street
abstract: SUCH is the renown of Warren E. Buffett that 10,000 admirers flocked to last year's shareholder meeting in Omaha for his conglomerate, Berkshire Hathaway. Many of them regard publication of the company's annual report, whose main feature is Mr. Buffett's folksy philosophizing, as a highlight of their financial calendar. And people gladly shell out $30 for two decades' worth of the chairman's collected letters.    So why would this icon of Graham and Dodd investing, a man stingy with public utterance, who cares nothing for short-term performance, suddenly decide to establish a special link to Wall Street, cultivating a fraternity he has often disdained? And why did Mr. Buffett agree to give Alice D. Schroeder, an analyst little known outside insurance circles and employed by a primarily, ugh, retail brokerage house, unprecedented access to Berkshire -- access that culminated in her issuing a report on the company last week, marking the first time a major Wall Street firm has covered the Omaha conglomerate?

headline: The Art of the Sale
abstract: To the Editor:    I was delighted to see the article debunk conventional sales wisdom. But I was disappointed that credit was not also given to the work of Neil Rackham, who advocated breaking the mold with his pioneering ''Spin Selling'' (McGraw-Hill, 1988).

headline: Missile Plan Puts U.S. in Quandary on China
abstract: Clinton Administration, having planned major outlay for defense missiles, now faces major diplomatic and military quandary with China; anxieties over North Korea's missile firing over Japan last August underlie US plan to develop limited national system of missile defense, at proposed cost of $10.5 billion over six years; Sec William Cohen recently discussed joint venture with Japanese officials, raising Chinese fears about Japan's military ambitions; US troops in South Korea and Japan would be vulnerable to improved North Korean missiles; analyst Richard Armitage notes irony that China's client, North Korea, brought debate into daylight (S)

headline: Angola Says It Will Abandon Treaty With Rebels
abstract: High-level Angolan Govt official, in further sign of deterioration of peace efforts, says ruling party will abandon four-year-old peace treaty with mainstream Unita rebels and will deal only with splinter group (S)

headline: Bewildered Europeans Deplore 100% U.S. Tariff
abstract: Europeans deplore Clinton Administration's imposition of retaliatory 100 percent tariffs on European goods after failure to settle long-running dispute over European import rules for bananas; European business executives and government officials angrily denounce US, calling its action arbitrary, unjustified and illegal; Sir Leon Brittan, European Union's top-ranking trade official, calls tariffs 'unacceptable and unlawful' and accuses US of endangering European jobs; trade ministers from Britain, France and Italy all condemn action in similar terms; list of products slapped with 100 percent tariffs; photos (M)

headline: A Long-Shot House Vote to Limit Steel Imports
abstract: News analysis contends that vote in House of Representatives to limit steel imports reflects strong sense of frustration within domestic steel industry over low-price steel that landed on American shores during economic crises in Asia and Russia last year; holds measure, violation of world trade rules and a long shot at best in Senate, would do little to help steel industry in long run (M)

headline: Russia's Patchwork Economy; Korean Companies, Chinese Workers and U.S. Entree
abstract: Growing number of South Korean companies are now making clothes in Russia, in part because of low wages and, as means of skirting American import quotas; factories have been set up in 10 cities in Russian Far East, including Vladivostok, port city that until 1992 was off-limits to foreigners; American apparel companies have long farmed out work to manufacturers in low-wage countries, but in an elaborate global trading system known as Multi-Fiber Agreement, which is supposed to be dismantled in 2005, US, like Europe, has set up restrictions on imports from countreis whose exports are thought to threaten domestic apparel industry; South Korean textile firms, limited by American quotas for decades, have produced clothing in foreign countries and are now coming to see Russia as new 'back door' by which to sell their products in US; for Russia, apparel companies are double-edged sword: they provide jobs but raise possibility that sweatshop conditions, common to many South Korean factories in Latin American, could result in similar conditions in Russian factories; photos (L)

headline: MANAGEMENT IS REORGANIZED AT UNOCAL TO HELP CUT COSTS
abstract: Unocal Corp reorganizes its top management to better handle its oil and natural gas reserves and help it reduce cash costs by as much as $200 million a year; four-member management committee is named to set company strategy and investment priorities; chief executive Roger C Beach will head committee with John F Imle Jr, Timothy H Ling and Charles R Williamson (S)

headline: Hachette Closes A Magazine
abstract: Hachette Filipacchi Magazines makes number of personnel changes as it closes Eating Well magazine Hachette, is promoted to vice president and publisher at Family Life (S)

headline: 5 Suspects Tell Story Of Cuba Bomb Case
abstract: Article on terrorist bombing case in Cuba noted

headline: Philippine Airlines Raising $200 Million
abstract: Philippine Airlines Inc expects to raise $200 million in fresh capital within three months to meet demands of secured creditors; airline will submit new plan to regulators on March 15 (S)

headline: Dow Surges 124.60 as It Flirts With 10,000 Mark
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average pushes within 65 points of 10,000 mark before losing quarter of its gains for day to close at 9,897.44; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 10.84 points or eight-tenths of percent, to 1,297.68, and Nasdaq index edges up 6.25 points, almost three-tenths of percent, to 2,412.25; recent rally has widened to include stocks other than technology shares; graphs; chart (M)

headline: Forgotten Flames /30 Years Later : A Czech Martyr's Dreams Give Way to Velvet Malaise
abstract: PRAGUEâ€”  Ten years ago Tuesday, the playwright and human rights activist Vaclav Havel laid a small bunch of lilies at a statue in central Prague to honor a Czech student, Jan Palach, who had set himself on fire in January 1969 to protest the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia.

headline: Price Rises Ahead for Road Warriors
abstract: Business travel is expected to cost employers 5 percent to 7 percent more this year than it did in 1998; corporate travel managers are not overly concerned, given fact that 1998 rise was 8 percent over 1997; photo (M)

headline: HARROW INDUSTRIES TO BE ACQUIRED BY INGERSOLL-RAND
abstract: Ingersoll-Rand Co to buy Harrow Industries for $160 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: L-3 to Acquire Aydin for $72.3 Million
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc agrees to buy Aydin Corp for $72.3 million in cash (S)

headline: U.S. Jets Attack Iraqi Targets After a Challenge by Baghdad
abstract: American and British warplanes attack air-defense sites in Iraq after Iraqi jets fly deep into no-flight zone over southern Iraq; make no effort to pursue Iraqi jets, which retreat quickly; attacks reflect new strategy of letting pilots hit any military targets when provoked, not just those that threaten them directly; Iraq scores bombing; claims civilian casualties (M)

headline: Once Derided, Noor Is Likely to Remain a Power at the Palace
abstract: Queen Noor, King Hussein's American-born widow, is now seen likely to endure as important voice behind Jordanian throne; is mother of new Crown Prince, Hamzeh; Noor, jibed at in past, won nation's affection during Hussein's illness; photo (M)

headline: Russian Deal Limits Exports Of Cheap Steel
abstract: Clinton Administration announces agreement with Russia to strictly control its surging exports of steel to US, an attempt to balance bitter complaints of American steelmakers with efforts to keep from worsening Russia's economic slide; Russia has agreed to roll back its sales of steel to US to amount it shipped in 1996 and first half of 1997, before sharp fall in value of country's currency led to surge of shipments to US; steel production accounts for 7 percent of Russia's gross national product, and is huge source of scarce hard currency; agreement leaves American steel producers and workers dissatisfied, and some in Congress are threatening to press legislation that would virtually cut off steel imports (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Regulators Take a Closer Look at Spinoffs
abstract: Growing popularity of corporate spinoffs has caught attention of Federal securities regulators; Jane B Adams, deputy chief accountant at Securities and Exchange Commission, says regulators fear that some of deals could mislead investors; deals allow companies to transfer research costs to new affiliates, while bolstering parents' bottom lines; at times, parent companies record large, one-time charges for payments to subsidiaries, payments that Wall Street analysts often play down, saying they mean little to company's future; Adams says commission has referred matter to task force at Financial Accounting Standards Board; that group, Emerging Issues Task Force, has authority from Federal regulators to write opinions that force public companies to change the way they account for certain transactions (M)

headline: Sex With a Subordinate Costs Israel Army General a Promotion
abstract: Israeli Supreme Court rules that Army Brig Gen Nir Galili, 43, who was disciplined for having sex with female subordinate three years ago could not be promoted; case reviewed (M)

headline: Nasdaq Panel Rejects Halts in Trading
abstract: Special committee of Nasdaq market makers, brokerage firms and other industry officials examining ways to deal with sharp price swings of certain Internet-related stocks has voted not to recommend that officials of Nasdaq stock market be given power to temporarily halt trading in those stocks (S)

headline: Markets Rally Sharply as Economic Fears Fade
abstract: Investors, who were braced for bad news from the February jobs report, got a pleasant surprise yesterday that helped push bond yields down sharply and stocks higher. The Dow Jones industrial average set a new high, rising 268.68 points, to 9,736.08 -- just 264 points from 10,000.    Instead of a jobs report reflecting surprisingly strong growth and threatening higher interest rates, investors got a more benign result.

headline: Pricing at Issue As U.S. Finishes Microsoft Case
abstract: Government calls its last witness in Microsoft Corp antitrust trial, Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Franklin M Fisher, after presenting 110 pages of his written testimony that amounts to summation of--and economic justification for--Justice Department's suit; much of Fisher's testimony is detailed review of major allegations in Government's case; Fisher also seeks to advance case and strengthen argument for strong sanctions against Microsoft with his analysis of Microsoft's pricing tactics; he asserts Microsoft commits predatory pricing by giving away its Internet Explorer browser (M)

headline: For Ordinary Saudis, Days Of Oil and Roses Are Over
abstract: Saudi Government is cutting its spending sharply in response to decline in oil revenues, and the effects are being felt by ordinary Saudis, who gained taste for luxury during the long boom years; cuts in agricultural subsidies bring migrants to the desert outside Riyadh, where poverty is evident; defense contractors and energy industries are also feeling the pinch; Saudis are even seeking new sources of income, even opening the country to foreign tourists; graphs (L)

headline: Planning, by the Numbers
abstract: Retirement plans are educated guesses, because they deal with most unpredictable of things, the future; financial preparation is more of a process than a blueprint, with series of midcourse corrections made periodically or as personal circumstances and economy change; drawing (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A trash hauler is buying a much bigger rival, a type of deal that makes Wall Street a bit nervous.
abstract: Market Place column on Allied Waste Industries' announcement that it will acquire Browning-Ferris Industries for $7.3 billion, plus assumption of $1.8 billion of Browning-Ferris debt; says with the deal, trashing hauling industry, once run by small, private operators, is further concentrating into business dominated by handful of national companies with huge fleets of trucks and enormous landfills; says Wall Street analysts are concerned about how Allied executives will pay off sizable debt load from takeover (M)

headline: Financial World Scrambles To Be Ready for the Euro
abstract: Thursday was a day for champagne and confetti. Today began the long weekend of strong coffee and takeout food.    A day after 11 European countries christened the euro as their new currency, financial institutions across the Continent began the enormous job of reprogramming their electronic networks before markets reopen on Monday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: RJR Nabisco to Spin Off Its Tobacco Operations  Faced with the twin burdens of debt and the persistent threat of smoking lawsuits, RJR Nabisco announced that it was splitting up its food and tobacco businesses and selling its foreign tobacco operations to the Japanese.

headline: COMPUTER ASSOCIATES TO ACQUIRE CONSULTING CONCERN
abstract: Computer Associates International Inc to buy Computer Management Sciences Inc for about $435 million (S)

headline: INTEGRATED HEALTH SERVICES SELLS 32 NURSING HOMES
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc sells 32 nursing homes to Monarch Properties LP for $135 million; Monarch leases sites to Lyric Health Care LLC; Integrated, which owns 50 percent stake in Lyric, will manage and run sites (S)

headline: MEDPARTNERS PLANNING $1 BILLION CHARGE, ANALYST SAYS
abstract: Piper Jaffray analyst Brooks O'Neil says Medpartners Inc, working to transform itself from largest US manager of group-medical practices to drug-benefits administrator, will take charge of $1 billion when it reports its fourth-quarter earnings (S)

headline: Charity May Begin At the State Comptroller
abstract: Web sites run by New York and California state comptrollers show many big charities have not claimed property states are holding for them, despite publicity campaigns by both states about unclaimed assets; some of funds were turned over to states by companies, including wide range of major corporations, who told comptrollers they could not find charities (M)

headline: Yes, Those Junk-Bond Funds Are Still Cheap, but Go on Tiptoes
abstract: Although prices of junk bonds have risen since tumble in summer 1998, it still cost less to buy mutual funds that hold hig-risk, high-return corporate debt than at any time since 1990; as of December 31, yields were stunning 5.55 percentage points higher than for comparable 10-year Treasury notes--down from spread of 6.2 percentage points on October 31, but still far above 3.73-point spread of late July; charts (M)

headline: New Toys Put Children In Middle of the Action
abstract: Intel and Mattel, as part of joint venture, introduce two new high-tech toys that enable children to shrink images of themselves, and greatly magnify images of bugs and fleas and the inside of the children's noses, then project all the images onto a computer monitor; toys, the Me2 Cam and the X3 Microscope, were introduced at Toy Fair in Manhattan; photo (S)

headline: Conceding Guidelines and Winning a Bit of Protection
abstract: Government's proposed antitrust settlement with Intel Corp is viewed as careful compromise that seeks to clarify ground rules for how powerful company can wield its intellectual property as weapon in marketplace; industry experts say both Intel and Federal Trade Commission seem to have emerged with partial victories; they say both sides had incentives to reach agreement; precise terms of planned settlement have not been disclosed, but agreement does set guidelines for when Intel has to disclose its technology to other companies (M)

headline: I.B.M. Conventional Monitor Will Challenge Flat Models
abstract: International Business Machines Corp develops a 19-inch computer monitor that is moderately priced and uses convention cathode-ray-tube technology but takes up little more desktop space that a 15-inch monitor; photo (S)

headline: In the President's Words: 'We Act to Prevent a Wider War'
abstract: Transcript of Pres Clinton's speech explaining NATO attack against Serbia

headline: GEOWORKS SHARES RISE 56% AFTER AMAZON BUYS 7% STAKE
abstract: Shares of Geoworks Corp surge 56 percent after Amazon.com Inc buys 7 percent stake in it for $5 million (S)

headline: MacManus Creating New Marketing Unit
abstract: MacManus Group is creating relationship marketing division in New York, Dialogue Works, by consolidating Ayer/Deare & Partners with two accounts and 25 employees of Clarion Direct; Bryan Dougherty and Trissie Rost will head Dialogue Works as co-presidents (S)

headline: Venator Profit Fell 73% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: Venator Group Inc reports profit from continuing operations for fourth quarter ended Jan 30 fell 73 percent, to $29 million, from $106 million a year earlier; net income was $37 million, down from $115 million; company says it works toward amended $400 million revolving credit accord from banks (M)

headline: Investing Success Breeds Unlikely Troubles
abstract: CMGI Inc, whose investments in Internet startups have grown far more quickly than its underlying direct marketing business, is in danger of being classified as a mutual fund, which would impose huge tax burdens on its shareholders; has until October to increase its investment in one of companies like Lycos in which it already owns substantial stakes, thus changing status of those holdings from investments to continuing business operations, or to sell off enough of its investments so that they fall below 40 percent threshold set by Federal securities law (M)

headline: In First Combined Results, DaimlerChrysler Profit Rises
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG, reporting its financial results as combined company for first time, says 1998 earnings rose 28 percent; earnings rose to 5.2 billion euros ($5.72 billion) compared with equivalent of 4.06 billion euros in 1997; sales rose 12 percent, to 131.8 billion euros, or $145 million; release of earnings also coincides with increased speculation that company is nearing agreement to buy significant part of ailing Nissan Motor Co; shares of Nissan surge nearly 6 percent on heavy trading in Tokyo (M)

headline: AT&T Finds Internet and a Crowd of Critics
abstract: AT&T is being pressured to open its cable system to Internet competitors; fight pits AT&T, which has struck cable deals that will give it access to nearly half of nation's homes, against coalition led by America Online; it has drawn large group of companies that are Internet gateways for millions of Americans, as well as influential lobbyists working for all sides; AT&T, by providing high-speed Internet service over cable systems on broad scale, will offer millions of consumers ability to navigate through World Wide Web at speeds up to 100 times faster than typical connection through ordinary telephone lines; but AT&T will require customers who subscribe to high-speed cable modem service to also pay monthly $40 fee for Internet access provided by At Home Corp, of which AT&T is largest shareholder; other Internet providers fear they may be frozen out (M)

headline: DDB Needham Ends Bermuda Relationship
abstract: DDB Needham New York resigns Bermuda Department of Tourism account (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN TOWER CORP.,  Boston, an operator of wireless communications and broadcast towers, and three shareholders filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell 19.3 million class A common shares.    SMURFIT-STONE CONTAINER CORP.,  St. Louis, the world's largest box maker, agreed to sell part of its 25.1 percent stake in Abitibi-Consolidated Inc., for about $80 million. The 7.8 million Abitibi shares are being sold to an unidentified institutional holder at a price of $10.25 each.

headline: Management by 2 Cultures May Be a Growing Source of Strain for DaimlerChrysler
abstract: Some American managers at DaimlerChrysler AG are complaining privately that merged company has come to be dominated by Germans, hurting morale in United States; some highly regarded Chrysler executives have resigned or retired early since the merger; 9 of 11 executives in management tier directly below company's two chairmen are German, although management board is divided equally between Americans and Germans; American co-chairman Robert J Eaton is increasingly expected to retire early (M)

headline: Lilly to Stop Developing Migraine Drug
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co announces that it will end development of an experimental migraine drug that had been billed as promising new method to treat monster headaches; while analysts applaud move, shares of Lilly extend their slide of last two weeks; announcement has greater impact on Synaptic Pharmaceutical Corp of Paramus, NJ, which had been developing migraine compound with Willy; Syamptic shares plunge 44.3 percent; migraine drug was one of Synaptic's leading compounds (M)

headline: Worries About Big Brother at America Online
abstract: America Online's 17-day closing of contentious discussion group on Ireland has fed growing discomfort with social and political power Internet service provider wields by dint of its surging popularity and unusual purview over individual communication; underscores challenges company may face as it seeks to balance free expression and civility while presiding over 180,000 continuing conversations on wide range of subjects; at issue is company monitoring of its message boards and chat rooms for messages deemed offensive to other subscribers; graphs showing AOL's dominance as Internet service provider; photo (M)

headline: INSIGNIA FINANCIAL EXPANDS BRITISH HOLDINGS
abstract: Insignia Financial Group Inc buys British real estate services firm St Quintin for $32 million, expanding is British subsidiary, Richard Ellis Group Ltd; New York-based Insignia says expansion of its London-based unit, to be renamed Richard Ellis St Quintin, will add 3 cents a share to its annual net incoe and 21 cnts to net cash flow (S)

headline: Bombs-to-Plowshares Program Criticized
abstract: Report by General Accounting Office criticizes key part of Clinton Administration's effort to stop spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons by helping employ scientists from former Soviet Union on peaceful projects; study of two Energy Department programs concludes that American aid may have instead supported scientists still working in Russia on projects related to weapons of mass destruction; says some scientists or their institutes may also have provided expertise not only to weapons programs in Russia but also to those of other countries (M)

headline: Cybernavigation: Joystick, Mouse and Key
abstract: J C Herz (Game Theory) article evaluates new Nintendo game (cartridge and cassette) called Glover, from Hasbro Interactive; price is $59.95; photos (M)

headline: OBITUARY
abstract: George Beaumont, 73, a media consultant who co-managed his Paris advertising agency, Liger Beaumont & Aljanvic, from 1961 to 1972, died Dec. 24 in Apt, France.

headline: Scandal Over Top Russian Prosecutor Deepens New Crisis
abstract: Yuri I Skuratov, who resigned on Feb 1 as Russia's Prosecutor General, announces in Parliament that he plans to stay in his job, in open defiance of Pres Boris N Yeltsin; television news program on Government channel broadcasts videotape of naked Skuratov in bed with two women, neither his wife; Skuratov photo (M)

headline: A Schroder Lieutenant Suggests Alliance With Ex-Communists
abstract: Germany's Finance Minister Oskar Lafontaine divides his own governing Social Democratic Party and irks Chancellor Gerhard Schroder with suggestion that political alliance with former East German Communists would be acceptable; Lafontaine's policy switch reflects fact that Party of Democratic Socialism is now important political force, winning 5.7 percent of national vote in federal elections last year and 21 percent of vote in former East Germany; party already cooperates with Social Democrats in government of two eastern states; Schroder, who is beholden to Lafontaine for party support, nevertheless refuses to consider his suggestion (M)

headline: Leftist Opposition Party in Mexico Wins Two Governors' Races
abstract: Left-of-center Party of the Democratic Revolution wins gubernatorial election in Baja California Sur and powerful office of Mayor in Mexico City; victories demonstrate continuing growth of party that has capitalized on dissension in governing Institutional Revolutionary Party (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ciena Shares Rebound After Strong First Quarter  The beleaguered shares of Ciena rebounded after the company reported a surprising return to profitability in its first fiscal quarter. Lost sales and a scuttled acquisition by Tellabs last September had eroded much of Ciena's once-stellar valuation.    Ciena shares closed Friday at $22.4375, up $1.5625, or 7.5 percent, in Nasdaq trading. While that number is still a fraction of the stock's 52-week high of $92.37, reached after the initial announcement of the Tellabs deal, it is still a significant multiple of the 52-week low of $8.12 set last October. [Page C2.]

headline: KORN/FERRY SHARES FALL BELOW INITIAL OFFERING PRICE
abstract: Korn/Ferry International, the world's largest executive search firm, dropped below its offering price on its first day of trading yesterday after an initial stock sale. Shares fell $1, to $13, as eight million shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange. On Wednesday, the company and existing shareholders sold 11.8 million shares at $14 each. Shares fell below that price three hours after they began trading. Investors' enthusiasm for Korn/Ferry may have been tempered by the company's recent announcement that it expects fiscal third-quarter revenue to drop. Korn/Ferry, based in Los Angeles, has been first in revenue among its peers for almost 20 years.

headline: A Proud but Pensive Moment in Warsaw
abstract: Celebrations held, Warsaw, to mark Poland's joining North Atlantic Treaty Organization; reaction discussed; photo (M)

headline: Hoechst Agrees To Collaboration
abstract: Hoechst A.G., Europe's fourth-biggest drug maker, and Inflazyme Pharmaceuticals Ltd., a Canadian biopharmaceuticals company, agreed today to collaborate to develop drug treatments of allergies, asthma and other respiratory diseases.    The companies said the accord meant Hoechst could pay Inflazyme as much as $91 million, consisting of a $16 million investment in the Canadian company and milestone payments that could total $75 million. It will pay Inflazyme royalties on products that may result from the partnership.

headline: Qunu Journal; Mandela's Childhood Left a Fond Spot in His Heart
abstract: Article profiles Qunu, South Africa, childhood hometown of Pres Nelson Mandela; photo; maps (M)

headline: Personal Business; Collectors Are Going Hollywood
abstract: Collection of Hollywood memorabilia becomes lucrative mainstream business; aging of the baby-boom generation and rise of Internet contribute to growth; photo (M)

headline: Loss Widens at British American Tobacco
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC says loss grew to 171 million pounds, or $275 million, in fourth quarter, from 163 million pounds a year earlier; larger loss linked to $206 billion settlement between cigarette makers and 46 American states (S)

headline: AEGON AND AMERICAN FINANCIAL ARE IN $115 MILLION DEAL
abstract: American Financial Group Inc agrees to buy auto insurer Worldwide Insurance Co from Aegon NV for $115 million in cash (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Executive Musical Chairs At Shopping.com, Again
abstract: Shopping.com, Internet retailing company, announces its third management team in nine months; Randall R Read will replace Frank Denny as chairman, and Denny will replace John Markley as president and chief executive; Markley has resigned (S)

headline: 3 Cable Companies Talking With AT&T
abstract: Mediaone Group, Comcast Corp and Cox Communications Inc have joined forces in talks with AT&T Corp regarding local phone service ventures (S)

headline: Government's Lawyer Raises More Questions About Microsoft Demonstration
abstract: At the Microsoft trial today, the Government attacked a key assertion in the company's defense: that bundling a Web browser with Microsoft's Windows operating system is not anti-competitive because consumers can quickly and easily download a competing browser from the World Wide Web.    That was the central message of a videotape demonstration that lawyers for the Microsoft Corporation played this morning. And, as has become routine in this case, David Boies, the Government's lead trial lawyer, immediately attacked the video as misleading.

headline: UNIFORM PROVIDER CINTAS TO BUY UNITOG FOR $357 MILLION
abstract: Cintas Corp will acquire Unitog Co for about $357 million (S)

headline: Hewlett Plans To Split in 2 In Revamping
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co says it will split into two independent companies, one focusing on computers, printers and scanners, and other on electronic test equipment and medical technology products; analysts say split will allow Hewlett-Packard's computer and imaging business to compete more effectively with more focused companies that have lower cost structures; after the split, computer and imaging company will continue to be known as Hewlett-Packard Co, while new name will be chosen for measurement company; Hewlett-Packard plans public offering of 15 percent of measurement company's outstanding shares by year-end, which would be largest initial public offering in Silicon Valley history; photo (M)

headline: Scientists Are Publishing More on Line
abstract: Internet has given rise to thousands of electronic journals, helping usher in new era for scientific publishing; article in journal Nature states that high-price, low-circulation print journals no longer represent best means of scientific communication; rise in number of so-called E-journals has been meteoric in past three years; Reed-Elsevier, largest commercial publisher of scientific journals, has more than 1,200 of its titles on line; advent of E-journals has yet to help lower high price of subscribing to scientific journals; photo (M)

headline: Fed Maintains Steady Stance In Rate Policy
abstract: Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee leaves interest rates unchanged, and passes up opportunity to signal any concern about inflation; Federal funds rate remains at 4.75 percent; Conference Board reports index of consumer confidence rose in March by eight-tenths of a point, to 133.9 from revised 133.1 in February (M)

headline: GUATEMALAN ARMY WAGED 'GENOCIDE,' NEW REPORT FINDS
abstract: Independent truth commission report concludes that United States gave money and training to Guatemalan military that committed 'acts of genocide' against Mayans during Guatemala's 36-year brutal civil war; report contradicts years of official denials of torture, kidnapping and executions of thousands of civilians in war that commission estimates killed more than 200,000 people; commission's nine-volume report lists Central Intelligence Agency training of Guatemalan officer corps in counterinsurgency techniques as key factor that had significant bearing on human rights violations during armed confrontation; staff member of commission says panel also found evidence that United States had knowledge of genocide and still supported Guatemalan military; commission was set up as part of United Nations-supervised peace accord that ended war in 1996; photo (M)

headline: A Test Case Of Internet Exuberance
abstract: Some financial analysts say initial public offering by Prodigy Communications, which is expected in week of Feb 7, could provide a litmus test of just how exuberant Internet investors are; note that Prodigy does not offer much in the way of growth or profits anytime soon, although it has been around since 1984; graphs; table; photo (M)

headline: G.O.P. Tax Plan Is Flawed, Democrats Say
abstract: House Democrats say Republican proposal to cut income taxes by 10 percent across the board means that millions of middle-class families will get only part of tax break and taxes will increase for large middle-income families, by as much as 14 percent; this is because of how income tax system interacts with two other laws, alternative minimum tax and child credit for middle-class families; Sen William V Roth Jr, Republican chairman of Senate Finance Committee, says reforming alternative minimum tax to exempt middle-class families should be part of this year's tax legislation (M)

headline: Doner and Ikon Part Company
abstract: W B Doner resigns advertising account of Ikon Office Solutions, which agency had handled since summer 1996; Ikon spokesman describes decision as 'a mutual agreement' (S)

headline: SEAGRAM WEIGHS SALE OF FILM COMPANY TO A SAUDI PRINCE
abstract: Seagram Co is in talks to sell remaining assets of Polygram Filmed Entertainment to Saudi Arabian Prince Muhammad bin Bandur Abdul Aziz for as much as $600 million in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Report Finds Banks Failed To Oversee Big Hedge Fund
abstract: Report issued under auspices of Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and under supervision of William J McDonough, president of New York Federal Reserve, shows handful of world's largest commercial and investment banks failed to adequately oversee lending and trading activities with hedge fund giant Long-Term Capital Management; McDonough says banks had been blinded by 'magic' of once high-flying firm's vaunted reputation, situation that he says could recur if banks do not tighten their monitoring of such funds (M)

headline: Short-Term Frustration, Long-Term Success
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column discusses Dow Theory, stock market timing strategy based on synchronism, or lack thereof, of Dow Jones industrial and transportation averages; notes indicator turned bearish in Aug, correctly predicting market swoon, but has remained bearish through big fourth-quarter rally and 1999 market gyrations; graph (M)

headline: When Art Mocks â€” and Inspires â€” Fashion
abstract: PARISâ€”  "One thing is sure. There are more fashion designers who want to be artists than the other way around," says Elein Fleiss, co-founder of Purple, fashion's artiest style review.

headline: Fluor to Cut 5,000 Jobs and Reorganize Operations
abstract: Fluor Corp will cut 5,000 employees, reorganize its operations and narrow range of construction projects it undertakes; moves are expected to reduce overhead costs by $160 million annually but will require $130 million pretax charge against earnings in current quarter; company will reorganize into four units: Fluor Daniel, construction division, A T Massey, coal producer, Fluor Global Services, which combines businesses such as equipment leasing and temporary staffing, and Shared Services, which will sell computing and administrative services to other divisions; Alan L Boeckmann is promoted to head construction division (M)

headline: Productivity Gains Help Keep Economy on a Roll
abstract: Corporations are confounding widely held view that inflation is inevitable result of sustained prosperity, eight years into US economic expansion, by foregoing price increases in face of intense global competition, while raising wages and making healthy profits; new labor-saving efficiencies, gained through greater flexibility in manipulating labor costs, is key element in their success; many, such as Maytag Corp, have resorted to popular practice of 'accordian' scheduling involving use of temporary workers and part-timers, whose wages are up but whose hours are adjusted day to day, and more have adopted practice of shifting work to lower-cost cities; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Goldberg Moser O'Neill plans revamping in a bid to make itself better known as a creative shop.
abstract: San Francisco-based Goldberg Moser O'Neill is reorganizing to gain higher profile among advertisers; at center of shake-up is reorganization involving account planning department (M)

headline: Force Possible If Milosevic Stays Defiant, West Warns
abstract: Western powers warn Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic that political solution must be found for Kosovo or he risks threat of NATO air strikes; say simply allowing head of international monitoring mission to remain there is not enough; NATO's supreme Commander, Gen Wesley K Clark, underlines threat of force; photo; map (M)

headline: As New Israeli Party Emerges, Netanyahu Becomes the Issue
abstract: Israeli election has become referendum on Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, incumbent whose strong character is lightning rod for fierce emotions that rule Israeli society; Netanyahu appears certain to be Likud candidate when primary votes are tallied; Yitzhak Mordechai, popular Defense Minister whom Netanyahu dismissed, will head ticket of new center party; running with him are former Army Chief of Staff Amnon Lipkin Shahak, former Finance Min Dan Meridor and former Tel Aviv Mayor Roni Milo, who proposed party seven months ago; Moshe Arens is to take over as Defense Minister; Netanyahu himself predicts new party will dissolve into Labor party before elections (S)

headline: Sun-America Online Terms Disclosed
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc will pay America Online Inc a minimum of about $1.28 billion over three years as part of their agreement to sell Netscape Communications Corp's software (S)

headline: Dow Advances by 22.14, to 9,297.03, in Mixed Trading
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 22.14 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,297.03; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 11.74 points, or nearly 1 percent, to 1,241.87; Nasdaq composite index falls 8.02 points, or three-tenths a percent, to 2,313.87; graph; chart (M)

headline: Argentina Looks for a Way to Stem Illegal Immigrants
abstract: Argentinian Pres Carlos Saul Menem introduces series of bills to Congress to stem flow of illegal immigration from Bolivia, Paraguay and Peru (M)

headline: Saipan Journal; Palm Trees and Sun (and Who Needs an Address?)
abstract: Growth of Saipan Island, US Commonwealth in Northern Mariana Islands, creates some impatience with absence of street names and numbers; legislature passed bill calling for action, but job remains incomplete; many islanders say street names and numbers would be unnecessary bother and unwelcome intrusion of modern life; maps; photo (M)

headline: Did You Get Her E-Mail Address?
abstract: Electronic mail is reviving practice of epistolary romance, allowing people involved in relationships to once again formulate feelings and desires by writing them down; has changed role of letter in courtship rites (M)

headline: Saatchi Selected In Insurance Merger
abstract: The UNUM Corporation in Portland, Me., and the Provident Companies in Chattanooga, Tenn., have named Saatchi & Saatchi in New York, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C, as the agency of record for the company to be formed by their merger, planned to take place in the second quarter. Billings for the combined account, to sell group and individual disability insurance, were estimated at $30 million.

headline: Notes From the Land of the E-Less
abstract: Journal by Dirk Johnson says not everyone is surfing the Net, it just feels that way; says it used to be stylish to be a Luddite, but now he and other techno-laggards are considered duds; notes certain nastiness creeping into computerized voices on telephone menus; says he feels like social misfit; drawing (M)

headline: Thais Show Albright the Fruits of American Aid: Meaningful Jobs and Legal Crops
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright meets with group of young women in Chaing Mai, Thailand, who tell her that US aid has helped turn them away from drugs and prostitution and toward meaningful jobs (M)

headline: Few Willing Wallets On an Opening Night
abstract: Business executives and socialites are out in force for opening of Winter Antiques Show at Seventh Regiment Armory in New York, but most resist the urge to buy; photo (S)

headline: British GQ Fires Editor
abstract: Conde Nast fires James Brown as editor of British edition of GQ magazine after magazine included 'the Nazis' in list of 200 most stylish men of 20th century; photo (S)

headline: Montreal Journal; Orphans Who Weren't Recall Care That Wasn't
abstract: Demonstration held recently in Montreal, Canada, calls on Catholic Church to apologize to and compensate so-called Duplessis orphans, about 3,000 out-of-wedlock children classified incorrectly as mentally ill and raised in Quebec orphanages run by Roman Catholic nuns in 1940's and 50's; when federal money became available for health care, but not education, government reportedly encouraged religious order to transform their orphanages into mental institutions; children claimed they were abused; Jean-Claude Cardinal Turcotte, current head of church in Quebec, challenges orphans to prove they were abused; photos of demonstrators wearing straitjackets of type they say were used on them as children (M)

headline: Airbus Won't Be Transformed This Year, Finance Chief Says
abstract: Airbus Industrie's chief financial officer, Ian Massey, says the jet consortium, jointly owned by four European companies, will not transform itself into single corporation this year; indicates lengthy negotiations lie ahead; Airbus had planned to complete transition to private company by January but bickering among its partners, Aerospatiale, DaimlerChrysler Aerospace, British Aerospace and Construcciones Aeronauticas SA, over value of their stakes in unified company has delayed move indefinitely (M)

headline: TOYS 'R' US GOES ON LINE IN BRITAIN
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Inc starts free Internet service in Britain to increase on-line sales; is second retailer in world to offer free Internet access (S)

headline: Milosevic Advantage: In Talking Peace He Can Win Big
abstract: News analysis says threats by Clinton Administration and its NATO allies to bomb Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic into ceding effective control over Kosovo Province not only make it easier for him to justify eventual concessions but also make him indispensable to any settlement (M)

headline: Business; Is Bentley Hiding a Grin Behind Its Stiff Upper Lip?
abstract: Volkswagen AG chairman Ferdinand Plech introduces sleek new Bentley concept car at Geneva Motor Show; controversy over what will become of Rolls-Royce logo when VW must surrender it to BMW in 2003 discussed; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft to Sell Business Internet Software
abstract: Microsoft Corp announces its electronic commerce strategy, range of software products and services designed to automate business; company offers Biztalk, new language, or set of conventions, that it says will help draw together disparate business practices and electronic commerce technologies via Internet; chairman-chief executive William H Gates comments (M)

headline: CRESTLINE BUYS 74% INTEREST IN MARRIOTT RESIDENCE INN
abstract: Crestline Capital Corp acquires 74 percent limited partnership interest in Marriott Residence Inn USA LP from private Japanese investor for $34.4 million (S)

headline: Dresdner Bank Moves Money to Partnerships
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG has put shareholdings worth about 12.8 billion euros ($15 billion) into partnerships, sheltering assets from Government clampdown on tax loopholes this year (S)

headline: Mercedes-Benz of North America dismisses Lowe & Partners/SMS, its agency since 1993.
abstract: Mercedes-Benz of North America dismisses Lowe & Partners/SMS as its advertising agency, effective April 30; decision to dismiss Lowe sets off acrimonious dispute that includes statement from Lowe describing executives as 'appalled'; dismissal also puts up for grabs account with billings estimated at $125 million (M)

headline: In Russia, Even Holidays Are Long and Perplexing
abstract: Russian calendar is perplexing, reflecting two interlocking Russian traditions: one anchored by Russian orthodox Church's calendar, other by Soviet bureaucratic habit of moving around holidays like pawns on chessboard; as result, Sunday periodically pops up as regular working day, and many stores and offices are forced to post schedules on their doors, advising customers and clients who might otherwise not be aware of regular working days and days off; photo (M)

headline: With Minimalist Approach, Paleontology Is Brought to Life
abstract: Article on Web site operated by University of California's Museum of Paleontology; photo (M)

headline: Follow the Soaps By Watching a P.D.A.
abstract: Columbia Tristar Interactive offers new newsletter on daily doings of television soap operas that downloads automatically to mobile computing devices plugged into Internet; joins some 70 companies that provide content to Avant Go (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   5.06   4.68   6.00        3-month T-bills   4.44   4.41   5.07        6-month T-bills   4.47   4.41   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.80   3.65        10-yr. T-note   5.01   5.05   5.43        30-yr. T-bond   5.34   5.42   5.79        Telephone bd.   6.93   7.00   7.05        Municipal bds.   5.16   5.15   5.15          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Mitsui Trust Foresees Bigger Loss for Year
abstract: Mitsui Trust and Banking Co says losses this fiscal year will exceed expectations; bank raises its loss forecast 15 percent, to 150 billion yen ($1.24 billion) (S)7

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: OCEAN ENERGY INC., Houston, a petroleum exploration company that is merging with Seagull Energy Corp., agreed to sell United States oil and natural gas properties for more than $42 million, to be used to reduce debt.    NEXTEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., Mclean. Va., said its Mexico unit planned to invest $20 million to expand its digital two-way radio communication network in Mexico City and adjacent regions.

headline: Earnings at Bankers Trust Remain Extremely Weak
abstract: Bankers Trust Corp reports fourth-quarter profits of $96 million, down 54 percent but better than what analysts predicted; BankBoston Corp, another bank with substantial exposure in Latin America, earns $207 million for the quarter, down 12 percent, which is in line with analysts' estimates (M)

headline: Golden Books in Talks as Trading Halts
abstract: Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc is negotiating bankruptcy reorganization plan with its creditors; shares of Golden Books are halted by Nasdaq pending disclosure of more information from publisher (S)

headline: Dow Recovers From an Early Slide to Close Down 7.21, to 9,537.76
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 7.21 points, to 9,537.76; Nasdaq composite index rises 5.23 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to record 2,326.09; Standard & Poor's 500-index falls 22.61 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,269.73; Treasury issues fall; price of 30-year bond falls 30/32, to 100 14/32; yield rises to 5.22 percent, from 5.16 percent; graph; charts on stocks with large price percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: DOW JONES & CO., New York, named Rick Stine managing editor of Dow Jones News Service, the financial news wire. Mr. Stine, who had been deputy managing editor, replaces Neal S. Lipschutz, who was appointed senior editor of Dow Jones Newswires for the Americas. Mr. Lipschutz, in turn, succeeds John C. Hitchcock, who was named managing director of Dow Jones Newswires for Latin America.

headline: CHESAPEAKE HOPES TO ENTER EUROPE IN FIELD GROUP DEAL
abstract: Chesapeake Corp agrees to buy Field Group PLC of Britain for $320 million (US) to increase earnings by getting foothold in high-margin European specialty-packaging market (S)

headline: IN MY . . . SATCHEL: JACQUES BLONDEAU
abstract: Interview with SCOR Group chief executive Jacques Blondeau on contents of his travel satchel; photos (S)7

headline: About the Tables
abstract: New York Times is revising some stock and commodity tables (S)

headline: ALLSTATE PLANS TO BUY SOME INSURERS TO INCREASE SALES
abstract: Allstate Corp chief executive-chairman Edward M Liddy says company wants to acquire property and casualty companies to reverse slump in sales growth; company reports fourth-quarter earnings fell 7 percent; operating profit declined to $641 million from $691 million a year earlier (S)

headline: What's Weighing on Buffett's Stock?
abstract: Drop in stock price of famed investor Warren E Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway discussed; class A shares are down 7 percent in 1999 and 19.7 percent from June 1998 peak; Buffett invests 'float' generated by insurance subsidiaries in stocks and other Berkshire operating businesses; graph; photos (M)

headline: Smile at the Laptop And Say 'Cheese'
abstract: Sony Corp introduces Picturebook, $2,300 laptop computer with an embeded digital camera; says new laptop is 'all-in-one solution for professionals on the go,' such as real-estate agents, interior designers and journalists; photo (S)

headline: Oil Industry Sees More Job Losses
abstract: Independent Petroleum Association of America, industry group based in Washington, reports the United States oil industry may lose more than 17,000 jobs by this summer if oil prices do not rise above $14 a barrel over the next six months; says about 24,415 jobs have been lost since price decline began in November 1997 (S)

headline: Resurgence of a Grime Fighter
abstract: Profile of Clorox Co, which has reinvented itself over past three years by introducing new products and more appealing packaging; company stock has shot up 372 percent in past five years and 45 percent in 1998; it has acquired First Brands Corp; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Fed Takes Steps to Make Its Activities More Open
abstract: Federal Reserve discloses that it will be somewhat more open about its secretive policy deliberations, saying it will signal more clearly whether it is leaning toward higher or lower interest rates; central bank's policy-making Federal Open Market Committee announces two changes that will let it be more open (M)

headline: Earnings Off at Hoechst As Chemical Prices Fall
abstract: Hoechst AG says fourth-quarter profit fell 25 percent; net income rose to 400 million euros ($441 million) from 79 million euros a year earlier (S)Ã»

headline: U.S. Embassy in Israel Shut; Said to Be Under a Threat
abstract: The United States Ambassador to Israel ordered the American Embassy in Tel Aviv closed today after what embassy officials called a ''direct and credible'' threat of a terrorist attack against the building.    American officials said the threat was received Wednesday night, but they would not reveal its source or content, or how it was communicated. They denied Israeli radio reports that the threats were directed specifically against the Ambassador, Edward S. Walker.

headline: After Tobacco Merger, Bids on Australia Units
abstract: British American Tobacco PLC will probably bid for outstanding shares currently worth about $950 million (Australian), or $600 million (US) in Rothmans Holdings Ltd and WD&HO Wills Holdings Ltd, Australian tobacco companies, after buying Rothmans International (S)

headline: Vice President for Siberia
abstract: Readers are asked to submit stories about being offered promotions at work only to learn that they were being moved over rather than up (S)

headline: DVD! No, Divx! No . . .
abstract: Letter by Bret Cohen responds to Jan 28 article on Divx; says he noticed a definite anti-Divx slant in article

headline: For Cyclists, Easier Shifting
abstract: New bicycle from Mavic USA lets cyclist change gears by tapping small electronic switches located in three different spots on handlebars; commands travel to handlebar-mounted computer that sends signal to rear derailleur to tell it to shift; new bicycle from Shimano of Japan can change gears automatically (M)

headline: How the Web Can Improve Corporate Underwriting
abstract: Interview with investment banker William R Hambrecht on underwriting of equity and debt issues on Internet and on recent plunge in Internet stocks; he discusses his introduction of on-line auction system for underwriting initial public stock offerings; photo (M)

headline: Arafat Says Little on Clinton Meeting
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat, after meeting with Pres Clinton in Washington, DC, refuses to say whether he will unilaterally declare Palestinian state on May 4, as he has indicated; Clinton opposes such declaration (M)

headline: A Leader Who Climbed the Ranks, as His Father Did, to Become the Chief of Staff
abstract: Interview with Gen Michael Edward Ryan, US Air Force Chief of Staff, who says he is unsure whether air strikes will put end to Pres Slobodan Milosevic's campaign against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo or whether mission can be accomplished without use of ground troops; photo (M)

headline: Delta Sets a Fee for Not Using Its Web Site
abstract: Delta Air Lines, citing rising cost of conventional booking methods, is imposing surcharge--$1 one way, $2 round trip--on domestic tickets purchased anywhere but on airline's own Internet site; no other airline has yet followed suit, but United Airlines says it is studying such a move; travel agents contend airline's long-range strategy is to further weaken travel agents, whose commissions have been sharply cut by carriers since 1995, by weaning customers away altogether (M)

headline: El Al at a Turning Point; A Mirror of Israel's Divisions Prepares to Go 49% Public
abstract: El Al Israel Airlines Ltd, Israeli international flag carrier, plans to sell shares to private investors as early as April after years of being owned by Government; El Al executives say private ownership and private management are key to carrier's economic future, taking their cue from dozens of other state airlines that have been converted into commercial enterprises in recent years; airline's history as terrorist target has made it perhaps most security-conscious carrier in the world; security costs add up to $70 million to $100 million a year, daunting figure for company that generates about $1.2 billion in annual revenues; under state ownership, about two-thirds of expense has been absorbed by Israeli security agencies, but Government and El Al management are now debating how those costs should be shared, and calculated, once El Al is no longer wholly owned by Government; airline's history detailed; graph; photos (M)

headline: DuPont Buying Top Supplier of Farm Seed
abstract: DuPont Co will pay more than $7.7 billion in cash and stock to buy remaining 80 percent of Pioneer Hi-Bred International, world's largest producer of seed corn; deal is part of DuPont's effort to push aggressively into life sciences arena, where it would compete in race to create and develop genetically engineered seeds and crops; DuPont hopes to sell altered seeds directly to farmers worldwide in tandem with its herbicides and pesticides; if acquisition is approved by regulators, DuPont will take control of last remaining giant seed company, making it formidable competitor to Monsanto Co, which has acquired more than $8 billion worth of large seed companies in last two years (M)

headline: Mexican Phone Investment
abstract: Telefonos de Mexico S.A., Latin America's largest telecommunications company, said today that it had agreed to buy a 55 percent interest in the Miami-based Topp Telecom Inc. for about $57.5 million. Topp, a closely held company, makes the Tracfone, a pay-as-you-go cellular phone that displays an air-time balance, ending the need for a service contract. Telefonos de Mexico markets a prepaid cellular program under the Amigo name and has about 1.4 million prepaid wireless subscribers.

headline: Ronald Willetts, 83, of Britain, Expert on Life in Ancient Crete
abstract: Prof Ronald Willetts, British authority on life in ancient Crete, dies at age 83 (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Continue to Slide As Fears About Brazil Grow  Stocks continued to decline as fears intensifed that Brazil's financial turmoil, reflected in the devaluation of its currency, may spread to other Latin American economies and dampen business with the United States.

headline: Credit Cards Get Tough On the Tardy
abstract: Consumer advocates say credit card companies are increasing their late fees and applying them more rigorously than in the past; say they are also raising penalty rates and in some instances confusion card holders with due dates that change month to month; banks, which have had to lower interest rates on unpaid balances because of fierce competition, acknowledge that they taking a stricter line, but deny that they mislead or gouge customers; photo (M)

headline: Hyundai Is Starting Truck Exports to U.S.
abstract: The Hyundai Motor Company began exporting commercial vehicles to the United States this week, becoming the first South Korean car manufacturer to do so.    The company, South Korea's biggest auto maker, already exports 15,000 commercial vehicles to Europe and Asia annually.

headline: Holbrooke Agrees to Pay $5,000 to End Influence Case
abstract: Richard C Holbrooke, Pres Clinton's choice to be US ambassador to UN, reportedly agrees to pay $5,000 to Justice Department to settle civil charges that he violated Federal lobbying laws in contacting US Embassy in Seoul to arrange meetings with South Korean officials; Holbrooke was acting as vice chairman of Credit Suisse First Boston; Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman Jesse Helms intends to make his own determination on matter (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     New-Home Sales   Feb.    TUESDAY     Consumer Confidence   March    WEDNESDAY     G.D.P.(4th Qtr. Rev.)    Factory Orders   Feb.    THURSDAY     Weekly Jobless Claims    Personal Income   Feb.    Construction Spending   Feb.    FRIDAY     Employment   March

headline: Hitachi Faults A Strong Yen For Its Losses
abstract: Hitachi Ltd increases its estimate of its losses for fiscal year that ends March 31 and attributes rise largely to stronger Japanese yen; company expects to lose additional 125 billion yen, or $1.1 billion, bringing its estimated losses to 375 billion yen, or $3.3 billion (M)

headline: Turkish Mayor's Jailing a Sign of Bolder Moves on Opposition
abstract: Former Istanbul Mayor Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who will begin serving 10-month prison sentence on March 26 for subversion, will be most visible victim to date of intensifying campaign against what military commanders and civilian allies call Islamic fundamentalism; he resigned at end of 1998 after conviction for reading poem judged an incitement to religious rebellion; conflict between secular establishment and religious-orinted political parties, which has dominated Turkish politics in recent years, has again intensified; prosecutors are threatening pro-Islamic politicians with political bans, jail sentences and even execution (M)

headline: A Conciliatory Mission
abstract: Iraq's Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz, during visit to Ankara, Turkey, tells Turkish officials Iraq has complied at least partly with UN disarmament resolutions and is ready for dialogue with outside world, including US; any progress in soothing Turkish concerns may have vanished with subsequent threat by Vice Pres Taha Yassin Ramadan to attack Incirlik air base, from which American and British warplanes patrol no-flight zones in northern and southern Iraq (S)

headline: Popular Drug For Diabetes Is Scrutinized
abstract: Food and Drug Administration advisory committee will review Warner-Lambert Co's oral diabetes drug, Rezulin, which has been linked to 28 deaths and liver problems that resulted in seven transplants; analysts do not expect FDA to pull Rezulin from market, but if agency adds new cautions to its label, as expected, that could slow powerful force in Warner-Lambert's sales growth; Rezulin notched $748 million in sales in 1998; Rezulin's sales never surpassed Bristol-Myers Squibb Co's Glucophage, nation's leading oral diabetic pill; Glucophage is associated with 20 deaths during its first million uses, but no liver damage; Glucophage is far less expensive than Rezulin; two treatments similar to Rezulin are awaiting FDA review: Avandia from SmithKline Beecham PLC, and Actos from Eli Lilly & Co and Takeda Chemical Industries; graph (M)

headline: Pope Reported To Plan Visit To Jerusalem Next March
abstract: Israel's Tourism Min Moshe Katsav says Pope John Paul II intends visit Jerusalem in March 2000 to celebrate the millennium, which would be first papal trip to Holy Land since Paul VI visited Jerusalem in 1964; Vatican says trip has not been set, adding that neither date nor itinerary has been worked out (S)

headline: 2 Big Advertisers Consolidate Work
abstract: Glaxo Wellcome PLC consolidates media services account at Media Edge; H J Heinz Co selects Leo Burnett Co to handle brand duties for convenience meal products (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Internet Stocks Propel Nasdaq to Another Record  A further advance in Internet and telecommunications shares helped push stocks higher, lifting the Nasdaq composite index 59.97 points, or 2.5 percent, to 2,408.17, a new high.    Other market averages, which bobbed for much of the session, rallied late. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 14.67 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 9,355.22. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 8.74 points, or seven-tenths of a percent, to 1,252.00. In the bond market, Treasury prices fell as the yield on the 30-year issue rose to 5.14 percent from 5.12 percent. [Page C10.]

headline: Refusing Pleas, European Bank Holds Key Interest Rate at 3%
abstract: European Central Bank leaves interest rates unchanged, resisting political pressure that it cut borrowing costs to counter slowing economic growth in core of Europe; bank keeps its benchmark refinancing rate at 3 percent (M)

headline: Gold Dispute With the Swiss Declared to Be At an End
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore and Swiss Pres Ruth Dreifuss say dispute over disposition of Nazi gold and treatment of Holocaust survivors by Swiss banks is over, news conference, Davos, Switzerland; do not mention Swiss National Bank's failure to take part in settlement, even though more than 80 percent of looted gold Nazis deposited in Switzerland was put in central bank (M)

headline: Nasdaq Passes 2,500 as G.D.P. Rise Revives Profit Hopes
abstract: Stocks advance as Nasdaq index wraps up biggest monthly gain in 24 years, rising 28.55 or 1.2 percent to close at 2,505.89; Dow Jones industrial average closes up 77.55 points at 9,358.83; graph (S)

headline: A Newspaper Publisher Circles the Competition
