abstract: William Dean Singleton's Media News Group Inc has bought up string of small dailies in Southern California, in pincer-like move around dominant paper, Los Angeles Times; Media News's merged operations will have daily circulation of 830,000 statewide--63 percent in Los Angeles area; Media News competes with Los Angeles Times for readership and advertising sales, but they are cooperating on distribution of preprinted circulars; that arrangement is now subject of preliminary investigation by Justice Dept; inquiry is likely to focus on whether alliance amounts to price-fixing arrangement in which advertisers are without real alternatives; photo; map; chart (M)

headline: From Ink Stains to Marketwatch.com
abstract: Larry Kramer, journalist, created Marketwatch.com, on-line financial news service, on a shoestring in 1995; now Marketwatch.com is selling shares to dot-com-crazed public for up to $130 each; Kramer's 200,000 shares are now worth $16 million; photo (S)

headline: Will Beijing's Nuclear Arsenal Stay Small or Will It Mushroom?
abstract: Washington questions whether China's current bare-bones arsenal of missiles and nuclear weapons will grow to become more potent arsenal that could rekindle kind of fears that shaped cold war; suspicion that China stole design of America's most advanced miniaturized warhead from Los Alamos National Laboratory 10 years ago has prompted anger in Washington, especially in Congress; despite continuing evidence of Chinese espionage abroad, most experts doubt China intends to change fundamentally its largely defensive nuclear strategy; experts outside US Government say China wants arsenal large enough to give it global status and deter potential for nuclear blackmail, but small enough so that country will not be bankrupted by its military force, as Russia was; they say China's modernization could accelerate its ability to threaten its neighbors; map (M)

headline: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO ACQUIRE EXCEL FOR $321.9 MILLION
abstract: Dura Automotive Systems Inc agrees to buy Excel Industries for about $321.9 million in cash and stock; will also assume about $153.7 million in debt (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice rebounds from 13-month low; other futures trading results; graph (S)

headline: G.M. and Union Are Near Deal on New Plants
abstract: General Motors Corp and United Automobile Workers union are close to agreement on construction of three new assembly plants in US that will need only a third as many workers as operations they replace (M)

headline: China's Disabled Are Victims of a New Economy
abstract: Many of China's handicapped workers, long employed at simple tasks for modest salaries at subsidized 'welfare factories,' have lost jobs because few such factories can compete in emerging market economy; Government's new efforts to integrate disabled into mainstream work force are running up against legacy of discrimination and neglect (M)

headline: As an Entertainment Play, Liberty Is a Variety Show
abstract: Article on investing in Liberty Media Group, programming arm of Tele-Communications Inc, both of which have been purchased by AT&T (M)

headline: I.B.M. and 3 Others Develop Copy Guard for Audio DVD's
abstract: IBM, Intel Corp, Matsushita Electric Industrial Co and Toshiba Corp say they have developed a way to prevent illegal copying of new music format; companies have created technology standards to 'mark' and code music electronically on audio digital versatile disks, or DVD's; top music companies are backing technology (M)

headline: Recession in Brazil Is Now Official
abstract: Brazil reports its gross domestic product shrank 1.9 percent in fourth quarter from year-earlier period and 1.6 percent from third quarter; second consecutive quarterly drop pushes economy into first official recession since 1992; second-half collapse cut economic growth for 1998 to 0.2 percent, down from 3.7 percent in 1997 (M)

headline: UTILICORP OF KANSAS IN AUSTRALIA UTILITY DEAL
abstract: Australian state of Victoria agrees to sell its Multinet Gas/Ikon Energy natural gas utility alliance to Utilicorp United Inc and Australian financial services group ANP Ltd for $1.25 billion (S)

headline: Armed Serbs Detain 21 Monitors in Kosovo
abstract: United States aide William Walker says Serbian troops detained twenty-one international monitors in Kosovo for 20 hours in violation of their diplomatic immunity; Serbia apparently ignored repeated requests by Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe to free unarmed monitors, who sought to return to base in Macedonia; also bars other monitors from entering Bukos, where Serbian troops apparently carry out major sweep to flush out remaining ethnic Albanian guerrillas; photo (M)

headline: Balloon Crew Has First Global Nonstop in Sight
abstract: Breitling Orbiter 3, having floated some 20,000 miles over Europe, Africa, Asia, Pacific Ocean and Central America, heads into home stretch over Atlantic Ocean in its bid to become first balloon to circle world nonstop; Dr Bertrand Piccard is pilot and Brian Jones is co-pilot; diagram (M)

headline: Kosovo Albanians, in Reversal, Say They Will Sign Peace Pact
abstract: Ethnic Albanians at Kosovo peace talks, Rambouillet, France, reverse stand and pledge to sign peace settlement in two weeks; respond to plea from United States Amb Christopher R Hill, saving peace effort; Clinton Administration officials admit pledge does not give them enough leverage to squeeze Pres Slobodan Milosevic, who opposes NATO peacekeepers in Serbian province; fear Milosevic will try to exploit delay by making inroads against Kosovo Liberation Army; conference organizers say they will reconvene Mar 15; State Sec Madeleine K Albright comments; photo (M)

headline: Turk Hints at New Approach if Rebel Kurds End Violence
abstract: Prime Min Bulent Ecevit says Turkey will consider changing its policies toward Kurdish minority if Kurdish guerrilla movement lays down its arms; says substantial decrease in terrorism would be conducive to improvements and reforms in social, economic and political life of country; blames much of Kurdish violence on Greece and criticizes Greece's recent efforts to shelter Abdullah Ocalan, rebel leader who was captured by Turkish commandos in Kenya; rejects European pressure to grant autonomy or self-rule to Kurdish regions (M)

headline: Treasury to Hold Weekly Auction of Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.75 percent and a six-month bill was 4.48 percent.

headline: Beijing Journal; Writer Rides Dirty Laundry to the Top in China
abstract: Each day An Dun receives a dozen calls from people desperate to spill their deepest secrets, vying to have their private lives laid bare and dissected in her popular weekly newspaper column. Some have become pregnant out of wedlock. Some have been raped by their bosses. Some have been abandoned by their husbands. Others have done the ditching themselves.    In conservative Chinese society, such topics are generally taboo even among close relatives and best friends, and they are certainly not mainstream media fare. But since 1996, when Ms. An started recording matter-of-factly the stories of real people caught in such predicaments, she has wowed the younger generation with her candor and helped to liberate a nation's skeletons from the closet.

headline: Mandela, After Wrangling, Announces June 2 Is Election Day
abstract: Pres Nelson Mandela, after months of wrangling over how to conduct second post-apartheid elections in South Africa, announces that voting will be on June 2 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., -- Denver, a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy Calhoun Beach Club Apartments, a 351-unit property based in Minneapolis, for $79.6 million.    ITT INDUSTIRES, -- White Plains, a provider of industrial manufacturing services, purchased Water Pollution Control Corp., an aeration products and systems designer with annual revenues of $40 million. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against Japanese yen as Japanese central bank pumps money into nation's financial system; in New York, dollar settles at 121.77 yen, up from 120.23 on March 2; graph; chart (S)

headline: Media Talk; A Promise From NBC: Less Emphasis on Sex
abstract: NBC, network that pioneered the sex comedy at 8 PM, promises 'less emphasis on sex'; Scott Sassa, new president of NBC Entertainment, says network's coming programs include more traditional family shows and fewer shows about dating habits of single New Yorkers working in media; photo (S)

headline: Ailing Chief Of Azerbaijan Flies to Turkey
abstract: Pres Heydar A Aliyev of Azerbaijan, becomes ill and is flown to Turkey for treatment; said to be ailing with bronchitis and viral infection (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    UKRAINE: LARGE NUCLEAR DUMP PLANNED -- Europe's largest radioactive dump, with a capacity of 650 tons of waste, is to open next year at the Zaporizhye plant in southern Ukraine. Most of the nuclear waste produced at the plant had been shipped to Krasnoyarsk, in Siberia. But authorities there said last November that they would no longer acccept the waste because Ukraine did not pay enough.   (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Text-to-Speech Programs With Touchy-Feely Voices
abstract: Computer-generated voices are starting to sound more human; classic robotic monotones of synthetic speech are giving way to voices that sound sad, happy, polite, warm and even frightened; manufacturers hope speech synthesizers that sound better will attract customers to range of new devices that talk; drawing (M)

headline: French Bank Seeks to Buy 2 Big Rivals
abstract: Banque Nationale de Paris SA offers $37 billion in stock to acquire two of its biggest French rivals, Societe Generale SA and Paribas SA, which last month agreed to merge; merger would create largest bank in the world (M)

headline: Canada Proceeds With Law To Protect Magazine Industry
abstract: Canadian House of Commons is set to pass legislation that would protect its magazine industry from American competition by making it illegal for advertisers to buy space in 'split run' magazines, which are Canadian versions of publications like Sports Illustrated or People; US officials have threatened to retaliate by imposing tariffs on goods including steel, lumber, plastics, pharmaceuticals, textiles and clothing (M)

headline: Sudanese Foes Agree to Extend Cease-Fire in Famine Region
abstract: Main warring factions in Sudan agree to extend cease-fire in part of country hardest hit by famine (M)

headline: Teaching New Hires to Feel at Home
abstract: Elaborate orientation programs for newly hired executives are beginning to spread because they can greatly reduce turnover; Foodmaker program that introduces executives to corporate culture and operations cited; drawing (M)

headline: Sunday News Gets Bigger
abstract: New York Daily News will introduce several new Sunday magazine sections on Mar 14; they will offer service information, entertainment and cultural reporting; photo of Edward Kosner, Sunday editor (M)

headline: Colt's Best Defense; In Difficult Times, a Gun Maker Tries to Counterattack
abstract: Colt's Manufacturing Co, under new owners after emerging from bankruptcy, is one of many gun makers facing lower demand for handguns and anti-gun lawsuits; Colt's hopes to capitalize on global brand name and diversify away from consumer handguns and toward military small-arms sales; it is also pushing forward new technologies it says will make handguns safer, in effort to blunt criticism and find new customers; Colt executives say they are prepared to abandon handgun business entirely if it becomes impossible to continue making them profitably; domestic production of consumer handguns, rifles and shotguns fell to 3.5 million in 1997, from high of 5 million yearly in mid-1990's; Colt's had profit of $2 million on sales of $96 million in 1997; photo of company's new chief executive, Steven M Sliwa; graph (L)

headline: On-Line Searches For Off-Line Work
abstract: Job hunting on the Internet noted (S)

headline: Monsanto Profit Fell 51% in 4th Quarter
abstract: Monsanto Co reports fourth-quarter earnings of $55 million, down 51 percent, on revenue of $2.1 billion, up 18 percent (S)

headline: Flat TV's, Still for the Fat-Wallet Set, Improve as Prices Fall
abstract: Article on high-quality flat-panel plasma televisions that represent future of television; photos (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 12% Gain in I.B.M. Profit Beats Wall Street Forecast  I.B.M. reported a 12 percent gain in earnings, exceeding Wall Street analysts' estimates by 2 cents a share, as strong gains in software and services offset the economic turmoil in Asia and Latin America and pricing pressure on key products.    For the quarter, I.B.M. reported earnings of $2.35 billion, or $2.47 a diluted share, compared with $2.09 billion, or $2.11 a share. Revenue rose 6 percent, to $25.13 billion. Before the earnings were announced, shares of I.B.M. rose $2.50, to $197. [Page C2.]    Sun Microsystems, one of the biggest makers of computers that run the Internet, said its second-quarter earnings rose 22 percent. [C7.]    Currency and Stocks Fall in Brazil  A day after the Brazilian Congress approved austerity measures perceived by investors as a crucial test of the country's commitment to reduce systematic overspending, its currency and stock market fell, and fears mounted that Brazil is running low on dollars to pay for debts, imports and other expenses. [A3.]    Judge Questions Microsoft Witness  The judge in Microsoft's antitrust trial asked the company's expert witness on economics a series of skeptical questions, suggesting that the software giant may have a difficult time with one of its defenses -- that it does not have a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems. [C5.]    Profit Falls 54% at Bankers Trust  Bankers Trust, posting its next to last earnings report before the expected completion of its acquisition by Deutsche Bank, said its profit in the fourth quarter plunged 54 percent. [C2.]    Promotion Within Insurance Family  Jeffrey W. Greenberg, the eldest son of one of the country's most influential insurance executives, Maurice R. (Hank) Greenberg, was named president of Marsh & McLennan and was designated its next chief executive and chairman. As the eventual chief of Marsh, Mr. Greenberg will be heading a company that mainly arranges insurance coverage for corporations with American International Group, run by his father, and other insurers. [C7.]    Rough Times for Drug Stocks  After soaring 49.9 percent last year, the Standard & Poor's drug index, a bellwether of industry stocks, has become one of Wall Street's laggards. Not only has the index trailed the five-tenths of a percent gain of the Standard & Poor's 500, it has also notched a negative 5.49 percent return this year. Market Place. [C8.]    Two Plead Guilty in Stock Scheme  Two reputed organized crime figures pleaded guilty to charges that they participated in a conspiracy to manipulate the price of a stock in a scheme that the authorities have called the most ambitious yet by organized crime to infiltrate Wall Street. [B6.]    Lucent Earnings Climb 26%  Lucent Technologies said that earnings before charges and gains rose 26 percent in its fiscal first quarter, more than analysts expected, but that sales growth lagged behind forecasts because the company could not complete the paperwork on some orders in time. The shares of the telephone-equipment maker fell $8.875, or 7.7 percent, to $106.625. [C5.]    SBC Communications reported a 17.8 percent increase in fourth-quarter profits driven by growth in services such as caller identification and voice messaging. [C5.]    Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the securities firm, said its fourth-quarter earnings declined 32 percent as trading revenue fell. [C8.]    Exxon, the largest oil company in the United States, said its fourth-quarter income fell 30 percent as crude oil prices plunged and profit from chemical sales fell. [C7.]    Sears, Roebuck's profits fell in the fourth quarter after the retailer took one-time charges and suffered from falling clothing sales. [C7.]    Boeing Close to Settling Bias Suit  Boeing is close to settling a racial discrimination suit brought by hundreds of its workers nationwide, people close to the talks said. [C6.]

headline: Smart Phone Venture to Use Sun's Java
abstract: Sun Microsystems Inc says Symbian, venture of Motorola, Ericsson, Nokia and Psion, will use Sun's Java, only programming language that can run on all computer systems, in software for advanced mobile communications devices (S)

headline: Ailing Yeltsin May Go to Jordan To Show He Is Still in Command
abstract: Ailing Pres Boris N Yeltsin signals he is still in command with plan to lead Russian delegation to funeral of Jordan's King Hussein; trip would be less demanding than diplomatic mission, give Yelsin chance to be seen with world leaders and let him upstage Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov (M)

headline: Andes Battle: Right vs. Left vs. Civilians vs. Troops
abstract: Three decades of political violence and terror in Colombia, in which right-wing death squads and left-wing guerrillas both regard civilians as targets, may be spilling over Colombia's borders; scope of strife appears to be widening, becoming more of a regional problem; as Colombian situation deteriorates, and it bcomems clear that it cannot be resolved simply by Colombians, it may bring neighboring countries together to work out coordinated, sustained reponse; since at least 1996, units of Peasant Self-Defense Forces, Colombia's main right-wing paramilitary group, have made forays into Panama, attacking villages and killing civilians in remote Darien province; assassination of Jaime Hurtado, leader of Ecuadorean Marxist-Leninist party called Popular Democratic Movement, on busy street in downtown Quito on Feb 17 marks new level of violence; map (M)

headline: When Your Rival Is Also The Referee
abstract: Diana B Henriques Market Watch column on regulation of private stock trading services known as electronic communications networks by New York Stock Exchange and National Association of Securities Dealers, with which they compete; cites possible move toward single industry-supported regulatory organization; graph (M)y

headline: Sharing Their Talents and Their Dollars
abstract: Social Venture Partners comprises 135 junior philanthropists drawn from technology companies around Seattle, and they like to apply to their charities the skills they apply to their companies; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Some Detected Warning Signs On Dell's Sales
abstract: Market Place column on the warning signs detected by Daniel T Niles, analyst with BancBoston Robertson Stephens, that Dell Computer Corp would not meet analysts' estimates for the quarter; Dell shares have lost nearly 20 percent of their value since Feb 11; stock falls $7.1875 to close at $81.5625, as 112 million shares traded, third-largest volume for Nasdaq stock ever (M)

headline: Some Communities Span Cradle to Gray
abstract: Small but growing number of retirees are seeking places to live in which they can spend their later years actively involved with other generations; latest trend in community planning is to build places well-suited to such mixing; photo (M)

headline: Regulators Give Green Light to Olivetti's Bid for Telecom Italia
abstract: A $60 billion bid by the No. 2 Italian phone company, Olivetti S.p.A., for Telecom Italia was given a green light to move forward today, when Italian stock market regulators ruled that it was legally admissible.    The ruling came two days after Telecom Italia's chairman, Franco Bernabe, won boardroom backing for what is expected to be a long and bitter corporate battle, unaccustomed for the Italian business world and reminiscent of big American hostile buyouts of the 1980's.

headline: Fast-Track Economy: A Rocky Global Road
abstract: Deborah Stead article on Edward Luttwak's stand in his book Turbo Capitalism: Winners and Losers in the Global Economy that United States economy has become excessively lean and mean; Luttwak holds economy moves too fast to pick up poor or reassure anxious middle class; photo (M)9

headline: Chupa Chups USA Hires Richards
abstract: Chupa Chups USA, part of SA Chupa Chups, names Richards Group to handle creative part of its advertising account, which had been handled by Lois/EJL in Chicago (S)

headline: Cendant Chief Earned $61.1 Million in '98
abstract: Henry Silverman, Cendant Corp chairman and chief executive, earned profits of $61.1 million last year by exercising stock options, more than offsetting cut in his annual bonus to $1.21 million from $2.37 million in 1997 (S)

headline: From Bosnia to Kosovo, U.S. Point Man for Peace
abstract: Profile of Gen Wesley K Clark, NATO's Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, who has become point man for US in efforts to forge peace agreement for Serbia (M)

headline: Air France Shares Jump On First Day of Trading
abstract: Shares of Air France rise 15 percent, airline's first day of trading, as investors bet on company's prospects for growth; shares rise 2.1 euros, to 16.10 euros ($17.76), from offering price of 14 euros (S)

headline: China Reaffirms Drive to Overhaul Bloated State Industries
abstract: Senior Chinese officials reaffirm determination to squeeze dead wood and red ink out of bloated state-owned enterprises, vowing to make nearly all competitive and profitable by end of 1999; Zhu Rongji, reporting on first year as prime minister, says he will press ahead with overhaul and streamlining of bureaucracy despite 'grim environment at home and abroad'; implicitly acknowledges social unrest that has flared as urban unemployment grows and farmers protest taxes and corruption; projects seven percent economic growth for 1999 (S)

headline: New Leader's First Test Lies in Internal Politics
abstract: Crown Prince Abdullah of Jordan, appointed acting monarch by Jordanian Cabinet, faces as his first test internal political challenges rather than foreign affair crises; few analysts expect major political problems in first months of rule, but say he will be forced to move in short order to replace some members of current Cabinet, including unpopular Prime Min Fayez Tarawneh (M)

headline: British Air Buying 9% of Spanish Line
abstract: British Airways will buy nine percent of Iberia (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Trade Officials Warn Of Danger of Steel Quotas  Facing a wave of protectionist sentiment, two top trade officials contended that a House-passed measure to impose quotas on steel imports would hurt the American economy, lead to raw material shortages and rising prices and could set off a trade war.    Speaking before the Senate Finance Committee, United States Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky and Commerce Secretary William Daley said the quotas could disrupt the steel market. In spite of these warnings, the steel industry and some Senators vowed to push for quotas. [Page C6.]

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COTTON FALLS 3.1 PERCENT.  Expectations of a bumper crop and weak exports sent the price lower for the fifth time in eight sessions. The March contract declined 1.88 cents a pound, to 57.89 cents.

headline: A Secretive Army Grows to Maintain Order in China
abstract: China, while shrinking army, is expanding People's Armed Police, more secretive military branch dedicated to internal stability; force, trained in riot control, reflects leaders' growing preoccupation with domestic unrest and wish not to use army combat troops to quell popular demonstrations; has used armed police units over last year to help ordinary police contain many of hundreds of demonstrations reported around nation; protests, almost always centered on economic complaints, have generally been small, and ended peacefully (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: A Battle For the Ears Of Europe
abstract: EUROPE'S big national telephone companies got a warning last week: the first attempted hostile takeover against one of their own.    It will probably be some time before anyone knows whether Olivetti's $58 billion bid for Telecom Italia will succeed. Yet the attempt itself highlights the fact that the European telecommunications industry is engaged in a turbulent free-for-all, where investors have racked up some stunning returns and once-lumbering telephone companies are trading at dizzying heights.

headline: A Wealth of Charity That Eludes Most Counts
abstract: Survey financed by California Communication Foundation finds that 73 percent of Los Angeles residents give to charity, compared with national figure of 68 percent; figures do not include a form of giving that flourishes among Latinos in Southern California, who regularly send money, clothing or food to friends or relatives in other countries (S)

headline: Car Makers Get Strong Start To 1999 Sales
abstract: Auto makers sold new family vehicles at blistering pace in January; with gasoline prices continuing to fall, sales of gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and minivans soared, rising 19 percent at DaimlerChrysler, 20 percent at Ford Motor Co and 32 percent at Toyota Motor Corp; car sales were also brisk after months of weakness (M)

headline: Agency Withdraws From a Review
abstract: DDB Needham Chicago resigns creative and media planning portions of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co's Discover Card credit card account after 10 years by withdrawing from review; billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million (S)

headline: Bombs Kill 6 in Kosovo Markets As Leaders Depart for Paris Talks
abstract: Three powerful bombs exloded in midst of markets in two towns in Kosovo, killing at least six people, including two children, and wounding dozens more; attack comes as leaders of ethnic Albanian majority leave for new round of peace talks with Serbs in Paris; two sides blame each other (M)

headline: MORE ON THE BOMBINGS
abstract: Clinton Explains Decision  The President said he decided to use force because of moral revulsion at the killings in Kosovo and to serve American interests. Page A15.    Serbs Turn Back to Loyalty  Even the Serbs most bitterly opposed to President Slobodan Milosevic feel a surge of nationalism at a threat from the West. Page A14.

headline: Fight Over Fish Poaching Stirs Up Icy Southern Sea
abstract: MELBOURNEâ€”  Bitterly cold, terrifyingly remote and frequently lashed by gale force winds and mountainous waves, the Southern Ocean seems an unlikely Eldorado for poachers.

headline: Machine Tool Orders Fall
abstract: Industry survey shows orders for machine tools fell 4 percent in December, third consecutive month of declining orders (S)

headline: U.S. Ignores Mexico's Anti-Drug Failures
abstract: Clinton Administration officials praise Mexico's record on fighting illegal drugs this year even while admitting publicly that that record is bad by most statistical measures; yearly 'certification' process has become in the case of Mexico more of a joint public-relations campaign aimed at Congress than an objective appraisal; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Behind Olivetti's Move: Cellular Explosion
abstract: Olivetti's decision to acquire Telecom Italia, company five times its size, represents one of biggest hostile takeover attempts by any company; some analysts question wisdom of move, saying it will lead to asset stripping by selling off Telecom businesses; other analysts say potential for turning Telecom into leaner, more efficient phone company gives Olivetti's plan inner logic; Franco Bernabe, Telecom chairman, is trying to persuade Italians that Olivetti's bid would fatally weaken Telecom and lead to massive layoffs (M)

headline: It's Like Typing Class, but You Set the Rhythm
abstract: Mavis Beacon Teaches Typing, instructional software from Mindscape, assessed; photo (M)

headline: Swiss Guard Corporal Killed Chief, Vatican Report Affirms
abstract: Report by Vatican concludes that 23-year-old Swiss Guard Cedric Tornay fatally shot superior Alois Estermann and wife, Gladys Meza Romero, in April 1998 and then committed suicide; say drugs and illness may have played role in murders (S)

headline: Israel Court Weighs Legality Of What Many Call Torture
abstract: Israeli Supreme Court weighs legality of methods used by Shin Bet security service to interrogate Palestinians, methods called torture by United Nations, Amnesty International and other human rights groups; began hearing petitions by prisoners and human rights groups year ago, but has held only three sessions, last ending in indefinite delay; is reluctant to rule on matter Chief Justice Aharon Barak says should be regulated by law (M)

headline: Economists Foresee a Stumble in Uzbekistan's Stride
abstract: A striking new look has crept into this capital of Soviet-era concrete blocks, where a half-dozen swank hotels, office buildings and a theme park that people call ''Mini Disneyland'' are open or under construction.   The change is puzzling, because hotel rooms are not scarce here; guests are. And the potential foreign tenants for prime new office space, who initially flocked to the country, have been deserting Uzbekistan's closed economy for two years.

headline: German Stock Market Soars As Leftist Fiscal Chief Quits
abstract: Germany's financial markets soar one day after abrupt resignation of Oskar Lafontaine as Finance Minister; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder struggles to keep his five-month-old government from collapsing; names Hans Eichel to succeed Lafontaine; photo (M)

headline: Kosovo Peace Plan Takes Shape As Russia Prods Serbs on Troops
abstract: Broad shape of agreement to end ethnic conflict in Serbian province of Kosovo emerges, with Russia playing key role at talks in Rambouillet, France, to persuade Serbs to allow NATO peacekeepers on their territory; French Pres Jacques Chirac says Russians, traditional ally of Serbs, feel ground force in Kosovo is best solution to stopping bloodshed in separatist province and that Russian soldiers are likely to be part of deployment; photo (M)

headline: Saipan: Where Oasis Has Many Meanings
abstract: American lawyers see it one way, Chinese workers another. According to a class-action lawsuit, the garment workers of Saipan are ill-treated and underpaid for inhumanly long days in sweatshops. The suit portrays them as just short of slaves.    But on Saipan, an American territory where United States law and Chinese culture meet, the Chinese workers stitching and pressing clothing for American companies find work is not a prison, but an opportunity to take home money.  Article, page A3.

headline: Bill Sale Is Sole Item on Treasury Schedule
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.35 percent and a six-month bill was 4.35 percent.

headline: Profit Rose 26% Last Year for Audi
abstract: Volkswagen AG's Audi unit reports 1998 profit rose 26 percent, to 463 million marks ($258 million); predicts slower growth in 1999 (S)

headline: Auditors Given New Rules To Prevent Bias
abstract: Independence Standards Board says auditors must disclose any relationships they have with public companies they audit that could weaken their independence; new rule, effective in July, is first to come from board, which was created by Securities and Exchange Commission in 1997 because of concerns about growing number of ties between some auditors and their clients; board is considering proposal to prevent auditors from going to work for their audit clients for period of time (M)

headline: Lycos Board Member Quits to Protest Deal
abstract: David S Wetherell, who controls largest block of Lycos Inc stock, resigns from Lycos board to protest proposed deal between Lycos and USA Networks Inc; Wetherell is chairman of CMGI Inc, investment fund that owns 18.5 percent of Lycos; Lycos agreed last month to complex transaction in which it would gain control of Home Shopping Network and Ticketmaster units of USA Networks; it would also acquire Ticketmaster Online Citysearch; in return, USA would gain control of 61.5 percent of Lycos shares (M)

headline: U S Airways Plans Buyback Of $500 Million in Stock
abstract: US Airways Group says it will buy back $500 million in stock to lift its lagging shares; also says its first-quarter earnings will be in line with analysts' recently reduced forecast (S)

headline: Head of Porsche Opposes Possible Aid for Rover
abstract: Porsche AG chairman Wendelin Wiedeking says he plans to send letter to European Commission's cartel officer, Karel van Miert, to stop plans to give subsidy to Rover, ailing British unit of BMW AG (S)

headline: Israel Cuts Terms of 5 Jews Who Killed or Tried to Kill Arabs
abstract: Pres Ezer Weizman of Israel commutes sentences of five Jews serving long prison terms for murder or attempted murder of Arabs; move draws harsh criticism from Palestinian offcials and lawmakers from Israeli opposition, who accuse Government of double standard; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu has refused to release Arab prisoners with 'blood on their hands' as part of interim peace accords with Palestinians, and he has routinely accused Palestinian Authority of freeing Arab terrorists (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    TURKEY: REBEL WARNING TO TOURISTS -- The Kurdistan Workers Party, a guerrilla group that is said to have been behind recent bombings that have killed at least 14 people in Turkey, said it would ''step up the war'' and might attack ''areas seen by the Turkish Republic as tourist areas.'' A German Government spokesman said he took the warning very seriously, and a British spokesman said the safety of tourists could not be guaranteed.    Stephen Kinzer (NYT)

headline: Israel Arrests 8 U.S. Cultists Who Expect Apocalypse
abstract: Israeli police officials arrest eight American members of Denver-based Concerned Christians apocalyptic cult, who reportedly planned to mark millennium by committing suicide or provoking their own killings in streets of Jerusalem; cult members disappeared early in fall 1998, emptying houses and leaving Colorado without trace; reportedly planned to destroy themselves shortly before millennium in order to hasten Second Coming of Christ; photo (M)

headline: Multi-Use Service Is Introduced by AT&T
abstract: AT&T Corp introduces service that lets businesses combine voice, video and data traffic on one phone network; service will compete with similar products from MCI Worldcom Inc and Sprint Corp (M)

headline: AT&T to Offer Single Rate For All Users
abstract: AT&T Corp will offer long-distance and wireless service at single rate of 10 cents a minute on a single bill; joining the plan will cost about $30 a month; new price would yield big savings for people who make even fair number of wireless calls; AT&T is hoping that leads to acceleration in already-exploding use of wireless phones; and after AT&T completes acquisition of Tele-Communications Inc, cable-television provider, it intends to include local telephone service--using TCI's cable wires--into new plan; chart (M)

headline: Ex-Police Chief Recounts His Beating of Anwar
abstract: KUALA LUMPURâ€”  Abdul Rahim Noor, the police chief who beat Anwar Ibrahim in September, offered for the first time his account of the incident in testimony Tuesday that sharply contrasted with that of police officers who witnessed the beating as well as with Mr. Anwar's account.

headline: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES ADDING 2 FRENCH BOTTLERS
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises acquires privately owned Coca-Cola bottling operations in southern France for about $100 million; companies are Sud Boissons SA and Societe Boissons Gazeuses de la Cote d'Azur; company will have rights for all of France except Corsica when deal closes (S)

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS; From Texas, With Love and Peanuts
abstract: Profile of no-frills Southwest Airlines, based in Texas, which has started offering low fares, frequent service and humor on flights from Islip, Long Island; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar falls 6 percent on expectations that Brazil, world's top grower, will process more crops for export, adding to swollen stockpiles; in New York, sugar for May delivery falls 0.35 cent, to 5.5 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: ABC to Move Top Management From New York to Los Angeles
abstract: ABC will move more than 200 of its employees, including most of its top management, from New York to Los Angeles within next 18 months; moves are intended to consolidate management of network at headquarters of Walt Disney Co, ABC's parent; decision involves 240 positions at ABC, about 5 percent of its work force, but only 211 employees will be affected because other 29 positions are vacant; move reaches even network's top executive, Patricia Fili-Krushel, president of network; Robert A Iger, president of ABC Inc, will be based in both New York and Los Angeles (M)

headline: Sears P.L.C. to Give More Cash to Holders
abstract: Sears PLC will return more money than previously planned to shareholders; Sears will return 215 million pounds ($353 million) to shareholders on or after April 6, more than 84 milion pounds it previously indicated; payments comes as Sears tries to dampen takeover speculation after rejecting proposed offer by Philip Green's Medinbond Ltd; Sears is selling its Creation credit card business to Groupe Cofinoga and Banque Nationale de Paris for 141 million pounds (S)

headline: U.S. Starts Push to Salvage Kosovo Talks
abstract: Clinton Administration unleashes what it hopes wil be speedy diplomatic offensive to salvage Kosovo peace proposal in effort to avoid reprise of last inconclusive round of talks; officials hope to have ethnic Albanians' agreement pinned down by time talks are scheduled to resume Mar 15, and to know exactly where main impediment to settlement, Pres Slobodan Milosevic, stands; Administration has enlisted former Sen Bob Dole, champion of ethnic Albanian cause, to go to Kosovo to try to persuade ethnic Albanians to agree to settlement they balked at signing week ago; Milosevic has denied Dole visa to enter Yugoslavia; Dole plans to meet with ethnic Albanian leaders in Macedonia instead (M)

headline: DELTA SAYS IT WILL SELL 119 PLANES TO PRATT & WHITNEY
abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc says it will sell 119 Boeing 727's and 39 spare jet engines to Pratt & Whitney in what Delta calls biggest-ever sale of used aircraft; Pratt & Whitney will market planes through partnership with Republic Financial Corp, which will convert them to cargo carriers; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: U.S. Fires Scientist Suspected Of Giving China Bomb Data
abstract: Energy Sec Bill Richardson says Wen Ho Lee, Taiwan-born scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory, was fired for security breaches after FBI questioned him in connection with China's suspected theft of US nuclear secrets; accuses Lee of 'stonewalling' investigation; Lee has not been charged with crime, but he has been identified by Federal officials as prime suspect in spying; China denies any such theft; Sen Fred Thompson criticizes Clinton Administration for failing to notify Congress in 1997 that China had stolen nuclear secrets when Administration certified that Beijing was no longer helping other nations build nuclear bombs (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cocoa rebounds from five-year low; cocoa for May delivery rises $11, to $1,187 a metric ton; graphs; table (S)

headline: Political Battle: What to Reveal On China Arms
abstract: Clinton Administration and Congressional committee are wrangling over how much to make public of committee report on China's acquisition of sensitive American military technology; bipartisan committee found China harmed national security over last 20 years by stealing nuclear secrets and acquiring other American technology; dispute is taking on more partisan tone, providing ammunition for critics of Pres Clinton's China policy in days before key United States-China talks; committee members comment (M)

headline: 2 Mexican Banks to Plead Guilty in Laundering Case
abstract: Grupo Financiero Bancomer SA and Grupo Financiero Serfin SA, two of Mexico's biggest banks, will plead guilty to criminal charges of money laundering in move bringing swift end to most important legal cases stemming from major investigation into movement of illegal drug profits; will forfeit millions of dollars seized by Govt and pay fines of $500,000 each; outcome is triumph for group of Federal prosecutors, Justice Dept officials and US Customs Service who resisted strong pressure from both Mexican Govt and banks to have charges dropped (M)

headline: FORD TO TAKE $630 MILLION IN FOURTH-QUARTER CHARGES
abstract: Ford Motor Co will take $630 million in fourth-quarter after-tax charges for loss on sale of its stake in Kia Motors Corp, early retirement programs and new joint venture; will take pretax charge of at least $250 million for North American and European job cuts and sale of its Kia stake (S)

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES SNARLED AS PILOTS DEFY COURT ORDER
abstract: Defying a Federal judge's order to end their protest and return to work, more pilots called in sick at American Airlines yesterday, forcing the carrier to cancel more than half of its flights and insuring that its operations would be crippled during the Presidents' Day holiday.     The disruption at American, which entered its sixth day, continued to upset the plans of tens of thousands of travelers and businesses around the world. The airline, the nation's second largest, said that it had already canceled 500 flights scheduled for today, a number that it said would most likely rise, because planes are out of position. Passengers will have fewer alternatives because most airlines are expected to be full. [Page C4.]

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    GERMANY: U.S. TO HAND OVER SPY FILES -- The United States has agreed to hand over East German foreign intelligence files believed to include lists of the names of agents who spied for East Berlin, the German Government said. The files were bought by Central Intelligence Agency agents nearly 10 years ago in the aftermath of the fall of the Berlin wall. Bonn has repeatedly asked the agency to return the files, which it says are vital for identifying public figures who spied on their fellow citizens.   (Reuters)    RUSSIA: ENVIRONMENT IMPROVES -- Environmental conditions in Russia have improved in recent months because of the fall in industrial production since the August financial crisis. Viktor Danilov-Danilyan, head of the state committee for the environment, said industry now gives off 35 percent less air pollution than in 1991, and 15 to 18 percent less water-borne and other pollutants.   (Reuters)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RESOURCES INC., Toronto, a mining company, said it had terminated its agreement to buy 50 percent of a Chilean copper mine from Finland's Outokumpu Oyj for $265 million (United States).    URBAN SHOPPING CENTERS INC., a real estate investment trust, said it was negotiating to buy the Century City Shopping Center on the west side of Los Angeles from Chicago-based Urban Shopping and RREEF, for about $250 million.    APPLE COMPUTER INC., Cupertino, Calif., confirmed it would move production of its iMac computer from its Irish plant to a plant in Wales.

headline: France to Sell 17% Stake in Airline
abstract: France says it will sell 17 percent stake in Air France by early Feb in initial public offering (S)

headline: Anti-Apartheid Cleric Sentenced to 6 Years for Embezzlement
abstract: South African Judge John Foxcroft sentences former anti-apartheid activist Allan Boesak to six years in prison for stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars donated to help needy children and educate black voters (M)

headline: ACE TO BUY CIGNA UNIT FOR $3.45 BILLION IN CASH
abstract: Ace Ltd agrees to pay $3.45 billion in cash for property and casualty businesses of Cigna Corp (S)

headline: Geeks Breathe a Sigh of Relief At the Reincarnation of Byte
abstract: Byte, indispensible magazine for those known affectionately as computer geeks, folds in print form for lack of advertising, but comes back on on Internet; Jerry Pournelle, longtime Byte columnist, is writing more than ever, no longer constrained by paper and printing costs; photo (S)

headline: Saving for a College Education, Made Easier
abstract: AROUND report card time, there is no anxiety in the Brooklyn household of Lincoln and Marlene Nixon. Their son, Khari, 7, always has high marks and is ranked in the top percentile in both reading and math.    But the Nixons do feel anxiety about the tax season, because of the usual bill from Uncle Sam; it averages roughly $1,000 a year, on top of the taxes withheld from their paychecks. The tax liability often makes it tough to save for their children's education. They would like to increase the monthly allotment for a fund they set up for their son's college education and to begin a similar fund for their daughter, Kamila, 4.

headline: Forget Taiwan Missile Shield, China Warns
abstract: Wang Daohan, China's chief negotiator on Taiwan, attacks proposal under consideration in US to deploy missile defense system; contends that if it was used to protect Taiwan, it would provoke arms race (M)

headline: U.S. Warns Of A-Alert If Computers Misread Year
abstract: US urges Russia to set up joint missile-warning center before end of year to reduce risk that Year 2000 computer problem might touch off false nuclear alert; proposal is part of broader effort to prevent millennium bug from disrupting Russian systems used to warn of enemy attack and to maintain control over nation's vast nuclear arsenal (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: STOCKS -- Japan Lowers Key Rate, but (Surprise) Bond Yields Go Higher; U.S. Treasuries Fall, Sending Stocks Down
abstract: US bond prices drop sharply, pushing interest rates to highest levels since last August; selling is touched off by rising yields in Japan; surge in interest rates also pushes stocks down; yield on 30-year Treasury bond jumps to 5.42 percent; Dow Jones stock average falls 88.57 points, closing at 9,274.89 (M)

headline: Stock Prices Fall As an Internet Selloff Continues
abstract: Stock prices fall, led by Internet and other technology issues; Dow Jones industrial index drops 71.83 points, to 9,264.08; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 21.46 points, to 1,235.16; Nasdaq composite index falls 70.77 points, to 2,344.72; graph (M)

headline: Profit at Exxon Down 30%; Low Crude Oil Prices Cited
abstract: Exxon Corp reports fourth-quarter net income of $1.53 billion, down 30 percent, on revenue of $29.7 billion, down 15 percent; cites sharply lower crude oil price and decline in profit from chemical sales (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.75   5.09   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.42   4.44   5.04        6-month T-bills   4.44   4.47   5.07        10-yr. T-infl.   3.79   3.80   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.97   5.01   5.48        30-yr. T-bond   5.39   5.34   5.83        Telephone bd.   6.88   6.93   7.09        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.16   5.16          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: FINOVA GROUP TO BUY SIRROM CAPITAL WITH STOCK
abstract: Finova Group will acquire Sirrom Capital Corp for about $379 million in stock (S)

headline: $116 Million Punitive Award Against Aetna
abstract: Jury in San Bernardino County, Calif, Superior Court awards $116 million in punitive damages to David Goodrich's widow, Teresa, who contends her husband died after subsidiary of Aetna Inc, nation's largest health insurer, delayed approving treatment for stomach cancer that its own doctors had recommended; lawyers on both sides call it largest such verdict against health maintenance organization; Aetna says it is confident that damages will be overturned on appeal, as will finding by jury, which awarded $4.5 million in actual damages in 1995 death (M)

headline: Prosecution Almost Rests in the Microsoft Trial
abstract: Prosecution's antitrust case against Microsoft Corp nears end; it is increasingly clear that case in indictment not only of business practices of world's dominant software maker but also of its corporate character; witnesses have portrayed Microsoft as bullying monopolist; photos of Goverment's lead lawyer, David Boises, and Microsoft lawyers, John L Warden, William H Neukom and Richard Urowsky, and Microsoft chairman, William H Gates (M)

headline: PROVIDIAN ACQUIRES GETSMART.COM FOR $33 MILLION CASH
abstract: Providian Financial Corp, nation's biggest issuer of credit cards backed by deposits, acquires Getsmart.com, which operates Internet site where consumers can apply for loans, for $33 million in cash (S)

headline: FEDERAL EXPRESS PILOTS EXPECTED TO APPROVE CONTRACT
abstract: FDX Corp's pilots are expected to approve first labor contract at Federal Express (S)

headline: Nascar Waves Techies Away From Track
abstract: Drivers on National Association of Stock Car Auto Racing (Nascar) circuit are using computers to enhance performance of their cars; however, Nascar limits use of this technology to manufacturing and test drives; drivers like two-time defending Nascar champion Jeff Gordon discuss how computers enable them to reach new performance highs; Nascar officials say ban on use of on-board computer is aimed at keeping sport affordable and, more important, human; photos of Gordon and his race crew; computer diagnostic of race car's performance (L)

headline: VLSI REJECTS PHILIPS'S $17-A-SHARE OFFER
abstract: VLSI Technology Inc formally rejects $777 million bid from Royal Philips Electronics NV as inadequate (S)

headline: C.I.A. Sees a North Korean Missile Threat
abstract: CIA Dir George Tenet warns Congress that North Korea is on verge of developing ballistic missiles that could hit continental US 'with large payloads,' and appears to be working on producing nuclear weapons; tells Senate Armed Services Committee in annual security review that he 'can hardly overstate' concern about volatile situation, with background of famine and political instability in North Korea; his photo; Tenet also warns that Russia is backsliding on commitments to curb transfer of advance missile technology to Iran (S)

headline: BP Amoco Will Not Join Iran Oil Venture
abstract: BP Amoco PLC says that it will not join $19 million venture to explore for oil in Iran with Royal Dutch/Shell Group and Lasmo PLC but that it is still interested in operating in Iran; BP Amoco says it wants to avoid work in disputed waters of Caspian Sea claimed by both Iran and Azerbaijan (S)

headline: LG Will Let Hyundai Take Lead on Chips
abstract: LG Group, bowing to Government pressure in South Korea, agrees to allow Hyundai Group to run merged computer business; Pres Kim Dae Jung, who had imposed financial sanctions on LG to force end to dispute over which company will control business, extracts pledge from LG's chairman Koo Bon Moo to give control to Hyundai (M)

headline: 2 Days of Treasury Auctions This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills and a sale tomorrow of a 52-week bill and a 19-day cash-management bill.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.38 percent and a six-month bill was 4.35 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill was 4.47 percent.

headline: American Airlines Urges Contempt Citation for Union
abstract: American Airlines asks Federal Judge Joe Kendall to hold pilots' union in contempt for continuing sickout in face of court order; Kendall delays ruling, but warns union to get pilots back to work; photo of Allied Pilots Assn president Rich LaVoy (S)

headline: Aggressive Competitor Outside of Britain
abstract: Article on Britain's Vodafone Group PLC in light of its acquisition offer for Airtouch Communications; says company has grown to be Britain's leading mobile phone company by employing aggressive mixture of foreign expansion and domestic price-cutting in furiously competitive market (M)

headline: Ex-Livent Officials, Now in Canada, May Not Make Court Date
abstract: Garth H Drabinsky and Myron I Gottlieb, Canadians who founded Livent Inc, say through their lawyers that they will not come to Manhattan to face criminal fraud charges brought against them by US prosecutors; Federal prosecutors had asked two men to turn themselves in and confront charges they masterminded scheme that defrauded Livent's investors out of tens of millions of dollars while lining their own pockets; Drabinsky's lawyer, Edward L Greenspan, says his client believes it would be 'very difficult' to get fair trial in US; US prosecutors will quickly file papers in Canadian courts to extradite them; that process could take many months; Royal Canadian Mounted Police is also investigating case, but that probe is expected to take more than a year (M)

headline: Argentina May Suffer Most From Neighbor's Ills
abstract: Analysts say Argentina is likely to be rattled most severely from Brazil's devaluation of its currency and that other countries bordering Brazil will be shaken more than Mexico, where ties to US economy would cushion the shock; photo (M)

headline: More Foreign Papers
abstract: Letter from Hugo Stangeon Mar 4 article on foreign newspapers available on Web (S)

headline: Fed Sees Continuing Strong Growth With Low Inflation
abstract: Regional survey by Federal Reserve, commonly known as the beige book report, indicates economy's run of strong growth and low inflation shows few signs of changing; outlook is based on reports from Fed's 12 district banks; report cites rising consumer spending, higher vehicle sales, expanded manufacturing, gains in construction and pickup in business lending as evidence that eight-year economic expansion continues; map showing regions covered in report (M)

headline: AMERICAN MEDIA SELLS RIGHTS TO 2 SOAP OPERA MAGAZINES
abstract: American Media Inc ends publication of Soap Opera News and Soap Opera Magazine and sells two publications' trademarks to Primedia Inc; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: B-2's Debut: 4 Warplanes Join Strikes
abstract: B-2 stealth bomber, most expensive and intricate aircraft ever built, finally makes its combat debut; Defense Dept officials say four have taken part in air strikes on Serbia (S)

headline: Cross-Media Deals Mean Bonanzas for Publishers
abstract: Tom Brokaw and Peter Jennings, anchormen on NBC's and ABC's nightly news programs, are broadcasting segments from books they have written on their nightly news programs; this is part of intensifying trend in publishing industry, which by necessity is searching for new ways to grow by reaching readers through unconventional outlets or through publicity they could not afford without alliances; one of oddest corporate matches is Coca-Cola Co's campaign to give away book excerpts for six novels in 45 million packages of diet soda; Thomas B Rosenstiel, media critic, does not think ethical questions are raised about news shows being used by networks or news anchors to promote their books; photos (M)

headline: Japan Money Supply Rises
abstract: Japan's most-watched measure of money supply rises at annualized rate of 4.8 percent in February, faster than expected pace (S)

headline: DURA AUTOMOTIVE TO BUY BRITISH AUTO PARTS MAKER
abstract: Dura Automotive Systems Inc to buy Adwest Automotive PLC for $210 million and assume $210 million in debt (S)

headline: East Timor Seems Suddenly to Be on Verge of Independence
abstract: Clinton Administration and foreign diplomats welcome Indonesian Pres B J Habibie's statements favoring independence for East Timor, but fear that if break is too sudden it could lead to chaos and even civil war as Timorese factions maneuver for power; maps (M)

headline: Recoil, Then Recovery
abstract: Brazil's plan to devalue its currency initially deflated the confidence of stock investors in the United States and abroad. But after a sharp selloff in the first half-hour of trading, American stocks rebounded steadily throughout the day.     Business Day, page C1.

headline: Paris Journal; In 25 Years, Pen Has Hit Ripe Targets
abstract: Article on Plantu, popular political cartoonist for Le Monde, who lampoons French politicians; notes that Plantu, whose real name is Jean Plantureux, began working for French newspaper in 1972; photo (M)

headline: Internet Auto Seller Plans to Offer Stock
abstract: Autobytel.com Inc, which operates Web site for buying new and used vehicles, revives plans for initial public stock offering, more than one and half years after canceling earlier plans; company files with Securities and Exchange Commission to raise about $72 million by selling 4.5 million shares for estimated $16 each (S)

headline: American Topics : Not Much but Nostalgia Left Of the Catskills Borscht Belt
abstract: For decades, predominantly Jewish crowds flocked to the green mountains and grand hotels of the Catskill Mountains north of New York City for fresh air and caustic jokes, big bands and mountains of all-you-can-eat food: rib steaks, blintzes and borscht (hence the nickname, the Borscht Belt). "It was like New Year's Eve every night," said Jackie Horner, a dance instructor in one of the big hotels. "We danced all day and danced all night, then we danced some more."

headline: Accord in Ecuador Can't Hide Woes
abstract: Ecuador, despite political accord announced by President Jamil Mahuad that ended two weeks of strikes and political turmoil, remains as divided and economically vulnerable as ever; many Ecuadoreans see agreement, which ended state of emergency and rolled back gasoline prices in exchange for opposition support for other austerity measures, as nothing more than short-term solution; photo; map (M)

headline: WILLIAMS-SONOMA GUIDE TO GOOD COOKING
abstract: Eric Asimov reviews Williams-Sonoma Guide to Good Cooking, a CD-ROM cookbook; photo (M)

headline: Microsoft Denies That It Is Developing a Language Similar to Java
abstract: Microsoft Corp plays down report it has been briefing software developers on new programming language similar to Sun Microsystems Inc's Java software, but free of technological or licensing obligations to Sun; Sun recently won court order blocking Microsoft from shipping products containing Microsoft's own version of Java, which Sun says was altered to work only with Microsoft's Windows operating system (M)

headline: In a Tiny Office, Khmer Rouge Files Tell Grisly Tales
abstract: Dozen Cambodian researchers sit at computers in tiny office in Phnom Penh, processing hundreds of thousands of documents that form core of potential legal case against leaders of Khmer Rouge; photo (M)

headline: Out of the Frying Pan and Into the Desktop
abstract: Eric Asimov on merits and drawbacks of CD-ROM cookbooks; reviews four titles: Joy of Cooking, Williams-Sonoma Guide to Good Cooking, The Complete Interactive Cookbook and The Complete Mastercook Suite; photos (L)

headline: Across Euroland, Echoes of a Devaluation
abstract: Interview with Mark Howdle, Salomon Smith Barney European equity strategist, on outlook for European markets; photo (M)

headline: Newly Merged Chrysler Loses 2 Executives To Rival Ford
abstract: DaimlerChrysler Corp senior vice presidents Shamel T Rushwin and Chris P Theodore join Ford Motor Co, latest of several departures by executives at former Chrysler Corp since its merger in November 1998 with Daimler-Benz AG (M)

headline: British Officials: 'Large Volume of Refugees Fleeing From Their Villages'
abstract: Excerpts from news conference by British Foreign Sec Robin Cook and Gen Sir Charles Guthrie, chief of Britain's Defense Staff, on plight of ethnic Albanian refugees fleeing Serbian province of Kosovo (M)

headline: In 90 Minutes, 60 Planes Are Launched
abstract: Description of scene in Aviano, northern Italian air base that is launching pad for many of NATO aircraft striking Yugoslavia; 60 planes are launched in 90 minutes (S)

headline: Sitting Pretty With Zero Down
abstract: Innovative mortgage arrangement developed by Merrill Lynch and offered by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter allows home buyers to use stock as collateral without putting any cash down; photo of Robert Cramer, attorney who bought $965,000 home in Malibu Beach with $400,000 in stock collateral, and no down payment; graph (S)

headline: Schwab Says Profit Will Beat Forecasts
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp says its first-quarter earnings will exceed analyst estimates by as much as 30 percent, doubling income in period year earlier; Schwab says it will earn $130 million to $140 million, or 31 cents to 34 cents a diluted share in quarter; analysts had esimated 26-cent-a-share gain (S)

headline: A Major Player Goes on Line
abstract: Appraisal of Web Turbotax, which handles Federal returns as well as those from any one of 44 states, for those filing taxes electronically (S)

headline: Haris Journal; Iranian Snapshot: Idle Townsmen, Hocus-Pocus
abstract: Touring showmen and magicians are still fixture in depressed Iranian towns like Haris, where unemployed men have little else to entertain them; map; photo (M)

headline: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
abstract: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?

headline: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
abstract: Ian Austen evaluates Velo News Internet site on cycling (www.greatoutdoors.com/velonews) (M)

headline: Belgrade 'Targets' Find Unity 'From Heaven'
abstract: Bombing of Yugoslavia by NATO warplanes has bred sense of solidarity among residents of Belgrade, cosmopolitan capital, pulling city further away from Europe into isolation, uniting Serbs behind their soldiers, their Kosovo and even Pres Slobodan Milosevic; residents say they have been united from heaven by bombs, not by God; angry mobs trash American Center, British Council, Goethe Institute and French Cultural Center; many residents wear 'target' logo that has swept city in gesture of contempt toward NATO; Govt is urging citizens to run to air raid shelters for 12 or 15 hours each day, understanding that collective panic provides sense of solidarity with nation and its military; photos (M)

headline: Two Approaches To Tax Resentment
abstract: Deborah Stead reviews books Hide Your Assets and Disappear by Edmund J Pankau and The Greedy Hand: How Taxes Drive Americans Crazy and What to Do About It by Amity Shlaes; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; All is right with the world (well, not so bad, at least), and U.S. Treasuries are in the doldrums.
abstract: Market Place column on US Treasury market, which is the doldrums after being fine performer in 1998; says it may take another rush of panic about world's economy and global financial stability to turn things around (M)

headline: Russia and U.S. Urge Kosovo Talks; Albright Weighs Troops
abstract: Russia and US call on combatants in fighting in Kosovo, Serbia, to hold talks toward achieving political settlement; US weighs use of force but Russia is opposed; Clinton Administration officials say joint statement, issued on second day of visit to Moscow by Sec of State Madeleine K Albright, will be helpful in showing Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic that he cannot automatically count on Russians for support (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Several Lawsuits Challenge Internet Ads
abstract: Some fundamental assumptions of Internet advertising are being challenged in recent round of lawsuits; in one, Playboy Enterprises is suing Netscape Communications and Excite in effort to keep banner ads for pornographic, non-Playboy sites from appearing when Web surfers use either Netscape or Excite to look for material with key words 'playboy' or 'playmate'; selling advertisers access to co-called key words, such as competitor's brand name, is widespread in Internet business; photo (S)

headline: Art on the Head of a Microchip
abstract: Some computer chip designers mark their work with drawings; Michael Davidson, research scientist with Natural Magnetic High Field Laboratory, has photographed more than 60 chip designs and made them available through his laboratory's Web site (microscopy.fsu.edu); photo of chips with drawings (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen improves as bond yields rise and expectations spread that exporters and banks will convert foreign assets into yen, increasing demand; dollar falls to 113.49 yen from 114.35; graph; chart (S)

headline: Help for Schools
abstract: Letter from Michelle Longosz on donating old computers to schools (S)

headline: Shorting With Agouron
abstract: Short-sellers reduce their stake in Agouron Pharmaceuticals from 20.5 percent in mid-December to 12.1 percent by mid-January, thus reducing losses they faced with Warner-Lambert's agreement to acquire company for $60 a share in stock (S)

headline: NATO LAUNCHES DAYTIME STRIKE; MILOSEVIC RESISTING FIERCELY; TWO SERB JETS ARE SHOT DOWN
abstract: NATO forces step up thier air and missile assault into daylight hours as Pres Slobodan Milosevic maintains fierce resistance both on ground and in the air; two of his MIG-29 fighters are shot down while on what NATO claims was foray into neighboring Bosnia; sweep by Serbian troops through ethnic Albanian villages continues unabated, despite third straight day of air assaults that alliance officials say are succeeding and will remain unrelenting until Milosevic accepts peace; Pres Clinton seeks to appeal directly to Serbian people in televised statement, beamed by satellite throughout region, in which he denounces Milosevic; photos (L)

headline: 157 Homes Burned in Religious Clash in India
abstract: Hindus and Christians clash in eastern Indian state of Orissa, and 157 of 250 Christian homes are burned down; officials say they presume that Hindus set fires, but have no solid evidence (S)

headline: Filmmaking, Minus the Camera
abstract: J D Biersdorfer reviews interactive CD-ROM from Electronic Vision on how to make a movie; photo (M)

headline: Controlling City Limits
abstract: Nonprofit group Sprawl Watch Clearninghouse is formed following January conference among 40 foundations on effort to manage urban sprawl; photo (S)

headline: From Poetry to Newspapers, MP3 Fare for the Literary Set
abstract: Audible Inc offers literary fare for downloading in MP3 format; many of Audible's Web site offerings are free, making this first time books not in public domain are legally available for download in MP3 format (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: De Novo Corp acquires Creative Solutions International and Convergence Group (S)

headline: Russian Biologist Denies Work in Iran On Germ Weapons
abstract: Dr Valery Bakayev, Russian biologist in Iran, denies conducting research that could have helped Soviet Union or Iran develop germ weapons; says while he worked at Pasteur Institute in Teheran for more than five years, work focused solely on civilian development of vaccines against diseases and on other nonmilitary research (S)

headline: Auto Makers Up On Merger Rumors
abstract: Shares in Honda Motor Co and Nissan Motor Co rise sharply in Tokyo stock market on rumors that auto makers may be acquired by foreign competitors; autommotive executives call rumors untrue (S)

headline: San Luis Potosi Journal; Mexico's Troubadors Turn From Amor to Drugs
abstract: Hundreds of Mexican country bands sing lyrics that chronicle drug traffickers' daily lives and violent routines; extraordinary popularity of their music in Mexico and in United States underscores profound roots drug industry has sunk into North American popular culture, suggesting that millions of fans quietly admire smugglers' fabled wealth, anti-establishment bravura and bold entreprenuerial skills; photo of popular band singing in San Luis Potosi about a rooster, parrot and goat, code words for drugs; map (M)

headline: Sony to Propose a Method For Protecting Digital Music
abstract: Sony Corp will propose new copy protection method designed to enable recording industry to sell music safely, both on line and on digital formats like CD's and audio DVD's; Sony is responding to growing threat of digital music piracy via the Internet; its proposal is first such method to be submitted to industry standards group, Secure Digital Music Initiative, which was established last month by Recording Industry Assn of America (M)

headline: Sonat to Take a Charge
abstract: Sonat Inc, oil and natural gas exploration company, will take first-quarter charge of about $200 million to write down value of reserves because of low energy prices (S)

headline: Scandinavian Merger Unites 2 Food Makers
abstract: Danish food and packaging group Danisco A/S and Cultor Corp, Finland-based food products concern, agree to merge in transaction that values Finnish group at $1.41 billion (US); partners do not specify how control of merged group's equity will break down (S)

headline: SPENDING TO AVERT EMBASSY ATTACKS ASSAILED AS TIMID
abstract: Adm William J Crowe Jr claims State Dept is so frightened of seeking money from Congress that United States embassies could be left vulnerable to terrorist attacks; Crowe, retired Chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, led probe of bombings of two American embassies in Africa last summer; says embassy security budget that State Dept requested, $3 billion over five years, is less than half the amount that two expert panels have recommended; says he thinks there will be more attacks, and more lives lost; Crowe is apparently angry at Clinton Administration for failing to act quickly on crucial recommendations of report he prepared for State Dept on African bombings; senior department officials insist that budget requests would significantly improve security and that additional money will be requested shortly; photo (M)

headline: Business; Playing 'The Price Is Right' With Windows
abstract: Economist Robert E Hall and his son, software developer Chris Hall, analyze prices of Microsoft products with regard to antitrust suit against company; most of Government's case turns on whether Microsoft has monopoly power over price of its operating system, but question is why that price is not higher; arguments on both sides noted; photo; graph (M)

headline: Marius Schoon, 61, Is Dead; Foe of Apartheid Lost Family
abstract: Marius Schoon, opponent of apartheid who had been fighting amnesty application by police spy who killed Schoon's wife and daughter with mail bomb, dies at age 61; photo (M)

headline: Group Rethinks Ratings on Year 2000 Readiness
abstract: Global 2000 Coordinating Group, composed of over 230 international banks, securities companies and insurers, weighs retreat from plans to publicly rate readiness of over 30 nations to avoid major Year 2000 computer disruptions; fears inadvertently causing capital flight and destabilizing some large developing nations; other groups are already providing country ratings, but Global 2000 effort raises concerns because of worldwide financial influence of its members (M)

headline: Internet Service Is Planning $6 Billion Deal to Buy Excite
abstract: Home Network, high-speed Internet service, plans acquisition of Excite Inc, leading Internet destination, in deal worth approximately $6 billion; merger would be one of biggest in flurry of recent Internet acquisitions; would strengthen At Home's position in competition for destination sites that are increasingly defining Internet; would sharpen position of AT&T, At Home's major shareholder; under agreement, Excite shareholders would receive about 30 percent of At Home in stock transaction involving issuing of new shares; resulting company would be named At Home; Excite's chief executive George Bell would become At Home board member and would take executive position in combined company (M)

headline: DATABANK: February 1-5; A Lovers' Quarrel With Technology Issues
abstract: Investors, long enamored of technology stocks, had a sudden change of heart last week, and chip makers and computer-related companies tumbled, sending the tech-nology-heavy Nasdaq composite index down 132.27 points, or 5.3 percent, to 2,373.62. Intel, Cisco Systems and Microsoft were all down for the week.     The broader market was also off, but not nearly so much. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 9,304.24, down 54.59 points, or 0.6 percent. Low unem-ployment figures and other buoyant economic news led to worries that the Federal Reserve, which left rates unchanged last week, might soon nudge them up.

headline: Cambodia Spurns U.N. Plan For Khmer Rouge Tribunal
abstract: Cambodia, after months of wavering, officially rejects United National recommendations to convene tribunal to try surviving senior Khmer Rouge leaders, seeming to kill any chance of international court (M)

headline: Geek Elite: Gadgets They Use
abstract: PC Forum 99 conference in Scottsale, Ariz, has attracted 800 of world's technological elite, people who envision, finance and make products and services used by those who buy new technologies for technology's sake; those attending forum describe their own favorite gizmos and gadgets, including their dependence on cell phones and pagers; drawing (M)

headline: Even Hedge Funds Have a Heart
abstract: Hedge Fund Care, group of hedge fund managers, brokers, lawyers and accountants, will hold charity banquet in New York to aid abused children (S)

headline: Clinton Defends His Policies In Kosovo, China and Mexico
abstract: Pres Clinton, citing need for American leadership in face of globalization, defends his efforts to cooperate with Mexico in fighting drugs, to engage with China to spur political freedom and to threaten force to bring peace to Kosovo, speech, San Francisco; lists regions and issues where he plans to use United States troops, trade, aid and cooperation to advance goals (M)

headline: Gateway Will Give a Year Of Net Access With Computers
abstract: Gateway, in clearest evidence yet that the Internet is the main catalyst for PC sales, says it will now include year's worth of Internet access in the price of nearly all new computers it sells (S)

headline: Joining the Club, and Profiting
abstract: Abby Ellin Preludes column on steady increase in number of investment clubs being formed by younger professionals; drawing (M)

headline: Business & Investing; Buying In to 'Communicopia,' a Rich New Data Landscape
abstract: Richard P Simon, media analyst at Goldman, Sachs, and Oscar A Castro, co-manager of Montgomery Global Communications fund, answer questions on how investors should respond to convergence of data and voice communications, entertainment programming and economic commerce; photo (M)

headline: 2 Proposed Italian Bank Combinations Win Favor of Market
abstract: Share prices of Banca Commerciale Italiana, sought by Unicredito Italiano, and of Banca di Roma, sought by San Paolo-IMI, rise, reflecting investors' delight with premiums buyers will pay to gain greater size in Italy's fragmented banking industry; deals are confined to national boundaries as big mergers across European borders largely remain blocked by political interests, labor union resistance and rigid bank ownership structures (M)

headline: People
abstract: Monica Karo, media director at TBWA/Chiat/Day, is named corporate media director, succeeding Stacey Lippman (S)

headline: CNL GROUP TO MERGE 18 OF ITS PARTNERSHIPS
abstract: CNL Group Inc reaches agreement to merge 18 partnerships it manages and other assets into $1.5 billion real estate investment trust; combined company would own or have investments in more than 1,400 fast-food and casual dining restaurant properties (S)9

headline: 'Quality Time' on Two Fronts
abstract: Diane McManus letter, responding to February 28 article on parents' career obsessions, says friendships also suffer as result (S)

headline: Politically Correct Mergers; Europe's Deal Frenzy Tends to Stop at National Borders
abstract: Merger wave sweeping Europe includes very few cross-border deals; many of mergers seem aimed at keeping foreigners, epecially other Europeans, at bay; many are explicitly promoted on nationalistic grounds; Europe's biggest cross-border deals have been with American companies; table; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks to End 'Mixed Messages' Over Lockerbie Suspects
abstract: Clinton Administration asks Secretary General Kofi Annan to handle all communications with Libya about turnover of two suspects wanted in 1988 bombing of Pan American flight in Lockerbie, Scotland; also asks Annan to discourage efforts by envoys from Saudi Arabia and South Africa to give Libya further assurances about trial, treatment of suspects or sanctions if men are handed over; decision to narrow mediation effort reflects growing concern that Col Muammar el-Qaddafi might be receiving 'mixed messages,' in form of assurances that neither United States nor Britain would agree to (M)

headline: Reuters to Cut Workers In Britain and Ireland
abstract: Reuters Group PLC will cut 5 percent of its work force in Britain and Ireland to lower costs; Reuters will cut just under 100 of 2,100 jobs as it replaces some traveling support staff with phone services for smaller clients; Reuters is cutting jobs in its TV division as it relies more on computers (S)

headline: Britain and F.B.I. To Look Into Slaying Of Lawyer in Ulster
abstract: Northern Ireland police chief Ronnie Flanagan says British police and agents from Federal Bureau of Investigation will probe possibility of police collusion in killing of Rosemary Nelson, prominent Roman Catholic human rights lawyer, by car bomb placed by Red Hand Defenders--Protestant splinter group dedicated to destroyng Northern Ireland peace agreement approved 10 months ago to end 30 years of sectarian violence; photo (S)

headline: Astra to Reacquire Rights to Several Drugs
abstract: Astra AB reacquires rights to certain drugs from Schering-Plough Corp for about $800 million (S)

headline: Monitor of the Olympic Mettle
abstract: Article on effort by John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance president and chief operating officer David D'Allesandro, who is leading corporate drive to clean up modern Olympics in wake of Salt Lake City bribery scandal; photo (M)

headline: Property Trusts Plan to Merge In Stock Swap
abstract: Real estate investment trusts Duke Realty Investments Inc and Weeks Corp to merge their operations, creating company with market value of about $5.4 billion; combined company will be called Duke-Weeks Realty Corp (S)

headline: Board Ousts BMW Chief and His Heir
