abstract: FRANKFURTâ€”  - The maker of BMW autos announced the departures of its two top executives Friday in a rare German boardroom revolt that analysts said was triggered by heavy losses at the company's British Rover auto-making subsidiary.

headline: How U.S. Hit a Snag In the Kosovo Talks
abstract: The Clinton Administration appears to have walked into the Kosovo peace talks without a clear idea of what to do if the ethnic Albanians failed to follow the script.    The Administration expected the Kosovo Albanians to accept NATO troops as their protectors, allowing it then to press the Serbian leader to sign an accord. But it didn't turn out that way as the Kosovo Albanians, who want independence from the Serbs, balked at a deal for autonomy.

headline: Teotihuacan Journal; An Ancient Sun Melts Mexico's Modern Stresses
abstract: Multitudes of Mexicans flock to pyramids and sacred shrines of pre-Colombian ancestors on March 21, communicating with cosmos and soaking in force from sun that forbears venerated in celebration of last spring equinox before millenium; are responding to millenium's approach, pained by economic crises and political scandals, by summoning spiritual reserves and turning to mystical beliefs; largest celebration takes place at stately ruins at Teotihuacan, city founded 1,900 years ago and became flourishing religious capital before fading mysteriously in seventh century; maps; photos (M)

headline: SKYMALL SHARES PLUNGE AFTER CHIEF EXERCISES OPTIONS
abstract: Skymall Inc shares plunge after chief executive, Robert M Worsley, exercises options to buy 2.4 million shares held by company's co-founder, Alan Ashton, and his wife, Karen, for $17.6 million, 74 percent discount; Worsley also buys 518,000 shares held by Bert Getz at discount; now owns 54 percent of shares outstanding (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cable Deregulation Raises Specter of Higher Rates  Cable television, one of the last industries to have its prices controlled by the Government, is set to become almost completely deregulated this month. But while the prospect of competition was supposed to drive prices down, the opposite has happened. Cable rates continue to rise, with many companies announcing increases for this year averaging 5 percent, more than twice the projected inflation rate.    The Telecommunications Act of 1996 assumed the cable industry would be facing far more competition from satellite broadcasters and telephone companies. But that has not happened, raising deep concerns that cable companies unshackled from price controls and not threatened by competition will continue to impose big rate increases. [Page A1.]

headline: Saying No to Summer Panic Brings a Winter of Content
abstract: Mutual funds industry turned in superior performance in final quarter of 1998 in dramatic comeback, with average diversified stock fund returning 18.8 percent--highest for any quarter since 1982; buoyed by Federal Reserve whose interest rate cuts clearly reflected more concern about world recession than about fueling stock prices, market rewarded overwhelming majority of fund investors who sat out midyear turbulence or used it to pick up bargains (M)

headline: British and Irish Leaders Try to Calm Fears Over Ulster Peace
abstract: Irish and British leadership and highest-ranking officials in Northern Ireland move to allay fears that peace effort in Ulster is crumbling; effort has been stalemated over dispute between Roman Catholic and Protestant leaders on issue of disarming overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army; Seamus Mallon, Deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland Assembly, calls for compromise retreat from brinkmanship that could collapse peace effort (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities trading results; orange juice futures surge 1.9 percent; table; graphs (S)

headline: Microsoft Will Alter Its Software In Response to Privacy Concerns
abstract: Microsoft Corp moves to defuse potentially explosive privacy issue, saying it would modify feature of its Windows 98 operating system that has been used to create vast data base of personal information about computer users; Microsoft in effect concedes that unique identifying number used by Windows and other Microsoft products has potential to be more invasive than traceable serial number in Intel Corp's new Pentium III computer chip, feature that has privacy advocates up in arms; Microsoft contends that option to collect information was added to software so that company's support employees would be able to help users diagnose problems with their computers; denies company ever intended to use data for marketing purposes (M)

headline: New Round of Job Cuts Planned at BASF
abstract: BASF AG will cut further 1,000 jobs at its main plant in Ludwigshafen, Germany, as part of long-term drive to keep plant viable (S)

headline: Deal Said to Be in Works That Would Free Hacker
abstract: Kevin D Mitnick, perhaps nation's most notorious computer hacker, reaches plea agreement with Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles that could pave way for his release from prison; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE  GERMANY: BAN ON A-FUEL LIFTED -- Germany will drop a ban on reprocessing spent nuclear fuel abroad in a proposed law to phase out nuclear power, the Environment Ministry said. British and French reprocessing companies had threatened to seek payment if Germany broke contracts under a measure pushed by Environment Minister Jurgen Trittin, who is a leader of the Green Party.   (AP)

headline: Halifax Offers Plan For Capital Return
abstract: Halifax PLC announces plans for 1.5 billion pounds ($2.5 billion) capital return, overshadowing otherwise respectable 3.6 percent gain in 1998 pretax earnings; move is aimed at bolstering Halifax's return on equity; reports that 1998 pretax profit rose to 1.71 billion pounds from 1.65 billion pounds a year earlier; graph (S)

headline: A Less Apparent Heir
abstract: Ana Patricia Botin resigns as executive vice president of Spain's largest bank, Banco Santander, one day after newspaper identifies her as 'most powerful woman in Spain'; Botin is daughter of Santander's chairman, Emilio Botin; photo (S)

headline: Jubilation in Turkey, and a Fierce Debate
abstract: Jubilation envelopes Turkey following capture of Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan, but debate over his forthcoming trial has already begun to turn bitter; foreign leaders and human rights groups urge Turkey to give Ocalan chance to defend himslf; photos (M)

headline: Access to Lots of Gadgets Could Be at Your Fingertips
abstract: People using new Siemens technology will need the right touch to unlock their laptops, power up their PDA's and make calls on their cellular phones; specifically, each user will need to touch the device with a finger so it can recognize the fingerprint as being the correct one (S)

headline: . . . But Twilight Cloaks Russia
abstract: Russia's extravagant hopes for Western-style capitalism are now buried in financial collapse and mood of bitter disappointment; country is more divided than ever about whether to embrace the West and its models or to remain apart, wrapped in the solace of its own historical peculiarities; Russians do agree that Pres Boris N Yeltsin has betrayed their trust; photo of statue of Feliks Dzerzhinsky, founder of KGB, being taken down seven years ago; Parliament has voted to put statue back; photo of tax policeman confiscating goods in Moscow (M)

headline: Top Ethnic Albanian Rebel Asks NATO to Start Strikes
abstract: Suleyman Selimi, general commander of Kosovo Liberation Army, calls on NATO to carry out air strikes on Serbia to put end to violence, as Yugoslav Army and police forces continue ransacking and burning villages; special Serbian police units continue setting houses and farm buildings ablaze in village of Poljance; maps; photos (M)

headline: Qwest's Chief Executive Gets Added Post
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc names its president and chief executive, Joseph Nacchio, as chairman; his new title will be chairman and chief executive; Philip Anschutz, largest shareholder, will continue to head company's board (S)

headline: Pretax Profit Off 15% For SAP in Quarter
abstract: SAP AG reports fourth-quarter pretax profit fell 15 percent, to 712 million marks ($421 million), down from 834 million marks in 1997 period; 1998 net income rose 14 percent, to 1.05 billion marks; shares rise nearly 6 percent on news (S)

headline: Media Talk; Group Settles Suit Against Writer
abstract: DARE, drug prevention group, settles and dismisses its $10 million libel lawsuit against writer Stephen Glass over fabricated articles he wrote about organization for New Republic and Rolling Stone magazines (S)

headline: NATO Warning to Yugoslav: Another Hollow Threat?
abstract: Analysis of disarray in Western response to Serbian attacks in Kosovo; presence of 700 unarmed international monitors makes immediate NATO bombing unlikely and spurs search for face-saving compromise with Pres Slobodan Milosevic (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Murdoch is said to be pushing for a merger of British Sky Broadcasting and Canal Plus.
abstract: Canal Plus SA of France acknowledges that it has held 'conversations' with Rupert Murdoch's media group, but industry analysts are overwhelmingly skeptical that two companies will merge their pay-television operations; stocks of both Canal Plus and British Sky Broadcasting jump on word that Murdoch is pushing for merger; Murdoch's News Corp owns 40 percent of B Sky B (Market Place column) (M)

headline: To Speed Up, Typists Slowed Down
abstract: Origin of Qwerty typewriter keyboard recalled (S)

headline: India Gives Rushdie a Visa to Return, and Muslims Quickly Warn of Protests
abstract: Salman Rushdie is granted visa to return to India, his native land; country's banning of his novel The Satanic Verses in 1988 began chain of events that led to death threats by offended Muslims and a life in hiding; decision to allow Rushdie to return is made in highest reaches of Indian Government, but various Muslim leaders protest and make veiled threats about his safety if he does return (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: U.S. INDUSTRIES, Iselin, N.J., a diversified industrial management company, said its board had approved a share buyback plan for up to $100 million of the company's outstanding stock.    3COM CORP.,  Santa Clara, Calif., a network equipment maker, said it hadbought Smartcode Technologie, Montpellier, France, a wireless technology developer, for $17.5 million in cash.

headline: Bank of England Cuts a Key Interest Rate
abstract: Bank of England cuts key interest rate as Britain's economy continues its slide toward recession; cut, by a quarter of a percentage point, to 6 percent, still leaves British rates double those for 11 nations taking part in new single currency, the euro (M)

headline: MENTOR GRAPHICS ABRUPTLY DROPS QUICKTURN BID
abstract: Mentor Graphics Corp abruptly drops its unsolicited offer for Quickturn Design Systems Inc, clearing the way for Quickturn to merge with Cadence Design Systems Inc in stock swap valued at about $268 million (S)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.63   5.04   5.35        3-month T-bills   4.36   4.38   5.05        6-month T-bills   4.40   4.42   5.07        10-yr. headline: Sunset for Cape Town Vigilantes?
abstract: Article on People Against Gangsterism and Drugs, violent Muslim anti-drug group in Cape Town, South Africa, that is suspected of killing 25 drug dealers and police captain, wounding police superintendent and carrying out series of bombings; public acceptance of group, which emerged in 1996 in crime-ridden Cape Flats neighborhood and was accorded Wyatt Earp status because of police ineptitude, has soured because of its misdirected violence and open rejection of Government; city, which once had crime rate far lower than Johannesburg's, is currently locked in three-way war between organization's vigilantes, drug gangs that have become more powerful and police; photo (M)

headline: Steep Increases Seen In Charges for Drugs
abstract: Patients are facing steep increases in out-of-pocket charges for prescription drugs. Standard co-payments are often doubling for drugs that patients have been using for years. But even bigger increases, of 300 percent or more, are appearing for some remedies that are not on insurers' lists of approved drugs.    In many cases, insurers are refusing to endorse more costly new versions of life-sustaining drugs when cheaper alternatives exist.    Article, page A18.

headline: When the Government Plays Investor
abstract: Gretchen Morgensen column holds that Pres Clinton's plan to invest $700 billion of Social Security trust fund's reserves in stock market in flawed because it leaves investment decisions to Government; says history shows that public investors do not behave as profitably as private investors do; graph (M)

headline: The Name of the Almighty
abstract: Joshua Kaplan letter on Dec 31 review of Jewish sacred texts on CD-ROM; notes he must bury, not discard, section because it contains screen shot of holy name (S)

headline: Luanda Journal; In Angola's Capital, Life Does Not Yet Imitate Art
abstract: Unraveling of Angola peace accord and return of civil war threatens Luanda's cleanup effort; expanding military budget, corruption and more war refugees are likely to overwhelm limited city services; photo (M)

headline: Abovenet to Split Stock
abstract: Stock of Abovenet Communications Inc rises more than 32 percent after company says it will split its shares 2 for 1 (S)

headline: Israeli Parliament Deals Setback to Non-Orthodox Movements
abstract: Efforts by Conservative and Reform Jewish movements to gain official recognition in Israel suffers setback when Israeli Parliament passes bill intended to bar non-Orthodox Jews from country's powerful religious councils; bill, whose practical effect remains to be tested, has fueled debate over religious pluralism and role of religion in Jewish state; leaders of small Conservative and Reform movements, who have been chipping away at Orthodox control of religious affairs in Israel, warn legislation will cause rift with Jews abroad, most of whom are not Orthodox (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.81   5.10   5.57        3-month T-bills   4.53   4.57   5.05        6-month T-bills   4.55   4.58   5.10        10-yr. T-infl.   3.86   3.86   3.71        10-yr. T-note   5.31   5.38   5.77        30-yr. headline: Iraq Still Trying to Conceal Arms Programs, Report Says
abstract: Report to Security Council by chief UN arms inspector Richard Butler accuses Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein, who has barred return of arms inspectors, of still actively trying to conceal past and present illegal weapons programs; says Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz is among handful of officials close to Hussein who devised and still run concealment effort; other findings discussed (M)

headline: U.S. Hammers At Microsoft's Browser Deals
abstract: Microsoft Corp vice president Cameron Myhrvold acknowledges in Federal court that company's contracts prohibited Internet service providers from offering its browser on same Web page as its main competition, Netscape Communications Corp, because Microsoft executives 'thought we would lose in a side-by-side choice'; admission pleases Government lawyer David Boies so much so that he asks same question four different ways and gets same answer each time (M)

headline: Reduced Pay Increase Reported at Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp agrees with its union to raise salaries by an average of 7,600 yen ($64) a month starting in April, according to financial daily Nihon Keizai Shimbun (S)

headline: Moscow Court Weighs Jehovah's Witnesses Ban
abstract: Moscow court weighs ban on activites of Jehovah's Witnesses, one of fastest-growing proselytizing religious groups in Russia, for allegedly inciting religious discord; case is closely watched by religious and human rights groups as first significant effort to use 1997 law curbing nontraditional denominations (M)

headline: A campaign for Miller Lite goes back to basics and beyond the appeal to younger consumers.
abstract: Miller Brewing Co is making abrupt about-face by ending campaign for flagging Miller Lite beer brand; campaign generated contentious debate over its unconventional content, which attempted to appeal to younger consumers with offbeat entertainment rather than product pitches; replacement campaign begins March 5 with commercials taking more traditional, broadly directed and product-oriented approach; campaign is being produced by Fallon McElligott (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.82   4.82   5.52        3-month T-bills   4.47   4.46   4.94        6-month T-bills   4.50   4.48   4.97        10-yr. T-infl.   3.91   3.89   3.67        10-yr. T-note   5.19   5.16   5.55        30-yr. T-bond   5.56   5.55   5.86        Telephone bd.   7.28   7.29   6.97        Municipal bds.   5.23   5.22   5.27          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Lusty New Papers Take On the Powerful in Mexico
abstract: Alejandro Junco de la Vega is shaking Mexico's power elite through the newspapers he owns in country's three largest cities, Reforma in Mexico City, Mural in Guadalajara and El Norte in Monterrey; has fought freedom-of-information battles with top industrialists, Supreme Court, political parties, even Pres Ernesto Zedillo and his predecessors; acknowledges that key to survival is selling newspapers and advertising; growth of his media empire causes some concern that it may smother rivals that have also pioneered quality papers in regional cities; photo; map (M)

headline: A Canadian Rousts Diplomacy (and Ruffles the U.S.)
abstract: Canada's Foreign Minister, Lloyd Axworthy, has made waves during his three years in office, often by running up against United States; Axworthy bristles at suggestion that he or his initiatives are anti-American, but he refuses to consider United States 'the indispensable nation' that Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright has declared it to be; Axworthy feels that even though US is world's only superpower, countries like Canada can set the pace; photo (M)

headline: A Science Fiction Game Jumps From Video to the Big Screen
abstract: Wing Commander, science fiction video game created by Chris Roberts, spawns movie of same name, which Roberts directed; this marks first time video game creator has also directed movie based on game (S)

headline: Futures Trading Firm Files for Bankruptcy
abstract: The Griffin Trading Company, a Chicago futures trading firm, filed for bankruptcy on Wednesday after some $10 million in losses by a London trader left Griffin unable to meet its obligations, the firm's lawyer said today.    Griffin, a member firm at the Chicago Board of Trade since 1976, sought to liquidate its assets under Chapter 7 of the United States Bankruptcy Code in a Federal court filing on Wednesday, said Ty Fahner, co-chairman of the Chicago law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt.

headline: HEWLETT-PACKARD TO SELL NEW ORACLE COMPUTER SYSTEM
abstract: Oracle Corp and Hewlett-Packard Co plan to announce that Hewlett-Packard will become first computer maker to sell Oracle 8i Database Appliance, which include both hardware and software; system is intended to simplify complexity of running corporate computers by hiding operating system function and offering computer that is tailored to single application (S)

headline: Contract to Apollo Metals
abstract: Apollo Metals PLC wins 10-year contract worth about 500 million pounds ($813 million) to provide metal for British Aerospace PLC's military aircraft (S)

headline: On Russia's Far East Fringe, Unrealpolitik
abstract: Politics takes a turn toward farce in Vladivostok, far eastern Russian port, which has become an object lesson in how hard it can be to raise a democratic society out of ruins of Soviet empire; a power struggle is being waged by autocratic Governor of Primoriye region, Yevgeny Nazdratenko, and Viktor Cherepkov, the highly eccentric mayor of Vladivostok until he was ousted from office in December; Cherepkov claims extrasensory perception; Nazdratenko has received a mysterious $1 million prize for leadership from World Aristocratic Academy, an organization whose only known address is a post office box in the Bahamas; photos; map (M)

headline: Digging Into Berkshire Turns Up a Best Seller
abstract: Second printing is expected for the pioneering research report on Berkshire Hathaway written by Alice D Schroeder of Paine Webber (S)

headline: For Neighborhoods in Many Cities, Virtual Community Centers
abstract: E.Central, Denver, offers neighborhoods in 11 metropolitan areas access to Internet tool that residents can use to communicate among themselves and with local governments; system, called Neighborhood Link (www.neighborhlink.com) sets up on-line neighborhood Web sites that include Web pages for the neighborhood association and for other groups and individuals; Ted Pinkowitz, head of E.Central, says sites are catching on slowly and that in Denver, 285 neighborhood associations have begun using their Web pages; idea behind Network Link is not unique and there are similar sites in other regions of country; photo (M)

headline: Nigerian Ex-Ruler Captures Lead in Race for President
abstract: Gen Olsegun Obasanjo, who earned international esteem by becoming Nigeria's first military ruler to give up power voluntary, wins nomination of country's leading political party as its presidential candidate; move sets stage for his return to position he held 20 years ago, but as democratically elected President; he vows to make Nigeria great again; photo (M)

headline: New campaign by Merrill Lynch puts the bull out to pasture, sort of, in favor of higher sentiments.
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co is beginning new ad campaign showing company's employees and executives are as devoted to furthering 'human achievement'--as theme of ads proclaim--as they are to selling stocks, offering financial advice and making deals; $75 million campaign was developed by J Walter Thompson New York (M)

headline: With Euro, Europe Reinvents Itself
abstract: Eleven European nations open for business on Jan 4 with new common currency: the euro; it is political and economic achievement that seemed impossible and even quixotic as recently as three years ago; photos (M)

headline: In a Parish in Peru: The Priest, His 2 Sons and a Very Angry Bishop
abstract: Roman Catholic Church hierarchy threatens to suspend all charitable donations to tiny town of Morrope, Peru, because its Catholic priest, Rev Jorge Arbanil Rico, has two teenage children whom he fathered years after he entered priesthood; local Bishop has forbidden him from baptizing or marrying; Arbanil Rico is unrepentant; against orders of church hierarchy, he offers Mass in town cemetery and in streets; this is first time in modern Peruvian history that priest has defied Roman Catholic hierarchy by continuing to practice priestly functions while openly admitting to having broken vow of celibacy; Arbanil Rico's case is not unique; there are other Peruvian priests with children, but these other would-be rebels received quiet acquiescence of their local bishops; photo; map (M)

headline: Clinton Moves to Support Jordan, Trying to Speed Up Aid Delivery
abstract: Pres Clinton moves swiftly to show American support for Jordan as Cabinet makes historic transfer from ailing King Hussein to son, Crown Prince Abdullah; will seek to accelerate delivery of $300 million in financial assistance and will press international lenders to ease foreign debt burden (M)

headline: The Bottom Line
abstract: Orrin Riley letter supports Mark Hulbert's February 21 article on investors who avoid selling losing stocks offers another reason for doing so (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PFIZER INC., -- New York, the maker of the anti-impotence pill Viagra, said it would hold a vote in April that could authorize a 3-for-1 stock split.    EQUIFAX INC., -- Atlanta, a provider of financial information services, will repurchase $275 million of its stock, or about 5 percent of the company's 144.4 million shares outstanding.

headline: Amid Political Interference, The Euro Has Yet to Foster A Unified Monetary Policy : Initial Luster Of New Money Begins to Fade For Europe
abstract: Two months after its rollout into the market, the euro is well into the process of becoming a no-longer-new-currency. The long haul is setting in.

headline: HCC INSURANCE CANCELS 'GROSSLY INADEQUATE' CENTRIS BID
abstract: HCC Insurance Holdings Inc withdraws its unsolicited $156.2 million takeover bid for Centris Group Inc, a few hours after Centris rejects offer as 'grossly inadequate' (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: THE EURO FALLS.  The dollar rose against the euro after Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the United States economy was ''the envy of the world.'' In New York, the euro traded at $1.12350, down from $1.13310.

headline: Microsoft Rests Its Case, Ending On a Misstep
abstract: Microsoft Corp rests its case in Government's landmark antitrust suit, but not before presiding Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson shouts angrily at company's final witness, Robert Muglia, and orders him to stop talking; incident is yet another blow in several months of missteps and embarrassments as Microsoft has tried to defend itself against Government's charges that company bullied computer industry and used its monopoly in computer operating systems to disadvantage of competitors; court will reconvene in mid-April for several weeks of testimony from rebuttal witnesses (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.88   4.76   5.47        3-month T-bills   4.42   4.38   5.10        6-month T-bills   4.42   4.41   5.08        10-yr. T-infl.   3.79   3.78   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.92   4.94   5.64        30-yr. T-bond   5.34   5.35   5.94        Telephone bd.   7.00   7.01   7.17        Municipal bds.   5.14   5.15   5.21          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: $3.5 Million Bonus for Chief of Philip Morris
abstract: Geoffrey C Bible, chairman and chief executive of Philip Morris, receives $3.5 million bonus from his company's compensation committee for his participation in talks that led to $206 billion settlement between cigarette makers and 46 states; proxy statement reveals other officers of company also received larger bonuses because Philip Morris's worst fears were allayed when settlement became official (M)

headline: U.S. Aides Meet With 'Inflexible' Milosevic
abstract: Senior American diplomats, Amb Christopher Hill and James Pardew, have an almost entirely unproductive four-hour meeting with Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, telling him he must meet Western demands to ease Kosovo crisis or face NATO military action; Milosevic denies any Serbian forces were responsible for killing of 45 ethnic Albanians in Racak; he does agree to allow William Walker, head of monitoring mission, to remain; photo of people returning to homes in Racak (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil futures prices fall amid expectations that warm weather will cut demand; crude oil for March delivery falls 25 cents, to $12.44 a barrel; graphs; table (S)

headline: U.S. Presses Air Attacks on Iraq In a Low-Level War of Attrition
abstract: US air strikes on Iraq on almost daily basis have turned into equivalent of low-level war, hitting wide range of military targets, some of which pose little immediate threat to American or British pilots; jets have pounded more than dozen targets in north and south over last four days, including newly assembled missile site that could threaten ships in Persian Gulf; targets over last month include more batteries than were hit during four nights of intensive strikes in December; new war of attrition is meant to keep Saddam Hussein in check, and is taking out his air defenses 'piece by piece'; Iraq remains defiant, even offering bounty for downing of jet or capture of pilot; Iraqi missiles open fire in north and in Fao Peninsula south of Basra; map; diagram (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINCOCHET DEFENSE RESTS -- Lawyers for the Chilean Government concluded their case in the House of Lords, Britain's highest court, saying Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 83, should be freed and sent home. Spain is seeking the extradition of the general, Chile's former dictator, on charges of murder, torture and hostage-taking. A ruling could come by next week.   (AP, Reuters)

headline: Indonesia Talks of Leaving Timor, and Both Sides Are Nervous
abstract: Indonesian authorities and East Timor's pro-independence group, with little in common, agree that sudden withdrawal of Indonesian security forces would lead to more violence in former Portuguese colony; security has worsened sharply in last two months as military arms several thousand anti-separatist paramilitary troops; map (S)

headline: Surging Internet Stock's Trading Halted for a Time
abstract: Nasdaq exchange temporarily halts trading of Broadcast.com, a Dallas Internet company, after a more than 70 percent jump in price of its shares, then allows trading to resume even though company declines to comment on what might have caused surge (M)9

headline: For Fidelity, Hedge Funds Have Become a Class Issue
abstract: What does the mutual fund industry need? Emboldened and more effective fund directors, says Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, who hosted a conference in Washington last week on the topic.    But Robert C. Pozen, chief executive of Fidelity Management and Research, the fund company, had his own suggestion at the conference's first panel discussion: A clampdown on hedge funds, the largely unregulated investment partnerships that manage more than $200 billion that might otherwise be invested with companies like Fidelity. The lack of Federal hedge fund oversight is a ''total abdication,'' Mr. Pozen said, costing Fidelity and other fund families precious stockpicking talent that has opted to go to hedge funds, with their bigger paychecks.

headline: Death Taboo Weakening, Japan Sees 1st Transplant
abstract: Doctors in Japan, for first time, perform legal heart transplant striking at taboo on taking organs from patients whom Japanese traditionally do not consider dead; operation on man in 40's is ethical and emotional milestone in country that has long believed that death comes only after heart stops beating and body turns cold (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PNC BANK CORP.,  Pittsburgh, a bank holding company, said it planned to repurchase up to 15 million of its 304 million shares outstanding, or about $765 million in stock.    COCA-COLA CO.,  Atlanta, said it would increase its quarterly dividend by 6.6 percent, to 16 cents, payable April 1 to shareholders of record as of March 15.

headline: For Jane and Joe Public, Wariness and Ignorance
abstract: Reaction in Florida to NATO bombing of Serbia is mostly indifferent; some people have never heard of Kosovo; photo (M)

headline: Yeltsin Sends His Premier To Urge Serbs to Negotiate
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin, alarmed by prospects of widening war in Balkans, sends Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov on high-risk mission to Belgrade to coax Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic back to negotiating table; Russia will insist first on halt to NATO bombing, which officials say is barbaric act of aggression; despite tough talk, Primakov's mission is seen as sign that after five days of NATO bombing, Moscow is ready to commit its own diplomatic muscle to test its influence on Milosevic; delegation will include Defense Min Igor Sergeyev, Foreign Min Igor Ivanov and top intelligence officials (M)

headline: Europe Pay-TV Provider Expects Profit This Year
abstract: Shares of Canal Plus SA rise 6 percent after company, Europe's biggest pay-television concern, forecasts it will return to proft in 1999 as its satellite TV service breaks even (S)

headline: Microsoft Seeks Some Salvage In Courtroom
abstract: Microsoft Corp, burned by searing Government cross-examination of Compaq Computer Corp aide John T Rose, who testified for Microsoft, seeks to regain ground in antitrust trial; Rose insists Compaq's ties with Microsoft, while bumpy, always focused on benefiting customers (M)a

headline: 2 More Antiaircraft Incidents in North Iraq
abstract: US warplanes attack antiaircraft batteries in northern Iraq in two skirmishes on January 11 as Baghdad continues its defiance of American and British control of skies over no-flight zone; reportedly attacked after batteries tracked them with radar; map; photo (M)

headline: NBC Moves To Sell Goods To Its Viewers
abstract: NBC will make significant investment in cable network Value Vision and link it with NBC network, cable channels CNBC and MSNBC, and Web site MSNBC.com; NBC, first broadcast network to own portion of home shopping channel, is positioning itself to deliver products directly to viewers; move speaks to NBC's strategy to move away from old network economic model, which has always generated revenue only through advertising; NBC cable president Thomas Rogers says NBC has entered into strategic alliance with Value Vision and GE Equity, equity arm of GE Capital, subsidiary of NBC's parent company, General Electric, that will deliver 15 percent stake to NBC and GE Equity in exchange for $44 million; NBC will try to get Value Vision placed on more cable systems; move is likely to mean even more effort to merchandise products introduced by NBC programs (M)

headline: U.S. Can't Solve Every Crisis, He Says, Urging Quick Action : Blair Presses Case For Europe Force
abstract: LONDONâ€”  Correction published in the International Herald Tribune, March 11, 1999:

headline: Qwest Announces Network Expansion
abstract: Qwest Communications International Inc completes local telephone networks in 10 US cities and plans to expand in nine more this year (S)

headline: Underwriter Reaffirms iVillage Offering
abstract: Lead underwriter Goldman, Sachs says iVillage Inc's planned initial public offering will not be delayed by suit by former iVillage employee Todd L Kenner, who holds company reneged on promised stock options; company's former chief financial officer, Joanne O'Rourke Hindman, filed declaration in suit accusing company of inappropriate accounting practices (M)

headline: Financiers Plan To Put Controls On Derivatives
abstract: Some of world's largest financial institutions reach agreement to try to set their own industrywide standards in huge and volatile market of complex securities known as derivatives; by setting their own voluntary guidelines, industry hopes to lessen chance of recurrences of problems in derivatives markets and keep stricter regulations from being imposed by Federal Government; agreement is embraced by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan and Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin (M)

headline: Lochinver Journal; At Long Last, Scots Can Lord It Over the Lairds
abstract: Donald Dewar, Britain's Secretary for Scotland, says first order of business when new Scottish Parliament convenes in May 1999 will be to reform ancient land-holding structure, under which half of Scottish land in private hands belongs to just 350 people, and 1,500 private estates account for 80 percent of country; under plans, local communities would gain right to buy estates at market value and be able to tap National Lottery money to help raise purchase price; purchase of 13-hamlets near Lochinvar from Swedish owner by residents, who set up Assynt Crofters' Trust cooperative self-government discussed; photos; map (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Dreamworks SKG, Universal City, Calif., to GSD&M, Austin, Tex., part of Omnicom Group, to handle its media account, which had been handled by Focus Media, Santa Monica, Calif. Billings were estimated at $85 million.    * Duramed Pharmaceuticals, Cincinnati, to Gillespie, Lawrenceville, N.J., part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $15 million.

headline: Agencies Taking Donations for Refugees
abstract: List of agencies that are accepting contributions for Kosovo refugee assistance

headline: As Big Stocks Whiz Along, Hope Exceeds Returns in the Small-Cap Universe
abstract: Stocks of small companies lagged behind large-company stocks in 1998 for fifth consecutive year; some professionals are questioning viability of small stocks as investment class; investors have remained hopeful, continuing to add new money to small-cap mutual funds (M)

headline: QLT'S STOCK JUMPS AFTER REPORT ABOUT AN EYE TREATMENT
abstract: Canadian company QLT Phototherapeutics Inc says new study shows its Visudyne therapy helps treat macular degeneration, eye condition that is responsible for severe vision loss; shares in company rise 23 percent (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STAPLES INC., Westborough, Mass., the office supply chain, will repurchase up to 7.1 million of its common shares, or $200 million in stock. The company had about 461 million shares outstanding as of Jan. 30.    CNS INC., Minneapolis, a maker of consumer products, said its board of directors had authorized the repurchase of an additional one million shares of the company's 16.3 million shares outstanding.

headline: Bonds Rally, Driving Yield To New Lows In Japan
abstract: Japanese bonds rally, driving yield of benchmark issue to its lowest level in more than two months as expectations grow that central bank will extend its efforts to cut short-term interest rates; Bank of Japan, after pushing overnight lending rate close to zero on March 3, is considering lowering other short-term rates (M)

headline: TSI SOFTWARE PLANS TO BUY BRAID GROUP FOR $91 MILLION
abstract: TSI International Software Corporation, which makes computer programs that link unrelated business software, says that it will buy Braid Group Ltd of Britain for about $91 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Prudential of Britain Moves to Expand
abstract: Prudential Corp PLC proposes to acquire M & G Group PLC for 25 pounds a share in cash, total of 1.9 billion pounds; graph (S)

headline: Criticism Over Book By Ex-Arms Inspector
abstract: The State Department said that a new book by Scott Ritter, a former United Nations weapons inspector who has contended that the Central Intelligence Agency helped plan arms inspections in Iraq, was inaccurate, misleading and could ''only serve Saddam Hussein's propaganda machine.''

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Weight Watchers Meets Its Goals; Onetime Dud Becomes the Star Of an Uninspired Cast at Heinz
abstract: Weight Watchers International, owned by H J Heinz Co, has had resurgence and represents larger portion of Heinz's profits; was a dud just two years ago but is now fastest-growing division of Heinz's empire; revival comes amid general upturn in industry as people flee diet drugs; graph; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Continuing Education; Barry Diller Keeps Redefining 'Convergence' ... and Convergence Keeps Redefining Him
abstract: Article on corporate strategy of USA Networks Inc's chief executive Barry Diller in light of his proposal to control new company that would combine Lycos, popular portal to World Wide Web, with electronic shopping holdings of his USA Networks; says new operation, to be called USA Lycos Interactive Networks, would entertain, inform and sell things on line, on television and over telephone; holds it was valued at $22 billion when it was announced, before Wall Street panned deal, sending shares of Lycos--and deal's prospects--tumbling; chart lists of Diller's media deal beginning in December 1992; photos (L)

headline: U.N. Criticism Angers Charities Buying Sudan Slaves' Release
abstract: Private charities that are buying freedom for enslaved children and young women in Sudan react angrily to recent criticism of them from Unicef, United Nations Children's Fund; John Eibner, head of Christian Solidarity International of Zurich, which since 1995 has bought and set free 5,942 Sudanese children, spending about $50 a child, declares 'It is very difficult to understand why Unicef should say our activities are intolerable'; Charles Jacobs of American Anti-Slavery Group in Boston, which helps raise money to support Christian Solidarity, holds 'What is intolerable is to leave these women and children in the hands of brutal captors' (M)

headline: Ntsu Mokhehle, 80; Fractious Land's Premier
abstract: Ntsu Mokhele, longtime leader of Lesotho, dies after falling ill at his 80th birthday party in December; photo (S)

headline: DATABANK: March 15-19; Asian Markets Gain, as the Dow Teases Teases
abstract: DataBank column assesses stock market performance for week of March 15 to 19; graphs (L)

headline: Loss by Oxford Narrows, but Not Enough
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc eports fourth-quarter loss of $18.8 million compared with loss of $284.7 million in year-earlier period; revenue fell slightly to $1.13 billion from $1.14 billion (M)

headline: Bank of New York Adding Scottish Trust Bank
abstract: Bank of New York Co to buy Royal Bank of Scotland PLC's trust bank, making it world's largest custodian of investor assets; will also buy minority stake in Royal Bank's investor services unit; plans other acquisitions in Europe (M)

headline: Europeans Focus on Local Content to Spur Internet Growth
abstract: LONDONâ€”  One of the biggest challenges to the growth of the Internet in Europe can be summed up in a few words. Words like Yahoo!, AOL or Amazon.com.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Others' Risk Of Contagion From Brazil
abstract: Brazil, Philippines, Indonesia and Thailand could face economic problems later this year either in raising money or in defending their currencies; analysts and economists say these four countries are not now teetering on brink of financial disaster; Thai economy shows signs of stabilizing; nation has improved its balance of trade, and its currency, the baht, has rebounded 50 percent from low in January 1998; Philippines has been upgraded from negative credit outlook by Standard & Poor's Corp; Indonesia is not as well off, with progress slow in revamping economy and banking system; its currency has slumped more sharply than Thailand's and Philippines' in wake of Brazil's devaluation; but financial analysts and strategists say these countries and Brazil are particularly vulnerable should world financial markets tighten up; each of these countries has significant amount of debt and interest to pay this year, including loans to banks and bonds sold globally to investors (Market Place column) (M)

headline: ADVANTA CORPORATION TO JETTISON AUTO LOANS BUSINESS
abstract: Advanta Corp is closing its auto-lending business and combining others to cut costs and focus on more profitable businesses (S)

headline: U.S. Aid to Scientists In Russia Is Assailed
abstract: A study to be issued by Congressional auditors is highly critical of a key part of the Clinton Administration's effort to stop the spread of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons by helping to employ scientists from the former Soviet Union, saying that some of them may still be working on prohibited weapons.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: AXA Says Profit Rose 8% in Half
abstract: AXA SA, Europe's biggest insurer by sales, indicates that its second-half profit rose 8 percent, in line with expectations, as it was helped by earnings at its French and United States life insurance businesses; implied net income rose to 3.997 billion French francs ($672 million) from 3.7 francs a year earlier (S)

headline: Outlets Slipping Out of Fashion; Traditional Stores Counter as Off-Price Malls Overreach
abstract: Retail outlet industry has run into trouble after nearly a decade of explosive growth and outsized profit margins; Value Retail News says at end of October, sales in outlet center stores open at least a year were down nearly 2 percent; regional malls, by contrast, were up 3 percent; Prime Retail Inc, biggest player in field with 25 percent of all outlet space nationwide, expects Christmas sales to be below 5.9 percent growth entire retail industry experienced in 1998; outlet stores are facing increased competition from fashion-conscious discounters and sale-happy department stores; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Indonesia Bank Bailout Is Put on Hold
abstract: Indonesia defers plan to inject 3.75 trillion rupiah ($430 million) into Lippo Bank after some legislators accuse Government of favoring the Riady family, which controls bank (S)

headline: NEWS WATCH; Strange Bedfellows Sue Group That Puts Sex Sites on Line
abstract: Archdiocese of St Louis sues Seth Warshavsky and his sex-oriented on-line company, Internet Entertainment Group, for its sites tied to Pope's upcoming visit to St Louis; sites look like official church information, but closer look reveals section titled Unholy Sex (S)

headline: The Brazilian Bear Growls Again
abstract: Review of adverse reaction of stock markets around the world to the deepening of Brazil's economic crisis; graphs (M)

headline: There's but One Rule for Footwear Here:Display!: In Japan, the Allure of Feet
abstract: TOKYOâ€”  When the Japanese talk about female sexuality, the one thing everyone agrees on is the allure of feet. For more than a millennium, women's feet and footwear have played a major role in defining femininity. Fifteenth-century samurai warriors picked concubines by their feet, often without bothering to inspect the rest. In 19th-century Edo (old Tokyo), presenting a woman with sandals was the prelude to any sexual relationship. And until about 30 years ago, Kyoto geishas treated favored clients with the sight of their bare feet.

headline: STOCK OF WIRELESS COMPANY DROPS ON EARNINGS NEWS
abstract: Electromagnetic Sciences Inc shares fall 13 percent after company says fourth-quarter earnings will fall from year-earlier levels and says it cut 120 jobs, 10 percent of work force, in quarter; company expects earnings to be 'near break-even' (S)

headline: Vision Things; New Corrective Eye Implants Show Promise in Trials
abstract: Corrective eye implants show promise as alternative to laser surgery, contact lenses and eyeglasses for people with mild nearsightedness, or myopia; condition affects 22 million Americans; Keravision, small Calif company, has conducted experimental treatment in which clear polymer arcs, called Intacs, were implanted in eyes, with impressive results; if Food and Drug Administration, as expected, aproves Intacs, it will be first surgical corneal implant for vision correction to be sold in United States; other companies are racing to develop other types of eye implants; one company, Presby Corp, is developing plastic implant that would eliminte need for reading glasses and bifocal lenses; these products are aimed at grabbing share of $11 billion Americans now spend each year for glasses and contact lenses; potential seen in implants comes with caveats: possible side effects and complications, and cost, which is $5,000 for surgery to both eyes; photos; charts (M)

headline: KPMG's Canadian Unit Is Preparing to Bolt
abstract: Five thousand accountants and consultants working at KPMG in Canada are planning to firm of Arthur Andersen, concerned that KPMG is not staying competitive at time many companies have global operations; if merger of two Canadian firms takes place as planned, Arthur Andersen will become largest accounting firm in Canada, while KPMG may lose most of its Canadian business; Colin M Sharman, chairman of KPMG International, says firm will fight to keep its most valued Canadian clients; merger must still be voted on by all partners at both Canadian firms and is subject to approval by Canadian regulators (M)

headline: Tactics Were Barrier To Top Serb's Indictment
abstract: Although US officials consider Slobodan Milosevic largely responsible for much of warring that has ravaged Balkans for past eight years, he has not been indicted by international war crimes tribunal, publicly or secretly; American and tribunal officials say US Government and tribunal are responsible for Milosevic's avoidance of legal accountability; Clinton Administration made him partner in seeking peace in Bosnia, and neither court nor US has considered indictment priority; neither have devoted resources to amassing evidence for indictment (M)

headline: ANTITRUST SUIT SAYS DENTSPLY RESTRICTED TOOTH TRADE
abstract: Dentsply International Inc, world's top maker of artificial teeth, is accused by Justice Department of illegally restricting competition among denture distributors; antitrust suit says Dentsply sells 70 percent of artificial teeth in US and has enforced restrictive arrangements affecting more than 80 percent of distributors; in December, Dentsply sued Justice Department, noting it had been under investigation since 1995 and asking for ruling that it was not a monopoly and did not illegally restrain trade (S)

headline: Watch Your Language Around This Digital Bird
abstract: Computer operations usually directed by the mouse can be done through voice commands with technology developed by Mindmaker; photo of the technology's on-screen parrot, Prody (S)

headline: AT&T's Embrace of New Technology Signals Next Era
abstract: Analysis: AT&T's recently announced goal to stop buying traditional telephone switches for core of its network by end of 1999 is seminal moment for communications industry, even for everyone who uses a phone; AT&T is retooling its network around new generation of technologies inspired partly by Internet; Sprint and MCI Worldcom are doing likewise, but AT&T wields proportionately larger influence in market and with technology suppliers; for consumers, evolution to younger, more efficient technologies could lead to lower prices; it might also lead to new sorts of features and services, as new technologies expand from core of network to homes and businesses (M)

headline: Got a Big Crush on Someone? Send a Secret E-Valentine
abstract: Secretadmirer.com, Web site, allows visitor to send a Valentine's Day message to person sender has crush on; receiver is then informed that he or she has secret admirer and is given option of sending note, also anonymous, to whomever he or she might have crush on; if notes make match, computer program informs both parties; if there is no match after two weeks, computer sends original sender rejection note; site was developed by Miles Kronby (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: List of key rates on Treasury bonds

headline: Kurds' Rebel Leader May Prove a Discredit to His Cause
abstract: Rise of Abdullah Ocalan as revolutionary leader of Kurds may have been been one of greatest modern tragedies to befall hapless group, which has been exploited and slaughtered by dozens of regimes over centuries; Ocalan, whose return to Turkey as prisoner seems to have ended his 14-year career as guerrilla leader, is by most accounts dogmatic and tyrannical; even though many Kurds have followed him, with many still considering him their leader, in eyes of world he has done as much as anyone to discredit their cause; many with whom he formed Kurdistan Workers Party in 1970's were later killed, some tortured to death on his orders; others fled to live clandestinely in Europe after he branded them as traitors for challeging him or pressing for more democracy within revolutionary movement; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: COMCAST CORP., Philadelphia, an operator of cable-TV systems, said it would split its stock 2 for 1 and eliminate its quarterly dividend after its stock almost doubled in the last year. The last dividend of 23 cents a share will be payable on March 25 to shareholders of record on March 4.    POLYCOM INC., San Jose, Calif., a maker of audio and video-conferencing products, said Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co. had exercised a warrant to buy two million Polycom shares for $15 million, or $7.50 a share. The warrant agreement was due to expire this month.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Optiva Corp gives account to Goodby, Silverstein & Partners; Frank's Nursery and Crafts gives account to Quantum Media International (S)

headline: Advance in Dow Is Matched By Other Share Measures
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 184.54 points, or 1.88 percent, to close at record 10,006.78; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 27.37, or 2.1 percent, to 1.310.17; Nasdaq composite index jumps 73.67, or 3 percent, to 2,492.84 (M)

headline: No Quick Chinese Entry Seen Into Trade Group
abstract: American officials say China's entry into World Trade Organization is not expected soon because difficult and complex issues remain across all areas of trade; Chinese and American officials have negotiated intensively for last week in Beijing over scale of market-opening concessions that China must make to qualify for membership in WTO; US trade representative Charlene Barshefsky, after meeting with China's Prime Min Zhu Rongji and trade official Wu Yi, says substantial gaps in critical areas remain; Commerce Sec William M Daley says deal will be reached sometime before the fall; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Lauds King Hussein As Man of Vision and Spirit
abstract: Pres Clinton leads American delegation at funeral of Jordan's King Hussein; is accompanied by former Presidents Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter and George Bush; lauds Hussein as man of vision and spirit; meets with King Abdullah after funeral; offers moral and financial support; says Abdullah embodies strength and humility of father and is committed to domestic development and regional peace; pays condolence call, with First Lady Hillary Rodham Clinton, on Hussein's widow, American-born Queen Noor; photos (M)

headline: AT&T, British Telecom Said To Be Moving Into Japan
abstract: AT&T Corp and British Telecommunications PLC are close to buying stake in Japan Telecom Co, adding a third partner to their $10 billion alliance and speeding their entry in Japanese market; British Telecom will buy 20 percent and AT&T will buy 10 percent in Japan Telecom, country's fourth-largest phone company (M)

headline: People
abstract: David Howe is named managing director at Foote, Cone & Belding Direct New York, succeeding John Penberthy, who is promoted to president at Foote, Cone Direct International, London; Brad Back, vice president and account director at Publicis & Hal Riney Chicago, is named senior vice president and worldwide account director for Subway Restaurants account; Lisa Zaccheo is named vice president and managing director at Cronin Direct, new subsidiary of Cronin & Co; Jeannine Shao Collins, associate publisher of Better Homes and Gardens, is named publisher, succeeding Alex Mironovich; Steven E Meisner is named to new post of executive vice president at Ray Gun Publishing and publisher of Ray Gun and Bikini magazines; as publisher, he succeeds Marvin Scott Jarrett, previous co-owner of company who sold his interest in November; Jesse H Jackson is named to new position of associate publisher for marketing at Teen People magazine; Kurt M DeMars, special projects manager at Out magazine, is promoted to advertising director; he succeeds Amy Simmons, who is named publisher at HIV Plus, new magazine also from Out Puiblishing Inc (M)

headline: D.E.A. Chief Warns Senate On Traffickers In Mexico
abstract: Thomas A Constantine, Drug Enforcement Administration head, warns Mexican drug trafficking organizations pose unprecedented criminal threat to United States, Senate Caucus on International Narcotics Control; cites their access to large staffs, arms arsenals and best technology; sidesteps question about whether Mexico deserves to be certified as cooperating in drug-fighting efforts (M)
