headline: Sensing value in its well-known but languishing name, Esprit de Corp. starts a revival campaign.
abstract: Apparel maker Esprit de Corp will begin revival campaign with ads in March issues of magazines and posters in New York and San Francisco; campaign, with estimated budget of $5 million to $6 million, is first by Toth Brand Imaging (M)

headline: 20 Years On, Anger Ignites Against Khmer Rouge
abstract: Cambodia embarks, spontaneously, on long-delayed national conversation about its traumatic past; countless unburdenings are taking place among Cambodians, recalling killings of family members, years of fear and hunger, loss of youth and education, and continuing harshness of life; comments suggest emerging political assertiveness among people better informed and more aware of their rights; near-unanimous view is that defecting Khmer Rouge leaders, who recently flaunted their impunity in tourist trip around Cambodia, should be put on trial, if only to determine who is really to blame for country's suffering; photo; map (M)

headline: LUCENT IN $50 MILLION DEAL FOR LOCAL AREA NETWORK UNIT
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc to buy Ethernet local area network business of Enable Semiconductor for about $50 million; local area network is group of computers connected with coaxial cables, optical fibers or standard telephone lines (S)

headline: China Grimly Pledges to Push On With Reforms
abstract: Prime Min Zhu Rongji says China will push on with economic and social reforms despite 'grim economic picture'; says China will continue to open country wider to outside world; his sobering speech before Parliament enumerates China's many current problems--from unemployment to official corruption to flagging export market; says China will continue recent policy of massive deficit spending to bolster economy and insulate itself from worst of Asia's economic woes; predicts China will have economic growth of 'around 7 percent' in 1999, down from official 7.8 percent in 1998 (M)

headline: Ad Council President Is Stepping Down
abstract: Ruth A Wooden, president of Advertising Council, will leave this summer after 12 years; Wooden's duties will be assumed temporarily by S Murray Gaylord, chief operating officer, as search for her successor begins (S)

headline: Protecting Innovation
abstract: Robert P Haub comments on Jan 17 article on stealing other's ideas

headline: Private Sector; Down for the Count, a Stock Becomes a Net Heavyweight
abstract: George Horowitz, chairman of Active Apparel Group, discusses 'unnerving' rise in share prices since he opened retail Web site (S)

headline: Ticketmaster and Microsoft Settle Suit on Internet Linking
abstract: USA Networks Inc's Ticketmaster settles suit against Microsoft Corp, resolving issue of whether Microsoft's Sidewalk on-line city guides can bypass many of Tickemaster's advertising-laden Web pages and link Sidewalk users directly to ticket-purchase parts of Ticketmaster site; Ticketmaster says Microsoft has agreed to point visitors who want to buy tickets to Ticketmaster home page; settlement disappoints hopes that case would establish legal precedent on intellectual property rights of Internet companies (M)

headline: Women's Suicides Reveal Rural China's Bitter Roots
abstract: Wang Xuexia remembers vividly the cool May night when the minibus raced past newly planted fields of rice and corn and dropped her high school classmate at the emergency room, disheveled and semiconscious, exuding the sickly sweet odor of pesticide.    Though fresh out of nursing school, Ms. Wang knew the drill: pump the stomach, then give oxygen, a shot of Atropine and, intravenously, an antidote to the lethal poison. Such patients were so common at the hospital in Lutou that the diagnosis was never in question: another desperate rural woman attempting suicide.

headline: Dr. Brain
abstract: Margot Slade evaluates Dr. Brain, learning software for children from Knowledge Adventure ($30) (M)

headline: Southern Shipyard to Build 2 Large Passenger Vessels
abstract: Ingalls Shipbuilding, subsidiary of Litton Industries and American Classic Voyages Inc, to announce contract for shipyard to build two 1,900-passenger cruise ships, for $440 million for use in Hawaiian Islands; two ships will be registered in US; in exchange for agreeing to order ships, Congress gives American Classic Voyages special rights that will make it difficult for other companies to join it in Hawaiian cruise market; it is first private project in America since 1958 (M)

headline: When Joystick Starts Shaking, Hang On
abstract: Growing intrerest in video games has driven technology in peripherals to new levels; latest devices offer more realistic responses to games, better designs and, most important, better support for kinds of games that take advantage of them; photos of new types of joy sticks; costs and manufacturers noted (M)

headline: About 900 Women Will Join Suit Against Merrill Lynch
abstract: About 900 women are planning to file claims charging sex discrimination at Merrill Lynch with March 2 deadline approaching; nearly 2,900 current and former women brokers at Merrill Lynch are eligible to file; under settlement, women employed at Merrill Lynch's domestic retail brokerage business between Jan 1, 1994, and June 18, 1998, can seek compensation (M)

headline: CENDANT SETTLES LAWSUIT BY INVESTORS FOR $350 MILLION
abstract: Cendant Corp agrees to settle class-action lawsuit by investors for $350 million; company agrees to raise by $350 million market value of securities it issued last year to help finance failed bid to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc; plaintiffs contended company's executives misled investors by failing to disclose accounting fraud in April that resulted in drop in Cendant's share price (S)

headline: Loan Delinquencies Rose in 4th Quarter
abstract: American Bankers Association reports consumer loan delinquencies rose slightly in fourth quarter, but remained well below record levels (S)

headline: Who Holds The Deed to Stock Data?
abstract: Article on issue of who, among stock exchanges, brokers or individual buyers and sellers, owns rights to real-time stock quotations; photo; graph (M)

headline: On-Line Book Clubs: Everything but Food
abstract: On-line book clubs are growing in number, and they are proving that it is possible to have successful, serial book discussion without face-to-face interaction; Internet's lack of time constraints is appealing to many members; even off-line book clubs can make use of the Internet resources; photo (M)

headline: Germany Tries to Adjust as All Its Neighbors Become Friends
abstract: Germany enjoys friendly relations with the countries that surround it for the first time since unification in 1871, but its elation at this achievement is tempered by its sense of the instability in Russia; Government of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder now seeks to project stability eastward by bringing the three new NATO countries, Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic, into European Union as soon as possible and by insuring survival of NATO's nascent but troubled partnership with Russia; map; photo (M)

headline: LVMH BUYS 33% SHARE IN THE MICHAEL KORS FASHION HOUSE
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA acquires 33 percent of American fashion house Michael Kors LLC; remaining ownership will be shared in equal parts with co-presidents Michael Kors and John Orchulli (S)

headline: SmithKline Expands Mediacom's Role
abstract: SmithKline Beecham PLC consolidates national electronic media buying responsibilities on accounts with billings estimated at $150 million at Mediacom; those duties had been divided between Mediacom and Jordan McGrath Case & Partners Euro RSCG (S)

headline: A Surge in Popularity of Software That Unlocks the Code
abstract: Unforeseen computing trend in 1998 was surging popularity of open-source software, which provides every computer user with free access to software's source code, actual lines of commands that programmers write to create software (M)

headline: JIM BEAM AND EUROPEAN PARTNERS PLAN VENTURE
abstract: Fortune Brands Inc says its Jim Beam Brands Worldwide unit has agreed to form joint venture with Highland Distillers PLC of Britain and Remy-Cointreau SA of France to sell and distribute wine and liquor outside US; each partner will invest $110 million in assets or cash and will own a third of venture, which will be independent and have its headquarters in Amsterdam (S)

headline: A Pox on the High-Rates 'Cure'
abstract: Some economists are questioning wisdom of raising interest rates when financial crisis strikes a country and its currency plunges; high rates are favored by Clinton Administration and International Monetary Fund; critics, including Jeffrey D Sachs at Harvard and Joseph Siglitz at World Bank, believe that raising rates courts recession by signaling to investors that debtors in stricken country are in danger of defaulting on foreign loans (M)

headline: LEAR TO BUY PARTS UNIT OF UNITED TECHNOLOGIES
abstract: Lear Corp, world's largest maker of car seats and interiors, to buy the United Technologies Corp's auto-parts unit, UT Automotive, for $2.3 billion (S)

headline: Star-Crossed Pakistani Couple Diverted From Flight to 'Happy Ever After'
abstract: Mehmood Butt and his wife, Humaira, were married in Pakistan despite opposition of her father, Punjab legislator Abbas Khokar; couple tried to flee to US, but landed in police custody in Lahore; photo (M)

headline: Family Suffers Double Loss From U.N. Crashes in Angola
abstract: United Nations officials in Angola are trying to negotiate rescue mission to crash sites of two UN chartered planes reported to have been shot down over rebel territory; say first plane, which went down on Dec 26, was piloted by John Wilkinson; say his son Hilton was aboard second plane, which went down on Jan 2 (M)

headline: COMPUTER CONSULTANT MOVING INTO HEALTH CARE DATA
abstract: Computer Task Group to buy Elumen Solutions Inc to help expand into health care data; Computer Task will pay $86 million in unspecified mix of cash and assumed debt and will assume about 125,000 shares (S)

headline: Matsushita Reduces Profit and Sales Estimates
abstract: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co reduces its sales and profit projections for year ending March 31; reports that profit for quarter ended Dec 31 was 20.3 billion yen ($163.1 million), a 48 percent drop from 1997 period (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice futures fall 8.5 percent after Government says production in 1999 will be greater than expected; in New York, orange juice falls 7.95 cents, to 92.25 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Myanmar Opposition Leader's Husband Dies, Denied a Last Visit
abstract: Michael Aris, 53, British husband of Burmese opposition leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, dies of cancer in London after being barred by Myanmar authorities from visiting her; she has refused to leave Myanmar, fearing authorities would bar her return; American Embassy in Myanmar, in unusual move, phones her message of thanks to those who helped Aris to reporters abroad (M)

headline: War Crimes Panel Finds Croat Troops 'Cleansed' the Serbs
abstract: Investigators at international war crimes tribunal in The Hague have concluded that Croatian Army carried out summary executions, indiscriminate shelling of civilian populations and 'ethnic cleansing' during 1995 assault that was turning point in Balkan wars; investigators have recommended that three Croatian generals be indicted; map (M)

headline: BASF Profits Weaken As Chemical Prices Fall
abstract: BASF AG says fourth-quarter profit fell 23 percent; net income fell to implied 748 million marks ($415 million) in quarter from 972 million marks a year earlier; full-year earnings rose 2.7 percent, to 3.32 billion marks ($1.84 billion); Bayer AG says profit for year rose 7.3 percent, to about 3.2 billion marks ($1.78 billion) (S)

headline: Media Talk; Column by Slate Writer Draws Fire
abstract: Scott Shuger, writer of column in Microsoft's on-line magazine, Slate, draws outrage of readers when he suggests that computer ownership among students at traditonally black colleges is far below that of students at elite private colleges because the African-American students choose to spend their money on other things, not because computers are too expensive; defends column but acknowledges that his late deadline might have muddied his thinking; photo (M)

headline: FUNDS WATCH; Bidding Adieu to a Century
abstract: Twentieth Century mutual funds family plans to drop Twentieth Century and Benham from all of its fund names as century draws to close (S)

headline: First Atlantic Capital Deal
abstract: First Atlantic Capital Ltd acquires majority stake in Otis Spunkmeyer Inc; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: 'Get Your Hot Dogs! Peanuts! Screen Wipes!'
abstract: Five hundred football fans will watch Super Bowl in test of Choice Seat technology developed by Williams Vyvx Services; touch-screen monitors, hooked into central computer, will let them watch game from 13 camera angles, view instant replays and get updated statistics, other data; photo (S)

headline: The Cordless Options
abstract: Cordless phones, which act as small radios, sending signals between handset and receiver, are now available in less congested frequencies; come in analog, digital and digital spread spectrum formats; photo (M)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY  Dana Corp  John Nuveen  Pillowtex

headline: Making a Tough Choice: A Bowl Game or a Baby
abstract: New Web site, Babycenter.com, offers Sports Event Conflict Catcher and Conception Blocker, which allows prospective parents to enter anticipated due date of their baby and determine which of 3,000 sporting events they are likely to miss as result; drawing (S)

headline: Milosevic-Holbrooke: Never a Smooth Mix
abstract: Article on US envoy Richard C Holbrooke in view of breakdown in negotiations with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to end Serbian aggression against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo (M)

headline: ING Barings Is Trying to Dispel Recent Worries About Its Future
abstract: ING Barings chief executive David Robins and chairman Michael Tilmant are touring US, Europe and Asia to explain company's just-completed reorganization plan and to dispel worries about the future (M)

headline: Media Talk; Rush Limbaugh Brings His Show to the Internet
abstract: Rush Limbaugh, conservative radio talk show host, begins broadcasting his radio show over Internet; says he is bowing to public demand to do so; photo (S)

headline: Amoco's Ex-President to Leave Merged Company
abstract: William J Lowrie, former Amoco Corp president, has left BP Amoco PLC board and will leave as deputy chief executive and president for refining, marketing and chemicals; deputy chief executive Rodney F Chase will take charge of refining and marketing unit; Richard L Olver will become chief executive for exploration and production; Enrique J Sosa, former Amoco executive, will also leave BP Amoco; Bryan K Sanderson, with whom he shared duties, will become chief executive of chemicals business (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: New evidence of surging US growth pushes euro to lowest level since it was introduced; euro closes in New YOrk at $1.345; table; graph (S)

headline: Morgan Stanley Names 3
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co names three people to head three new regional sales divisions as it moves to replace Robert J Dwyer, 55, who is retiring as national sales director on April 1; Eastern division will be run by Bruce F Alonso, Central by Alan A Schroder and Western by Stephen R Miller (S)

headline: If the Grass Is Greener
abstract: Experts give advice on how to approach one's current boss about a job offer from a different employer (M)

headline: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC TO BUY ABT BUILDING FOR $160 MILLION
abstract: Louisiana-Pacific Corp signs definitive agreement to buy ABT Building Products Corp for about $160 million in cash and assumption of about $65 million in debt (S)

headline: APTARGROUP PICKS UP EMSON RESEARCH FOR $150 MILLION
abstract: Aptargroup Inc acquires Emson Research Inc for $150 million in cash, debt and stock (S)

headline: 3% Drop in Sales Of Licensed Goods
abstract: The Licensing Letter, newsletter published by EPM Communications, says retail sales of licensed merchandised in North America dropped 3 percent in 1998; says sales declined to $71.3 billion in 1998 from $73.2 billion in 1997; some reasons for decline in sales noted (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybeans fall close to their lowest level in 23 years on expectations of bumper crop in Argentina and Brazil; on Chicago Board of Trade, soybeans drop 4.25 cents, to $4.74 a bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: From Conservative Steps, Liberal Gains
abstract: Article by Mark Hulbert on proliferation of mutual funds newsletters; says entire industry has sprung up to respond to needs of investors, who no longer consider mutual funds lifetime holdings but treat them with as much abandon as shown for individual stocks; photos (M)

headline: Pinochet Faces 33 New Counts In Extradition
abstract: Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon, whose extradition request has kept Gen Augusto Pinochet under house arrest in London, sends British prosecutors 33 new charges of human rights abuses against former Chilean dictator; all new charges relate to period beginning in 1988, when torture overseas became crime punishable in Britain (M)

headline: Ruling on Tight Jeans and Rape Sets Off Anger in Italy
abstract: Ruling by Italian high court, that woman cannot be raped while wearing jeans since tightness makes them impossible to remove without her help, reopens angry national debate about rape and about how judges view sexual assault; group of female lawmakers is on open-ended 'jeans strike,' vowing to wear jeans to Parliament until decision is changed (M)

headline: SEAGRAM DECIDES TO KEEP POLYGRAM FILM UNIT
abstract: Seagram Co will keep international operations of Polygram Filmed Entertainment after talks to sell it to Saudi Prince Muhammad bin Bandur Abdul Aziz for as much as $600 million break down; Seagram's Universal Studios will integrate Polygram business (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Cotton for Mar delivery jumps 1.9 cents, or 3.3 percent, to 60.09 cents a pound, after Government says importers in Mexico bought three-quarters of last week's United States exports; graphs of cotton prices; tables of prices of key commodities (S)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Tops Estimates by 9 Cents
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co reports mixed financial results, with first-quarter earnings well above Wall Street analysts' estimates, but both revenues and orders below expectations; for quarter ended Jan 31, Hewlett-Packard earned $960 million, up 3.3 percent from $929 million in year-earlier period; revenues rose 1 percent, to $11.94 billion, from $11.82 billion in first quarter of 1998 fiscal year (M)

headline: Russian With Many Faces May Get Lift in U.S. Visit
abstract: Russian Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov is facing one of his greatest challenges this week when he visits United States in effort to win several billions of dollars in credits from skeptical International Monetary Fund; success would help Russia to regain modicum of respectability on world financial markets as well as to restructure its colossal foreign debt; it would also make Primakov a conquering hero at home, with greatly improved chances of succeeding President Boris Yeltsin; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DIGITAL COURIER TECHNOLOGIES INC.,  Salt Lake City, a developer of electronic-commerce software, agreed to acquire Databank International SKB, a credit card transaction processing firm, in a deal valued at more than $50 million.

headline: European Ministers Outline Reduction in Farm Subsidies
abstract: European farm ministers agree to reduce European Union's $45 billion program for agricultural subsidies, potentially important breakthrough on one of Europe's most divisive political problems; agreement could pave way for European heads of state to rebalance what is now lopsided budget that channels billions of euros to countries like France and Spain, at expense of Germany; agreement would also allow European Union to open its membership to nations like Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic; they sell meat and dairy products at much lower prices than allowed in Western Europe; their admission to EU's free-trade zone would either bankrupt subsidy system or cause havoc with farmers; it remains unclear whether agreement would hold together (M)

headline: Music of the Spheres, Squiggles and Snips
abstract: Game Theory column appraises Shift Control, which showcases dozen ways to stretch, bounce and manipulate sound in environment studded with references to computer games, techno music and club culture; it is from Audiotrom; photo (M)

headline: SYNOVUS FINANCIAL TO PURCHASE MERIT HOLDING
abstract: Synovus Financial Corp agrees to buy Merit Holding Corp for $109 million in stock, expanding its banking business around Atlanta (S)

headline: An On-Line Glimpse of the Harlem Renaissance
abstract: Marking Black History Month, the Encyclopedia Brittanica Web site features an exhibition on the Harlem Renaissance (www.harlem.eb.com), including photographs from the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and clips of various black artists; photo (S)

headline: MacManus Consolidates Media Departments
abstract: MacManus Group forms Mediavest Worldwide by consolidating various media units and media departments at two of its agencies; combined billings for new agency are estimated at $8 billion; Irwin Gotlieb is named president and chief executive (S) will report to Roy Bostock, who is chairman and chief execu

headline: Bank of Montreal Chief Executive Resigns After Merger Fails
abstract: Bank of Montreal chairman-chief executive Matthew W Barrett announces his resignation as chief executive; Barrett also says he will retire as chairman in November; he is replaced as chief executive by F Anthony Comper, bank's president and chief operating officer; Barrett has been under pressure from investors and shareholders since December, when Canada's finance ministry rejected proposed merger between his bank and Royal Bank of Canada (M)

headline: BASF to Buy Back Up to 5% of Shares
abstract: BASF AG will buy back as much as 5 percent of its shares (S)

headline: For Mexico, An Economy With Gusto
abstract: Top executives from foreign companies have breakfast with President Ernesto Zedillo and tell him that they plan to spend $10 billion this year on factories and other projects in Mexico, matching last year's direct foreign investments; foreigners preference for Mexico over other Latin American countries has been felt in stock and currency markets as well as in longer-term investments; recent demand for pesos from investors has lifted Mexico's currency to levels not seen before decline in global economy began last year (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph showing plunging price of natural gas on commodities markets on reports that inventories fell less than expected

headline: PHILIPS TO START TENDER OFFER FOR VLSI AT $17 A SHARE
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics NV will start cash tender offer for VLSI Technology Inc at $17 a share; VLSI is evaluating offer of $777 million in cash (S)

headline: Inchcape to Sell Latin Bottling Business
abstract: Inchcape PLC to sell its South American bottling interests to Chilean soft drink bottler Embotelladora Arica SA for $750 million (S)

headline: Pope, in Mexico, Urges Moral Pressure on U.S. by Bishops
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrives in Mexico City and is welcomed by thousands of followers; will meet in Mexico with bishops from all the Americas to underscore his point that churches should work more closely; also wants his bishops to pool their strengths to exert greater moral pressure on Washington; in Mexico, as everywhere else, Pope intends to remind people of dangers of materialism; photo (M)

headline: Pentagon Backs Off on Arms Inspector's Book
abstract: Defense Dept drops demand that former UN arms inspector Scott Ritter provide Pentagon with advance copies of book in which he is expected to step up his criticism of Clinton Administration; says letter demanding that book be subject to prepublication review was sent in error and was not intended to intimidate him; Ritter has accused US of undermining arms inspections in Iraq because of vacillating policy (M)

headline: Cirrus Chief Steps Down
abstract: Cirrus Logic Inc chief executive Michael L Hackworth resigns, giving position to David D French, company's president (S)

headline: U.S. STEALTH FIGHTER IS DOWN IN YUGOSLAVIA AS NATO ORDERS ATTACK ON SERB ARMY UNITS
abstract: American F-117 stealth fighter crashes in Yugoslavia, first allied loss in Balkan conflict, as NATO opens broad new phase of air assault on Serbia; United States officials say American team rescued pilot; Serbia claims its air defenses brought down radar-evading plane; Pres Clinton hails rescue; says United States and NATO broaden targets to include Serbian army and police equipment and troops; shift is response to numerous reports of atrocities in Kosovo, including mass executions, deportations and forced marches; maps; photos (M)

headline: EDISON UNIT TO BUY 40 PERCENT OF NEW ZEALAND UTILITY
abstract: Edison International Inc says its Edison Mission Energy unit has submitted winning bid of $1.21 billion (New Zealand) (US $640 million) for 40 percent stake in New Zealand Government-owned electric utility Contact Energy Ltd; Edison has also emerged as leading bidder for group of power plants being sold by Unicom Corp (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; System Crash Doesn't Hurt E*Trade Stock
abstract: Market Place column on E*Trade Group's stock, which was not hurt by two days of computer problems and announcement by New York State Attorney Gen Eliot L Spitzer that he will investigate Internet trading industry after his office received complaints about delayed orders and unavailable trading system; photo (M)

headline: Revenue Rises 19% at Accounting Giant
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers says revenue for fisal year 1998 ended June 30 rose 19.9 percent, to $15.3 billion; revenue represents combined revenue of Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand, which merged on July 1 (S)

headline: Safer Web Playgrounds Are Aimed at Kids (and Paying Parents)
abstract: Alan Rothenberg says his company, Junior Net, has produced first safe on-line service just for preteen-agers; after logging on, members can access only approved links, trade messages only with approved friends and post only approved postings; several other companies are also offering these services, which are called 'subscription-based virtual private environments for children'; photo (M)

headline: Judge Questions Microsoft Videotape Evidence
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson openly questions reliability of video evidence Microsoft has presented in court and calls situation 'very troubling'; Jackson, at request of Microsoft, agrees to end proceedings for the day to let Microsoft regroup and try again on Feb 4; at issue has been videotape that Microsoft has shown to try to demonstrate key defense point--that its Windows operating system and Internet browser are not, as Government contends, separate products bundled together to stifle competition, but single product blended seamlessly to benefit consumers (M)

headline: Media Talk; Seattle Times Decides To Publish in Morning
abstract: Seattle Times, afternoon paper, says it expects to switch to morning publication, going head to head with The Seattle Post-Intelligencer; photo (S)

headline: Market for Cashmere Shawl Expands : The Lure of Pashmina
abstract: NEW DELHIâ€”  The Himalayan mountains are a long way from the world's fashion capitols, but this remote region at the top of the world is the source of one of this season's best-selling accessories. Brilliantly colored, featherweight pashmina shawls have become a fashion sensation, combining today's essential elements of style: comfort and luxury.

headline: Jack Tarver, 82, Atlanta Publisher in Civil Rights Era, Dies
abstract: Jack Tarver, who used his influence as publisher of Atlanta Journal and Atlanta Constitution in 1960's and early 1970's to protect Ralph McGill, The Constitution's Pulitzer Prize-winning editor, from bitter complaints about his support for civil rights movement, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: New York Shift For Angotti, Thomas
abstract: Angotti, Thomas, Hedge, unit of Interpublic Group of Companies, will absorb New York office of sibling agency, Anderson & Lembke, which has estimated billings of $30 million to $40 million (S)

headline: Popular Intellectual Magazine Is Shut in Crackdown by Beijing
abstract: Chinese authorities shut down popular intellectual monthly magazine, called Way, for 'reorganization,' latest move in an uneven tightening of controls over liberal publications; Way has a circulation of 20,000 and is widely read in academic circles; in recent years, under the banner of interdisciplinary inquiry, it has branched out from its original mandate to focus on natural sciences, carrying essays on nature of freedom, rule of law and dangers of totalitarian rule (S)

headline: Prague Spy Scandal Raises Concerns Over Czech Entry Into NATO
abstract: PRAGUEâ€”  As the Czech Republic prepares to join NATO this year, a murky spy scandal has erupted in Prague that raises concerns among top officials that the country could not keep secrets while uncovering an alleged Iraqi plan to blow up the Prague headquarters of the U.S.-owned Radio Free Europe.

headline: E-Mail by Any Other Name
abstract: Letter by Dr Paul Levinson on Jan 28 article on E-mail; comments on mistakes he made in sending message

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.81   4.80   5.50        3-month T-bills   4.51   4.48   4.97        6-month T-bills   4.54   4.52   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.89   3.89   3.69        10-yr. T-note   5.26   5.31   5.65        30-yr. T-bond   5.59   5.60   5.98        Telephone bd.   7.31   7.26   7.04        Municipal bds.   5.23   5.24   5.30          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Still Locked in Storm's Horror, Hondurans Are Fearful of Future
abstract: Article on how Santa Rosa de Aguan, Honduras, is trying to rebuild after Hurricane Mitch; notes that little has improved in two months after hurricane struck and discusses plight of some village residents; map; photos (M)

headline: Multiple Mailbags
abstract: Answer to reader's question on using one computer to read E-mail sent to another one (S)

headline: Outbreak in Afghan Region Concerns W.H.O.
abstract: World Health Organization is trying to get two epidemiologists into remote part of Afghanistan to diagnose mysterious disease; United Nations officials say Afghan representative to world health group appealed for help in diagnosing illness, which has infected 2,000 people and killed at least 150 in Darwaz area; map (M)

headline: HONDA MOTOR SAYS EARNINGS CLIMBED 16% IN 4TH QUARTER
abstract: Honda Motor Co says earnings increased 16 percent in fourth quarter; net income rose to record 75.5 bilion yen, or $636 million, from 65.2 billion yen, a year before; sales fell 3.9 percent, to 1.49 trillion yen from 1.55 trillion yen; North American sales rose 6 percent, to 780.27 billion yen (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Depleted Omega Advisors Loses a Key Strategist
abstract: Market Place column on Omega Advisors, $3 billion hedge fund, focuses Leon G Cooperman, key strategist at fund, who has decided to resign; says Cooperman's departure comes as Omega attempts to recover from last year's losses; holds during last year, $518 million has flowed out of Omega Overseas Partner, Omega's largest single fund (M)

headline: CITIGROUP TO BUY PITTSBURGH BANK'S CREDIT CARDS
abstract: Citigroup Inc to buy Mellon Bank Corp's credit card business (S)

headline: Mortgage Tax Break: Who Gets What
abstract: The income-tax deduction for home mortgage interest is one of the most popular politically, but its economic effects are perverse: Experts call it an ''upside down'' subsidy because the more a taxpayer earns, the greater the tax cut it yields.

headline: Schwab Says It Settled Customers' Claims
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp, biggest on-line broker, says it settled claims from some customers who tried to cancel orders for shares in fast-rising initial public offering of Theglobe.com Inc in November; Schwab has since barred on-line trading of initial public offerings for first 24 hours and limited amount of shares in certain Internet stocks that could be bought using borrowed money (S)

headline: Jean Ballarin Dies at 84; Led French Cavalry Charge
abstract: Jean Ballarin, who was last man to have led French cavalry charge on Jan 2, 1941, died on Feb 3 at age 84 (M)

headline: This Company Is a Customer That Bankers Love to Help
abstract: Article on RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp's relationship with investment bankers, who have made millions of in advisory fees over years from Nabisco's corporate deals (M)

headline: For Medicare, A Rocky Road To Competition
abstract: Stuart Altman and Laura D'Andrea Tyson, economists on Federal commission appointed to fix Medicare, hold deciding votes on whether commission will forward to Congress a proposal favored by Sen John B Breaux, chairman, and nine other members to scrap existing system in favor of creating a market for competing public and private plans; agree that competition is needed to modernize a sclerotic Medicare system, but they are pushing for specific set of benefits, including coverage for prescription drugs, which Medicare does not now provide; Breaux is willing to concede something to Tyson and Altman but not so much that he would lose support of Republicans worried about adding new benefits before Medicare's financial predicament is settled; thus, what began as high-minded debate over competition could quickly become an old-fashioned spat over money; photo; graphs (L)

headline: Wanted: F.O.B.'s (Friends of Barbie)
abstract: New Web site allows users to make their own customized Barbie dolls; photo (M)

headline: A Gadget That Taught a Nation to Surf: The TV Remote Control
abstract: BACK when the culture of instant digital gratification was just a gleam in a futurist's eye, a revolutionary device was invented that was one of the first steps toward technological power for consumers: the remote control.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Exelon Corp, unit of Peco Energy, to Tierney & Partners, unit of True North Communications, to handle advertising and public relations; billings estimated at $8 million (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Bug Watcher Sees the Pests Outrunning the Exterminators
abstract: Bruce Brown says bug situation was so bad in 1998 that he has canceled his annual award for most improved software performance of year; says his on-line service, Bugnet, received voluminous E-mail from frustrated users unable to get satisfactory answers to their software problems (S)

headline: Coalition Against Ads on Channel One
abstract: Unusual coalition of advocacy organizations is asking marketers to stop advertising on Channel One, unit of Primedia Inc, that broadcasts daily programs and commercials to more than 12,000 schools nationwide (S)

headline: Brazil Pledges Curbs on Debt And Budgets
abstract: Brazilian officials reach revised agreement with International Monetary Fund, pledging to enforce substantially greater budget discipline than originally promised and to keep inflation below 10 percent; new agreement detailed; IMF's first deputy managing director Stanley Fischer says IMF achieved its goals; Finance Minister Pedro Malan pledges that Brazil will accelerate privatization of energy and banking industries; accord does not call for privatization this year of Petrobras, state oil company, or of Branco de Brasil, state-owned commercial bank (M)

headline: Group Moves to Limit Internet Music Piracy
abstract: Three dozen software and hardware companies and on-line retailers endorse use of so-called certificates of authentication that would accompany songs and albums distributed digitally; effort is designed to cut down piracy of music on Internet (S)

headline: Executive Joins Dugan Valva
abstract: McCracken Brooks chairman Keith McCracken is leaving to join Dugan Valva Contess as executive vice president and general manager for Midwest and West (S)

headline: Industry View; How did a small company turn itself into a powerhouse of data storage systems? In part, through its marketing.
abstract: Glenn Rifkin article on how little-known EMC Corp came to dominate $10 billion market for large data storage systems, market it wrested from IBM; part of EMC's success lies in radical marketing: creating community atmosphere among customers, and making marketing one of top priorities of chief executive; at EMC, tone is set by co-founder and chairman, Richard J Egan, and chief executive, Michael C Ruettgers; drawing (M)

headline: GE Capital to Buy the Assets Of Failed Big Japanese Leaser
abstract: GE Capital Services says it is buying leasing business of Japan Leasing Corp, Japanese company that collapsed with Long-Term Credit Bank last fall; it is one of largest acquisitions by foreign company so far in Japan; GE Capital will acquire assets of Japan Leasing, but essentially no bad debts; purchase price is reported to be between $6 billion and $7 billion; GE Capital is expected to take on many of Japan Leasing's employees, including top management, and it will also get good franchise and wide customer base; money GE Capital pays to Japan Leasing will go toward paying off portion of its $20 billion in debts (M)

headline: HDTV Set Prices Are Falling, But Consumers Remain Scarce
abstract: High-definition television sets are not selling as well as expected; Gary Shapiro, head of Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Assn, which sponsors annual Consumer Electronics Show, announces that his member companies sold 13,176 HDTV's to dealers in last months of 1998, a tiny fraction of nation's television business; last year, Americans bought more than 27 million conventional sets; HDTV manufacturers are being urged to drop their prices--and fast, so transition to digital broadcasting can pick up speed; as result one company, Hitachi, is selling HDTV of sorts for $2,999, although to receive HDTV buyer must also buy $700 ditigal tuner box; many other companies say they will also lower prices on HDTV's, most of which now sell for $7,000 to $12,000; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Said to Be in Deal For Volvo's Car Business  Ford Motor plans to announce today that it will acquire the passenger car operations of Sweden's Volvo for $6 billion to $7 billion, people close to the talks said last night.    Ford's deal, which beat a rival bid from Italy's Fiat and strengthens its position as the No. 2 auto maker in the world, marks the latest step in the consolidation of the global automotive industry. Car makers worldwide are rushing into deals because they fear a coming shakeout in the industry, in which the only survivors will be the lowest-cost producers with the greatest economies of scale. [Page A1.]

headline: DVD! No, Divx! No . . .
abstract: Letter by Rayner Colton responds to Jan 28 article on Divx; says he fears ecological problem because he does not believe such disks can be recycled

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Under Pressure, Kellogg Speeds a Shift at the Top
abstract: Kellogg Co, struggling to gain market share in its breakfast business, names Carlos M Gutierrez chief executive, promoting him just six months after naming him president and chief operating officer; he replaces Arnold G Longho, who will officially step down as chief executive on April 23; Longho will remain chairman until April 2000; analysts and investors say company is under mounting pressure from shareholders to make drastic changes; photo (M)

headline: Odd Twosome Takes On South Africa's Status Quo
abstract: South Africa's first multiracial party, United Democratic Movement party, was formed by Bantu Holomisa, black man, and Roelf Meyer, who is white; recent poll suggests they may already have won over as much as 9 percent of voters; that is twice goal they set when they formed party year ago; they operate on shoestring, mostly relying on volunteers, as they campaign around country; nobody expects Holomisa-Meyer team to win South Africa's second post-apartheid elections, scheduled for June 2; but they may push aside crumbling former National Party and Zulu-focused Inkatha Freedom Party to become biggest opposition party; some political analysts even wonder if they might some day challenge African National Congress party of Pres Nelson Mandela; photo (M)

headline: Pope Is Returning to Mexico With New Target: Capitalism
abstract: Pope John Paul II will begin fourth visit to Mexico, 20 years after he was greeted by millions of Roman Catholics in outpouring of hope and excitement; he spoke out then against leftist liberation theology in Latin America, unveiling his unwavering Polish-bred stance against Communism; this trip comes amid papal warnings that unbridled free-market system threatens human race with more 'subtle' forms of 'slavery'; Pope hopes visit to Mexico City and St Louis will re-energize Catholics to pursue new evangelization; thelogian George Weigel says Pope also wants to get North American church to relate more to Latin neighbors; photo of Cardinal James Francis Stafford at cathedral in Mexico City (M)

headline: Korea to Sell Control of Bank to U.S. Investors
abstract: South Korea to sell 51 percent stake in Korea First Bank to consortium led by GE Capital and Newbridge Capital, buyout fund backed by David Bonderman's Texas Pacific Group; deal is clearest vote of confidence in Pres Kim Dae Jung's Government from foreign investor since Asian economic crisis took hold last year; marks start of final phase of Government efforts to overhaul debt-laden financial system, underscoring swiftness with which Kim has moved to repair parts of economy (M)

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Says Profit Rose 15%
abstract: Saatchi & Saatchi says second-half profit rose 15 percent to 11 million pounds ($17.9 million) from year earlier (S)

headline: Russia's Move To End Strikes Loses; Margin Is a Surprise
abstract: The United States and the NATO alliance won a victory today when  the Security Council rejected, 12 to 3,  a Russian resolution demanding an immediate end to NATO's air attacks on Yugoslavia.    Voting in favor of the measure were two of its sponsors, Russia and China, and Namibia. Voting against were the five Council members who are NATO members -- the United States, Britain, France, Canada and the Netherlands -- together with Argentina, Bahrain, Brazil, Gabon, Gambia, Malaysia and Slovenia.

headline: A video process allows the insertion of brand-name products in TV shows already on film.
abstract: Advertising column describes new advertising technique that digitally inserts image of logo of company into television program after it is made; photo (M)

headline: New Japan and Wako Will Merge Next Year
abstract: New Japan Securities Co and Wako Securities Co agree to merge in Apr 2000 under New Japan name; will cut work force to 5,000 from current combined 7,197; will end foreign operations (S)

headline: Big Food Distributor's New Chief Performs Emergency Surgery
abstract: Mark S Hansen, new chief executive of Fleming Companies, nation's second-largest food distributor, is closing plants, eliminating departments and dismissing workers in effort to step losses and revive company's stock, which has lost nearly three-fifths of its value since 1994; part of plan is making management more accountable to shareholders by requiring directors--including Hanson himself, who is also chairman--to be re-elected annually instead of every three years; photos; graph (M)

headline: Hopes for Improved Ties With China Fade
abstract: Seven months after President Clinton's return from a picture-perfect trip to China, the promise of a new era in Chinese-American relations has faded, leaving the Administration grappling with an unexpected round of repression of human rights in China and a mounting perception in Congress that Beijing is threatening American security interests.    The high expectations set by Mr. Clinton in China have run up against a pessimistic tone set by political forces in both countries that Administration officials say are more intent on confrontation than cooperation.

headline: Disney Gives New Jobs to 2 of Its Top Managers
abstract: Walt Disney Co names Robert A Iger to new post of president of Walt Diseny International and also makes him chairman of ABC Group; Steven M Bornstein, former chairman of ESPN and president of ABC Sports, replaces Iger as president of ABC; chairman Michael D Eisner comments; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: COFFEE IN DEMAND. Coffee prices surged as roasters, expecting a smaller crop in Brazil, snapped up beans at prices near a three-year low. In New York, coffee for May delivery rose 5 cents, or 4.8 percent, to $1.092 a pound.

headline: Discovering the Dark Side of Britain's Popular Tabloids
abstract: Britain's hugely popular tabloid press can play sinister role in lives of hapless people it writes about; tabloids get into bidding wars to get exclusive stories from people in the news, and once they become exclusive property of one tabloid, people in news find other tabloids turning against them, printing negative 'spoilers' designed to blur impact of their rival's scoop; latest example is story of foster parents on the run with two girls they want to adopt; photo (M)

headline: Canada Faces New Pressure To Safeguard Rare Wildlife
abstract: Wildlife advocates are pressuring Canadian Government to adopt national endangered species law to protect wildlife and its habitats; some US wildlife groups plan to institute legal action that raises threat of trade sanctions against Canada unless effective law is passed (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: 'GENETIC FOOD' WARNING -- Britain ordered restaurants, cafes, delicatessens, fast-food outlets and caterers to tell their customers if their meals contain genetically modified products. Failure to comply with the regulations, which go into effect immediately, could bring fines of up to $8,750.   Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: Levitz Furniture To Review Account
abstract: Levitz Furniture Corp begins review on creative part of its account, with billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: R. J. Reynolds Will Place A Disclaimer on Winston
abstract: Federal Trade Commission says R J Reynolds Tobacco Co will start including disclaimers with its advertising for Winston cigarettes; disclaimers will read 'No additives in our tobacco does not mean a safer cigarette'; in 1997, company settled on 'No bull' as advertising slogan for its Winston cigarettes, which it said were 100 percent tobacco with no additives (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Brouillard Communications receives ad and public relations account for Astoria Federal Savings and Loan Association (S)

headline: H-P 12C, the Calculator That Lives Forever
abstract: Wall Street MBA's are wondering how planned Hewlett-Packard spinoff will affect their beloved H-P 12C calculator, which many see as essential tool; calculator, introduced in 1981, is one of company's best-selling products ever; company says calculator operations will remain part of old Hewlett-Packard; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Franklin Mutual Advisors Inc reports holding 6.1 percent of UST Corp (S)

headline: For Villages Of Kosovo, War Is Part Of Daily Life
abstract: Monitors from Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe are struggling to keep up with fighting in Kosovo; Serbian security forces have attacked string of villages in last week; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.87   4.62   5.62        3-month T-bills   4.38   4.24   5.07        6-month T-bills   4.44   4.27   5.02        10-yr. headline: Quality, Not Quantity, In Investment Information
abstract: Albert Goll letter replies to Gretchen Morgenson's Jan 3 column complaining that investors are not getting the information they need to make investment decisions

headline: Equity and Convertible Issues Set This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Iraq Issues Threat to Hit Turkish Base Used by U.S.
abstract: Iraq threatens to attack Incirlik air base in southeastern Turkey if American and British warplanes based there continue patroling no-flight zone in northern Iraq; threat, delivered by Iraq's Vice Pres Taha Yassin Ramadan, comes weeks after air strikes against military targets in northern and southern no-flight zones have steadily eroded Iraq's defenses; photo; map (M)

headline: Chevron to Cut Jobs at a Unit
abstract: Chevron Corp will cut as much as 17 percent of work force at its Chevron USA Production Co unit, or about 94 jobs (S)

headline: Leader of Chechnya Survives Car-Bomb Assassination Attempt
abstract: Aslan Maskhadov, leader of Russia's breakaway region of Chechnya, survives assassination attempt when car bomb explodes near motorcade in capital of Grozny; several are wounded, including bodyguards; explosion comes two days after bomb attack in marketplace in Vladikavkaz, 30 miles from capital, which killed more than 50 people (M)

headline: U.S. Gives Colombia And Mexico Nod on Drugs
abstract: Pres Clinton certifies Mexico and Colombia as fully cooperative allies in fighting illegal drugs, even though most hard drugs flooding United States come from those nations; stand illustrates extent to which other Administration goals in region influence its annual assessment of drug threat; House Speaker Dennis Hastert signals he will not fight Clinton on issue; Sens Paul Coverdell, Dianne Feinstein and six other Senators call for new standards for evaluating Mexico's cooperation, letter to Clinton; Atty Gen Janet Reno reports Administration refuses to certify only Afghanistan and Myanmar; says Cambodia, Haiti, Nigeria and Paraguay have not done enough to stanch smuggling, but that sanctions are waived in American national interest (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:  Com21 Inc., Milpitas, Calif., 3 million shares. CS First Boston.    Concentric Network Corp., San Jose, Calif., 2.5 million shares. Bear, Stearns & Co.

headline: Buffett Deplores Trend of Manipulated Earnings
abstract: Warren E Buffett uses annual report to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders to accuse many fellow chief executives of manipulating earnings figures with accounting tricks; praises efforts of Arthur Levitt, SEC chairman, to end practice; report provides few surprises about Berkshire's holdings or Buffett's investment outlook but it does make clear that Buffet would like to make another big acquisition (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Silver falls on commodities markets after Warren E Buffett declines in annual report to disclose his holdings, which last year equaled quarter of annual mine production (S)

headline: Russia to Offer U.S. Deal To End Iran Nuclear Aid
abstract: Russia offers to curtail nuclear cooperation with Iran if US ends sanctions against two leading Russian nuclear research centers; proposal by Atomic Energy Min Yevgeny Adamov comes as Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov prepares for critical talks in Washington on security issues and Russian appeals for billions of dollars in credits from International Monetary Fund; aim is to remove major irritant in relations with West and unlock valuable contracts to nation's hard-strapped nuclear institutes; photo (M)

headline: New Twist in Possible America West Sale
abstract: Texas Pacific Group, largest shareholder of America West Airlines, has substantially raised price for acquiring airline by saying that it will go along with sale only if potential buyer bids for all of America West Holdings Corp, airline's parent company; disclosure is made by America West chairman-chief executive William A Franke; development appears to strengthen hand of UAL Corp, parent of United Airlines, while putting more pressure on Continental Airlines if it wants to play spoiler (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.50   4.54   5.29        3-month T-bills   4.34   4.36   5.07        6-month T-bills   4.37   4.40   5.06        10-yr. T-infl.   3.96   3.94   3.77        10-yr. T-note   4.71   4.73   5.52        30-yr. T-bond   5.16   5.20   5.78        Telephone bd.   6.84   6.84   7.06        Municipal bds.   5.36   5.18   5.19          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Mayor Says Shanghai Investment Companies Are Healthy
abstract: Mayor of Shanghai, China, says state-owned investment companies in his city are solvent, in contrast with those in southern province of Guangdong; Mayor Xu Kuangdi hopes to ease international concern about health of China's financial institutions; stock and bond markets in Asia feed on rumors that China might devalue its currency after recent devaluation of Brazil's currency; John Pinkel, financial analyst, says it is unlikely that Beijing would consider potentially disruptive move such as devaluation amid concern about coming 10th anniversary of Tiananmen Square crackdown (M)

headline: Clinton on Kosovo: 'We Can Make a Difference''
abstract: Transcript of Pres Clinton's radio address on US commitment to send troops to Kosovo

headline: Aerospace Gets Japan's Message; Without Military Largess, Industry Takes the Lean Path
abstract: Decade after many American companies began adopting just-in-time delivery and other lean manufacturing techniques, aerospace industry is embracing concept to cut costs in face of reduced military spending and, in commercial aircraft, stiff competition from Europe's Airbus Industrie; executives are now bandying about Japanese terms like 'kaizen' (continuous improvement) and 'kanban' (just-in-time system); they are applying them well enough to achieve some startling efficiency gains in industry long known as much for high costs and wasteful procedures as for cutting-edge technology; lean manufacturing techniques adopted by B F Goodrich Co's aerospace division factory, Boeing Co factory in Long Beach, Calif, and Northrup Grumman plant in Palmdale, Ca, detailed; diagrams; photos (M)

headline: WPP Group Buying Stake in Brierley
abstract: Brierley & Partners is selling 20 percent stake to WPP Group PLC for estimated $15 million in cash (S)

headline: Delicate Holiday Questions
abstract: Max Maxwell letter about delicate financial questions at the holiday dinner table (S)

headline: Singer Sells Taiwan Plant
abstract: Singer Co has sold its sewing machine manufacturing operations in Taiwan to local investment group for $10 million plus $48.6 million of assumed debt (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    ITALY: IMMIGRATION LAWS EASED -- The Government says it will modify its immigration laws to allow as many as 200,000 illegal aliens to obtain residency permits, leading to concern in other European countries that some of them might move in search of better jobs. Every year tens of thousands of Albanian, Kurdish and North African refugees come ashore on the Adriatic coast.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)    GERMANY: A RIFT IN COALITION -- A major rift appeared in Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's coalition as Greens politicians refused to compromise on a plan to relax Germany's citizenship laws, an issue that contributed to an election defeat for the Social Democrats and Greens in Hesse state. Mr. Schroder, in turn, accused the Greens of pursuing too radical an agenda. The Greens insist that the new law retain provisions allowing dual citizenship.   (Reuters)

headline: Hyundai Investment Planned for North Korea
abstract: Hyundai Group plans to invest $397 million by next year to develop tourist resort in North Korea (S)

headline: A Flurry of Home Improvements
abstract: 1998 financial highlights include heavy consumer spending on interior decoration and record home sales; photo (S)

headline: Murder in Mexico: Reformers Uncover Police Plot
abstract: Mexico City reform government probe of Nov death in Mexico City of Frederick Mc Phail Jr has led to arrest and indictment of five police officers; authorities say officers forced him to drink entire bottle of liquor after they stole his bank card and looted his account; have identified dozen other people, including three foreign tourists, allegedly victimized by same rogue officers; Mc Phail's father, Frederick Sr, stirred public outrage over slaying with newspaper advertisements; he calls case example of rampant corruption and police violence, interview; photo (M)

headline: No. 1 Complaint of Chinese: All This Corruption!
abstract: Local Communist Party chiefs in China rule with authority of mobsters in Hepu and thousands of similar towns; country's new market economy has increased opportunities for corruption; Pres Jiang Zemin and Prime Min Zhu Rongji are alarmed by extent of corruption, but they are unwilling to change system that perpetuates it; He Jianlin, former chief of Hepu, was sentenced to eight years in prison for selling official positions and taking other bribes worth over $50,000; map; photo (M)

headline: Up in the 'Real Maine,' One Man Picks Up Where He Left Off
abstract: Article by retired journalist Douglas E Kneeland on returning to live in his hometown, Lincoln, Me; photo (M)2

headline: British Investment Trust Gets Unwelcome Bid
abstract: Electra Investment Trust PLC, British venture capital company, rejects takeover bid by 3i Group PLC and advises shareholders against selling their shares; contends $2.04 billion offer made by 3i is inadequate (S)

headline: Boeing Beats Estimates and Renews Promises
abstract: Boeing Co reports earning $465 million in fourth quarter, including $30 million tax credit, up from loss of $498 million in 1997 period that included after-tax charge of $876 million; chief executive Philip M Condit reiterates commitment to revamping antiquated accounting and manufacturing systems; introduces Deborah C Hopkins, new chief financial officer, as 'change agent' (M)

headline: The Dow Jumps 212.73 Points as Shares Surge Broadly
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 212.73 points, or 2.28 percent, to 9,552.68; Nasdaq composite index rises 58.41 points, or 2.56 percent, to 2,342.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 32.92 points, or 2.66 percent, to 1,272.14; graph; chart (M)

headline: United Technologies Acquires Sundstrand
abstract: United Technologies Corp, makers of Pratt & Whitney jet engines, announces $4 billion acquisition of Sundstrand Corp, maker of internal systems for airplanes, in deal that would enable United Technologies to provide airplane makers with broader array of aeronautics wares to buy; deal continues consolidation wave sweeping aerospace industry; United Technologies will assume around $400 million in Sundstrand debt (M)

headline: ADVANCE PARADIGM ACQUIRING ANOTHER BENEFIT MANAGER
abstract: Advance Paradigm Inc to buy pharmaceutical management business of Foundation Health Systems Inc for $70 million in cash (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Japanese Giant's Not-So-Subtle Courtship
abstract: Market Place column on Nissan Motor Co president Yoshikazu Hanawa's not-so-subtle campaign to get auto company to make a bid for Nissan; says Hanawa has embarked on sales campaign never before seen in Japan and perhaps in the world; holds so far, Renault SA is only potential partner that has publicly acknowledged interest in the company; photo (M)

headline: Gabelli Stock Offering Raises $105 Million
abstract: Mario J Gabelli raises $105 million by selling one-fifth of his fund-management firm, Gabelli Asset Management Inc, in initial public offering (S)

headline: Rohm & Haas Plans to Buy Morton in $4.5 Billion Deal
abstract: Rohm & Haas Co to acquire salt and chemical maker Morton International Inc for $4.5 billion (M)

headline: Vivendi of France Acquiring U.S. Filter
abstract: Vivendi SA to acquire United States Filter Corp for $6.2 billion in cash; deal will create world's largest company in water treatment and services; photo (M)

headline: U.S. to Push NATO to Issue Ultimatum to Serb Leader
abstract: Clinton Administration officials say they will push NATO allies for ultimatum warning Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, that he must back down in Kosovo or face air strikes within days; seek to save NATO's credibility as alliance's 50th anniversary nears; Gen Wesley K Clark, NATO commander, holds Milosevic was uncooperative at their meeting because he does not yet feel any realistic military threat; photos (M)

headline: 2 in Computer Industry Are Holding Reviews
abstract: Dell Computer Corp begins review for its home and small-business group ad account; billings, which has been handled by Goldberg, Moser O'Neill, estimated at $30 million; Oracle Corp begins review for its account, which had been handled by Think New Ideas; billings estimated at $42 million (S)

headline: Federal Express to Raise U.S. Rates 2.8%
abstract: FDX Corp's Federal Express unit will raise its rates 2.8 percent on March 15 for all shipments within US; Fedex also says it will increase rates on 10- and 25-kilogram boxes for shipments to Mexico and reduce rates for those boxes on shipments to several other countries; it will also drop $1 residential delivery surcharge on its three-day continental US service called Fedex Express Saver (S)

headline: Art History 101, Continued
abstract: Verne G Kopytoff reviews art history computer software from Reindeer Co; photo (M)

headline: Without Beijing Nod, Town Has Election
abstract: Remote farming region in central China holds country's first direct elections for township leader, apparently without formal approval from Beijing; local party's favorite candidate won in Buyun, anyway (S)

headline: Rocky Path To Market For Edible Foe Of Cholesterol
abstract: Raisio Group of Finland has not been able to get its cholesterol-reducing margarine, Benecol, to US market because McNeil Consumer Products, its American partner, lost precious time trying to get FDA to approve Benecol as a dietary supplement rather than a food; now Uilever has a cholesterol-fighting margarine of its own ready for market, and Kellogg plans a whole line cholesterol-reducing products; graph shows rise and fall of Raisio stock price (M)

headline: Another Chinese Investment Company Falters
abstract: China's Dalian International Trust and Investment Corp, finance arm of one of nation's bigget ports, misses payments on loans; payment delay by Dalian comes less than 48 hours after Guangdong International Trust and Investment formally files for bankruptcy; underscores growing concern over loans to investment companies across China (M)

headline: A New Breed in Paris:Hyper-Realistic Designers
abstract: PARISâ€”  If there is a common link to the young designers working in Paris right now â€” Jeremy Scott, Bless, Gaspard Yurkievich, Sharon Wauchob â€” it is that they all belong to a school of hyper-realism.

headline: Softbank Trims Its Yahoo Stake
abstract: Softbank Corp sells $410 million stake in Yahoo Inc to finance new investments (S)

headline: Avoiding the Worms When Bobbing for Overseas Investments
abstract: Top-performing international fund managers, burned by bad bets over past two years, are treading carefully through global economic uncertainties with few taking big gambles; even though some see undervalued stocks countries they deem less risky, they are concentrating mainly on relatively strong, established businesses that appear in best positions to weather unseen storms; photos (M)

headline: Mexico Faulted on Drugs
abstract: Differing sharply with President Clinton, Representative J. Dennis Hastert, the Republican Speaker, said he did not think Mexico should be certified as a fully cooperative ally in fighting drugs. In an on-line chat with high school students, Mr. Hastert cited wide corruption and said, ''They haven't done their part as far as helping us stop drug trafficking.''

headline: What Is Art? That Can Mostly Depend on the Context
abstract: J C Herz appraises Le Plus Beau Musee du Monde (The Most Beautiful Museum in the World), CD-ROM published by France Telecom Multimedia, which has works from world's best museums, by artists ranging from Old Masters to marquee idols of modernism; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar rises against Japanese yen; euro rises against dollar in quiet trading; graphs; table (S)

headline: Ottawa and Provinces (but Not Quebec) Agree on Social Program
abstract: Leaders of nine Canadian provinces and two territories agree to three-year administrative arrangement under which federal Government agrees not to introduce new national social programs unless majority of provinces first accept them; federal Government also agrees that any new programs dealing with health, education or other social benefits would come with federal financing; Premier Lucien Bouchard of Quebec refuses to join pact, saying federal Government dropped important provision that would have allowed provinces to back out of national programs but still accept federal financing that would have accompanied them, if they substituted local programs with similar goals and standards; despite Quebec's refusal to join, Prime Min Jean Chretien calls new arrangement a success (M)

headline: Bracing for Another Year of Reckoning, Amid a Few Hints of Change
abstract: Even self-described optimists are predicting horrendous economic times ahead for Japan; there is air of desperation in Government's latest efforts to spur growth, moves that critics say must be accompanied by overhaul of economy to be effective (M)

headline: Compaq Buys Zip2 to Enhance Altavista
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp, in effort to make its Internet search engine, Altavista, more competitive, acquires Zip2 Corp, privately held company that helps newspapers develop city directory-type Web sites; Zip2 already has partnerships with media companies in 60 of 100 top metropolitan areas, including The New York Times Co, for which it helped create on-line city guide, New York Today (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar plunges to 27-month low against Japanese yen but gains ground as speculators begin buying dollars back; in New York, dollar trades at 111.04 yen, down from 112.66 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Microsoft Is Starting Web Site Aimed at Big Audience: Women
abstract: Microsoft Corp will introduce Web site for women, hoping to capture what many feel is largest ad fastest-growing market on Internet; site, called Women Central, will feature content from Women.com, largest on-line publisher of women's material, as well as original material; company signs Unilever Corp as site's primary sponsor (M)

headline: MacManus Consolidates P.& G.'s Account
abstract: MacManus Group consolidates its large Procter & Gamble Co accounts by shifting brands from its smaller agency, N W Ayer & Partners, to its larger one, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications (S)

headline: Making Late-Course Adjustments to the Rest of Their Lives
abstract: HERB ELLIOTT is more excited than perhaps one man should be as he shows off a small pile of Native American arrowheads and stone tools, which he found among the bulldozers and overturned dirt on the eighth fairway near his new home.    He exhibits the same enthusiasm for many things about his busy life as a new retiree. It is a bit jarring, because for a man without a job, Mr. Elliott seems to have found dozens.

headline: The NATO General Who Is Intimately Familiar With His Adversary
abstract: Profile of Wesley K Clark, four-star American general who as Supreme Allied Commander in Europe is in charge of powerful NATO air offensive against Serbia for its attacks against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo; an allied diplomat, not American, says he thinks that Clark, 54, is intellectually the most impressive chief alliance has ever had, but that he is fixated on idea that force is the only language Serb leadership understands (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Are Dragged Down By High-Technology Shares  Stock prices fell sharply, pulled down by software and computer companies, which fell in the wake of weaker-than-expected sales from Dell Computer and Hewlett-Packard.

headline: WINSLOEW FURNITURE CHAIRMAN LEADS A COMPANY BUYOUT
abstract: Winsloew Furniture chairman, Earl W Powell, is leading $205 million management buyout of company (S)

headline: PERSONAL BUSINESS: DIARY; If Taxpayers Decided Where Their Money Went
abstract: Tax resisters have often said they would be less opposed to rendering unto Uncle Sam if they could direct where their taxes would go. Taxpayers now have just one such option, a $3 contribution to subsidize the financing of the Presidential election cycle. But what if they had more choices? Intuit, the tax software company, had Ropers Starch Worldwide ask more than 1,000 Americans which of six causes they would give $1 of their tax payments.   One finding was that few taxpayers, given such options, would aid and abet politics -- only 2 percent would contribute to the Presidential campaign, far less than the 12 percent who the Internal Revenue Service says contributed in 1997.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices fall 2.8 percent after National Weather Service forecast that cold weather in Northeast and Midwest will end shortly; February contract drops 35 cents, to $11.99 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Azerbaijan Asks the U.S. To Establish Military Base
abstract: Vafa Guluzade, chief foreign affairs adviser to ailing Pres Heydar Aliyev, says United States and Turkish military bases would be welcome in Azerbaijan as protection from Russia, interviews; cites evidence that Russia sends advanced arms to Armenia, Azerbaijan's neighbor and enemy; American officials, who have not gotten formal request for base, are wary but intrigued (M)

headline: Click for Customer Service. Then Wish You Hadn't.
abstract: Complaints about poor customer service are mounting with rapid growth in on-line retailing; Web sites of retailers and other companies often create false illusion that companies are accessible and easy to interact with; table of sites rated best at customer service by customers; photo (M)1

headline: U.S. and I.M.F. Warn Brazil Not to Try to Prop Up Currency
abstract: Senior Clinton Administration officials and International Monetary Fund warns Brazil's Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso that his Government is unlikely to hold devaluation of its currency to 8 percent, and might waste billions of dollars of its precious foreign currency reserves attempting to do so; warning comes as Brazilian stock market falls 10 percent before it is shut down, and as currency speculators force Brazil to spend more than $1 billion in attempt to keep currency, the real, from falling further (M)

headline: 3 Victims in Colombia Defended Indigenous People
abstract: Associates say three Americans kidnapped and killed while on mission to help Uwa people of Colombia distinguished themselves in United States and in international organizations as passionate defenders of environment and of rights of indigenous people; biographical sketches of three, Lahe'ena'e Gay, Terence Freitas and Ingrid Washinawatok; photos (M)

headline: Albright Introduces a New Phrase to Promote Hussein's Ouster
abstract: US Secretary of State Madeleine K Albright makes quick trip to moderate Arab states to explain Clinton Administration's new goal for Iraq: 'regime change,' jargon for overthrow of Saddam Hussein; Albright is seeking support from leaders of Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan; Albright's spokesman, James P Rubin, says Albright found general agreement in these countries on goal of policy, but that sentiment is that overthrow should come from within Iraq rather than from outside; Clinton Administration officials say no decision has been made on how to assist Iraqi opposition groups or whether to give them lethal or non-lethal aid; photo (M)

headline: MCDONALD'S IS SLOWING ITS EXPANSION IN RUSSIA
abstract: McDonald's Corp says it slows its expansion in Russia in face of plunging ruble; says it might open another five restaurants there this year (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TRANSMEDIA NETWORK INC., Miami, said it was negotiating with the Signature Group, a unit of the retailer Montgomery Ward, to buy its Dining A La Card unit, which, like the Transmedia card, enables users to receive cash back on visits to participating restaurants.

headline: Japanese Stocks Hit 3-Month Low
abstract: Japanese stocks suffer their biggest declines in three months on concern a stronger yen will prevent exporters from meeting their profit forecasts; benchmark Nikkei 225 stock average drops 426.28, or 3.1 percent, to 13,415.89 (S)

headline: Citigroup Joins Mastercard's Smaller Board
abstract: Citigroup, which has abandoned Visa International's board and plans to issue only Mastercards, joins Mastercard International board, which is cut from 31 to 17 members; Citigroup official Robert Wilumstead is named to board, along with Orient Corp chairman Hiroshi Arai; Donald Boudreau remains chairman (M)

headline: Lights, Sound, DVD
abstract: Peter H Lewis assesses quality of DVD players now available or about to enter the market; says prices are coming down, with units typically ranging from low of $200 to well over $1,000 depending on features (M)

headline: The Time-Killing 1040
abstract: James Schembari Midstream column on burden on babyboomers who spend much time preparing their own tax returns or gathering records for their accountants; drawing (M)

headline: Sir Anthony Nutting, 79, Dies; 'No' on Suez Cost His Career
abstract: Sir Anthony Nutting, British Deputy Foreign Secretary who sacrificed potentially brilliant political career by resigning over Britain's involvement in 1956 attack on Suez, dies at age of 79; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA    JAPAN: NEW JUSTICE MINISTER  A 65-year-old legislator, Takao Jinnouchi, has been appointed Justice Minister, replacing Shozaburo Nakamura, who resigned after a scandal in which he allowed the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger to enter Japan without a passport. Mr. Nakamura, a fan of the actor, has denied that he took home documents permitting the actor to enter Japan instead of filing them with the ministry.   (Agence France-Presse)    JAPAN: U.S. GETS OKINAWA BASE  Urasoe, a small city on Okinawa, decided to allow a U.S. naval port to relocate there in return for Japanese Government aid to develop the city's waterfront. Under a 1974 agreement, the U.S. agreed to return its military port in Naha, the capital of Okinawa prefecture, on condition that the port be relocated on Okinawa. Until Urasoe made an offer, no city appeared to want the base.   (AP)

headline: Major Auto Makers Report Record Sales
abstract: Most major auto makers, including Ford Motor Co, DaimlerChrysler AG and American Honda, report record sales for February; sales rose 8 percent, to 319,340 vehicles at Ford; sales at DaimlerChrysler totaled 215,450 unit, up 8 percent over year ago; Honda reports record car and truck sales of 81,910 units, up 14 percent from year ago; Volkswagen reports its best February in 18 years; Audi had best February since 1986; Volvo, Subaru and Kia also report higher sales (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Protecting a patient's rights without inviting lawsuits.
abstract: Michael M Weinstein (Economic Scene) column on who should control patient care; says Senate Labor Committee will vote this week on patient protection bill that would turn ultimate decision in cases where beside physicians and insurance companies disagree over to expert panels, some at faraway academic medical centers; notes just how to carry out external review remains controversial; bill was proposed by James M Jeffords, Republican chairman of Labor Committee (M)

headline: Outlook Is Dim for Guangdong's Creditors
abstract: The Chinese Government will soon announce how it plans to cover the debts of the nation's second-largest financial company, which it closed in October, and the news for foreign bankers is likely to be bad.    China closed the financial arm of the company, the Guangdong International Trust and Investment Corporation, because the company could not repay more than $2 billion of foreign debt. Since then, banks have been submitting claims for what they say they are owed. Claims may be submitted until Jan. 6.

headline: Ice Road Journal; Big Rigs Out on the Ice, Holding Their Breath
abstract: Article on truckers who perform dangerous job of transporting heavy loads on ice roads that traverse 400 miles of frozen lakes and burned-out tundra during coldest part of tough winters in Canada's remote Northwest Territories; ice roads, which cost millions to create, allows mining companies to save by bringing in heavy equipment on trucks rather than on planes; photos; map (M)

headline: Pechiney's Net Rises; Unit Will Trade in U.S.
abstract: Pechiney SA indicates 1998 second-half earnings rose about 9 percent, to 130 million euros ($142 million), compared with equivalent of 119.5 million euros in 1997 period; reports full-year profit rose to 311 million euros, from 277 million; plans to list its beverage can division on New York Stock Exchange (S)

headline: It's NATO Peacekeepers, Not Bombs, Irking Serbs
abstract: Threat of NATO air strikes has grown familiar over last few months and few Serbs seem to think they will actually happen now; issue that is far more important to Serbs living in Kosovo is whether NATO-led military force will come to enforce peace settlement; Serbs are violently opposed to such a plan, which will give ethnic Albanians self-rule in Kosovo, and they place blame for idea on United States; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Crosses 10,000 Mark But Retreats for the Day  The Dow Jones industrial average continued its flirtation with the 10,000-point mark, even crossing it briefly. But it reversed its early climb and ended the session down 28.30 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 9,930.47.

headline: Tyson May Sell Units
abstract: Tyson Foods Inc might sell its pork and seafood divisions to concentrate on chicken sales (S)

headline: As Ulster Peace Effort Stalls, Eyes Turn to U.S.
abstract: Irish and British officials are looking increasingly to President Clinton for another intervention in the Northern Ireland peace effort, hoping he can end the dispute over the disarmament of the Irish Republican Army.
