The dispute threatens to end attempts by Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders to achieve lasting peace in the northern British province.

headline: CNET BUYS KILLERAPP FOR $46.7 MILLION IN STOCK
abstract: CNET Inc buys Killerapp Corp for about $46.7 million in stock (S)

headline: Gain by Pharmacia Hints at a Turnaround
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc reports net income of $137 million for fourth quarter compared with loss of $128 million a year earlier; sales rose 9 percent, to $1.85 billion from $1.70 billion (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; As Jones Apparel and Nine West plan nuptials, some investors already want an annulment.
abstract: Market Place column prompted by expected merger of Jones Apparel Group Inc and Nine West Group Inc; notes that companies have much in common; their chairmen, Sidney Kimmel and Jerome Fisher, are friends who built their companies with same goals and ideas; says both men took their companies public, even using same investment banker to do so, but still run their businessses as if they were privately held; notes that while two companies say merger will make them stronger, investors have doubts; notes at least four lawsuits have been filed on behalf of Nine West shareholders, who say company did not look hard enough for another buyer (M)

headline: Iacocca Mourns Loss of Big Three
abstract: Former Chrysler chairman Lee A Iacocca expresses disappointment with Chrysler's merger wtih Daimler-Benz but predicts venture will succeed; is promoting electric bicycle; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SAPIENT CORP.,  Cambridge, Mass., a maker of web software, acquired Adjacency Inc. of San Francisco, an Internet consulting firm, for $54 million in stock.    OFFICE DEPOT INC., Delray Beach, Fla., the office-products retailer, acquired the remaining 50 percent of its Japanese operations from its joint-venture partner, Deo Deo Corp., for about $28 million.

headline: Stock Mutual Fund Deposits Remained Light Last Month
abstract: Investment Company Institute says mutual fund investors remained relatively unimpressed in December with stock market's sharp rebound, pouring just $3.4 billion into stock funds even as market continued steady climb back from its late-summer selloff; officials say January is shaping up much better (M)

headline: Korea Plans to Raise $24.5 Billion for Banks
abstract: South Korea plans to sell 29.6 trillion won, or $24.5 billion, of Government bonds this year, one-third more than it sold in 1998, to help pay for the revamping of the nation's battered financial institutions.    At that amount, Government bonds will account for more than 10 percent of total domestic bond sales, up from only 1 percent last year, the Finance and Economy Ministry said this week. The ministry itself plans to sell 22.6 trillion won in bonds.

headline: France Sells a Third of Aerospatiale to Groupe Lagardere
abstract: French Government announces agreement on terms of long-expected combination of state-owned Aerospatiale group and privately owned Matra High Technology; Groupe Lagardere, Matra's owner, will pay Government as much as $345 million for third of shares in new company, Aerospatiale-Matra; it would become world's fifth-largest military and aerospace contractor; French authorities hope that restructured company could eventually attract DaimlerChrysler Aerospace (M)

headline: S.E.C. Explores Directors' Roles
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission schedules conference on 'the critical watchdog role' that independent mutual fund directors play in protecting the interest of fund shareholders (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee futures rise amid concern about small midseason crop in Colombia, world's largest producer of arabica beans; in New York, coffee for May delivery rises 2.05 cents, to $1.062 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Pearson Hopes to Sell Some Publishing Units
abstract: Pearson PLC says it will try to sell several Simon & Schuster reference and business publishing divisions it acquired from Viacom Inc in 1998 (S)

headline: EMC SIGNS A $3 BILLION, 5-YEAR DEAL WITH I.B.M.
abstract: International Business Machines Corp, expanding plan to profit from sales of its technology, wins $3 billion parts order from rival, EMC Corp; five-year deal is likely to include custom computer chips as well as cross-licensing of computer storage technology (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AFRICA    GUINEA-BISSAU: THOUSANDS FLEE FIGHTING  Thousands of people scrambled to flee Bissau, the capital, as fighting intensified between loyalist and rebel forces, and the rebels announced ''a final assault'' on the city. At least 15 people were reported killed. The fighting appeared to signal the end of an accord in November that halted a five-month civil war in the former Portuguese colony.   (AP)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: LAW LORDS TO RULE ON PINOCHET -- Seven Law Lords, instead of the usual five, will decide whether Gen. Augusto Pinochet, as former Chilean head of state,  enjoys immunity from arrest or must face extradition proceedings to put him on trial in Spain for crimes against humanity. The hearing, which starts Jan. 18, was prompted by the unprecedented setting aside last month of an earlier judgment against the former dictator because one judge failed to disclose his wife's involvement with Amnesty International, a party to the case.   Warren Hoge (NYT)    RUSSIA: A NEW FIGHTER -- A MIG fighter jet was unveiled outside Moscow, though the plane has yet to carry out its maiden flight. The ''multifunctional fighter'' has been kept under wraps since development began in the late 1980's. The aircraft has only carried out runs on the airfield but is expected to take to the air at the end of February, said its chief designer, Mikhail Korzhuyev.   (AP)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Walking a Brazilian High Wire; Can BankBoston Take More Shocks in Latin America?
abstract: BankBoston, oldest bank in US, is being buffeted by fears that Brazil's economic crisis may overwhelm it; bank has also been embarrassed by financial scandal, trading losses and untimely and expension acquisition; its stock has plunged from 52-week high at time when mergers are sweeping banking industry, and as a result, bank is now seen by analysts as takeover target; Brazil is plagued with unusually brutal economic problems, and BankBoston lacks overall heft of other banks that have decided to run risks of doing business there; BankBoston executives acknowledge hardships of last year, but they remain confident bank is well positioned for long haul; bank president Henrique Meirelles and chief executive Charles K Gifford comment; graph; photos (M)

headline: Seeking More Sizzle, Details Magazine Hires Maxim's Editor
abstract: Conde Naste, seeking more sizzle, appoints Mark Golin, editor in chief of Maxim magazine, to be editor in chief of Details magazine; after weeks of intense speculation, Michael Caruso, current editor in chief of Details, steps down; Maxim, testosterone-rich, off-color bible of sports, sex and humor for young men, has proved to be one of most successful new magazines of decade; photo (M)

headline: ORACLE TO SPLIT ITS STOCK 3 FOR 2 AFTER PRICE DOUBLES
abstract: Oracle Corp will split its shares 3 for 2 after stock more than doubles since September (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STANDARD REGISTER CO., Dayton, Ohio, a data management and business forms company, agreed to acquire DuPont's printing operation in Boothwyn, Pa., for undisclosed terms. The company also signed a $100 million, five-year outsourcing agreement with DuPont.    I.B.M. CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the computer maker, filed to raise as much as $4 billion from sales of debt, preferred stock or other securities.    WALGREEN CO., Deerfield, Ill., the drugstore chain, said its board of directors had declared a 2-for-1 stock split to shareholders of record on Jan. 27, that will be distributed on Feb. 12.

headline: Path to a Comfortable Retirement: Knowing What to Spend When
abstract: AH, retirement, and early retirement at that. Trips to Hawaii and Mexico. Lazy days restoring a sailboat.    These are some of the activities of Ken and Marilyn Rocky of Little Silver, N.J., who are now planning to travel to England, having just returned from Puerto Vallarta. They have started on a life of travel and a pursuit of their own interests -- and are loving it.

headline: Clinton Urges Sides to Pursue Peace in Ulster
abstract: Pres Clinton, with nearly year-old Northern Ireland peace agreement facing critical turning point, urges both sides to move ahead in forming joint Protestant-Catholic government; meets separately with Northern Ireland First Min David Trimble, Deputy First Min Seamus Mallon, Sinn Fein leader Gerry Adams and Ireland Prime Min Bertie Ahern before annual St Patrick's Day reception at White House (M)

headline: Dell Reports Strong Quarter, But Wall Street Isn't Satisfied
abstract: Dell Computer Corp reports fourth-quarter earnings that match analysts' estimates, but investors sell off shares because of slowing of growth rate; Dell reports earnings of $425 million for quarter ended Jan 29, up 49 percent from $285 million in year-earlier period; revenues rose 38 percent, to $5.17 billion, from $3.74 billion in fourth quarter of 1998 fiscal year (M)

headline: Report Issued Early Shows Rise in Producer Prices
abstract: Labor Department reports prices paid to producers rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December; for all of 1998, Producer Price Index fell one-tenth of 1 percent; in 1997, index declined 1.2 percent (S)

headline: The Attractions of Asian Art
abstract: Rich and famous attending International Asian Art Fair in Manhattan, cautious in their spending, nevertheless raise $400,000 for Asia Society; photo (S)

headline: For Serbs, Apparatchik Appeals to Nationalist Pride to Become a Hero
abstract: Profile of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, who transformed self from colorless Communist hack into Serbian nationalist firebrand in 1987 with his support for Serbian minority in Kosovo; he used nationalism to gain power and set Yugoslavia on course of conflict, fragmentation and violence; photo (M)

headline: SIMON PROPERTY PLANS A NATIONAL AD CAMPAIGN
abstract: Simon Property Group Inc, largest American owner of shopping malls, to begin national advertising campaign in attempt to make its name more recognizable; company plans to put Simon name on more than 240 malls it owns across US and will spend $22 million for television commercials (S)

headline: DEADLINE IS TODAY
abstract: Kosovo peace talks near collapse as ethnic Albanian delegates refuse to sign proposed agreement despite exhortations of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright and last-minute visit from NATO Commander, Gen Wesley K Clark; Americans seem flabbergasted by spectacle of little-known insurgents holding US at bay and undermining Clinton Administration's strategy for agreement regarded as disproportionately benefiting ethnic Albanians; their main objection is absence of word 'referendum' in document, even though draft calls for international conference to assess 'will of the people'; refusal prevents US and allies from pressuring Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to agree to presence of NATO-led peacekeeping troops in Kosovo and puts hold on movement of thousands of NATO troops in advanced stages of preparation; attacks on villages in Kosovo and fighting between Govt troops and rebels increase; Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is providing monitors for fading cease-fire, accuses Serbian troops of attacking and harassing monitors; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: Ben West, president of West Wayne, is named to additional position of chief executive, succeeding Knox Massey Jr, who is named chairman of finance committee; Carl Nichols is named president of Einson Freeman Inc, succeeding Jeffrey K McElnea, who continues as chairman and chief executive; Ernie Schenck joins GSD&M in new position being called full-time freelance creative director; Don Brashears, executive vice president at Chicago office of Cramer-Krasselt, is named to additional new position of general manager, assuming many duties that had been handled by Peter Krivkovich, agency's president, who was named chief executive in July; Richard Ginsburg is named to new post of senior vice president for business development at Lois/EJL; Steven M Yorra is named to new position of senior vice president and account services director at Grey Entertainment, unit of Grey Advertising; Janet Northen is named to new position of senior vice president and communications director at McKinney & Silver (M)

headline: Alternative Minimum Tax: A Matter of Deductions
abstract: Katherine Montgomery letter on Jan 10 article notes very large middle-class family could avoid alternative minimum tax by claiming fewer exemptions

headline: Dreaming the Impossible Dream
abstract: In 1999, things will be different: You will carry out your New Year's resolution to advance your career or resolve a workplace conflict. Well, maybe. But what about past years? How close did you come to meeting a work-related goal that you set for yourself in January? Or, how did your efforts go awry?  Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: It May Still Be Certain, but at Least It's Easier
abstract: Web sites that deal with tax information have become more sophisticated; Internal Revenue Service says 25 million returns were filed electronically in 1998; agency expects that number to climb to 30 million this year; photo (M)

headline: On-Line Trading Woes Ruffle All Sides in Deals
abstract: Many small investors are frustrated with limitations of stock trading over Internet, even as they continue to pour money into on-line brokerage firms that now account for one of every four retail stock trades; trading frenzy that is causing headaches for them is also causing trouble for market makers--professional trading firms that match buyers with sellers or take other side of trades themselves--forcing them to change their procedures to keep up (M)

headline: Turkey Reassures U.S. on Air Base
abstract: Turkey reassures United States that it will continue to let US planes use Turkish base for attacks on Iraq despite planned visit by Iraqi Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz; Prime Min Bulent Ecevit defends visit by neighbor (M)

headline: G.M. WINS TAX-FREE STATUS FOR DELPHI SPINOFF
abstract: General Motors Corp's planned spinoff of its Delphi Automotive Systems Corp parts unit is granted tax-free status by Internal Revenue Service (S)

headline: Why Roll the Dice?
abstract: Proposals to invest Social Security funds it stock market are viewed warily by many people, among them Edith Chvala, who is 75 and lives in Silver City, NM, on $542 a month from Social Security and a $161-a-month pension, and L Douglas Lee, chief economist at HSBC Securities; he believes Government should fund the social welfare aspects of Social Security, like programs for the disabled and dependent children of workers who die; is suspicious of conventional wisdom that current system faces bankruptcy; does favor putting part of budget surplus into Social Security, in effect reducing the Federal debt (M)

headline: Retired Executives Offer Help on Line
abstract: World Wide Web is being studied by retired executives to better guide young business people; 12,400 people belong to Score, Service Corps of Retired Executives, group with 389 chapters around nation that offer free guidance to entrepreneurs; many Score members retired long before 'E-commerce' commenced; they are immersing themselves in Internet, and Score has Web page that guides would-be clients to closest Score office and other helpful Web sites; it even offers hot lines to few, including Small Business Administration and various consultants who offer advice on Year 2000 computer problems; it also lets clients ask advice of Score members via E-mail; photo (M)

headline: Nowhere to Surf
abstract: Mitch Field letter recalls early television remote control (Feb 11 article)

headline: Compressed Data; Titans Race to Do the Policing For the Electronic Roadway
abstract: First meeting of Global Business Dialogue attracts captains of media and technology industries; their goal is to prevent conflicting governmental regulations from obstrucing business in cyberspace; they plan to devise their own united policies on such issues as on-line privacy and taxation under umbrella of new organization; photo (M)

headline: Besieged U.N. Commission Chief Will Not Seek Another Term
abstract: Richard Butler, embattled chairman of United Nations commission charged with disarming Iraq of weapons of mass destruction, says he does not expect to seek another term as chairman but that he would resist any effort to oust him before his contract expires in June; Butler accuses Russia of trying to divert attention from Iraq's violations of its disarmament commitments and repeated efforts to conceal information and material from weapons inspectors; Sergey Lavrov, Russia's Security Council representative, has led fierce campaign against Butler and his commission, saying Butler is untrustworthy and biased; United States officials at UN seek to counter growing impression among diplomats that American support for Butler and his commission is weakening (M)

headline: Iraq's Parliament Puts Off Vote of Defiance Against U.N.
abstract: Government of Iraq, after more than month of rising defiance, postpones vote in which Parliament seemed ready to take further steps along collision course with Western foes; issues only mild statement critical of recent American-led air strikes, which prompted calls from some legislators for measures that would have been direct challenge to UN; photo (M)

headline: Kingstown Journal; An Outpost in the Banana and Marijuana Wars
abstract: US troops helped destroy over one million marijuana plants in Dec on St Vincent, second largest grower in Caribbean after Jamaica; growers on island were outraged; they protested on radio and in front of Government offices, appealed to business and political leaders and even started petition drive to ask Pres Clinton for damages; there is marked hostility against Clinton for waging war with Europe over banana trade preferences, legitimate backbone of island's economy; map; photos (M)

headline: Retirement-Happy Funds
abstract: Assets quadrupled for direct-marketed no-load fund firms specializing in 401K or defined-contribution retirement plans, to $52.9 billion in 1997, from $13.6 billion in 1996; plans accounted for 49.4 percent of all money flowing into such funds (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Warren Buffett Attacks Manipulation of Earnings  In his annual report to shareholders, the investor Warren E. Buffett makes an extraordinary attack on many of his fellow chief executives, who he says have worked purposefully ''at manipulating numbers and deceiving investors'' through accounting gimmicks and misrepresentations.    ''Many major corporations still play things straight, but a significant and growing number of otherwise high-grade managers -- C.E.O.'s you would be happy to have as spouses for your children or as trustees under your will -- have come to the view that it's O.K. to manipulate earnings to satisfy what they believe are Wall Street's desires,'' Mr. Buffett wrote in Berkshire Hathaway's 1998 report. [Page C2.]

headline: Clinton Asks Panel to Analyze and Solve Security Threats to Nuclear Labs
abstract: Pres Clinton asks an advisory panel today to analyze security threats at Energy Department's nuclear laboratories, after suspicions surfaced that China stole nuclear-weapons designs from United States (S)

headline: Credit Suisse to Acquire a Warburg, Pincus Unit for $650 Million
abstract: Credit Suisse Group will acquire Warburg Pincus Asset Management Inc for $650 million, a move that allows asset management arm of Credit Suisse to expand its sales of mutual funds and retirement investment products in US; deal is expected to close this summer following regulatory approvals (M)

headline: Italy Sets Ownership Limit on Soccer Rights
abstract: Italy's ruling coalition agrees to limit single broadcaster's ownership of soccer pay-television rights to 60 percent; News Corp executive Letizia Moratti says she still plans to bid for all rights to matches of Italy's two top leagues (S)

headline: Gucci and LVMH to Meet About Dispute
abstract: Talks between Gucci Group NV and LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton are moving closer to ending monthlong battle about LVMH's influence over Gucci (S)

headline: Throwing Away the Clock
abstract: Rhea Meltzer letter comments on Jan 31 article on retirement

headline: Sony Pictures, in an accord with MGM, drops its plan to produce new James Bond movies.
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment suffers defeat in long-standing legal dispute with Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc to produce new James Bond movies; Sony Pictures will pay MGM $5 million to settle lawsuit; MGM will pay Sony Pictures $10 million for rights to early James Bond spoof, Casino Royale, which was produced at Columbia Pictures, a Sony unit, and for international rights to James Bond films (Advertising column) (M)

headline: Few in Japan See Bargain In Price of Tobacco Deal
abstract: Japanese investors, analysts and business people are concerned that Japan Tobacco Inc, which bought RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp's international tobacco business for $8 billion, overpaid in acquiring the business; Japan Tobacco shares fall 4.7 percent (M)

headline: People
abstract: Hanft Byrne Raboy & Partners names Chet Halperin business development director, new post; Grey Advertising's Grey Entertainment unit names Rob Jacobson to new post of senior vice president and senior creative director (S)

headline: New Status For Berlin, Everywhere But the Air
abstract: Berlin Mayor Eberhard Diepgen is trying to resolve increasingly desperate problem: city presenting itself as 'new capital of Europe' does not have single direct flight to or from US; Dr Volker Hassemer, chief executive of Berlin Partner, company trying to promote business in city, says situation has become extremely embarrassing for image of Berlin (M)

headline: Tuneups for the Young Brain: Try This at Home
abstract: Margot Slade (Library/Thinking Skills) article on software products designed to offer children opportunity to acquire and practice learning skills in various ways, while allowing parents or children to adjust level of play; offers suggestions to parents on ways to find such software; evaluates four software packages; photo (L)

headline: Iranians Assert Rogue Officers Slew Dissidents
abstract: Iran's Intelligence Ministry says that rogue Iranian intelligence officers were responsible for killings late last year of five prominent critics of Government's conservative wing; Government's public acknowledgment could suggest that, under Pres Mohammad Khatami, Iran may be becoming kind of country in which embarrassing secrets can no longer be permanently harbored; all five of those who were slain had criticized hard-line clerics within Iran's Government who have been principal opponents of Khatami's moves for greater moderation and openness; ministry's statement does not identify or say how many agents have been arrested; dissidents who were killed are Dariush Foruhar and his wife, Parvaneh, Mohammad Jafar Pouyandeh, Mohammad Mokhtari and Majid Sharif (M)

headline: Treasury Offers Bills and Notes
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills, one-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and 10-year Treasury inflation protected securities being auctioned on Wednesday.    By the close of the New York cash market on Thursday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.45 percent and on a six-month bill was 4.53 percent.

headline: 5 Problems Tarnishing a Robust Economy
abstract: Deep-seated problems remain despite benefits of temporary buoyant economy; discussion of five profound problems facing American economy: income inequality, wealth inequality, sluggish productivity, education gap and tattered safety blanket; drawing (M)

headline: Judging the Tuition Plans
abstract: College Savings Bank chairman Peter A Roberts letter expands on February 28 article on tax incentives for parents who prepay college tuition (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Can You Play 'Feelings' On the Ocarina?
abstract: New Nintendo video game, Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time, is expected to become one of best-selling video games ever; its popularity seems to have spawned another craze--demand for real ocarinas, flute-like musical instruments that look line sweet potatoes with finger holes; photo (M)

headline: Hong Kong Asks Its High Court to Clarify Ruling Beijing Dislikes
abstract: Hong Kong government asks its high court to clarify landmark ruling opposed by China that children born on mainland who have at least one parent living in Hong Kong have right to residency; move rattles legal experts, who say government seems to be pressing court to retreat before China forces its hand; see threat to autonomy (M)

headline: Serbs Hold Foreign Reporters
abstract: Serbian military authorities begin to crack down on foreign journalists who are reporting news of NATO air strikes from Yugoslavia; briefly detain Washington Post correspondent Peter Finn, shut down all television transmission complexes and threaten CNN crew in Pristina (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; The Chinese Chase a Ticket to Bliss (That's a Car)
abstract: Lotteries are being held in Beijing and other cities across China as part of Lunar New Year festivities, drawing hundreds of thousands of hopeful participants; Government, which has discovered a politically painless way to supplement its revenues even as it supposedly maintains general ban on gambling, estimates that lotteries scheduled between Oct 1998 and June 1999 will sell tickets equivalent to $1.20 for every Chinese, or close to $1.5 billion; photos (M)

headline: AMERICAN WATER WORKS PLANS NEW ACQUISITION
abstract: American Water Works Company will acquire National Enterprise Inc for $475 million in stock, as well as assumption of $226 million in debt; New Jersey-based utility completed 22 acquisitions in 1998, adding 55,000 customers, and awaits regulatory approval of 23 other merger agreements (S)

headline: A Frenzy of Cross-Border Mergers
abstract: Many American companies merged with or were acquired by foreign concerns in 1998; photo (S)

headline: Insurers Pay the Brokers, Making Customers Wary
abstract: Contingency fees insurance companies pay commercial insurance brokers and extent to which they should be disclosed are hot topic in commercial insurance business in United States, Canada and Britain; brokers get hefty commissions and fees from corporate clients to shop for best coverage at best price; risk managers are concerned that rapid consolidation of brokerage industry will enable brokers, less restrained by competition, to divert business to insurers who offer them biggest incentives; brokers hold contingency fees are small part of total revenue and do not influence their choice of carriers; graphs of brokerage industry concentration; photos (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Mexican Bank's Stock Delisted in New York
abstract: Grupo Financiero Serfin S.A., one of Mexico's largest banking companies, will be suspended from listing on the New York Stock Exchange because its financial problems mean it no longer meets the market's minimum listing requirements.   Exchange officials in New York announced late Wednesday that Serfin's shares would no longer trade starting on Feb. 24, and that the exchange would ask the Securities and Exchange Commission to remove Serfin from its list.

headline: F.B.I. Helped Chile Search For Leftists, Files Show
abstract: The F.B.I. tried to track suspected associates of Chilean leftists in the United States in the 1970's on behalf of the Government of Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the Chilean dictator, newly declassified documents show.    The Federal Bureau of Investigation sent agents in New York and Dallas to search for two people whose names were found in the address book of a courier for an underground Marxist group in Chile. The courier was arrested in Paraguay in 1975, and the Paraguayan police passed on the information to American officials, the records show.

headline: Toyota President Is Choice to Lead Trade Group
abstract: Japan Federation of Employers' Associations seeks to elect as its new chairman Hirochi Okuda, president of Toyota Motor Corp; federation, known as Nikkeiren, faces its biggest challenge since World War II; Japan's unemployment rate has reached 4.4 percent, almost double rate country is accustomed to (M)

headline: A Fresh Set Of U.S. Goals
abstract: R W Apple Jr analysis notes that in hours before missiles began striking targets in Kosovo, White House and State Dept denied that NATO was trying to bomb Serbia back to bargaining table and force Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic to sign peace agreement; maintains that neither Pres Clinton nor other senior American officials have addressed important questions such as who will maintain peace in Kosovo once bombs have stopped falling (M)

headline: LEAR AGREES TO BUY SEAT BUSINESS OF HYUNDAI MOTOR
abstract: Lear Corp, world's largest maker of car seats and automotive interiors, agrees to buy seat business of Hyundai Motor Co of South Korea for about $87 million (US) (S)

headline: An Order for Airbus Hits Its Rival, Boeing, Close to Home
abstract: Airbus Industrie makes further inroads against its archrival, Boeing Co, when Boullioun Aviation Services, fast-growing aircraft leasing company founded by former Boeing executive E H (Tex) Boullioun, announces its first purchase of Airbus jets; Boullioun orders 30 A320 jets; deal is worth $1.3 billion; Boullioun president Robert J Genise comments; Scandinavian Airlines System says deliveries of its new 737 jets are six to 10 weeks behind schedule; Boeing must must pay penalties for such delays (M)

headline: Women's Groups Urge More Breast-Feeding
abstract: Group of women's organizations tells meeting of United Nations Commission on Status of Women that increased breast-feeding could save lives of up to 1.5 million of roughly 12 million children under age of 5 who die every year around world (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Business Digest

headline: Irate Boston Media Fault '60 Minutes' For Nanny Report
abstract: Boston news media assail 60 Minutes over March 7 report questioning aspects of case against of Louise Woodward, young British convicted of kiling an infant in her charge; CBS stands by report; photo (M)

headline: Joining the Fray, More Funds by Blacks, of Blacks and for Blacks
abstract: Article on intense competition among major brokers, including 16 black-managed mutual funds as well as thousands of general-purpose funds, to court expanding black middle class; photo (M)

headline: Concern Rising About Mergers In Health Plans
abstract: Health insurance industry is rapidly whittling itself down to a few giant companies that dominate health systems of some of country's biggest cities; doctors and hospitals are increasingly concerned, and trend is also raising questions about cost and availability of care of millions of patients and their employers; criticism sharpens after recent announcements of two billion-dollar deals that would propel Aetna Inc to first place among nation's health insurers; last month, Aetna agreed to buy Prudential Health Care, No. 5 for-profit managed care company, while it was still digesting its July purchase of NYL-Care, No. 11 (M)

headline: Mergers
abstract: Online Partners.com Inc and Pridecom Productions are merging under Online Partners name; terms undisclosed; merged company will operate Gay.com Network; Andrew Cramer continues as chairman and chief executive at Online Partners.com, and Mark Elderkin, president at Pridecom, becomes president at Online Partners.com (S)

headline: CIT to Acquire Newcourt in Stock Swap
abstract: CIT Group to acquire Newcourt Credit Group Inc in stock swap valued at about $4.2 billion; Albert R Gamper, CIT's president and chief executive, will become chairman and chief executive of new company, which will retain CIT name; Steven K Hudson, Newcourt's president and chief executive, will be president of merged company (M)

headline: Sinn Fein Negotiator Predicts Success of Peace Talks for Ulster
abstract: Martin McGuinness, chief negotiator for Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, says growing crisis in Northern Ireland peace effort will be resolved by end of March, target date for British Govt to return home rule powers to northern province of Ulster (M)

headline: Germany to Compensate 240 American Survivors of Nazi Camps
abstract: US and Germany announce tentative agreement for German Govt to compensate estimated 240 Americans who were imprisoned in Nazi concentration camps; survivors will reportedly receive $100,000 each, which would put total value of settlement at $24 million (M)

headline: Sterkfontein Journal; Solving a 3.5-Million-Year-Old, 3-D Jigsaw Puzzle
abstract: Interview with Dr Ronald J Clarke, South African anthropologist engaged in effort to extract skeleton believed to be 3.5 million years old from Sterkfontein caves near Johannesburg; his discovery, announced in December 1998, may help answer some enduring questions about human evolution; scientists have likened find to discovery of famous 'Lucy' skeleton in Ethiopia in 1974; photo; maps (M)

headline: iVillage Offering Is Priced Higher
abstract: Price range for initial public offering by iVillage Inc is being increased, move that could raise the proceeds by as much as 58 percent; shares will now be offered at $22 to $24 each (S)

headline: Calling In Experts to Fix Microsoft if It's Broken
abstract: Analysis of possible steps court could take if Microsoft Corp loses antitrust case; says if US wins suit, which is expected, remedies range from full breakup of company to 'behaviorial modification'--prohibiting Microsoft from writing exclusive contracts, requiring it to publicly disclose software specifications for Windows, forcing it to publish Windows pricing list for major manufacturers, and requiring antitrust training for all Microsoft managers (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.69   4.49   5.48        3-month T-bills   4.35   4.31   4.87        6-month T-bills   4.35   4.32   4.89        10-yr. T-infl.   3.87   3.80   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.86   4.77   5.41        30-yr. T-bond   5.27   5.22   5.73        Telephone bd.   6.87   6.84   7.06        Municipal bds.   5.20   5.19   5.13          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Wolverhampton Wins Bid for Marston Brewery
abstract: Wolverhampton and Dudley Breweries PLC wins its $473.7 million (US) bid for Marston, Thompson & Evershed PLC in acquisition that will create Britain's largest regional brewer (S)

headline: FINE AIR SERVICES AGREES TO BUY A RIVAL FOR $115 MILLION
abstract: The Fine Air Services Corporation, a cargo airline, agreed yesterday to buy a rival, Arrow Air, from International Air Leases Inc. for $115 million in cash. The purchase includes Arrow's 13 DC-8's, 4 L-1011's and about 130 jet engines, as well as aircraft parts and service sites. Arrow had $87.5 million in revenue for the year ended September 1998. The companies, based in Miami, are closely held. Fine Air, which had 1998 revenue of $116 million, pulled back its $123.3 million initial public offering in August 1997 after one of its cargo planes crashed in Miami, killing five people.

headline: Among Rebels' Officer-Trainees, No Sign Kosovo Fighting Is Over
abstract: Officer-trainees in Kosovo Liberation Army are still preparing for war even as talks progress in France to reach agreement between rebels in Kosovo province and Serbian Govt; those at training school near village of Suva Rika say they will obey superiors' commands following any peace with Serbs; say core of rebel force must remain intact and armed, in order to protect ethnic Albanians when Western forces leave; over period of year, rebel army has gone from ragtag guerrilla bands to force of between 10,000 and 15,000, equipped with increasingly sophisticated weapons and bent on achieving not only autonomy for Kosovo being offered at peace talks, but independence for Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority; photos; map (M)

headline: A Satisfied, Although Intense, Sportscaster
abstract: Fox Sports News has hired Keith Olbermann as its $1-million-a-year anchor in aggressive attempt to compete wih ESPN, which for nearly 20 years has owned sports-news franchise; Olbermann left ESPN in public pique in 1997; photo (M)

headline: SILICON GRAPHICS BUYS STAKE IN WAM NET FOR $75 MILLION
abstract: Silicon Graphics Inc acquires 8.6 percent stake in Wam Net Inc for $75 million in cash and real estate (S)

headline: Regulators Delay Ruling on Bid by Olivetti
abstract: Regulatory agency for Italian stock market postpones decision on validity of Olivetti's revised $60 billion takeover bid for Telecom Italia (S)

headline: A Growing Gap Between the Savers and the Save-Nots
abstract: Most important division among today's retirees is between those who own their own homes and those who do not: homeowners retire with average net worth of $115,000, while nonhomeowners have $800; this gap is expected to grow in years ahead as baby boomers begin retiring; drawing (M)

headline: Coal's Hot Competition Forges a Breed of Giants
abstract: US coal industry is increasingly controlled by well-financed, sharply focused companies, with top 10 companies now controlling 61 percent of nation's output, up from 35 percent in 1988; causes include changes in mining technology that require economies of scale, practices of electric utilities, which have tripled their coal consumption since 1970, and the fact that smaller operators are at disadvantage bargainging with railroads; profit margins are squeezed as lucrative long-term contracts written in 1970's and 80's expire and utilities demand progressively lower rates in new contracts; photo; graph (M)

headline: Deal Reached By Goodyear And Sumitomo
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co and Sumitomo Rubber Industries Ltd will combine many of their plants and sales operations into huge joint venture with annual sales of about $15.5 billion; Goodyear, which will be controlling partner, will pay Sumitomo about $936 million for assets it contributes; two companies will swap about $110 million in stock, giving Goodyear 10 percent of Sumitomo, and giving Sumitomo 1.4 percent stake in Goodyear; Michelin Group and Bridgestone Corp, leaders in industry, seem unimpressed by Goodyear-Sumitomo venture; chart (M)

headline: Kmart Earnings Sharply Higher
abstract: Kmart Corp says profit rose greater-than-expected 32 percent in its fourth quarter ended Jan 27; net income rose to $353 million compared with profit of $267 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 6.6 percent, to $10.4 billion from $9.76 billion (S)

headline: Rival Gains on Intel With Cheaper Products
abstract: The Intel Corporation's share of the microprocessor market fell to 75.7 percent in the fourth quarter as its rival, Advanced Micro Devices Inc., stole business with its cheaper products, a research firm said.    Market share for Intel, the No. 1 chip maker, slipped from 87.1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1997, according to preliminary numbers from the International Data Corporation. The Advanced Micro Devices share, meanwhile, rose to 15.5 percent, from 6.6 percent in the corresponding quarter a year earlier.

headline: Half a Globe Flown, Half to Go for 2 British Balloonists
abstract: Two British balloonists seeking to become first to circle world nonstop surpass some of their biggest hazards, greatly improving their chances of ultimate success; two, Andy Elson and Colin Prescot, complete dificult maneuvers to skirt Chinese air space, putting their worst political problem behind them; obstacles are still formidable to complete trip; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar ekes out gains against euro on concern that air raids against Serbian forces could sour investors on European assets; graphs (S)

headline: Lord Lewin, 78, British Strategist in Falklands
abstract: Sir Terence Thornton Lewin, British 'seadog' who is credited with engineering his country's victory over Argentina in Falkland Islands war in 1982, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: Agencies Open New York Offices
abstract: Wolff Olins, British corporate identity consultancy based in London, is opening its first US office in New York to provide more support for American-based clients; Kate Manasian, partner, will head New York office; British American Design, specializing in advertising and direct marketing design work, is opened in New York by Peter Eaton and Steve Means (S)

headline: After Ovitz: How Agency Hung Tough
abstract: Creative Artists Agency is locking horns with its founder, Michael Ovitz, and his new company, Artists Management Group; Creative Artists overcame what rivals saw as probable fatal blow--Ovitz's surprise departure four years ago--thanks to skills of its relentlessly ambitious agents and failure of competitors to step into breach; Creative Artists' battle to survive and its eventual clash with Ovitz has overtones of Greek drama, pitting young men against man whom they once considered fearful father-figure; photo; chart listing strengths and weaknesses of three top talent agencies in Hollywood: Creative Artists, International Creative Management and William Morris Agency (M)

headline: Microsoft's Settlement Talks Hinge On PC Makers
abstract: Microsoft Corp lawyers will meet with Justice Dept to seek settlement of antitrust suit against computer giant; main topic of discussion is expected to be nation's personal computer makers--and Microsoft Corp's relationship with them; lawyers say Microsoft must be willing to open up its pricing and marketing contracts with manufacturers in ways that fundamentally alter its relationship with producers of personal computers; Government lawyers claim current relationship too often leaves manufacturers in position of being 'captive distributors' for Microsoft software; Microsoft has reportedly told Government that overhauling its relationship with PC makers would amount to change in competitive structure of industry; if Government wins case, it could demand that Microsoft be broken up, or that Microsoft license software code for its industry-standard Windows operating system (M)

headline: I.B.M. Earnings Beat Analysts' Estimates
abstract: International Business Machines Corp reports 12 percent gain in fourth-quarter earnings, to $2.35 billion, which exceeds analysts' estimates; revenues rise 6 percent, to $25.13 billion; global services and software account for nearly 60 percent of gross profits at company; personal computer sales are up, but revenues from mainframes and servers are both down (M)

headline: Scanners: Softening Up Hard Copies
abstract: Article describes uses of scanning device and discusses various models available; diagrams (M)

headline: More Cycling Sites
abstract: List of some additional Internet sites on cycling (S)

headline: KODAK SAYS IT MAY SELL EASTMAN SOFTWARE DIVISION
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co says it might sell its unprofitable Eastman Software division, which was acquired two years ago from Wang Laboratories for $260 million (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Bombs Fall, Goal Unmet?
abstract: Reports of multiplying atrocities filtering out of Kosovo indicate NATO bombing raids have failed so far to meet even modest goals set by NATO and Pres Clinton of bolstering NATO credibility, deterring attacks on Kosovo Albanians and severely damaging Serb war-making machinery; it is unclear whether NATO has met first goal of weakening air defenses; photo (M)

headline: Charles J. Elia, Retired Business Writer, 72
abstract: Charles J Elia, retired business reporter and columnist, dies at age 72 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT CORP. Plymouth Meeting, Pa., said it had acquired 26 industrial buildings in South Carolina for $49.6 million.

headline: MCI Worldcom to Start Internet Service
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc confirms that it will start new Internet access service using information and content from America Online's Compuserve unit; new service allows MCI Worldcom to re-enter consumer Internet business that MCI Communications Corp exited last year; new service is available to MCI long-distance subscribers for $16.95 a month for first 150 hours of local access (S)

headline: Nonfighters In NATO Give Help For Raids
abstract: Iceland has no military. Luxembourg has no air force. Greece does not want to bomb a neighbor. And three other nations not contributing forces to the NATO air war against Serbia have been alliance members for only two weeks.     But those six nations, including the new members -- Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic -- bridle at the suggestion that they are not full partners in the allied attack.

headline: A Science Truly Dismal at Prediction
abstract: Forecasting has never been easy, and economists have been off base more often than not; in early 1999, forecasters seem to be setting some kind of benchmark for inaccuracy; for fourth consecutive year, economic seers have underestimated economic growth so markedly that rush to revise predictions started almost as soon as forecasts were made; old maxims have served economists poorly lately (M)

headline: Cautious King Took Risks In Straddling Two Worlds
abstract: Obituary of Jordan's King Hussein, who died at age 63; cites his twin legacies of peace with neighbors, including Israel, and fairly tolerant, stable society at home; chronology of events in Hussein's life; map; photos (L)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: Acer May Delay $200 Million Stock Sale
abstract: Taiwan's Acer Inc says because of nation's recent stock market slump it might delay $200 million international share sale that it began arranging last July (S)

headline: For Stock Car Fans; Racing Around With No Worry About Crashing
abstract: National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing's interactive division offers racing fans realistic computer games and behind-the-scenes Web site; enthusiasts for multiplayer games have been competing over Internet through Nascar Racing Online Series (www,nros,com) net-based game site available through pay-to-play Total Entertainment Network; hookup explained; game graphic (M)

headline: Shares End the Day Mixed As Dow Takes a Breather
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 9,727.61, down 8.47 points; Nasdaq composite index is up 60.51, or 2.6 percent, to 2,397.62; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index closes up 7.26 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to record 1,282.73; graph; chart (M)

headline: Stewing Over That Project? Laptop Stand Keeps You Cool
abstract: Lapstand Inc offers Lapstand, portable two-pound aluminum-alloy table that folds into size of large paperback book, for holding laptop computers; photo (S)

headline: Sale Set Tomorrow For 52-Week Bill
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a 52-week bill for auction tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 4.35 percent and the rate on the six-month issue, 4.29 percent. The rate for the 52-week bill is 4.29 percent.

headline: Subcontinent Sees a Light
abstract: News analysis of implications of visit by India's Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee to Pakistan, where he held summit with Prime Min Nawaz Sharif (M)

headline: Wary U.S. Broods on a Peace Effort Minus King Hussein
abstract: Clinton Administration officials express alarm at prospect of pursuing comprehensive Mideast peace without Jordan's King Hussein, who is gravely ill; national security adviser Samuel R Berger cites Hussein's importance to regional peace, interview; Hussein's illness has complicated peace effort by unsettling Israel's political and military leaders, who view him as reliable friend in Arab world; photo (M)

headline: AN IOMEGA HAZARD
abstract: Iomega recalls 60,000 external Jaz disk drives because of potential electrical hazard (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH TO TAKE A $172 MILLION CHARGE IN QUARTER
abstract: BellSouth Corp expects to take charge of about $172 million against first-quarter earnings because Brazil's currency devaluation has raised cost of debt for subsidiary BCP Telecomunicacoes SA (S)

headline: U.S Role as World Savior: A Delicate Balancing Act
abstract: Unstated assumption that United States will always be ready to step in to bail out faltering markets and governments around world is risky one; failure of Russian bailout was searing experience, and if instability around world continues, question of whether America should serve as savior of last resort seems likely to come under increasing scrutiny from all sides; photo (M)

headline: Enron to Provide Fiber Optic Feed
abstract: Enron Corp and Real Networks Inc form an alliance to deliver high-quality video to Internet providers and companies over Enron's fiber optic network (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Phillip N. Davidson; American Century Value
abstract: Interview with Phillip N Davidson, who manages American Century Value, a mid-cap fund; fund follows a strict value discipline that is sharply divergent from the more aggressive style of American Century's better-known growth funds; photo (M)

headline: Republic Bank Is Cutting Jobs As Part of Its Reorganization
abstract: Republic New York Corp plans to eliminate about 500 jobs, or about 7 percent of its work force; bank says that 384 of job cuts will be layoffs, while 127 positions will be eliminated through contract arrangements that include new job offers for those employees; rest of cuts will be through attrition and hiring freeze; says moves should result in about $42 million in pretax savings in 1999 (M)

headline: Travel Chaos as Sickout by Pilots Continues
abstract: American Airlines is forced to cancel about half its scheduled flights during Presidents' Day weekend after more than fourth of airline's pilots call in sick in defiance of Federal court order; air travel is disrupted across US, with scenes of chaos and angry passengers at several airports; photo; Judge Joe Kendall delays ruling on request for contempt citation but warns unions to press pilots to return to work (S)

headline: Earnings Rise 23 Percent At Major French Bank
abstract: Banque Nationale de Paris says net income climbed 23 percent in 1998, to 1.11 billion euros, more than analysts expected (S)

headline: Gucci Reports 11% Increase in Earnings
abstract: Gucci Group NV reports 11 percent increase in fiscal year 1999 earnings and says strong results show that Italian fashion house needs no help from LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, French luxury goods maker that is trying to take it over; Gucci reports profits for year ended Jan 31 of $3.28 a share, compared to $2.86 a share a year earlier (M)

headline: German Unemployment Shows a Slight Drop
abstract: Unemployment rate in Germany dropped to 10.5 percent in February from 10.6 percent in January; decline in jobless rolls of 6,000, compares with drop of 66,000 in January (S)

headline: Heroes vs. Intruders (NATO) and Terrorists (Albanians)
abstract: Serbian Govt, which has drawn its television network into daily political life, is harnessing it in cause of Serbia's defense in face of NATO bombing; Serbian television says bombing is part of longstanding 'criminal conspiracy' in West; describes ethnic Albanians in Kosovo as terrorists (M)

headline: Olivetti Improves Bid for Telecom Italia
abstract: Olivetti SpA sweetens its $60 billion takeover offer for Telecom Italia by proposing to buy back 30 percent of company's savings shares if its hostile bid succeeds; also says it will eliminate 15 percent of Telecom Italia's work force, or 19,000 jobs (M)

headline: McDonald's Earnings Up; Stock Split Set
abstract: McDonald's Corp reports fourth-quarter net income rose 9 percent, to $447.1 million, up from $410.9 million in 1997 period; sets 2-for-1 stock split (M)

headline: A Buyout King Looks Ahead
abstract: Buyout expert Thomas H Lee tells New York City breakfast meeting for buyout enthusiasts that leveraged buyout funds are not overfunded because current deals are only moderately leveraged, in range of 2-to-1 or 3-to-1, compared with 10-1 common decade ago, when junk bonds ruled; photo (M)h

headline: Bonds Falter, Taking Stocks With Them
abstract: Bond prices tumble for third consecutive session, pushing interest rates to their highest levels since August; rout in bond market sends stocks sharply lower for much of morning, but major market gauges later stabilize and then pare most of their losses during afternoon; Dow Jones industrial average settles at 9,366.43, down 33.33 points, Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes at 1,245.02, down 8.39 points, and Nasdaq composite index slips 12.56 points, to 2,326.82; price of benchmark 30-year Treasury falls 2 points, to 94 7/32; its yield rises to 5.65 percent, from 5.51 percent on Feb 24; graphs on Dow Jones industrial average and tax-exempt yields; charts on stocks with large percentage gains and losses and US key interest rates (M)

headline: On Line, Few Kick Tires, but Many Look
abstract: Article on Internet's virtual car shopping sites; notes that many shoppers favor independent services over carmaker sites as sources of reliable information; photo; chart (M)

headline: Media Talk; From the New Media Back to the Old
abstract: Crown Books to publish book Gig, collection of columns from on-line magazine Word on how people make their livings (M)

headline: N.E.A. Couldn't Tell a Book by Its Cover
abstract: National Endowment for Arts Chmn William J Ivey cancels grant for The Story of Color after learning from reporter that bilingual children's book was written by Mexican Zapatista guerrilla Subcomandante Marcos and bears picture of him wearing ammunition belt and mask; overrules multilayered, yearlong grant approval process; expresses concern that NEA funds might aid rebels; decision stuns Texas publisher, Cinco Puntos Press, shoestring operation that laid out $15,000 to print books; Bobby Byrd, who runs company, says he made it clear in grant proposal that guerrillas would not get NEA money; photos (M)

headline: COSMETIC CENTER TO CLOSE 116 STORES
abstract: Cosmetic Center Inc says it will close 116 of its perfume and cosmetic stores, almost half total number, and dismiss 875 workers (S)

headline: Many Flaws Blamed in Embassy Attacks
abstract: State Department investigation of last summer's bombings of two American embassies in East Africa finds that 'collective failure' by senior Government officials and lawmakers over decadees has left number of American embassies vulnerable to terrorist attack; senior Clinton Adm officials say two panels--both led by Adm William J Crowe, retired Chmn of Joint Chiefs of Staff--accuse State Dept and other agencies of giving low priority to embassy security (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar prices ease to 12 1/2-year low on oversupply worries; May contracts fall 0.13 cents, to 5.47 cents a pound; graphs; table (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Some On-Line Donations Don't Make It to Charities  In a new twist on Internet commerce, at least a half-dozen Web sites are offering to sell goods to on-line shoppers and send a portion of the purchase price to charity. Although the sums have been modest thus far, many charities see it as an important fund-raising development.    But it is impossible to know in every case what happens to the few dollars that customers thought were going to a good cause. Though many charities are getting checks directly from the sites, money may not end up in the charity's hands as fast as shoppers might imagine -- if at all. [Page A1.]    No Plans for Renault Name in U.S.  Having agreed last week to buy a little more than a third of Nissan Motor, Renault may start selling Renault cars under the Nissan name in the United States someday. But it has no plans to revive the Renault name in the American market because its reputation is so weak, the company's chairman and chief executive, Louis Schweitzer, said at the New York International Auto Show. [C4.]    Largest Award Ever in Smoking Suit  A state jury in Portland, Ore., ordered the largest award in a smoking-related lawsuit, ruling that Philip Morris must pay $81 million to the family of a man who smoked Marlboro cigarettes for four decades before he died. [A14.]    Microsoft Settlement Talks Begin  Settlement talks began between Microsoft and the Federal and state authorities who filed antitrust charges against the company. Both sides emphasized before the discussions started that they would talk in complete secrecy, but it was clear from the opening positions of both parties that a vast gulf divides them, making a settlement difficult at best. [C25.]    Dow Tumbles From 10,000 Perch  Just a day after the Dow Jones industrial average surpassed 10,000, it and other market gauges retreated on concerns about sales and earnings at big companies. The Dow fell 93.52 points, to 9,913.26, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dipped 9.42 points, to 1,300.75. The Nasdaq composite index lost 12.55 points, to 2,480.29. Bond traders bid up prices on the Federal Reserve's announcement that it would leave interest rates unchanged. [C14.]    Hedge Fund to Pay Back Rescuers  Long-Term Capital Management, the giant hedge fund that Wall Street firms saved from collapse during the turmoil in stock and bond markets in September, has recovered robustly and plans to start paying back its rescuers as early as June. [C25.]    Pepsi Bottling Plans to Go Public  Pepsi Bottling Group is going public in one of the biggest public offerings ever, but not necessarily the hottest. Market Place. [C13.]    U S Airways to Buy Back Stock  U S Airways Group, the nation's sixth-largest airline, said that it would buy back $500 million in stock to lift its lagging shares. The company also said that its first-quarter earnings would be in line with analysts' recently reduced estimates. Shares of U S Airways rose $3.3125, or 7 percent, to $49.8125. [C12.]    Equant Expands Its Data Services  Helping to expand the digital world to some of the globe's least-wired corners, Equant plans to announce that it will offer advanced data services in 25 additional territories. [C4.]    Stock of Express Scripts Surges  Express Scripts, a pharmacy benefits management company that has a customer base of more than 36.5 million people, announced plans for an on-line drugstore, and its shares surged $17.8125, or 24.1 percent, to $91.875. [C2.]

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Does the Dow Measure Up?; Despite Growth of Rivals the Old Gauge Still Matters
abstract: Market Place column on whether Dow Jones industrial average matters anymore as it closes above 10,000 for first time; says 30 Dow industrials still matter even though they have failed to keep up with gains of smaller, more sought after companies that are part of other indexes that track overall market; holds since beginning of 1995, Dow has lagged behind by few percentage points each year returns of Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and has fallen even further behind Nasdaq composite index; chart lists some facts about living standards and lifestyles on Nov 14, 1972, when Dow hit 1,003.15, with similar conditions on March 29, 1999, when average hit 10,006.78; photos (M)

headline: Talk is Cheap, If You're Careful
abstract: Katie Hafner article discusses wide range of cellular telephone plans now being offered by major carriers; offers advice to consumers on how to assess what service package they need; also notes Web has several wireless shopping sites, including one independent site, Wireless Dimension (www.wirelessdimension.com); photos; chart on costs, comparing usage by two persons living in the New York area; photos (L)

headline: Little Chance Seen That Fed Will Lift Rates
abstract: Analysts say that Federal Reserve is almost certain to leave interest rates unchanged when its policy-making committee meets on March 30, but central bank remains wary of resurgent inflation because of economy's continued strength; say that with overall price increases negligible and growth appearing to slow bit from blistering pace at end of 1998, Federal Reserve has no rationale for immediate rate increase (M)

headline: Serbs Reinforce Kosovo Forces, Clouding Talks
abstract: Kosovo peace effort is on verge of collapse as Serbia moves heavy tanks and thousands more troops into province while its negotiators insist on extensive changes to draft peace agreement; US officials say Serbs seem to be bracing for war instead of preparing for peace, with approximately 30,000 troops in or poised near province; cease-fire monitors say heavy tanks that rolled into province, in violation of previous pledges, are first to be seen in Kosovo in at least five months; Serbian negotiators show no signs of giving in on their objection to 28,000-member NATO peacekeeping force on Serbian soil to police accord; photo (M)

headline: Another Portable Way To Get Access to E-Mail
abstract: Research In Motion, wireless modem maker, and BellSouth introduce new E-mail-ready pager for use outside the office; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GREYHOUND LINES INC.,  Dallas, the bus operator, said its shareholders had approved a $650 million takeover by Laidlaw, Burlington, Ontario, which is North America's largest school bus and ambulance operator.    KMART CORP.,  Troy, Mich., won court approval for its offer to pay about $75 million for the rights to 11 stores owned by Caldor Corp., which is going out of business.

headline: JACOR TO BUY 2 PHOENIX RADIO STATIONS FOR $142 MILLION
abstract: Jacor Communications Inc to buy two Phoenix radio stations from Owens Broadcasting and Owens MAC Radio for $142 million; acquisitions will give Jacor four radio stations in Phoenix; stations being acquired are KNIX-FM and KESZ-FM (S)

headline: Don't Trust Car Dealers? Here's a New Deal
abstract: Ford Motor Co and General Motors are expanding their separate partnership ventures with automobile dealers, which involve buying up all their dealerships in a city and setting uniform business practices and, in most cases, prices for all sites; even some consumer advocates have welcomed change, but there have been unforeseen problems, including some car buyers' resistance to policy of not negotiating car prices; Ford and GM feel they must expand or lose too much control over their retail distribution to Republic Industries, auto retailer that has bought nearly 400 franchises in last two years, and other consolidators; photos; graph; map (L)

headline: China Power Generator Calls Off Stock Issue
abstract: Shandong International Power Development Co shelves $285 million initial public offering, third major Chinese company in a month to call off overseas stock sale; sale's failure underscores how deeply investors' confidence has been shaken by collapse in October of China's second-biggest investment firm, Guangdong International Trust and Investment (S)

headline: Not an Age, but an Expanding State of Mind
abstract: Article by retiree Robert W Stock holds views of retirement vary widely and are mostly wrong; notes way Americans retire and think about retirement has changed over last few decades, with more change on way; cites abrupt halt in decades-long drop in retirement age and tendency of many retirees to take easier, often part-time jobs; graphs of increasing number of older Americans; photos (M)

headline: New I.M.F. Aid Pact Further Limits Brazil
abstract: Brazilian Government and International Monetary Fund announce revised loan agreement that commits Brazil to more stringent conditions for receiving aid; new accord requires Brazil to produce bigger budget surplus than was initially agreed upon and restricts Brazilian central bank's ability to spend dollars defending value of real, national currency; Brazil and IMF originally signed $41.5 billion rescue package in November; new pact will enable Brazil to draw on second aid installation, worth $9 billion, from loan package agreed upon in November; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.44   4.23   5.42        3-month T-bills   4.31   4.34   4.96        6-month T-bills   4.32   4.37   4.96        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.96   3.70        10-yr. T-note   4.77   4.71   5.46        30-yr. T-bond   5.22   5.16   5.75        Telephone bd.   6.84   6.84   7.06        Municipal bds.   5.19   5.17   5.16          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: CHANCELLOR SAYS CLEAR CHANNEL IS INTERESTED IN A DEAL
abstract: Chancellor Media Corp says it received expressions of interest from Clear Channel Communications Inc and other companies about possible acquisition or other transaction (S)

headline: French Banks Raise Merger Profit Estimate
abstract: Societe Generale SA and Paribas SA, trying to avoid takeover of both by Banque Nationale de Paris SA, say their proposed merger would increase profit more than first estimated (S)

headline: Requiem for the Middleweights; Ho-Hum Taurus Marks End of Midsize Sedan as Style's Pace Car
abstract: Automotive design experts say 2000 model year Ford Taurus represents last of once-stylish, high-volume midsize sedans to take on new, more generic look as Ford and other auto makers put most of their automotive styling efforts elsewhere; after reigning for decades as main focus of automotive design in US, midsize sedans are losing their primacy to sport utility vehicles and to ever-growing array of so-called crossover vehicles that combine features of sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks, station wagons and cars; new Taurus, unveiled at New York International Auto Show, is much more conservative and closely resembles its competitors, including Toyota Camry and Honda Accord; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Their Business Bible Is, Well, the Bible
abstract: Some 15 leading business figures meet monthly in Howard Milstein's Manhattan office to discuss Torah in study group led by Rabbi Burt Visotzky; photo (M)

headline: Culver and Crunch Change Agencies
abstract: Alberto-Culver Co names Avrett Free & Ginsberg to handle creative duties for Alberto VO5 line of hair-care products; billings undetermined; Crunch Fitness International names Mad Dogs and Englishmen to handle creative portion of its advertising account, which had been at DDB Needham New York; billings estimated at $2 million (S)

headline: A Niche Market on Line
abstract: Marsh Edell letter, commenting on Feb 11 article on on-line shopping, tells of finding source of chipped plates through Ebay

headline: CHANCELLOR MEDIA INTENSIFIES ITS SEARCH FOR A BUYER
abstract: The Chancellor Media Corporation, soon to be the No. 1 owner of radio stations in the United States, said yesterday that it had heightened its search for a buyer for all or part of the company by hiring additional Wall Street advisers. Chancellor said it had hired Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, Goldman, Sachs & Company, Chase Securities Inc. and Greenhill & Company. Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Dallas buyout firm that will own about 25 percent of Chancellor after the completion of pending purchases, will also advise it. Chancellor also said yesterday that it had a fourth-quarter loss of $26.6 million, or 23 cents a diluted share, 3 cents more than Wall Street had expected. It attributed the loss mostly to expenses relating to a series of acquisitions dating to 1996. Chancellor shares rose $1.375, to $50.75.

headline: AT&T Plan Is a Search For Loyalty
abstract: Long-simmering battle among nation's giant phone companies to provide integrated basket of communications services moves to front burner with AT&T Corp announcement of communications package that charges identical 10 cents a minute for long-distance calls made from either standard home telephone or wireless mobile phone; Sprint Corp and MCI Worldcom Inc, as well as regional Bell companies, can be expected to respond with similar offers; first beneficiaries will be consumers, who will see lower rates for various communications services; ultimate winners will be companies that can put together biggest, broadest bundles; United States communications market is $200 billion business (M)

headline: REPUBLIC BUYING FIVE MORE AUTOMOBILE DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries will buy four automobile dealerships in California and one in Florida for $155 million; Republic, owned by H Wayne Huizenga, has about 366 new-vehicle franchises and about 40 Auto Nation used-car superstores (S)

headline: Securitas of Sweden to Acquire Pinkerton's in $384 Million Deal
abstract: Securitas AB of Sweden acquires Pinkerton's Inc, detective and security company, for $384 million (M)

headline: America Online Passes Milestone
abstract: America Online Inc, on-line service, reports its worldwide membership passed 15 million; is attracting new members at record rate with marketing drive for its upgraded software (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: 1998 Auto Sales Post Best Gain in 12 Years  Last month was the best for auto sales since December 1986, lifting the industry's sales for 1998 to the highest level in a dozen years despite a nearly eight-week strike last summer from which General Motors has not fully recovered.    With the last auto makers reporting their results, the industry's sales in the United States rose 7.1 percent last month from December 1997. For the year, 15.55 million cars, sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans were sold, a 2.8 percent increase from 1997. [Page C2.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Some Major Oil Producers Agree to Cut Production  A coalition of major oil producers, hoping to capitalize on their modest success in stabilizing world oil prices, announced they had agreed to reduce production by another two million barrels a day.    Some analysts predicted that if the cuts were carried out as promised by April 1, and if nascent signs of an economic recovery in Asia were realized, a steady recovery of crude oil prices could be in the offing. [Page A1.]

headline: HEALTHSOUTH TO REPURCHASE SHARES AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: HealthSouth Corp says its board has approved plan to buy back as many as 70 million shares, worth about $1 billion, and will take fourth-quarter charge of around $310 million (S)

headline: Stocks Aided Brokerage Firms' 4th-Quarter Recovery
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co, Bear Sterns Companies and Paine Webber Group report profits for final quarter of 1998 that fall short of levels a year ago but beat predictions by market analysts; Charles Schwab Corp posts record profits for fourth quarter and for the year; Merrill says it earned $359 million, down 23 percent from $469 million in year-earlier period; for the year, Merrill's profit fell 20 percent, to $1.6 billion; Paine Webber's net income declined 7.6 percent, to $100.4 million; Paine Webber earned record $433.6 million for full year, compared with $415.4 million in 1997; Bear Stearns says net income fell to $135.9 million from $160.2 million a year ago; Schwab earned $106.4 million in fourth quarter, nearly 70 percent increase in earnings for period; Schwab earned $348.5 million for the year, improvement of 29 percent over 1997 (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: J. PETERMAN, Lexington, Ky., the catalogue company, said it would stop taking telephone orders after a Federal judge approved plans for the company to liquidate and begin going-out-of-business sales. Peterman has been operating under bankruptcy court protection since Jan. 25.    3 COM CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., the No. 2 maker of computer and telephone networking equipment, opened a Washington lobbying office and announced plans to increase donations to political campaigns.

headline: 6 Finalists Named In Review by Lowe's
abstract: Lowe's Companies narrows review for its broadcast advertising account to six finalists; billings for account, which had been handled by Doner, are estimated at $100 million (S)

headline: Terror Suspect Said to Anger Afghan Hosts
abstract: Senior US officials say suspected terrorist Osama bin Laden and Taliban, his protectors in Afghanistan, have had violent falling-out, raising possibility that his days of refuge may be numbered; say fight broke out between bin Laden's bodyguards and Taliban officers assigned to watch over him; say bin Laden was expelled from Kandahar; say he was isolated in countryside and stripped of his satellite telephones, which allow him to plot with fellow radicals throughout world; Taliban has shown no sign that it is willing to deliver bin Laden to US; Taliban official says Afghanistan has sent emissary to US asking how to deal with him (M)

headline: In Russia, No Gloves But Also No Fists
abstract: Russian officials rail against NATO alliance in terms that recall tensest days of cold war; unruly mob protests at American Embassy in Moscow; but Kremlin has been careful not to match its angry rhetoric with deeds (M)

headline: Cisco Profit Up 33% With Internet Sales
abstract: Cisco Systems Inc says fiscal second-quarter profit rose 33 percent; profit before charges for quarter ended Jan 23 reached $606 million compared with $457.3 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 40 percent, to $2.83 billion from $2.02 billion (S)

headline: Executive Leaving Ammirati Puris
abstract: Mike Lotito, for 12 years a top executive at New York office of Ammirati Puris Lintas, will resign, effective Jan 29 (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls as traders take profits and questions arise about impact of resignation of German Finance Minister on Europe; in New York, euro is at $1.0901, down from $1.1023; graph; chart (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar again rises against Japanese yen; graphs tracking yen to dollar; table of key exchange rates (S)9

headline: Icahn Names His Own Board In Fight for Control of RJR
abstract: Carl C Icahn, moving forward with is bid to gain control of RJR Nabisco Holdings, names nine-member board of directors that includes Icahn himself and several officials of companies he owns (M)

headline: Anti-Apartheid Cleric Is Guilty of Stealing Money From Charity
abstract: Former anti-apartheid activist Allan Boesak is found guilty of stealing hundreds of thousands of dollars donated to his foundation; money was supposed to help needy children and educate black voters before South Africa's first all-race election in 1994 (M)

headline: Sierra Takes Major Step And Recalls Football Game
abstract: Sierra Sports recalls new football computer game because of software glitches that hamper play; game recalls, unheard of until few months ago, are spurred in part by rapid spread of bad news about games via Internet; photo (M)

headline: Japan Presses Large Banks to Accept Aid
abstract: Japanese Government is pushing 15 of nation's largest banks to accept at least 7.45 trillion yen ($64.80 billion) in aid--far more than banks first requested--in attempt to speed its rescue of troubled lenders; Fuji Bank Ltd and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd are likely to be largest recipients (S)

headline: U.S. Official Questions How Russia Used Loan
abstract: Treasury Secretary Robert E Rubin tells Congressional panel that he suspects that much of $4.8 billion in loans sent to Russia last summer by IMF 'may have been siphoned off improperly'; it is Clinton Administration's first public statement supporting accusations that bailout money simply helped wealthy Russian oligarchs move billions of dollars to Switzerland and other safe havens; financial regulators note that a huge flow of dollars left Russia immediately after IMF cash was delivered to Russia's central bank, suggesting that investors were getting out before ruble was permitted to collapse on Aug 17 (M)

headline: OLIMAN HAS NO PLANS TO RAISE BID FOR CELLULAR CONCERN
abstract: Oliman, joint telecommunications venture of Olivetti SpA and Mannesmann AG says it has no plans to raise its $1.5 billion bid for Cellular Communications International, even though Cellular shares are trading above offer price (S)a

headline: Jones to Acquire Nine West in $900 Million Deal
abstract: Jones Apparel Group Inc, women's clothing company, will acquire Nine West Group, one of nation's largest shoe companies, in deal valued at $900 million; Nine West will operate as separate unit; Jones will take on problems faced by Nine West, including slow sales and investigation by Federal Trade Commission into company's pricing practices; Mark J Schwartz, president of Palladin Capital Group, leveraged buyout firm, and member of Jones's board of directors, will replace Nine West's chairman Jerome Fisher; Fisher, who founded Nine West with Vincent Camuto in 1977, will become consultant to Nine West; it is not clear whether Camuto, Nine West's chief executive, will keep his title (M)

headline: A Lesson In Caucasus: Even War Has Rules
abstract: Sixth grade students in public school in Tbilisi, Georgia, take course in international rules of war, with an emphasis on sparing the wounded, not executing prisoners and respecting civilians; course, devised by International Committee of Red Cross, is an emblem of the ferocity of the civil wars that have followed the collapse of Communism in Georgia and other parts of former Soviet Union and an experiment in preventing war crimes; map (M)

headline: AETNA ACQUIRES BIGGEST ARGENTINE HEALTH CARE COMPANY
abstract: Aetna Inc acquires Asistencia Medica Social Argentina SA for $100 million in cash and $20 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of March 14 Market Insight column about legal and financial outlook for tobacco industry (S)

headline: New Bidder For British Media Group
abstract: Mirror Groujp PLC, publisher of British newspapers The Daily Mirror and The Sunday Mirror, says Regional Independent Media PLC has offered to buy it for 913 million pounds, or $1.5 billion, in cash after failed bid by Trinity PLC (S)

headline: Writing the Last Chapter of 'Barbarians at the Gate'
abstract: Article on history of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp in light of company's decision to split its food and tobacco operations and sell off its foreign tobacco operations (M)

headline: Indonesian Economy Shrank 13.7% in Year
