abstract: Indonesia reports its economy shrank 13.7 percent in 1998, less than 15 percent Government expected, while consumer prices rose 77.6 percent; says economy, helped by stronger rupiah, contracted only 0.27 percent in fourth quarter from third (S)

headline: Media Talk; Poz Magazine Apologizes for Mailing
abstract: Poz magazine, monthly title for HIV-positive readers, apologizes for giving subscribers' names to company even when subscribers specifically requested that their names not be rented out; photo (S)

headline: An Earlier China Spy Case Points Up Post-Cold War Ambiguities
abstract: Peter H Lee, Taiwan-borb physicist who once worked at nuclear weapons laboratory, will complete one year sentence within two weeks that will wind up murky case that speaks of ambiguities surrounding resurfaced suspicions of Chinese espionage; Wen Ho Lee, no relation, has been dismissed from Los Alamos National Laboratory for security violations; he has not been charged with any crime; both cases are linked only by official investigations seeking to determine how China may have gained access to American nuclear secrets (M)

headline: French Right Bickers After a Political Deal With Left in Lyons
abstract: Leaders of French conservative political parties that lost last national elections in 1997 are bickering over victory by Anne-Marie Comparini, member of Union for French Democracy, in election to head Rhone-Alpes regional parliament; Comparini won regional post after 37-hour marathon of 'shady bartering' described by party colleague as 'disgusting spectacle;' her victory, mostly with leftist support, plunges right yet further into disarray; is blow to Charles Millon, former Defense Minister, who had been head of regional parliament since 1988 and who had been losing ground since spring 1998, when he accepted support from extreme-right national front (M)

headline: Volvo Buys Stake and Says It Wants All of Rival Truck Maker
abstract: Volvo AB acquires 13 percent stake in rival Swedish truck manufacturer, Scania AB, for 5.2 billion kronor ($666.5 million) and says it wants to take over entire company (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Rare for an Internet company, Yahoo reports actual earnings. Not that such things matter.
abstract: Market Place column on Yahoo Inc reporting actual earnings in last quarter of 1998, a rarity for an Internet company; says earnings jumped to $25.04 million, more than 10 times $1.91 million a year earlier; says revenues topped $76.4 million, nearly triple level of a year ago and 40 percent ahead of third quarter (M)/

headline: Operating Profit Down at DuPont
abstract: DuPont says operating profits fell less-than-expected 9 percent in fourth quarter; profits from continuing operations fell to $682 million from $749 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 3.3 percent, to $6.1 billion from $5.9 billion (S)

headline: THERMO INSTRUMENT TO PAY CASH FOR SPECTRA-PHYSICS
abstract: Thermo Instrument Systems Inc will offer about $20 a share for all outstanding shares of Spectra-Physics AB; deal is valued at about $355 million (S)

headline: Revamping Said to Be Set At Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft Corp is expected to reorganize itself into divisions focused on different customer groups rather than on products; such a change would be big shift in orientation for a company that has long emphasized engineering over marketing; Microsoft spokeswoman Marianne Allison insists that no decision has been made on such a move; she declines to either confirm or deny article in The Seattle Times that first reported a coming reorganization (M)

headline: S.E.C. Halts Trading in the Shares of 6 Internet-Related Companies
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission halts trading in six companies whose shares have soared recently as they have been swept up in investment frenzy over anything related to Internet; five of companies have ties to Peter Tosto, stock promoter who was banned from brokerage industry in 1998 because of violations of securities laws; companies are Citron Inc, Electronic Transfer Associates Inc, Invest Holdings Group Inc, Polus Inc and Smartek Inc (M)

headline: A Russian Soap Opera In Real Life: Tycoon Tapes
abstract: Russian newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets publishes as part of monthlong campaign against tycoon Boris A Berezovsky transcripts of his television conversations with Pres Boris N Yeltsin's daughter Tatyana Dyachenko, with top television news anchor and with former Government official, which he reportedly taped himself over last few years; tapes show him lobbying for tax amnesty, planting damaging information about business rival and ordering campaign to browbeat members of Parliament; drive against him seems to originate with Prime Min Yevgeny M Primakov, rival for influence over Yeltsin and his inner circle; Berezovsky has emerged as symbol of Russia's unscrupulous, runaway capitalism (M)

headline: Typing or Keyboarding?
abstract: Elspeth Sladden letter, responding to Feb 18 article on typing, says programs mentioned in article fail to address the importance of ergonomics in learning keyboarding

headline: If Only DeMille Had Owned a Desktop
abstract: New digital technology is enabling small, independent filmmakers make quality movies at home using low-cost cameras and software; some are transferring film to video, where digitized images can be cut with editing software and enhanced with easy-to-use animation programs; others use digital video camcorders, then transfer results to film; some movie makers have given up film, choosing to shoot, edit and, in some cases, distribute work digitally; photos (M)

headline: The uproar over the USA Networks-Lycos deal may start a rethinking of the portal concept.
abstract: Proposed merger of Lycos Inc with USA Networks, which has sent stock of both companies plummeting, may catalyze rethinking of the business of Internet portals; some portal executives fear the business may have seen its best days and become the 'network television' of the Internet; are questioning value and proper roles of content and services as audience magnets; some are also beginning to agree with early critics who predicted that advetising would not be a viable long-term business strategy for the Internet; cartoon (M)

headline: Intel Pentium III Processor Makes Its Debut
abstract: Intel Corp's powerful new microprocessor, the Pentium III, begins appearing on store shelves in computers priced as low as $1,599; release of Pentium III has been marred by controversy over its processor serial number; though Intel has touted feature as advance for security in Internet commerce and for authenticating E-mail and other documents, privacy and consumer groups protest that it will allow marketers and others to track movements of computer users around the Internet (M)

headline: Martin Agency To Promote Aruba
abstract: Aruba Tourism Authority awards Martin Agency its advertising account, which had been at Fitzgerald & Co; billings estimated at $7 million to $10 million (S)

headline: British Insurer Selling 3 Property Operations
abstract: Royal and Sun Alliance Insurance Group PLC to sell three property companies to Moorfield Estates PLC for 392 million pounds ($631 million) (S)

headline: Telephones Pass Year 2000 Test
abstract: Telephone companies that form backbone of local voice and data communications in US say that extensive testing has demonstrated that their networks will operate smoothly in 2000 (S)

headline: METAMOR WORLDWIDE AND SPR CALL OFF PLANS TO MERGE
abstract: Metamor Worldwide Inc calls off plans to acquire SPR Inc after two companies decide deal is not in shareholders' best interest (S)

headline: Israel's Crowd-Pleasing General Throws His (Civilian) Hat In
abstract: Former Israeli Army Chief of Staff Amnon Lipkin-Shahak announces his centrist candidacy for Prime Minister; says Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu 'is dangerous for Israel' (M)

headline: They've Got Mail, and Game; Chess Fans Make Their Move
abstract: Internet becomes a popular medium for long-distance chess; photo (M)

headline: Frederick Zissu, 85, Chief of Vornado Inc.
abstract: Frederick Zissu, former chairman and chief executive of Vornado Inc, dies at age 85 (S)

headline: CAMBREX BUYS IROTEC LABORATORIES OF IRELAND
abstract: Cambrex Corp acquires Irotec Laboratories Ltd of Ireland for $40 million (S)3

headline: ECONOMIC GROWTH IN LAST PART OF '98 WAS ROBUST 6.1%
abstract: Commerce Department reports Gross Domestic Product grew at 6.1 percent annual rate in 1998 fourth quarter, up from previous estimate of 5.6 percent; says economy grew 3.9 percent in 1998, after adjusting for inflation; reports inflation dipped to annual rate of 0.7 percent in fourth quarter, lowest in over 40 years; inflation rate for year was 1 percent; graph (M)

headline: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
abstract: Ian Austen evaluates Rivendell Reader's, paper and Web-based magazine, Internet site on cycling (www.rivendellbicycles.com) (M)

headline: Microsoft Trying to Rebuild Tarnished Case in Antitrust Trial
abstract: Microsoft Corp's defense in antitrust case has been hurt by seemingly misleading inconsistencies in videotape it presented as important evidence; Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson called tape 'very troubling'; antitrust experts say that case will not be decided on issue addressed by tape, but that tape foul-up could become really damaging if it undermines credibility of company's evidence in general in eyes of Judge Jackson, who will deliver verdict in nonjury trial (M)

headline: COMPUSA SHARES TUMBLE AS LOSSES ARE EXPECTED
abstract: CompUSA Inc shares fall 22 percent to lowest level in almost four years, as largest United States personal computer retailer warns of unexpected losses for two quarters because of weak sales (S)

headline: Officer Is Denied Amnesty In the Killing of Steve Biko
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission denies amnesty to former police officer George Bizos, implicated in murder of anti-apartheid activist Steve Biko in 1977; reportedly ruled that amnesty could not be granted since Bizos has not admitted committing crime (M)

headline: Vanity Fair's Star Quality; Editor Celebrates Hollywood and Advertisers Applaud
abstract: Vanity Fair magazine cultivates Hollywood film industry in a relationship that enriches both of them and creates a powerful attraction on advertisers; magazine picked up more than 100 new advertisers in 1998, packed 1,882 ad pages for the year and lifted its revenue to over $109 million; circulation slipped 2 percent in second half of year, to 1.08 million, but advertisers love the reader demographic: median age of 37, average household income of $58,000 and 70 percent college-educated; photo (M)

headline: A Goodbye To the Weight Of Leveraging
abstract: Laura M Holson Investing column recalls leveraged buyouts of 1980's in light of RJR Nabisco Holdings' decision to demerge and return to its former self; chart; drawing (M)

headline: CENTRIS TO SELL USF UNIT TO FOLKSAMERICA
abstract: Centris Group will sell USF Re Insurance Company to Folksamerica Holding Company for $97.5 million (S)

headline: A Guru to Wall Street's Gurus
abstract: Some of savviest Wall Street investors sign up for Bruce Greenwald's two-day crash course in value investing at Columbia Business School; photo (S)

headline: The Sorrows of Goethe: A Creepy East German Tale
abstract: Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung newspaper reports on file documenting extraordinary and secret operation in 1970 in which East German scientists exhumed body of Goethe, loaded his corpse onto a cart, dragged it off to a nearby museum and worked on its preservation for three weeks; remains were then returned to their crypt in city of Weimar; Reiner Schlichting, official at Weimar Classics Foundation, which oversees city's cultural heritage, says operation was undertaken to 'strengthen Goethe's bones and give his sarcophagus a new lining'; he adds 'nothing else was changed'; details of exhumation described; photos (L)

headline: People
abstract: Jay Shields, executive vice president at Austin Kelley Advertising, is promoted to chief operating officer (S)g

headline: Deutsche Bank's Pretax Profit Up
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG's fourth-quarter operating profit rises to 1.2 billion marks, or $690 million; full-year 1998 operating profit is unchanged at 4.3 billion marks (S)

headline: G.M. CUTS EXECUTIVE BONUSES AT DELPHI PARTS UNIT
abstract: General Motors Corp's Delphi Automotive Systems unit cuts executive bonuses to reflect year-to-year decline in reported earnings; GM could face difficulty next month when it hopes to sell 17.7 percent of Delphi's stock (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Return of a Disk-Drive Jockey
abstract: Finis Conner, disk-drive pioneer, has new company, Conner Technology, that will make disk drives for budget end of computer market, selling $100 drives for PC's that would be priced around $600; photo (S)

headline: Wide Yield Premiums For Less-Risky Bradys
abstract: Possible reasons for current high yields on Latin American governments' collateralized Brady bonds explored (S)

headline: Using Your Head to Stop Phone-Call Pains in the Neck
abstract: Telephone headsets find a market beyond telephone operators and airline reservationists as multitasking becomes more common at home and work and as people become more aware of the damage that can be caused by cradling a telephone handset between one's head and shoulder; headsets from GN Netcom, Radio Shack and Plantronics assessed; photos (M)

headline: Trahan, Burden Wins 3 Accounts
abstract: Trahan, Burden & Charles is awarded three accounts with combined billings of $20 million: Foxwoods Resort Casino, Rumpus Toys and Candy Express Inc (S)

headline: IT GROUP IN DEAL FOR SOME ASSETS OF ICF KAISER UNIT
abstract: IT Group to pay $82 million in cash to acquire some assets of ICF Kaiser International Inc's Environmental and Facilities Management Group unit (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HASBRO INC., Pawtucket, R.I., a maker of toys, games, interactive software and other products, declared a 3-for-2 stock split, payable in the form of a 50 percent stock dividend March 15 to shareholders of record March 1.    DELTA AIR LINES INC.,  Atlanta, said it was pursuing an expanded code-share pact with Air France that would broaden its reach in Europe, Africa and Asia..    USN COMMUNICATIONS INC.,  Chicago, a provider of local telephone services, filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Microsoft Will Reorganize Into 5 Units
abstract: Microsoft Corp chairman Steven Ballmer, heralding era he refers to as 'vision version 2.0,' announces reorganization of company into five divisions that he suggests will act with some independence; Ballmer, in teleconference held with William H Gates, says he is beginning to reinvent company, focusing it on initiatives that are largely 'customer driven'; adds reorganization has nothing to do with Justice Department's antitrust suit; five new groups listed; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises after group of major producers agree to cut oil production by two million barrels a day; crude for April delivery increases 18 cents, to $14.49 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Despite Gains, Some Have Doubts
abstract: Michael M Weinstein Economic Scene column discusses whether Japanese officials have finally changed economic policy and whether changes, if real, can end deep recession; notes outside advisers are urging central bank to pump enough new money into economy to stop prices from falling; photo (M)

headline: A Brutal War's Machetes Maim Sierra Leone
abstract: Civil war that has pushed Sierra Leone to brink of disintegration takes even more brutish turn as fighting reaches capital of Freetown; rebels, pushed back by Nigerian-led forces, have for now retreated eastward into surrounding mountains, but not before killing thousands of civilians and mutilating hundreds of others; scores of men, women and children, their hands chopped off or dangling limply, flood hospital, evidence of horrific brutality; photo; map (M)

headline: QUINTILES BUYS HOECHST RESEARCH CENTER IN KANSAS CITY
abstract: Quintiles Transnational Corp purchases Hoechst Marion Roussel AG's drug innovation and approval operation in Kansas City, Mo, for $93 million and opens contract research facility in Kansas City (S)

headline: INSURANCE AUTO REJECTS COPART BID AND ITS SHARES RISE
abstract: Shares of Insurance Auto Auctions Inc rise almost 12 percent after company rejects $152 million takeover bid from rival, Copart Inc (S)

headline: Charles Francis Adams, 88, Former Chairman of Raytheon
abstract: Charles Francis Adams, former president and chairman of Raytheon, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: King Hussein Selects Eldest Son, Abdullah, as Successor
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan decrees that his eldest son, Prince Abdullah, is next in line for throne; photo; designation ends 51-year-old Prince Hassan's position as crown prince after 34 years; king recently issued public letter of criticism of Hassan, his brother, scholarly Oxford-educated technocrat more comfortable in blazer than in Arab dress; Prince Abdullah, 36, is son of king's English second wife, Toni Avril Gardiner or Princess Muna, whom king divorced in 1971; prince attended Sandhurst military academy in England, as well as Deerfield Academy in Illinois (S)

headline: Ladbroke to Buy Stakis Hotel Group
abstract: Ladbroke Group PLC to acquire rival hotel group Stakis PLC of Scotland for 1.16 billion pounds, or $1.63 billion, in cash and stock (S)

headline: Viag and Algroup Abandon Plan for Merger
abstract: Viag AG, Germany's third-largest utility, and Algroup AG, world's biggest maker of packaging for drug industry, abandon their $8.7 billion merger plan; proposed deal would have given Viag a 65 percent stake in Algroup (S)

headline: CMGI to Acquire Internet Profiles
abstract: CMGI Inc says it will buy Internet Profiles Corp for undisclosed price and will use it for expansion into Internet traffic-tracking business (S)

headline: Euro RSCG Buys Big Stake in Citron
abstract: Euro RSCG Worldwide acquires majority stake in Citron Haligman Bedecarre; Citron Haligman will be renamed Citron Haligman Bedecarre Euro RSCG and operate as autonomous unit of Euro RSCG (S)

headline: Mercedes-Benz executives express 'concern' with a longtime agency, Lowe & Partners/SMS.
abstract: Once-strong ties between Mercedes-Benz of North America and its agency of more than five years, Lowe & Partners/SMS, appear to be fraying after unusual meeting at which Mercedes-Benz executives were described as having expressed 'concern' over 'serious' issues affecting their relationship; account, with billings estimated at $125 million, is one of most prestigious in North American automotive industry (M)

headline: Saks Reports Earnings Gain
abstract: Saks Inc, owner of Saks Fifth Avenue and other department stores, reports its fourth-quarter earnings rose 26 percent, to $142.8 million, from $113.3 million in same period year earlier, but warns that this year's profit might be less than expected (S)

headline: Dangerous Selectivity About Rules of Global Trade
abstract: David E Sanger Economic View column discusses heated disputes between US and its trading partners over variety of products; focuses on politics involved in House approval of bill to limit steel imports by any means necessary (M)

headline: Trading on Hollywood Magic; Celebrities Push Models Off Women's Magazine Covers
abstract: Women's magazines, following lead of other magazine categories, are putting movie stars and other celebrities on their covers in place of models; shift reflects supermodels' waning public appeal; photos (M)

headline: For Help With a Benefits Package, Help Yourself
abstract: Increasing number of companies are having workers surf internal corporate computer networks and Web sites set up by benefit providers to check employer-sponsored benefits, task once exclusively job of human resources employees; other companies are using self-service call-in centers that link employees with benefits data; employee self-service notion is quickly sweeping workplace, cutting costs and increasing efficiency; employee reaction is mixed; photos (M)

headline: Wariness on Kosovo
abstract: While NATO considers sending peacekeepers to Kosovo, senior Pentagon officials are raising concerns about committing American troops without clear-cut military goals.       Article, page A9.

headline: Ford Tries to Avoid Closings In Wake of Factory Explosion
abstract: Ford Motor Co struggles to keep serious industrial accident that paralyzed its River Rouge manufacturing complex in Dearborn, Mich, from causing shutdowns at other factories across North America; explosion and fire killed one Ford worker, critically burned 13 and left at least a dozen more workers seriously injured; it also idled 10,000 at complex (M)

headline: Investment Banks Scurry For Pieces of Olivetti Bid
abstract: Almost every investment bank was scrambling to get piece of action in Olivetti SpA's hostile offer for Telecom Italia SpA last weekend; eleven European and US banks have lined up to represent various parties in transaction (M)

headline: GILEAD SCIENCES TO ACQUIRE NEXSTAR PHARMACEUTICALS
abstract: Gilead Sciences Inc to buy Nexstar Pharmaceuticals Inc for $550 million in stock (S)

headline: TRADE DEFICIT HIT NEW HIGH IN 1998
abstract: Commece Dept reports that US trade deficit soared 53 percent in 1998, to record $168.8 billion, as global financial crisis forced first decline in American exports in over decade; US officials say most of increase in deficit came from strong consumer spending for foreign-made goods; say deficit for Dec narrowed unexpectedly, to $13.8 billion, 10 pecent decline in Nov; biggest increases in trade deficit originated from hardest-hit nations of Asia; deficit with Japan rose to $64 billion, from $56 billion in 1997; graph (M)

headline: FCB FINANCIAL SHARES RISE ON ANCHOR BANCORP TAKEOVER
abstract: Anchor Bancorp Wisconsin Inc acquires FCB Financial Corp for $172 million in stock; shares of FCB Financial rise 38 percent (S)

headline: Friedman Associates Buys J. D. Greif
abstract: J Friedman Associates acquires and absorbs J D Greif Advertising (S)

headline: Barclays Names a New Chief Executive
abstract: Barclays P.L.C., Britain's second-largest bank, today named as its chief executive Michael O'Neill, the president of the BankAmerica Corporation's financial-services group.    Mr. O'Neill succeeds Martin Taylor, who resigned in November following losses at the bank's investment-banking unit, Barclays Capital. Barclays shares rose 5.5 percent in London today, closing at $:14.20, or $23.05, up 74 pence, as investors speculated that Mr. O'Neill would shrink or shed Barclays Capital, whose returns on equity are below those of the bank's other businesses.

headline: For All Sides in Kosovo, A Secluded Rendezvous
abstract: Peace negotiations on Kosovo will be held in former royal hunting castle in Rambouillet, France; Foreign Min Hubert Vedrine of France and Foreign Sec Robin Cook of Britain will co-chair talks, which formally open on Feb 6; French officials say after talks begin, castle's tall iron gates will be closed, leaving Serbian, ethnic Albanian and international negotiators inside to talk, eat and sleep until they produce accord; real key to peace is held by Pres Slobodan Milosevic, who is not expected to come to Rambouillet but is sending a deputy (M)

headline: Could a Small Ground Force Carve Out Safe Havens?
abstract: Several current and former American commanders say if NATO ordered ground troops to Kosovo, vanguard of force of 30,000 to 40,000 troops could be assembled in days and would be sufficient to protect many refugees from further attack; say small number of troops, backed by air power, could sweep into besieged province and create havens for tens of thousands of ethnic Albanians fleeing Serbian attacks (M)

headline: NATO Allows Chief to Order Air Strikes Against Serbs
abstract: NATO allies step up threats, giving their top civilian leader authority to mount air strikes directly against Serbian forces attacking ethnic Albanian separatists in Kosovo province; expanded authority of Sec Gen Javier Solana is subject to consultation with Western leaders (M)

headline: New Accusation May Harm Holbrooke's U.N. Chances
abstract: Justice Department accuses Richard C Holbrooke of civil violations of ethics laws involving 1996 business contacts with American Embassy in South Korea, complicating his nomination as United Nations ambassador; finds no evidence to support charges that he improperly lobbied embassy officials in Hungary in 1995, charges that initially sidetracked nomination; friends say he balks at paying fine to settle charges; Justice Department weighs suit (M)

headline: Equity Offering Is Set
abstract: The following equity offering is expected this week:

headline: European Data: A Mixed Outlook
abstract: Dutch Government says gross domestic product rose 1.2 percent in fourth quarter from previous three months and 3.7 percent in full year; higher consumer spending helped economy outpace average 1998 growth of 2.7 percent in 11 euro nations; in Germany, consumer prices fell two-tenths of 1 percent in January and December and rose two-tenths of 1 percent from year earlier; average German inflation in 1998 was 1 percent; France reports consumer prices increased only two-tenths of 1 percent in January from year earlier; says business confidence fell in February to its lowest level since November 1996; Confederation of British Industry reports further signs that slump in manufacturing is easing, reinforcing expectations that Bank of England will leave interest rates unchanged (M)

headline: Nasdaq Soars In Its Biggest One-Day Gain
abstract: Powered by a dramatic rebound in computer-related issues, the Nasdaq soared more than 4 percent yesterday to its biggest one-day point gain ever as investors piled back into beaten-down technology and financial shares.    In the absence of any dominating new developments, analysts cited the cumulative weight of several lesser factors and for once found a public appearance by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to be of little consequence.

headline: World News Briefs
abstract: EUROPE    SWITZERLAND: AUTHOR CLEARED OF TREASON -- The Cabinet dismissed a lawsuit charging a legislator, Jean Ziegler, with treason for writing a book accusing the Swiss of helping finance the Third Reich and for testifying in Washington that Switzerland should return Nazi gold. The ministers decided the complaint failed to show Mr. Ziegler had endangered Swiss security.   Elizabeth Olson (NYT)    TURKEY: LAWYERS TO SEE OCALAN -- Lawyers defending the Kurdish rebel chief Abdullah Ocalan have been given permission to visit him for the first time since he was seized by Turkish commandos on Feb. 16 in Kenya. The lawyers said they had been told two of them could visit the island prison in the Sea of Marmara where he has been under interrogation.   (AP)

headline: In State Dept. View, Envoy Did Not Lie to House
abstract: US State Department releases internal documents showing that it had concluded that a senior diplomat, James F Dobbins, who is new special envoy to Balkans, did not lie to Congress about death squads in Haiti; but agency admonishes him for not giving complete testimony (S)

headline: For Cadbury, Candy Looks Sweeter Than Soda
abstract: By agreeing to sell nearly all its international beverage business to the Coca-Cola Company, Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. made it clear last month that it was leaving the global soft-drink field to Coca-Cola and Pepsico Inc.     What is less clear is Cadbury's strategy for its remaining soft-drink business, which will now be concentrated in its most profitable market, the United States.

headline: Letting Little Go to Waste; An Enterprise Evolves From the Byproducts of Industry
abstract: Triad Energy Resources Inc, headed by Michael R Daley, president, is pioneer in developing eco-industrial parks, where industrial byproducts are turned into raw materials for other uses; Daley says he developed idea after noting companies paid carters to take away their byproducts, which could be used in manufacture of other products; more and more companies are now starting to follow Daley's lead and are buying their neighbors' wastes or selling their own; econ-parks are being developed in Mississippi, Mexico and are planned in Puerto Rico and Mesa del Sol, New Mexico; in addition, Dow Chemical Co is building one near its plants in eastern Germany; photos of Daley and his operation (L)

headline: How Old Is Your Fund Manager, And Does It Really Matter?
abstract: Morningstar Inc survey finds that average age of mutual fund managers is 44; Scott Cooley, Morningstar analyst, says there is no correlation between the age of a manager and his ability to take defensive action if a bear market occurs (S)

headline: MEDITRUST SELLING COBBLESTONE GOLF FOR $386 MILLION
abstract: The Meditrust Companies said yesterday that it planned to sell its Cobblestone Golf Group to Clubcorp International Inc. and the American Golf Corporation for $386.7 million, plus $6.3 million in assumed debt. Meditrust, a real estate investment trust, is splitting its businesses into separate health care and hotel companies. In November, Meditrust, based in Needham, Mass., said it planned to sell $1 billion in assets to pay down debt. The company said it would use $250 million from the  Cobblestone sale to pay off debt. The buyers will divide the Cobblestone portfolio of 45 golf clubs and courses in seven states.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.

headline: A New Mood In Accessories
abstract: MILANâ€”  Italian menswear designers are about to blow your socks off with anew range of luxurious yet functional accessories. From customized shoes to strap-on bags and wrist purses,men will never look the same again.

headline: The Suharto Legacy Lives On in Indonesia
abstract: Efforts to overhaul Indonesia's ruined economy and devastated banking system discourage even the most hardened realists; Pres B J Habibie was supposed to announce landmark step in bank-system rehabilitation--shutting down 38 banks and rescuing dozens of others with fresh capital, but he postponed decision at last minute; move has led to storm of criticism that Habibie is catering to politically connected bankers, who had lobbied for delay because their banks were likely to be closed; nearly 10 months afte collapsing economy and violent social protest toppled Pres Suharto, people contend that Suharto-style cronyism is now stalling recovery of world's fourth-most-populous nation (M)

headline: Rising Concern Over Profits Sends Dow Below 10,000
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 93.52 points, or 0.93 percent, to 9,913.26; Standard & Poor's 500 index dips 9.42, or 0.72 percent, to 1,300.75, and Nasdaq composite index loses 12.55, or 0.50 percent, to 2,480.29; graph; chart (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ST. JOHN'S KNITS INC., Irvine, Calif., a women's clothing company, said a group led by its founder and chief executive, Robert E. Gray, had extended until Jan. 15 its bid to take the company private.    GROW BIZ INTERNATIONAL INC., Minneapolis, which develops, franchises, and operates retail stores, completed its acquisition of Plato's Closet, which buys and sells used and new apparel for teen-agers.

headline: Pro Football Games Help CBS Report an Operating Profit
abstract: CBS Corp says it shifted to an operating profit in the fourth quarter as its radio stations and return to the television network of National Football League broadcasts leds to increased advertising revenue; also says it had net loss in fourth quarter of $1 million, compared with net income of $861 million in same period year earlier (M)

headline: Salinas Case: New Attitude or Old Mexican Politics?
abstract: Analysis of verdict sentencing Raul Salinas de Gortari, brother of former President of Mexico, to prison for 50 years for masterminding political assassination in 1994; decision sent strongest signal yet that political elite is no longer beyond reach of justice, but there remain troubling doubts about weak and tainted case on which it was based; Judge Ricardo Ojeda Bohorquez, who had sole responsibility for decision, acknowledges that there is no definite proof of Raul Salinas's guilt; even victim's family has expressed doubt about verdict, suggesting it was politically motivated; photo (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Plans Inexpensive Printers
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co forms subsidiary, Apollo Consumer Products Inc, to enter low end of ink-jet printer market (S)

headline: Ex-Ukraine Premier, Accused of Corruption, Detained by U.S.
abstract: Pavlo Lazarenko, former Prime Min of Ukraine and target of corruption inquiries there and in Switzerland, is apprehended by American Customs agents in New York while trying to enter US on tourist visa; has repeatedly denied charges against him, claiming to be victim of political persecution by Govt of Pres Leonid Kuchma (M)

headline: Italian Bank Bids Set to Challenge Mediobanca
abstract: ROMEâ€”  Italy's banking sector was rocked Sunday two separate multibillion-dollar bids that challenged the power of Mediobanca SpA, the secretive Milan-based bank that until now has wielded enormous influence over Italian finance and industry.

headline: Media Talk; CNN's Idea to Team Up With Networks Stalls
abstract: Gerald Levin, chairman of Time Warner, says little progress has been made since CNN talked last year with major networks about combining news operations; photo (S)

headline: Worldwide Drug Sales Up 7% in '98
abstract: IMS Health survey finds world pharmaceuticals sales rose 7 percent in 1998, to $251.3 billion, in response to popularity of several new drugs and their simultaneous introductions in many nations; finds US remained largest market, with $99.5 billion in sales, up 11 percent from 1997; Japan was second, with $38.8 billion, down 1 percent; Novartis AG led in sales, with $10.639 billion; Merck & Co fell to second, with $10.635 billion (M)

headline: Teaching Table Manners
abstract: Letter by Sheila Feit responds to Jan 28 article on using computer software to teach children table manners; says visual sound bites are no substitute for experience

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Oil prices rise after industry report shows that domestic crude oil supplies are not as high as estimated; graph; table (S)

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARDCOVER    This Month / Last Month

headline: A Handshake Becomes More Than a Symbol
abstract: The Israeli delegation to King Hussein's funeral theoretically united political foes in mourning. But nicey-nice lasts only so long among Israeli politicians.     By the time darkness fell over the King's grave on Monday, they were warring over their comportment among the Arab officials.

headline: Clinton Tells Arafat to Ease Israelis' Concerns
abstract: Pres Clinton warns Yasir Arafat against declaring Palestinian statehood without agreement on politically explosive issue with Israel; Clinton, meeting with Arafat in Washington, thanks him publicly and privately for his efforts toward reconciliation with Israel; also prods Arafat to do more to ease Israeli concerns about safety of Jewish residents of territories that come under Palestinian control (M)

headline: U.S. Ace in the Case: A Steel-Trap Memory, an Eye for the Jugular
abstract: The courtroom success that David Boies has enjoyed depends on thorough preparation, plenty of backup from lawyers for the Justice Department and 19 states suing Microsoft, and a steel-trap memory. He starts with a script but, far more than most lawyers, varies from it. He will let a witness give a rambling speech and then, seizing on a spoken sentence or two, he recalls a document among thousands in evidence that refutes the witness's testimony.    Microsoft insists that these ''gotcha moments'' of courtroom drama may be prominently reported in daily news accounts of the trial, but that they do not undermine the factual record of the case.

headline: Kosovo Rebels Hold Off A Strong Serb Offensive
abstract: Foreign military observers say separatist rebels in Kosovo are holding out surprisingly well against apparent major Serbian offensive in Kosovo, despite losses and shortage of ammunition; Govt forces have reportedly pushed ahead with unexpected energy, apparently attempting to gain advantage before NATO bombing takes too great a toll on forces (M)

headline: FIRST DATA TO BUY 45% OF PAYMENTECH FOR $400 MILLION
abstract: First Data Corp to buy 45 percent of rival Paymentech Inc for about $400 million and merge it into Bank One Payment Services, which owns other 55 percent; will jointly own payment-processing alliance with Bank One Corp; Pamela Patsley will run combined unit (S)

headline: China Tightens Rein on Writers And Publishers
abstract: China's powerful Department of Propaganda is engaged in quiet crackdown on liberal intellectuals, journalists and publications; has sent stern warnings to some magazines and newspapers that strayed too far from prescribed line, forced some editors and writers out of jobs and halted distribution of several books that delve into political alternatives or embarrassing episodes in history of Communist rule; campaign reflects leadership's concern for stability as it confronts rising unemployment and protests by workers and farmers; may also reflect concern over dissent related to upcoming 10th anniversary of violent pro-democracy demonstrations in Tiananmen Square and 50th anniversary of founding of People's Republic (M)

headline: Siemens Buys 2 Companies To Enter Data Networking
abstract: Siemens AG of Germany becomes latest European maker of traditional telephone equipment to push into market for data communications gear when it announces acquisition of Castle Networks Inc and Argon Networks Inc and investment in Accelerated Networks Inc; Siemens will fold two acquisitions and parts of existing US operations into new subsidiary called Unisphere Solutions Inc, based in Burlington, Mass; Siemens will initially commit $1 billion to venture (M)

headline: Levitt Asks Exchange Chiefs To Widen Options Trading
abstract: Arthur Levitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has sent a letter to the chief executives of the nation's four option exchanges asking for their cooperation in opening the options trading business to increased competition and electronic market integration.    The letter said, ''Technological advancements since the fledgling years of the options markets now render obsolete past claims that electronic market integration is not feasible.'' It was sent on Wednesday to William J. Brodsky, chairman of the Chicago Board Options Exchange; Richard F. Syron, chairman of the American Stock Exchange; Meyer S. Frucher, chairman of the Philadelphia Stock Exchange, and Robert M. Greber, chairman of the Pacific Stock Exchange. Mr. Levitt asked that they  respond to his letter by March 15.

headline: Even Milosevic Foes Criticize Western Media
abstract: Small but significant minority of Serbs, frustrated by war propaganda that passes for news in Belgrade, spend long hours every day watching satellite television, exchanging E-mail and surfing Internet; they say that NATO's media manipulation is simply more subtle than Belgrade's, that Serbian interests in Kosovo are ignored or trivialized and that Serbs are being demonized to justify bombing; Vesna Kostic, economic journalist and open opponent of Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic, comments; photo (M)

headline: Spanish Chain to Bid For Vivendi's Hotels
abstract: Sol Melia SA, hotel chain based in Spain, plans to bid for hotel unit of Vivendi SA, France's largest water utility (S)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH HIRES HELP FOR EQUITY CAPITAL MARKETS
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co hires Dante Roscini, managing director in European equity capital markets at Goldman, Sachs & Co, to serve in similar role in its own operations (S)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Bruce E. Behrens and Liam D. Burke; Flag Investors Communications Trust
abstract: William R Long Investing With column on Flag Investors Communications Trust and its managers Bruce E Behrens and Liam D Burke; photos; chart; graph (M)

headline: Two Khmer Rouge Leaders Spend Beach Holiday in Shadow of Past
abstract: Liberated at last from a life of revolution, two Khmer Rouge leaders came to the beach today with their families, their leisure wear and their sunglasses.     But their holiday was a drab one, spent mostly behind the dirty brown curtains of their tiny hotel rooms, trapped inside by their fear of a small group of reporters.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Brazilian real strengthens after central bank says it will continue to defend currency against speculators; graph; chart; table (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOK FINANCIAL CORP.,  Tulsa, Okla., a bank holding company, plans to buy Swiss Avenue Bank, Dallas, a $223 million institution, for an undisclosed amount of cash.    ABITIBI-CONSOLIDATED INC.,  Montreal, a forest products company, will shut down one of three paper machines at its mill in Iroquois Falls, Ontario, eliminating 240 jobs, or one-third of its work force, over the next few months.

headline: In Filmmaker's Ideal Russia, a Presidential Role?
abstract: Interview with Nikita S Mikhalkov, director of film The Barber of Siberia, who says he will weigh running for president himself if he cannot find candidate to support; possible candidacy reflects disillusionment Russians have with choices among infirm Pres Boris N Yeltsin and slew of pretenders widely seen as power-hungry opportunists; he calls for restoration of real or idealized virtues of Czarist Russia; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; This Is No Pie-in-the-Sky Concept
abstract: Noel Godin, Belgian anarchist who has made a career of throwing pies at authority figures, puts Bill Gates at the top of his target list; Gates was pied only last February (S)

headline: On the Horizon: A Way to Write In Thin Air
abstract: British Telecommunications is developing computerized pen that writes and acts as both electronic organizer and text-recording device; pen, called Smart Quill, will contain motion sensors that will record hand's movements; to translate movements into digital text, users will dip pen into electronic inkwell connected to PC that carries Smart Quill's translation software; photo (S)

headline: Net Income Up Sevenfold At National Westminster
abstract: National Westminster PLC says its second-half 1998 profit rose sevenfold, exceeding expected performance; net income rose to 876 million pounds ($1.4 billion) compared with 124 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: After the Years of Mourning, a Time for Joy
abstract: Albanian-Americans in New York metropolitan area rejoice when Pres Clinton announces that NATO bombing of Serbia had begun, but their joy is mixed with fear for their relatives and US servicemen; photo (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Swiss Enthusiasm for the Euro; Computers Are Reprogrammed, but Politics Intrudes
abstract: Switzerland has no plans to join 11-nation euro currency zone, but many Swiss companies and banks will use euro to help maintain their extensive business ties with rest of Europe; Switzerland cannot join 11 nations that have embraced euro because it is not a member of European Union; arrival of euro is expected to stoke debate about whether Swiss should forfeit their cherished separateness as Europe unifies all round them; no one expects country to desert Swiss franc any time soon; people are divided, their political parties even more so, and land of glacial public debate--where issues are subjected again and again to referendums--can hardly expect early or easy decision; map; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Airline Travelers Enjoying A Decline in Ticket Prices  When several major airlines raised their fares at the end of last month, they were bucking a longer-term trend of decreasing prices.    The new higher fares, part of the same search for greater profits that has made the airlines determined to keep a lid on employee costs, will primarily affect the business travelers who schedule flights too late to take advantage of most discounts. But in general, all passengers have experienced a drop in what they have paid for flights over the last two years.

headline: Argentines Suffering From Brazil Crisis
abstract: Economic crisis in Brazil, main engine of region's Mercosur trade union, threatens Entre Rios, Argentine province that has benefited from regional trade because of its roads and bridges linking Argentina to Paraguay, Brazil and Uruguay; Brazilian currency's fall is beginning to undercut competing Argentine exports; pressures are increasing to raise tariffs on Brazilian goods, move that would jeopardize dream of opening wide regional free-trade zone; map; photo (M)

headline: New Delhi Bid To Take Over Eastern State Hits Obstacles
abstract: For Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, the euphoria of his historic peacemaking visit to Pakistan was short-lived.     The stories about high-stakes nuclear diplomacy were quickly bumped off the front pages this week by his Government's mad scramble to salvage its move to dismiss the government of the eastern state of Bihar, one of India's poorest and most populous.

headline: Offerings of Equity Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    American National Financial Inc., Irvine, Calif., an initial offering of 2 million shares. Josephthal Lyon & Ross Inc.

headline: Consumers Still Seem Resistant to Some New High-End Electronics
abstract: Makers and sellers of consumer electronics products hope 1999 will be industry's best year ever; they say array of new and enhanced products are stimulating sales; sales of consumer electronics have grown at average of 3 to 5 percent a year since 1991; Consumer Electronics Manufacturers Assn expects sales to reach almost $80 billion this year, increase of more than 6 percent; in discretionary-spending terms, Americans spend more on consumer electronics than on furniture, jewelry, household appliances or sporting goods; rise in sales is attributed in part to stay-at-home habits of Americans; question is whether Americans will agree to pay high prices for new products, or wait until prices come down; photo; chart (M)

headline: Draft Peace Plan for Kosovo Would End Serbian Control
abstract: Proposed peace plan for Kosovo reportedly would effectively end Serbian control over province, international monitoring mission would get wide-ranging powers including right to appoint administrative and judicial officials; plan would also reduce number of Serb troops to 4,000 or 5,000, from 25,000; Sens Joseph Lieberman, Richard Lugar and Chuck Hagel make plea for support on sending NATO troops; plan would give Kosovo highest degree of autonomy posible over three years, but is vague on key issue of separating warring parties and imposing cease-fire (S)

headline: Makeover: The Postal Service Goes Hollywood
abstract: Warren Weideman, advertising executive hired by US Postal Service to find ways to improve its public image, says there is trove of true stories about exciting work of postal inspectors; as result, Postal Service has contracted with Showtime for four movies based on adventures of postal inspectors; first Showtime movie on subject, The Inspectors, starring Louis Gossett Jr, scored best ratings for any original film in that channel's history when it was broadcast last September; photo (M)

headline: The Players in the Printer-Copier Game Change Again
abstract: Printer-copier market changes again as Xerox Corp announces that it is buying SET Electronique, French company that makes continuous-feed printers that can print 500 pages a minute; SET's printers have 'controller' technology that enables them--unlike Xerox's printers--to accept data that are compatible with printers made by International Business Machines and Oce; currently IBM and Oce together control 90 percent of this market, which serves banks, utility companies and other big generators of transactional data-like bills and statements (M)

headline: Reporter Finds Russia Has Not Outlived Secrecy
abstract: Closed-door trial of Capt Grigory Pasko, charged with treason for reporting about dumping of military waste at sea, shows there are still limits on free speech in Russia, especially when military is concerned; follows arrest arrest of Aleksandr Nikitin, retired Navy officer who researched radioactive contamination caused by Russia's northern fleet; is being held in Vladivostok, far from Moscow's media glare; Pasko, career Navy officer, was working as reporter for Navy newspaper and freelancing for Japanese television network when arrested; map; photos (M)

headline: Acquisitions By 2 Agencies
abstract: McCann-Erickson World Health acquires health care communications companies MPE Communications and Curry Martin Sciavelli; terms undisclosed; Earle Palmer Brown acquires DMTG Inc, direct marketing and advertising agency; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Museum of Natural History Puts the Desert at Your Doorstep
abstract: Article on move by natural history and paleontology museums to explore new ways to use Internet to complement exhibits and enhance science education; photo (M)

headline: Pay and Duties Hefty for Barclays Chief
abstract: Barclay PLC's new chief executive Michael O'Neill negotiates compensation package that is based on his success in turning around Britain's second largest bank; O'Neill will buy $8.25 million worth of Barclays stock, to be matched by bank if he stays three years; he will also get $1.4-million salary plus bonus; O'Neill, who is American, says it is appropriate that he own stock himself (S)

headline: In 'Clarification' on Immigrants, Hong Kong Court Bows to China
abstract: Hong Kong's highest court bows to intense pressure and responds to Hong Kong government's request for 'clarification' with extraordinary statement that it had not meant to challenge Chinese authority with its recent ruling granting residency to mainland children of Hong Kong parents; does not alter ruling; lawyers and democracy advocates score stand (M)

headline: Less Serbian Diplomacy and More Fighting
abstract: Fighting spreads across southern Kosovo and Richard C Holbrooke, American envoy, leaves for Washington empty-handed after his meetings with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic; but Holbrooke first meets with reprs of other nations trying to bring peace to Serbia, then hands over negotiating to Greek and Russian Foreign Ministries; photo; map (M)

headline: Chevron Is Investing in Venezuela Projects
abstract: Chevron plans to invest up to $5.5 billion, by itself or with partners, in three oil projects in Venezuela; oilfield is operated under contract for Petroleos de Venezuela; Chevron's partners are Statoil of Norway and ARCO and Phillips Petroleum (S)

headline: U.S. Jet Fires Missile at an Iraqi Battery After Being Targeted
abstract: Iraqi antiaircraft battery, pressing its challenge against American and British control of its skies, turns its radar on American fighter jet, which responds by firing missile at it; map shows no-flight zones in Iraq (M)

headline: From Celebrity Doctor, Medical Advice on Line
abstract: Your Trusted Health Network, whose Web site bears name of Dr C Everett Koop, former US Surgeon General, will seek to raise $50 million through initial public offering; drkoop.com offers free medical information, discussion groups, support groups and information on insurance; photo (M)

headline: INVESTORS WANT CORPORATE EXPRESS CHAIRMAN REMOVED
abstract: Marlin Partners I LP and Brahman Management LLC, group that is major investor in Corporate Express Inc, urges company to replace its chairman, Jrika Rysavy, and hire investment banker to help consider alternatives like a merger; group wants title of chairman transferred to Robert L King, currently chief executive (S)

headline: Stock Fund Inflows Slip After January Gain of $15.7 Billion
abstract: Mutual fund companies report investors have been paring amount of money they put in stock mutual funds in February, after pumping $15.7 billion into funds in January; Investment Company Institute says pace of money moving into bond and money-market funds in February has also been lower than in January, when $8.43 billion went into taxable and municipal bond funds and record $60.8 billion poured in to money-market funds (M)

headline: You Want Fries With That Web Site?
abstract: Profile of Aron Leifer, who at age 18 is worth more than million dollars as result of marketing his computer skills through his software company, Multi Media Audiotext, which he hopes to take public within six months and join ranks of other multimillionaires; Leifer is not atypical of number of other young persons who are setting up what amounts to on-line versions of yesteryear's lemonade stands and earning money from their computer knowledge; sketches of other young computer entrepreneurs; suggestions on how to get rich at young age in computer field; photos (L)

headline: The N.B.A. Finally Returns and Marketers Yawn
abstract: Agreement in principle reached to salvage National Basketball Association season is being welcomed by most marketers and advertising agencies, but many in industry describe little if any significant damage from six-month lockout; they express concern that late start to season, as well as lingering perceptions of players and officials more concerned about salaries and selling than the game, will alienate fans; for many advertisers, real basketball season is the playoffs (M)

headline: Creative Waiting For Job Seekers
abstract: Michelle Cottle column answers reader's question on how job seeker should follow up on interview (M)

headline: EDISON BROTHERS AGAIN SEEKS BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Edison Brothers Stores Inc files for protection under Chapter 11 for second time, listing $346.8 million in assets and $295.1 million in liabilities (S)

headline: Lloyds TSB Profit Rose in Second Half
abstract: Lloyds TSB Group PLC reports 3.5 percent rise in second-half 1998 net income, for total of $1.9 billion (S)

headline: INTEL ALTERS PLAN SAID TO UNDERMINE PC USERS' PRIVACY
abstract: Intel Corp reverses plan to activate identifying signature in its next generation of computer chips, bowing to protests that technology would compromise privacy of users; Intel, which makes about 85 percent of world's computer processors, had said that serial number on Pentium III chips would enhance security of electronic commerce and guard against software piracy, but advocacy groups warned of further erosion of Internet anonymity that would allow companies to collect and sell detailed profiles of consumers; Intel now says user will have to voluntarily turn on identification system; Marc Rotenberg of Electronic Privacy Information Center warns concession is only temporary fix (M)

headline: MORE ON THE CONFLICT
abstract: ALLIED FRUSTRATION -- Hampered by overcast skies, NATO warplanes bombarded Yugoslav Army forces, airfields and supply depots around the clock. But after a week, they were still unable to knock out air defenses or check Serbia's offensive in Kosovo. Page A11.

headline: Company's Plan to Privatize Angers Shareholders
abstract: Minority PEC Israel Economic Corp shareholders file lawsuits to block PEC's largest shareholder, Discount Investments Corp, from buying up remaining shares and delisting PEC stock; offer to privatize PEC is made several months after Goldman, Sachs & Co paid $78 million for 9.5 percent stake in Israeli holding company that controls Discount Investments; Goldman, jointly with Lehman Brothers, also happens to be lead underwriter of Cellcom, Israel's largest mobile telephone operator and PEC investment, which plans to list shares in US shortly; lawsuits contend that offer substantially underestimates value of investments PEC has made over the years (M)

headline: Despite Brisk Sales, G.M. Won't Reach Market Goals
abstract: General Motors' top North American executive said today that a long-promised sharp rebound in the company's market share in the United States would not be possible this year if the industry's sales continued at their torrid pace because G.M. could not produce enough full-sized pickup trucks to meet demand.    The acknowledgment of G.M.'s difficulties is an unusual example of how the prosperity of the American economy combined with low energy prices has actually created problems for some companies. G.M. simply cannot make enough big V8 engines to build all the full-sized pickup trucks it needs to meet its market-share goals at a time of near-record auto sales and record light-truck sales, said Ronald Zarrella, the president of G.M.'s North American operations.

headline: AMERICA ONLINE ENLARGES ITS STAKE IN TEL-SAVE.COM
abstract: America Online Inc enlarges its share of ownership in Tel-Save.com Inc to about 15 percent and says it has extended its marketing agreement with Tel-Save by two years; America Online says it will make $55 million investment in Tel-Save.com common stock at $19 a share and will exchange about $19 million in Tel-Save.com warrants for common stock; investment will add to America Online's current holding of about 8 percent (S)

headline: Malaysia Says Its Much-Criticized Financial Strategy Has Worked
abstract: Mayalsian Central Bank briefs foreign fund managers on nation's investment outlook, saying its decision last September to impose strict controls on foreign investment have stablilized the country and put it on the road to recovery; asserts with delight that the disaster predicted by Internatinal Monetary Fund, US Treasury Department and other critics of capital controls have not occurred; says rules have since been relaxed and Malaysia is now ready for business; map; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN STANDARD CONSIDERS OPTIONS FOR MEDICAL UNIT
abstract: American Standard Cos weighs strategic options for its Diasorin Inc to capitalize on interest in unit's discovery of virus correlated with advanced liver disease (S)

headline: President of Toys 'R' Us Quits Abruptly
abstract: Bruce W Krysiak resigns as president and chief operating officer of beleaguered Toys 'R' Us; exec vice pres Mike Shannon is named president of US division; company does not name executive to replace Krysiak as president of overall company and chief operating officer (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.75   4.73   5.48        3-month T-bills   4.36   4.40   5.02        6-month T-bills   4.36   4.40   5.02        10-yr. T-infl.   3.80   3.80   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.88   4.87   5.56        30-yr. T-bond   5.36   5.30   5.84        Telephone bd.   6.98   6.98   7.10        Municipal bds.   5.12   5.14   5.18          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: A Bid for Gucci? Not Now, LVMH Says
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA says it does not plan to make takeover offer for Gucci Group NV 'under the present conditions'; LVMH paid $397.9 million for stake of about 15 percent of Gucci from Prada; analysts say LVMH is unlikely to be content with minority stake in long run (S)

headline: Pilots at Air France To Get Ownership Stake
abstract: Air France says its pilots will own 6.3 percent to 7.4 percent of equity in airline after Government sells minority stake in company; company says 78.8 percent of pilots agreed to take pay cut in exchange for equity; French Government is planning to sell one-fifth of airline in initial public offering this month (S)

headline: Caught With Their Pants On
abstract: Daniel Akst The Culture of Money column deplores failure of critics of Calvin Klein Inc's advertising drive for children's underwear line to protest everyday television programming and advertising that subject young viewers to violence and hucksterism; photo (M)g

headline: Happy Feet For Horses Of the Rich And Famous
abstract: Profile of Arnie Gervasio, farrier with loyal clientele in New Jersey's horse country and in West Palm Beach, Fla; photo (M)

headline: Thompson Revamps Office in New York
abstract: J Walter Thompson Co announces series of personnel changes as part of reorganization of agency's New York office by Bob Jeffrey, who recently became president; Doug McMahon, executive vice president-director, is named to additional title of general manager; Carol Potter, executive vice president-director, is named to additional new post of client services director (S)

headline: Starts of Homes Up; Factory Output Rises
abstract: Commerce Department reports that new-home construction starts rose in January at fastest pace in 12 years; starts rose 3.8 percent to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.804 million houses; December starts rose revised 5.1 percent, previously reported as 3.5 percent gain; Federal Reserve reports factory production rose one-tenth of a percent in January after similar gain in December; overall industrial production was unchanged; graphs (M)

headline: SHAW AGREES TO BUY TWO CABLE SYSTEMS IN NOVA SCOTIA
abstract: Shaw Communications Inc agrees to pay $167 million (Canadian), or $111 million (US), for 75 percent stake in Access Communications Inc of Nova Scotia, and all of Access Television Bedford/Sackville Ltd, to expand in eastern Canada (S)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT: To Beat the Market, Hire a Philosopher; Bill Miller Rethinks Value, and Keeps Thumping the S. & P.
abstract: Article profiles William H Miller 3d, manager of $6 billion Legg Mason Value Trust mutual fund that has over past eight years out-performed Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; since beginning of 1990's shareholders of fund have seen investments grow by 453 percent, or 20.9 percent per year on average; photo; charts; graphs (L)

headline: TheStreet.com Plans to Raise Up to $75 Million in Offering
abstract: TheStreet.com, on-line financial news service, says it will seek to raise as much as $75 million in initial public offering of its shares, but does not disclose what percent of its stock it will sell to public; in early February, TheStreet.com sold shares to The New York Times Co for about $11 each; Times Co has invested $15 million in cash and services in exchange for equity stake equivalent to about 8 percent of company (M)

headline: Royal and Sun Bids For Guardian Royal
abstract: Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance Group PLC seeks to buy rival, Guardian Royal Exchange PLC, for cash and stock (S)

headline: Without a Hitch, the Euro Opens To Trading in World Marketplace
abstract: Euro, Europe's new single currency, has nearly flawless debut in world markets as European financial institutions open for business without hitch and euro climbs in value against other major currencies; stock exchanges in London, Paris and Frankfurt open serenely despite grueling weekend in which millions of computers had to be reprogrammed; euro, in its first full day of trading, opens at $1.17, climbs to nearly $1.186 and by afternoon in New York is trading at $1.18060; stock markets in Frankfurt, Paris, Milan and Madrid all jump 5 percent or more; Britain, which has thus far refused to adopt euro, has less euphoric day; FTSE stock index ends up roughly even while pound slips against euro; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Coffee futures rise 2.3 percent after influential forecaster predicts Brazil's next crop will be smaller than expected; in New York, March arabica coffee rises 3.15 cents, to $1.20 a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: Japan Weighs Formal Status For Its Flag And Anthem
abstract: Prime Min Keizo Obuchi prepares bill to rehabilitate rising sun flag and song of praise for Emperor as national flag and national anthem despite criticism that they were emblematic of Japanese militarism in World War II; flag and song have been widely used in postwar period, so legal adoption would make little practical difference (M)

headline: Americans at U.N. Seek Parity With Foreign Co-Workers
abstract: Group of American citizens working for UN in professional-level jobs will intensify efforts to obtain same education grants for their children that foreign officials receive in New York; under agreement signed more than 50 years ago, foreign professionals working at UN headquarters as specialists in range of fields receive more than $15,000 in educational grants annually for each child which are intended to allow foreign families to pay for private education in language or culture of their home countries; critics say grant buys entry to best private schools and colleges for children who may have been born in US, have American parent or be part of family that has settled in US; since 1994, UN officials may apply for permanent residency after 15 years of work at headquarters (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Sugar futures fall almost 4 percent amid signs of weakening demand from India and Russia, world's biggest consumers; in New York, sugar for May delivery falls 0.24 cent, to 6.02 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Nike Raise in Indonesia
abstract: Nike Inc to raise wages it pays entry-level workers in Indonesia to equivalent of $31.44 a month, from $29.66; move coincides with expected rise in Indonesia's minimum wage to $27.41 (S)

headline: Plans for Rival Rallies on Religion Issue Stir Fears in Israel
abstract: An escalating conflict between religious and secular Jews is expected to spill into the streets here on Sunday when a mass prayer rally against the liberal Supreme Court faces a counter-rally by nonreligious Israelis who feel that democracy is under attack.    Political leaders worked unsuccessfully today to persuade religious leaders to cancel the prayer rally, which some feared could turn violent. By police prediction, at least 100,000 demonstrators are expected, a loose coalition against ''the judicial dictatorship'' including ultra-Orthodox Jews, religious Zionists and Jewish settlers from the West Bank.

headline: Germany's Pragmatic Ex-Radical Thinks Globally
abstract: Interview with Joschka Fischer, environmentalist and revolutionary agitator in 1960's who is Germany's current Foreign Minister; photo (M)

headline: Lilly and 3 Rivals to Settle Prozac Suit for $4 Million
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co reaches $4 million settlement with three drug companies that are trying to make generic version of Prozac, Lilly's popular anti-depressant; analysts see Lilly as big winner in settlement, which virtually guarantees that Prozac will not become generic before December 2003, when last of its patents expires; Lilly's patent infringement lawsuit was against Barr Laboratories, Geneva Pharmaceuticals unit of Novartis AG, and Apotex Inc of Canada (M)

headline: Life After The VCR
abstract: Peter H Lewis article on upgrading to DVD video player; advises against Divx video players; drawing (M)

headline: Two European Banks Facing Foreign Losses
abstract: ABN Amro Holding NV says second-half profit fell 13 percent, to 719 million euros ($790 million), from 823 million euros; full-year profit rose to 1.83 billion euros, from 1.76 billion euros in 1997; Dresdner Bank AG says 1998 pretax profit fell 7 percent, to 2.6 billlion marks ($1.46 billion) (S)

headline: IN APARTHEID'S WAKE: A special report.; South Africa Grumbles Toward Next Vote
abstract: Feeling of triumph that dominated South African elections in 1994 is all but history as country approaches second post-apartheid election in May; even though Govt of Pres Nelson Mandela has achieved many successes in past five years--decreasing political violence, improving living conditions, adopting world's most liberal Constitution and tackling other major issues than racial equality--its many victories remain symbolic and have have yet to be enforced; white farmers still own most of land, most maids still work without contracts and far beyond 48-hour-a-week limit and some restaurants in small towns still refuse to serve blacks; many people are unable to pay for new access to electricity and water and crime and unemployment still continue to dominate almost every aspect of life; despite economic policies that have been lauded by West, country's economy has grown slowly; some experts feel South African companies, adjusting to global competition and difficulties in mining industry, have trimmed 500,000 jobs since 1994; unemployment rate may be as high as 40 percent and interest rates are well over 20 percent; African National Congress is expected to win elections handily, but its support seems related more to loyalty than to satisfaction; photos; chart (L)

headline: TRADING IN NEW INTERNET COMPANY IS HALTED
abstract: SEC suspends trading in USA Talks.com Inc, start-up Internet telephone company, after shares almost quadruple in less than one month; questions about accuracy of public information about company cited (S)

headline: U.S. Issues Travel Warning
abstract: State Department issues worldwide travel warning and urges Americans to take special security precautions abroad because of violent protests over arrest of Kurdish rebel leader Abdullah Ocalan (S)

headline: 9 Die in Austria As Avalanches Sweep the Alps
abstract: Avalanche crashes through Galtur, Austria, ski resort, killing at least nine people and leaving dozens missing; snow and winds bars emergency helicopters from flying into village; local rescue workers, digging through night, free at least 30 people, some of them critically hurt; fiercest snowstorms in 50 years have set off huge avalanches all across Alps in recent weeks; death toll in Switzerland rises to seven; heavy snow forces train cancellations and blocks highways in many parts of Europe, stranding tourists in ski resorts; map; photo (M)

headline: Malaysia Eases Some Foreign Investment Controls
abstract: Malaysia, in first tentative step back into global economy, announces that it will relax some of sweeping controls on foreign investment that it imposed in September; Finance Min Daim Zainuddin says Government will lift 12-month moratorium on withdrawal of foreign capital from country; but to prevent outbreak of capital flight, it introduces exit tax that discourages investors from pulling their money out immediately; exchange controls on Malaysia's currency, the ringgit, remain in force (M)

headline: Visa U.S.A. Votes to Continue Ad Effort Based on Its Brand
abstract: Visa USA directors vote to keep Visa brand name at center of credit card group's marketing campaigns, following Citigroup's withdrawal from Visa in protest over issue; Citigroup will shift its new business to Mastercard; still unresolved is whether Visa logo will be moved to back of credit cards so as to emphasize name of issuing bank (S)

headline: An Entertainment Weekly series aims to give marketers an association with popular culture.
abstract: Entertainment Weekly plans four themed issues of magazine, supplemented by features on its Web sites and related television programs, that seek to bring together advertisers and retailers seeking to associate selves with growing American appetite for everything related to entertainment; Ford Motor Co's Mercury brand is lead advertiser on project (M)

headline: Jobs for Cambodians â€” or Sweatshops?
abstract: PHNOM PENHâ€”  At dawn each day, hundreds of shift workers file into garment factories dotted around a city that just over two decades ago was virtually an empty shell.

headline: Pentagon Presses Ex-Iraq Inspector on Book
abstract: Defense Dept demands that Scott Ritter, former United Nations weapons inspector in Iraq, turn over advance copies of book in which he is expected to step up his criticism of Clinton Administration and detail some of his work for UN; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Censures A Major Firm On Its Auditing
abstract: Federal regulators censure PricewaterhouseCoopers, world's largest accounting firm, for violating basic rule that all auditors must follow to be independent from companies they audit; Securities and Exchange Commission's lawyers say they discovered 70 instances in which accounting firm's partners, employees or pension fund invested in companies that firm audits; regulators do not disclose companies' names (M)

headline: Some Advice for Mr. Gates: Have Your Day in Court
abstract: Steve Lohr Economic View column in form of E-mail from one of Microsoft Corp chairman William H Gates's advisers urging Gates to personally defend company's aggressive form of capitalism at antitrust trial (M)

headline: Treasuries Are Sharply Lower In Advance of AT&T Offering
abstract: Treasury bond prices post their biggest loss in two weeks on speculation that AT&T Corp will increase its bond sale from $6 billion or more already planned; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 29/32 to 95 22/32; table shows key rates (S)

headline: Ayer Chief to Form New MacManus Unit
abstract: Mary Lou Quinlan, chief executive at N W Ayer & Partners in New York, takes new position of vice chairwoman at company's parent, MacManus Group; Mary Beth Casey, president at Ayer, will succeed her (S)

headline: Ebay to Offer Free Insurance and ID System
abstract: Ebay Inc, Internet auctioneer, says it will offer free insurance and user-identification system to increase users' confidence in security of its on-line trading network (S)

headline: Palestinians Reject Netanyahu Offer as Campaign Tactic
abstract: Palestinian officials reportedly rebuffed Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu's quiet offer to carry out several of Israel's obligations under frozen peace agreement signed last fall; Netanyahu, through intermediary, proposed that Israel open up promised southern safe-passage route between Palestinian territories in West Bank and Gaza, and he volunteered to release some Palestinian petty criminals from Israeli jails; but Palestinians did not take initiative seriously, because Netanyahu made no offer to cede any additional territory in West Bank; Saeb Erekat, senior Palestinian peace negotiator, says he views Netanyahu's offer as domestic political gesture to help him get re-elected; photo (M)

headline: No. 2 Official Out at Mattel In Shake-Up
abstract: Mattel Inc's chief operating officer Bruce L Stein and Gary Baughman, president of company's Fisher-Price subsidiary, resign as part of sweeping management reorganization; Stein's position will be eliminated; Mattel will have five business products units headed by president who will report directly to chairwoman-chief executive Jill E Barad; company is trying to retool itself as broader children's products concern; reorganization comes as Mattel tries to recover from series of disappointing earnings reports and decline in sales in 1998 (M)

headline: Enron and Qatar Cancel a Gas Project
abstract: Enron Corp, one of world's largest energy companies, and Qatar Government cancel plans to build $4 billion liquefied natural-gas plant after three years of talks (S)

headline: Jules W. Lederer, 81, Salesman And Budget Rent-a-Car Founder
abstract: Jules W Lederer, founder of Budget Rent-a-Car and former husband of Ann Landers, syndicated newspaper advice columnist, dies at age of 81; photo (M)

headline: Yet Another Day of Canceled Flights Troubles Travelers and Tourist Officials
abstract: The tourist industry's high hopes that accompanied the court order issued Wednesday requiring pilots of American Airlines to return to work were dashed yesterday, as the airline was still forced to cancel nearly 1,200 flights -- many to popular holiday and vacation resorts in Florida and the Caribbean.     Dallas/Fort Worth International Airport resounded with the sounds of happy travelers bound for ski resorts in Colorado and other Western states, but American flights to warm-weather destinations were canceled left and right because many pilots continued to call in sick.

headline: 6 Years After Crash, Talk of Cover-Up
abstract: Dutch Parliament is investigating crash of El Al cargo plane into Amsterdam housing complex that killed 43 people on ground in Oct 1992; over 1,100 rescue workers and residents say they were somehow contaminated by burning aircraft, or its mysterious cargo; El Al in Oct 1998 revealed that cargo included vats of chemicals that can be used in manufacture of deadly nerve gas Sarin; investigation is expected to hear some 70 witnesses and last months more, drawing together reports of illness and allegations of cover-up by El Al and Dutch Government that have inflamed public passions in Amsterdam; photo (M)

headline: New York Times Co. to Invest $15 Million in TheStreet.com
abstract: New York Times Co agrees to invest $15 million in cash and services in TheStreet.com, on-line provider of investment news and financial information, in exchange for minority equity stake; Times Co also says it is 'currently discussing opportunities for strategic alliances with TheStreet.com'; Times Co vice chairman Michael Golden is nominated to serve on TheStreet.com's board of directors; Times chief executive-vice president Russell T Lewis says deal holds promise for Times Co; Times spokesman Lisa Carparelli says type of services to be provided to TheStreet.com have not yet been determined; deal brings together longtime friends, James J Cramer, TheStreet.com founder, and Martin A Nisenholtz, president of New York Times Electronic Media Co, unit of Times Co that operates its Web site (M)

headline: Car Makers Predict Strong Sales This Year
abstract: Plunging auto sales in Asia and South America hurt auto makers around globe in 1998; question now is whether sales will stay strong in North America, and whether European auto market will remain vigorous despite recent hints of weakness, particularly in Germany; graph (M)

headline: CARAUSTAR PLANS TO BUY MILL FROM INTERNATIONAL PAPER
abstract: Caraustar Industries agrees to buy Connecticut paper mill from International Paper Co for $108.3 million (S)

headline: Ecology:Cambodia's Next Man-Made Disaster
abstract: PHNOM PENHâ€”  The floating casino moored at the edge of this city, where the Mekong and Tonle Sap rivers meet, symbolizes the readiness of those who wield power and influence in Cambodia to gamble with its fragile environment and economic future, development specialists say.

headline: Kaduna Journal; If Army Can't Play Politics, There's Always Polo
abstract: Nigeria's military, which has ruled Africa's most populous nation for many years, suffers setbacks that have unsettled many old soldiers who live in Kaduna; photos of polo club, British institution introduced in 1904; map (Kaduna Journal) (S)

headline: More Peril for Microsoft With Videotape
abstract: The Microsoft Corporation once again today found itself in trouble with a videotaped demonstration in Federal court. And while even the Government lawyer who discovered the problem conceded, ''I don't mean to imply that this is terribly critical,'' it adds to a growing body of evidence that the Justice Department is using to throw Microsoft's credibility into doubt.    Last week, Microsoft played a videotape intended to demonstrate the advantages of integrating a World Wide Web browser with its Windows operating system.
