But over several days, the Government's lead trial lawyer, David Boies, pointed out so many problems and inconsistencies with the tape that Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson declared that he could not view it as reliable evidence.

headline: China Syndrome: Disputes Persist, Civility Rules
abstract: Jane Perlez analysis of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright's visit to China in which she and Beijing's leaders discussed their disagreements over human rights, trade and national security; notes that on her departure, Albright put best face on fractured US-China relationship, saying it is mature enough to withstand sharp disagreements; Albright photo (M)

headline: Japan Intercepts Two Boats That May Be North Korean
abstract: Japanese patrol boats, warships and aircraft intercept two suspicious boats with false markings and fire warning shots in attempt to force them to stop; it is first time in 46 years that Japan has fired warning shots at sea and first time since World War II that Japan has sent destroyers to chase suspicious vessels; Japan gives up pursuit as vessels flee toward North Korea; photo (M)

headline: They're King-Size Issues, Whatever You Call Him
abstract: Issues involved in copyright infringement suit filed by Artist Formerly Known as Prince against Uptown magazine noted; logo (S)

headline: Treasuries Gain on Sign Inflation Still Is No Threat
abstract: Treasury bond prices rise for second time in three sessions after Government report points to tame inflation, even amid strong economic growth; price of 30-year Treasury gains 6/32 to 96 19/32 (S)

headline: Nasdaq Open Short Sales Off
abstract: Open positions of short sales on Nasdaq stock market fall 3.3 percent in most recent monthly period, according to National Association of Securities Dealers, which oversees the market (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Hold Steady, Ending 5-Day Losing Streak
abstract: US bond prices are little changed, after five consecutive trading days of declines; benchmark 30-year bond gains 4/32, to 98 21/32, pushing its yield down to 5.34 percent; graph on 3-month Treasury bills; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Trade Deficit Soared 53%, To $168.8 Billion in 1998  The United States trade deficit soared 53 percent last year, to a record $168.8 billion, as the global financial crisis forced the first decline in American exports in more than a decade.    Most of the increase in the deficit came from remarkably strong consumer spending for foreign-made goods. But the deficit for December narrowed unexpectedly, to $13.8 billion, a 10 percent decline from November. [Page A1.]

headline: Holbrooke: Last Chip?
abstract: News analysis: Serbian officials believe special US envoy Richard C Holbrooke's visit to Belgrade in last-ditch effort to stave off military attacks by NATO forces is to placate nervous NATO allies more than to stop bloodshed, and that he will arrive from Washington with limited instructions and little ability to negotiate; while Milosevic understands that military force can do him great harm, he also understands that NATO is still divided, with its credibility on line just ahead of its 50th anniversary celebration in Washington (M)

headline: Novartis Profit Rises; Merger Savings Cited
abstract: Novartis AG says its profit in the second half of 1998 rose 20 percent to 2.51 billion Swiss francs ($1.7 billion) from 2.09 billion year earlier (S)

headline: Treasuries Off In Advance of Next Week's Fed Meeting
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities sag as market participants await next week's meeting of Federal Reserve's policy-setting committee; yield on 30-year bond is up 5 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 5.58 percent; its price falls 23/32, to 96 7/32; graphs (M)

headline: Motorola Invests In Home-Network Studies
abstract: Motorola Corp will donate $5 million to create a new research center at Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Laboratory to explore 'think and link' technologies that connect everyday appliances (S)

headline: Expanding Ties, Clinton Extends a Hand to Cuba
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  The United States, seeking to ease the plight of the Cuban people without strengthening its government, will allow a greatly expanded flow of cash donations to Cuba, authorize food sales and permit easier travel to the Caribbean island, President Bill Clinton announced Tuesday.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of picture caption with Jan 10 article that misidentified man who works at Greenpoint Manufacturing and Design Center

headline: South Korea's Jobless Rate Rises to 8.7%
abstract: South Korea's jobless rate rose to record 8.7 percent in February, in line with expectations, as manufacturers and contractors scale back hiring (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Orange juice futures fall almost 4 percent as record inventories overshadow forecasts for smaller Florida crop; in New York, frozen concentrate for March delivery falls 3.2 cents, to 84.25 cents a pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: LESLIE FAY'S TOP HOLDER SEEKS DEBT-FOR-STOCK BUYBACK
abstract: Dickstein & Co, which owns 41.8 percent of Leslie Fay Co, asks company to buy back 41 percent of its stock by exchanging 2.5 million shares for debt securities at premium to current share price; says it would participate in buyback and remain substantial shareholder (S)

headline: SPECTRASITE BUYING 2,000 TOWERS FROM NEXTEL
abstract: Nextel Communications, which offers wireless phone services to businesses, agreed yesterday to sell more than 2,000 towers to Spectrasite Communications for $560 million in cash and a 17 percent stake in the closely held Spectrasite. In addition, Spectrasite said it would receive $490 million to build 1,700 new towers within five years, including more than 1,000 this year. Equity investors including the investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe committed $400 million in cash to Spectrasite to complete the transaction. Shares of Nextel rose $1.625, to $32.125.

headline: Distrust and Egos Lie Behind Pilots Dispute
abstract: Airline pilots are some of America's best paid and most highly respected workers. They are also among the most militant.    Hundreds of pilots for American Airlines called in sick last week to vent their rage in a dispute with the airline's management, forcing the cancellation of thousands of flights and inconveniencing hundreds of thousands of passengers.

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: JEHOVAH'S WITNESS RULING -- Final judgment was deferred in a closely-watched court case against the Jehovah's Witnesses, who have been charged with violating Russia's restrictive law on religion. A judge sent the case to a panel that includes two linguists, a psychologist and two experts on religion. Rights advocates, who see the case as a test of religious tolerance, said the order was an attempt to put off a politically-charged decision.    Celestine Bohlen (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Worldwide, Things Are Not Going Better for Coke
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's sales volume has dropped in many countries, profit is flat or falling, and company is trying to manage its way through more simultaneous crises abroad than at any time since end of World War II; Coca-Cola's damage control has moved into high gear in light of recession in Brazil and possible economic downturn of other Latin American nations; Coke chairman M Douglas Ivester, in consumer-products conference presented by Merrill Lynch for dozens of portfolio managers who hold keys to billions of dollars in investment funds, is expected to try to reassure investors that long-term outlook for Coke remains positive; analysts say investors are looking for more short-term security than company's shares can provide; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: New Floods of Refugees Are on the Move
abstract: People flee village of Srbica in Kosovo as Serbian forces advance and ethnic Albanian forces pull back; photo; map (M)

headline: Consumer Prices Held Almost Steady in February
abstract: Labor Department reports that consumer prices barely budged in February as reductions in apparel, automobile and fuel oil costs almost canceled out small increases in food and medical care expenses; says Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of one percent last month (M)

headline: COMPUSA SAYS IT WILL MAKE ITS ON-LINE UNIT INDEPENDENT
abstract: CompUSA Inc, in bid to exploit eager market for Internet-related stocks, plans to make its mail-order and on-line retailing unit, CompUSA Direct, an independent entity (S)

headline: British Food Company Rejects Bid From Dairy
abstract: Terranova Foods PLC, maker of chilled food that was spun off from Hillsdown Holdings PLC, in October, rejects an offer of 228.5 million pounds ($370.2 million) from Unigate PLC, Britain (S)

headline: Vending Machines Face An Upheaval of Change
abstract: Euro is becoming problem for vending machine manufactuers; rush to covert machines means that many of them will be out of commission for long periods, in limbo between currencies; many customers will be frustrated in July 2002, when currency conversion is completed, because they will still have their national currencies; vending machine manufacturers expect cost of replacing coin boxes, as well as loss of revenue while machines are being converted, to put sizable dent in that business; manufacturers are pondering when to change machines because if custoemrs do not have proper coins they will go elsewhere; photo (M)

headline: Business Travel; It's no accident that many of the faces in airport departure lounges are looking younger these days.
abstract: Business Travel column discusses hectic pace executives face as companies send them to more countries in shorter time periods; notes companies are turning to younger people who are more resilent to frequent airline flights; also notes airline travelers are becoming vocal at airports about delays (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Deutsche Telekom, Phone Home; Alien Concept of Competition Gets a Giant's Dander Up
abstract: Germany's Deutsche Telekom, one of last old state-run companies to lose its monopoly, has been forced to cut rates sharply and has lost significant share of long-distance market as competition has forced down telephone rates across much of Europe; long-distance prices have plunged by as much as 70 percent, and new price wars are breaking out; analysts estimate Deutsche Telekom has already lost about 30 percent of its long-distance market and may lose more this year; German regulators have softened their relentlessly hard stance and set new rules this month that will make it more expensive for rivals to enter local telephone market; Gerhard Schmid, chief executive of Mobilcom, which has become second-largest long-distance carrier in Europe's biggest and most bruising telephone market, comments; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Iraq Moves to Oust U.S. and British Aid Teams
abstract: Iraq takes its first step toward expelling US and British relief workers, saying their visas will not be renewed because their safety cannot be guaranteed in face of public anger over recent air strikes (M)

headline: Mexico Announces 'Total War' on Narcotics
abstract: Mexico's four top security officials jointly announce what they call new antinarcotics strategy, based largely on introduction of radar and other technology; Interior Sec Francisco Labastida Ochoa says Mexico will spend $400 million to $500 million over three years to buy new planes, ships, radar and other military and law enforcement equipment; says strategy involves pledges to co-ordinate country's law enforcement agencies and combat corruption more efficiently; rare joint public appearance by four officials may be effort to influence United States officials three weeks before Clinton Administration must certify whether Mexico is reliable partner in narcotics war (M)

headline: G.M. Disappointed by January Sales
abstract: General Motors Corp reports sales of 308,880 cars and light trucks in January, a 4 percent increase compared with sales in same month a year earlier, which were off 6 percent from January 1997; sales industrywide were up nearly 12 percent in January; GM's chief forecaster Michael DiGiovanni says company is disappointed in January results; chart (M)

headline: Brazil's Government Struggles To Pass Bills to Fight Crisis
abstract: Brazilian Congress is set to vote in next few weeks on series of key bills designed to cut huge budget deficit and calm investors; most contentious measure is sweeping reform of social security system, which Congress has repeatedly rejected; Senate, 64-12, approves increased levies on financial transactions, spurring 3.75 percent rise in stock prices amid heavy trading (M)

headline: Merger Rumors Abound at Big Auto Show
abstract: Merger rumors abound at North American International Auto Show in Detroit, Mich; company most often mentioned as potential acquirer is Ford Motor Co, which has accumulated $22 billion in cash; Ford's chief executive Jacques Nasser expresses amusement at rumors (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.56   4.83   5.44        3-month T-bills   4.46   4.51   4.94        6-month T-bills   4.48   4.54   5.01        10-yr. T-infl.   3.89   3.89   3.69        10-yr. T-note   5.16   5.26   5.65        30-yr. T-bond   5.53   5.59   5.95        Telephone bd.   7.29   7.31   7.04        Municipal bds.   5.22   5.23   5.30          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: The Dow Briefly Breaks 10,000 Before Retreating
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average breaks the 10,000 level for brief time before falling back; index, which rose to 10,001.78, closes at 9.930.47, down 28.30; graph; photo of reaction of traders on floor of New York Stock Exchange (M)

headline: Expert to Help Devise Format For Delivering Music on Net
abstract: Recording industry names Leonardo Chiariglione to head Secure Digital Music Initiative, in effort to create technical format for copyrighted sale and digital delivery of music over Internet; Chiariglione was instrumental in creating industry-standard formats for converting and compressing video and audio information into digital form known as MPEG; Chiariglione announces ambitious timetable, saying he plans to have preliminary standards on paper by June to insure that industry-backed format would be approved in time to sell music on line by Christmas; recording industry associations of North America, Japan and Europe want to be able to distribute songs and albums on Internet in way that protects copyright holders and foils many audio pirates who copy and distribute digital music illegally (M)

headline: Playing Catch-Up at the On-Line Mall
abstract: Traditional retailers are arriving on the Internet in droves, but list of the 50 most popular Web shopping sites contains few familiar names; some investors question whether so-called brick-and-mortar retailers will ever catch up in on-line sales with Internet-only retailers like Amazon.com and Etoys Inc; Web consultants and retailing chains themselves are cobbling together a whole new set of rules and standards for success; among them are speedy site navigation, generous return policies and companywide coordination; photos (L)

headline: A 'System on a Chip' At Higher Speed From I.B.M.
abstract: IBM will announce its entry in market for technology used in making so-called system-on-a-chip semiconductors; putting all key components of computer system on single chip sharply lowers cost while increasing performance of computing devices; photo (S)

headline: Though Suspected as China Spy, Scientist Got Sensitive Job at Lab
abstract: Government officials say that in spring 1997, Los Alamos National Laboratory chose Wen Ho Lee, scientist who was already under investigation as suspected spy for China, to run sensitive new nuclear weapons program; say Lee hired unidentified research assistant who was citizen of China; Lee has been fired for security breaches at Los Alamos and remains suspect in FBI's continuing investigation of allegations that China stole nuclear secrets from US weapons laboratories; he is under suspicion of having stolen data for one of America's most advanced nuclear warheads; his assistant has disappeared; Government officials are trying to determine if he played role in Chinese intelligence operation (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Mark L. Yockey; Artisan International Fund
abstract: Mark L Yockey, manager of Artisan International fund, discusses his investment strategy, which currently favors European stocks; photo (M)

headline: The Doppelganger; Errors Lead to a Cyberbond as Comfy as an Old Shoe
abstract: Tina Kelley article on learning that long-suffering person who was forwarding her misaddressed E-mail from similar E-mail address was not another Tina Kelly, but secretary who checks E-mail received at boss's old E-mail accounts (M)

headline: Copacabana Journal; Auto Insurance for All Comers, Yours for a Prayer
abstract: Drivers of all kinds of vehicles--taxis, trucks, buses, vans and ordinary cars--drive from all over Bolivia, Peru and even northern Argentina to remote town of Copacabana, Bolivia, to seek priest's blessings for protection against drunken drivers, landslides, bad brakes and broken axles; every morning and afternoon, but particularly on Sundays, Copacabana's central plaza becomes jammed parking lot of rattletrap buses and minivans splotched with mud from long, arduous journeys through Andean highlands; drivers drape their side-view mirrors and bumpers with colorful ribbons and bushels of pink and white gladiolus; pilgrims d not drive home until one of six Franciscan priests sprinkles holy water on their dressed-up vehicles and says a prayer asking for divine intervention against everything from accidents to faulty directions and gas shortages; popularity of pilgrimage makes it most important source of income for town of 5,000 people; custom of driving to Copacabana as religious rite began in 1950's; photo; map (M)

headline: For Fax Users on the Go, A Free Service, but With Ads
abstract: eFax.com, Silicon Valley company, offers service that will direct subscriber's incoming faxes to any E-mail address, not fax machine; subscriber then signs up with company for personal fax number and calls made to that number will be routed through eFax to user's E-mail address; service is free, but faxes that arrive in E-mail will be accompanied with advertisements above each message (S)

headline: U.S. Attacks a Microsoft Videotape as Misleading
abstract: Justice Department accuses senior Microsoft Corp executive James Allchin of offering misleading videotape into evidence at antitrust trial and using it to try to discredit important Government witness, Edward W Felten, Princeton University professor who devised program that he says extricates Microsoft's Web browser, Internet Explorer, from Windows operating system; initially, Allchin is embarrassed and says his staff made error; later, Microsoft says it viewed correct tape; issue is crucial because Government contends Microsoft's decision to combine Windows with Web browser was abuse of monopoly power to thwart competition; Government lawyer David Boies says episode raises questions about Microsoft's credibility (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PINOCHET HEARINGS END -- The House of Lords concluded 12 days of hearings to determine whether Gen. Augusto Pinochet, the former Chilean dictator, is immune from arrest and extradition to Spain on charges of torture, kidnapping and murder. Lord Browne-Wilkinson, chairman of the seven-member Law Lords, Britain's highest court, gave no clear indication of when a decision would be announced.   Alan Cowell (NYT)    RUSSIA: INQUIRY ON TYCOON WIDENS -- An investigation of the financier Boris A. Berezovsky has been widened to include Aeroflot, in which he had a stake. Those being questioned include the former Defense Minister Yevgeny Shaposhnikov; when he was head of Aeroflot, he directed the airline to channel hard-currency earnings to a Swiss company half-owned by Mr. Berezovsky, the newspaper Moskovsky Komsomolets reported.   Celestine Bohlen (NYT)

headline: Let's Get Serious
abstract: In the right hands, humor can be an invaluable capitalist tool. It can break tension, restore perspective and promote creative thinking. How have you used humor on the job to solve a problem or wriggle out of a tough situation? Or how did your attempt backfire? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Speakers Make Waves
abstract: J D Biersdorfer answers question on possible link between speakers and monitor distortion on personal computer

headline: An Ocean Of Little Fish Worth Swallowing
abstract: INSURANCE is like broccoli. It's good for you, but many people find it bland.     Still, lots of savvy investors are piling insurance company stocks into their portfolios as the number of companies peddling the stuff shrinks. Last year was a record for insurance company mergers, according to Securities Data, a Newark, N.J., research firm, with more than $100 billion of transactions completed worldwide.

headline: Cartel Has Cash Shortage
abstract: International Natural Rubber Organization, cartel financed by 17 producing and consuming nations to support rubber prices, faces cash shortage after some members fail to pay into fund used to buy rubber in open market (S)

headline: When a Buddy Makes It Big
abstract: Abby Ellin article says high-tech entrepreneurs who become millionaires in their 20's can keep the friends of their youth who live on much more modest incomes; cites friendship between Steven Aldrich, who is worth about $10 million, and Kent Kille, a college teacher; drawing (M)

headline: Brussels Journal; Where 15 Babbling Brooks Join in Wordy Torrent
abstract: Insistence of European Union's 15 members on protecting their own languages and their resistance to streamlining communication by dropping some of 11 official languages forces European Commission, its executive body, to maintain world's largest translation staff; commission employs over 1,900 full-time translators and interpreters and phalanx of freelancers; staff is expected to grow as more nations join union; photos (M)

headline: Group of Brokers Is Facing Charges of Insider Trading
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission and Justice Department announce group of stockbrokers from Renaissance Financial Securities has been charged with insider trading in scheme involving nonpublic information about coming articles in Business Week magazine; charges contend that from June 1995 through January 1996, Larry F Smath, former broker at Renaissance, paid employee of magazine distribution company approximately $200 a week for advance faxed copy of Business Week's widely read 'Inside Wall Street' column, which frequently reports on rumored acquisitions or stock recommendations of money managers; Smath then reportedly sold information to four other brokers; SEC says information was used as basis for purchases of $8 million of securities; Smath pleads guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit securities fraud; Peter L Cohen, Seth J Glaser and Joseph T Falcone are arrested on charges of insider trading; others named in SEC complaint are Tasin & Co broker Frank J Zangara and Gregory R Salvage, foreman at Hudson News Co, distributor of newspapers and magazines including Business Week (M)

headline: Analyst Who Promoted Intel to Join Tiger Hedge Fund
abstract: Thomas Kurlak will join Tiger Management LLC to manage its portfolio of technology stocks; Kurlak, in his years as analyst with Merrill Lynch, made unerringly accurate calls on Intel Corp stock, but his increasingly cautious predictions about Intel last year proved overly bearish, hurting his reputation (S)

headline: Command, Control and Adrenaline, and Relief at Pilot's Rescue
abstract: Interview with combat crew of Lockheed EC-130E command-and-control aircraft that herds NATO warplanes flying bombing attacks over Yugoslavia; diagram (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Fracmaster Ltd, Calgary, Alberta, oilfield services company, seeks court protection from creditors, as it rebuilds after an unsuccessful search for a buyer (S)

headline: 2 European Media Giants to Form Network
abstract: Mediaset SpA, Italy's No. 1 commercial television company, and Kirch Group, Germany's second-largest media company, say they have agreed to poll one billion Euros ($1.1 billion) in assets to create first pan-European television network (S)

headline: Assassination of Shiite Cleric Threatens Further Iraqi Unrest
abstract: Grand Ayatollah Mohammed Mohammed Sadeq al-Sadr, Iraq's leading Shiite Muslim cleric, is assassinated along with two sons; he is third Shiite clergyman to be killed in less than year; Iraqi Govt condemns killings and hints at foreign involvement; killings reportedly lead to clashes between between security forces and Shiite civilians in Baghdad; deep tensions have long existed between Sunni-led Govt of Pres Saddam Hussein and Shiite Muslims, who make up 65 percent of population (M)

headline: AXA of France to Buy Guardian of Britain
abstract: AXA Group of France to acquire Guardian Royal Exchange PLC for $5.68 billion; deal, through its Sun Life and Provincial Holdings subsidiary, will make AXA number 3 in Britain's property and casualty insurance business; deal gives AXA a corporate insurance unit in Germany to bolster its subsidiary there; as part of deal, AXA will sell Guardian Royal's property-casualty business in US to Liberty Mutual Group in Boston for $1.47 billion (M)

headline: FIRSTPLUS SELLS FINANCE UNIT TO THAXTON FOR $51 MILLION
abstract: Firstplus Financial Group Inc sells its Firstplus Consumer Finance Inc unit to Thaxton Investment Corp for $51 million (S)

headline: Small On-Line Brokers Raise Share of Trades
abstract: Business of buying and selling stocks for smaller investors is being shaped as much by lesser-known on-line brokerage firms as it is by big brand-name firms; on-line trading grew by record 34 percent in fourth quarter, and several large banks and Wall Street firms are trying to find ways to buy into that success; shares of several on-line brokerage firms have been soaring, because of tremendous success of their businesses; sticking point with smaller on-line brokerage firms is that many on Wall Street are wary of linking up with firm whose fortunes are tied too heavily to speculative, volatile trading in Internet stocks, which many on-line brokerages specialize in; chart (M)

headline: Israeli Planes Strike at Guerrillas in Southern Lebanon
abstract: Israel conducts aerial bombardment against four alleged Hezbollah strongholds deep inside Lebanon, stung into action by week of attacks that culminated in killing of Gen Erez Gerstein and three other Israelis in roadside bombing in southern Lebanon; bombardment ends day of intense conflict in low-level war in southern Lebanon; map; photo (M)

headline: Boston Celtics Stock Up
abstract: Stock of Boston Celtics LP hits 52-week high of $17.50 as publicly traded owner of NBA team says its private partnership, Castle Creek Partners, has made offer for up to 16 percent of company's stock (S)

headline: Executive Leaving Thompson Agency
abstract: John Geoghegan, general manager of J Walter Thompson Co, is leaving; will join Careguide.com; succeeds Oliver Mittermaier, who becomes chief operating officer; chief executive Larry Tolpin says agency has no plans to name successor; Tolpin has named Gordon Munroe to take vacant post of president at Thompson West (S)

headline: Federal-Mogul Ends Bid for Lucas Varity
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp drops out of bidding for Lucas Varity PLC, saying purchase would not clear its financial hurdles; that lets TRW Inc proceed with its offer of $6.53 billion in cash (M)

headline: BERKSHIRE REALTY REBUFFS A PURCHASE OFFER
abstract: Berkshire Realty Co, owner of apartment properties in South, calls $1.15 billion buyout offer from group of investors led by its chmn, Douglas Krupp, insufficient, and says it has received other offers (S)

headline: In Race to Develop Blue Lasers, Japanese Star Surges Ahead
abstract: Shuji Nakamura, a Japanese inventor working alone, develops new generation of short-wavelength lasers, an achievement that is likely to hasten introduction of high-definition digital video disks, higher-resolution laser printing and inexpensive and highly efficient light bulbs for use in the home; such lasers, in blue and violet part of spectrum and with shorter wavelength that infrared or red light, have been pursued for years by giant corporations; Nakamura's company, Nichia Chemical, Industries has begun shipping sample quantities of violet lasers with life span of 10,000 hours; photo (M)

headline: Immigration Ruling by Hong Kong Court Is Generating New Tensions With Beijing
abstract: Hong Kong court ruling that children born in mainland China to parents who are Hong Kong residents have right to live in Hong Kong stirs tensions between China and Hong Kong; judges used case to make broad statements about independence of Hong Kong's judiciary and about Hong Kong's autonomy in general; Tung Chee-hwa, Hong Kong's chief executive, says he will send Justice Secretary to Beijing to discuss conflict; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Drug Board Urges Research on Marijuana as Medicine
abstract: International Narcotics Control Board, which oversees international drug-control treaties for United Nations, recommends governments sponsor impartial research into medicinal benefits of marijuana, annual report; stresses research must not become pretext for legalizing drug; reports marijuana abuse is widespread in most nations (M)

headline: Big Dutch Insurer to Acquire Transamerica for $9.7 Billion
abstract: Aegon NV acquires Transamerica Corp for $9.7 billion in cash and stock; Aegon will also take $1.1 billion in Transamerica debt; with acquisition, Aegon will become third-largest life insurer in US in terms of assets and premiums; deal also reinforces its standing as third-largest insurance company worldwide in market capitalization; Transamerica will be merged into insurance businesses of Providian Corp, which Aegon acquired in 1997; photo of Aegon USA chairman Donald J Shepard and Transamerica chairman Frank Herringer (M)

headline: ENRON AGREES TO BUY PHILIP SERVICES WATER UNIT
abstract: Enron Corp agrees to buy Philip Utilities Management, water and sewer treatment business controlled by Philip Services Corp, for $107 million in cash and $13 million in assumed debt (S)

headline: RENTAL SERVICE IN $366 MILLION DEAL FOR RIVAL
abstract: Rental Service Corp agrees to acquire Nationsrent Inc, rival equipment rental company, for about $366 million (S)

headline: Canary Wharf Owners Plan to Sell Some Stock
abstract: Canary Wharf Group PLC, which owns office development that in 1992 caused Britain's biggest real estate collapse, announces plan to sell one-quarter of its shares to public; sale on London Exchange, which could take place in March or April, could raise 500 million pounds, or about $800 million; analysts say sale could value company at around $3.5 billion (M)

headline: Ruling Party In Mexico Wins Election For Governor
abstract: Election authorities in Mexico's Guerrero State declare Rene Juarez Cisneros, candidate of governing Institutional Revolutionary Party, winner of gubernatorial election; opposition angrily contests results, alleging irregularities in vote count (M)

headline: Saudis Admit Restricting U.S. Warplanes in Iraq
abstract: Nearly three months of US bombings against Iraq are proving irritant to ties between US and Saudi Arabia; senior Saudi officials acknowledge kingdom refuses to allow American warplanes based in Riyadh to take part in what it perceives as punitive raids; stand has forced US to rely more heavily on navy aircraft and on warplanes at other bases; while Saudi officials make clear privately that they would prefer someone other than Saddam Hussein ruling Iraq, their military position is indication of discomfort felt over American-led campaign (M)

headline: Rushing In as Insiders Rush Out
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on investment picks by Web trader Chris Rea, who is under Securities and Exchange Commission investigation; graph (M)

headline: He'll Take His Web Pages Straight, With No Java Jive
abstract: Article by Benjamin Cheever on the Internet and his preference for words over streaming video, downloading music and all the other supposed glorious images that Web is supposed to deliver; says he uses his computer mostly for writing and E-mail (M)

headline: The Different Faces Of Retirement
abstract: To the Editor:    The retirement article needs some tinkering. I played paratroop infantry officer for three wars and almost 30 years. Next, I spent 15 years as a university professor. Then, at 65, I put dolce far niente (the sweetness of doing nothing) on my card.

headline: Unintended Consequences
abstract: Kiev, Ukraine, businessman reportedly had auto accident when 50 pagers he had just bought for staff went off simultaneously while he was driving; each bore greeting from paging company (S)

headline: Talk Radio Copes With Life After Lewinsky
abstract: Radio talk show hosts and program directors are eager to move beyond the Monica Lewinsky story, which boosted their ratings early in 1998 only to turn viewers off in the fall, when focus shifted from Oval Office trysts to constitutional questions and impeachment hearings; Talkers magazine reports that Rush Limbaugh regained position of most-listened-to host in last half of 1998; he trailed Dr Laura Schlesslinger and Howard Stern a year ago; cartoon (M)

headline: Sports and TV Start-Ups Limit News Corp. Earnings
abstract: News Corp reports its fiscal second-quarter income fell 14 percent; income from operations fell to $339 million from $395 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 15 percent, to $4.06 billion from $3.53 billion; Fox Entertainment Group says profit rose 52 percent; net income rose to $105 million from $69 million a year ago; News Corp says it will end its agreement to buy as much as 80 percent of Stream pay-television unit of Telecom Italia if Italian Government decree limiting soccer-rights ownership is not changed; British Sky Broadcasting, which is 40 percent owned by News Corp, says sales for its new digital service surpassed forecasts; profit for fiscal second quarter fell to 800,000 pounds--about $1.3 million--from 61 million pounds--about $100 million (M)

headline: News Corp. Cutting Costs
abstract: News Corp ordered 3 percent cut in operating costs in January to tighten its budget and increase profits; no job reductions are expected (S)

headline: Pain of War for Guatemalans Isn't Over
abstract: Idea of reconciliation remains abstract for many Guatemalans, despite efforts of special truth commission to nurture national unity by offering first official acknowledgment of atrocities committed during 30 years of civil war; many Guatemalans say even though war is over, effort to trace loved ones and to bring those responsible to justice goes on; photo (M)

headline: Netanyahu's Absence of Outrage Over Atrocities Ignites a Debate
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, criticized in Israel for his Government's muted response to expulsion and killings of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo, condemns mass murder by anyone in conflict; says Israel will send aid to refugees (M)

headline: Publishers Root for Michael Jordan's Retirement
abstract: Book publishing industry waits eagerly for announcement that Michael Jordan will retire from professional basketball, knowing it would bump up sales of several new books about him; Random House has invested heavily in two books: Jordan's own book, For the Love of the Game: My Story, and David Halberstam's Playing for Keeps; Jordan's book, which was released last fall, has not sold according to publisher's high expectations, partly because of six-month National Basketball Assn lockout; Halberstam's book wil be published on Feb 1; Halberstam says Jordan's retirement was not reason he wrote book; photo (M)

headline: HUSSMANN TO BUY GRUPO KOXKA FOR $145 MILLION IN CASH
abstract: Hussmann International Inc acquires Grupo Koxka, Spanish commercial-refrigeration company, for about $145 million in cash (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY     None

headline: I.B.M. to Offer Linux With Netfinity Computers
abstract: IBM will ship its Netfinity line of network server computers with Linux, the free operating system, pre-installed alongside Microsoft Corp's Windows NT (M)

headline: Exchange Controls Lifted; Brazil Stocks Rise by 33%
abstract: Brazilian Govt lifts exchange-rate controls allowing currency to trade at market value; move sends markets soaring in Brazil and elsewhere; comes 24 hours after central bank ruled out move, fearing it would send currency plunging in value; Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso says he abandoned defense of currency only as last resort; says erosion of foreign reserves would have left country in worse shape; Finance Min Pedro Malan and new central bank president, Francisco Lopez, meet with officials of International Monetary Fund in Washington; fund has aided Brazil with $41.5 billion bailout package of loans from various countries and international agencies; Brazil, viewed as economic locomotive of Latin America, accounts for 20 percent of US exports and owes more than $228 billion in foreign debt; graph (M)

headline: G.M.'s Profit Rose 7.7% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: General Motors Corp announces unexpectedly large increase in profits during fourth quarter of last year; profit rose 7.7 percent, to $1.77 billion, but fell 53.2 percent, to $2.96 billion, for all of 1998 because of 54-day strike; chart (M)

headline: Media Talk; Wall Street Journal's Washington Appeal
abstract: Wall Street Journal, seemingly celebrating its own foresight, runs full-page ad in Washington Post containing reprints of Journal editorials dating from 1994 regarding Pres Clinton, special prosecutor and 'character questions' (S)

headline: Brazilian, in I.M.F. Talks, May Ask for Early Aid
abstract: Brazil Finance Min Pedro Malan begins talks with International Monetary Fund in Washington, DC; says he might ask for early release of next round of international assistance to country to help stabilize its economy; talks begin day after Brazil dropped efforts to defend value of its currency, raising fears of another bout of global financial turmoil and economic hardship (M)

headline: With Switch In Heir Plan, King Hussein Stuns Jordan
abstract: King Hussein of Jordan is preparing to select one of his sons as his heir, Jordanian officials said today, culminating a dizzying week in which the King returned from six months of cancer treatment abroad and then dismissed his brother as Crown Prince.    The sudden ouster of Crown Prince Hassan, who is 51 and had been the King's designated heir for 34 years, has stunned even Jordanians long used to surprises from the 63-year-old King, who has made change in course a hallmark of his 47-year rule.

headline: Suha Arafat: A Militant in a Blue BMW
abstract: Yasir Arafat's wife, Suha, does not look or act like typical Palestinian woman, but in ideology she is every bit the fiery Palestinian freedom fighter; she was raised in well-off home in West Bank, educated by nuns and refined at Sorbonne; her deep-seated Christian faith and Western assertiveness seem at odds with her husband's world: desperate Gaza with its veiled Muslim women; Suha Arafat is merciless critic not of her husband but of his government, and she does battle on Palestinian television with advisers she believes are dragging down Arafat and Palestinian people; Suha Arafat was dismissed as 'decoration' for Arafat when they married decade ago; by speaking her mind and establishing humanitarian institutions in Gaza, she has earned place for herself as Palestinian leader in her own right; photo with their 3-year-old daughter (M)

headline: Tangled in Talks
abstract: News analysis: Kosovo negotiations in France invite comparisons to Dayton talks that ended war in Bosnia, but the two differ significantly; Dayton talks were United States show from start to finish, while process at Rambouillet is dominated by Europeans; another big difference is that at Rambouillet there is very little discussion between the warring sides, who have sent only bit players, and the real negotiating is being conducted among European and US diplomats; most intense quarreling among sponsors of the talks has been over which country should do what in Kosovo in event of a peace agreement (M)

headline: Possible Bill Would Curb Posting Of Government Data on Internet
abstract: Environmental Protection Agency has dropped its plan to post on Internet its 'worst case scenario' plans for handling accidents at 66,000 chemical plants and chemical storage sites under Clean Air Act; intelligence agency officials say such information would create Internet road map for terrorists; environmental groups and community advocates say easy public access to data is necessary to help prepare for such accidents, should they occur; Rep Thomas J Bliley Jr is considering legislation to prevent environmental groups from obtaining information through Freedom of Information Act and posting it on their own sites (M)

headline: Rare Expose in China Warns Of Unrest Over Dam Project
abstract: Major intellectual journal in China has published searing expose of social problems caused by construction of giant Three Gorges Dam; article describes obstacles to resettling 1.3 million people whose homes and farms will be flooded by reservoir behind dam, on Yangtze River, which starts filling in 2003; contends that plight of these people may become 'explosive social problem' and dam region hotbed of sustained upheaval; such blunt dissection of major Government program is almost never seen in China; article is likely to cause speculation about possible cracks in high-level support for dam, which is considered pet project of former Prime Min Li Peng, who remains No 2 in Communist Party and heads China's parliament; map; photo (M)

headline: India Promises, With Pakistan, To Seek Peace
abstract: Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee of India and Prime Min Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan hold joint news conference in Lahore and issue joint declaration pledging immediate steps to reduce risk of nuclear war and to seek solutions to half a century of raging disputes, such as conflict over Kashmir; memorandum of understanding pledges to build trust in each other through series of high-level bilateral meetings and to adopt measures to prevent any accidental launching of nuclear weaponry; pledges to continue declared moratoriums on further nuclear trials and agrees to announce in advance any testing of ballistic missiles; Vajpayee extends invitation for Sharif and wife to visit New Delhi (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BIG ENTERTAINMENT INC.,  Boca Raton, Fla., an Internet-based seller of entertainment merchandise, agreed to acquire the Times Mirror Company's Hollywood Online Inc. unit, which operates a Web site for movie and celebrity information, for $31 million in stock.

headline: Australia Approves Flu Medication for Sale
abstract: Biota Holdings Ltd and Glaxo Wellcome PLC win approval to sell new flu drug, Relenza, in Australia; Food and Drug Administration panel voted against approving drug for sale there because it said positive findings from two small studies in Europe and Southern Hemisphere were not enough to overcome doubts about drug (S)

headline: Tensions Rise Before Albright's China Trip
abstract: A day before the arrival of Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, the Chinese Government tonight expressed ''strong resentment'' in a predictably tart response to the lambasting of its human rights record in a State Department report on Friday.     The official Chinese statement, read on the state-run television, accused Washington of meddling in China's internal affairs by ''fabricating unwarranted charges'' while ignoring serious rights violations in its own country.

headline: Paperwork Piles Up For Active Investors
abstract: KEEPING records of stock purchases and sales and completing the tax forms to report capital gains and losses are tricky enough for the average investor. But for day traders, who spend their days flipping stocks, and for a growing army of other investors who trade often, lured by the bull market and the ease of trading on line, compliance with tax reporting rules creates a mountain of paperwork.    Just ask John D. Rankin of Osprey, Fla., who spends 20 hours a week managing his portfolio. He figures he makes 150 to 300 trades annually.

headline: Talking Your Way To Career Failure
abstract: Consultant Debra Benton, author of new book Secrets of a C E O Coach, cites talking too fast, giving others too much detailed information and being judgmental or self-critical as reasons why executives fail to advance in their careers (S)

headline: Microsoft Executive Ends The Day Mostly Unscathed
abstract: For first time since Microsoft Corp began presenting its defense against Federal antitrust charges, major company witness, William Poole, leaves courtroom unscathed; Poole manages to hold his own, though Government lawyer David Boies leaves Poole mumbling and stammering and even backpedaling a few times (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.

headline: FIRST SECURITY TO SWAP STOCK FOR COMSTOCK BANCORP
abstract: First Security Corp to acquire Comstock Bancorp for about $65 million in stock (S)

headline: 3 Music Companies Press for Prosecution
abstract: Seagram's Universal music unit, EMI Group PLC and Time Warner Inc's music division, ask Norwegian police to prosecute copyright violations by Fast Search and Transfer, Norwegian company that provides Lycos Inc with directory of MP3 music files; record companies are battling new digital technologies that let consumers copy and distribute music over Internet without paying royalties to industry (M)

headline: Humor is the catalyst in a new $40 million campaign for Kinko's.
abstract: Advertising column describes new campaign for Kinko's Inc, leading business services marketer with 900 retail stores in 9 countries; campaign uses humor to help convince consumers of importance of company's products; campaign is first for Kinko's by TBWA/Chiat/Day unit of Omnicom Group; photo (M)

headline: How Stocks Could Work For Social Security
abstract: Peter Diamond, economist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, supports Pres Clinton's idea of having Social Security trust fund invest part of its money in stocks and bonds; says investments should be overseen by a new independent institution, stock investments should be made through broad index funds and actual investments should be done by private managers, who would commingle funds for Social Security with those from private investors; opposes idea of creating individual accounts as a substitute for defined Social Security benefits; is chairman of panel of National Academy of Social Insurance; photo (M)

headline: NATO's Plan: A Barrage, Not a Pinprick
abstract: European and US officials say initial NATO bombings of Serbia will be broader and more punishing than originally envisioned, going after 60 targets instead of delivering short, sharp strikes; say Supreme Allied Commander, Gen Wesley K Clark, will have authority to strike any targets he chooses after bombing starts; say air and missile strikes will be aimed at more than just those army and police units waging war against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo; say they will aimed at Yugoslav military more generally, striking at Serbian targets vital to supporting repression; map (M)

headline: Business Travel; Jamaica prepares to put troops on patrol at resorts to help ease tourists' fears of crime.
abstract: Jamaica is preparing to dispatch troops to resort areas to help ease tourists' fears of crime; final statistics for 1998 travel and tourism will not be compiled for months, but numbers are expected to surpass those for 1997, if just barely; while number of cruise passengers is likely to top 5.05 million who sailed in 1997, several other major tourist industries slumped last year; scandal over reports of bribery involving 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City, Utah, is creating concern that expected 50,000 additional visitors a day might not show up, either out of disgust with process used to land the Olympics or because diminished sponsorship might result in fewer events surrounding the Games (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: Trial's War of Economists Pits Student Against Teacher
abstract: Franklin M Fisher, economics professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology who testified for Government in antitrust case against Microsoft Corp, was thesis adviser of chief Microsoft economist witness, Richard L Schmalensee, also of MIT; Schmalensee appears to take impish delight at times in poking fun at his mentor; their arguments assessed (M)

headline: A New Campaign On Animal Rights
abstract: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, protesting Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories alleged mistreatment pregnant mares whose urine is used to make estrogen replacement drug Premarin, plans to distribute bottles of fictious beverage supposedly made from urine; is urging consumers to use other estrogen replacements (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: McCORMICK & CO.,  Sparks, Md., the spice and flavorings company, said it planned to buy back up to $250 million of its stock, or about 12 percent of its 71.9 milllion shares outstanding.    KONOVER PROPERTY TRUST,  Cary, N.C., a real estate investment trust, agreed to buy the closely held RMC Realty, the largest manager of strip shopping centers in Florida, for an undisclosed amount.

headline: Media Talk; A Magazine Checks Up on Its Investigators
abstract: Robert Maas, author of many books on mob-world figures, is angry that George magazine took eight months to print article he co-authored with Mike Barnicle, fearing backlash from scandal involving Barnicle and his former employer, Boston Globe; photo (S)

headline: People
abstract: Eric Rosenkranz, client services director at Grey International, unit of Grey Advertising, is named regional director for Latin America, succeeding Frank Clarke, who is retiring; Matthew R Seiler, executive vice president and senior account director at BBDO New York, is promoted to new post of director for strategic services (S)

headline: British Sears Accepts $:548 Million Cash Offer
abstract: Sears PLC of Britain agrees to a 548 million pound ($904 million) cash offer from a group led by the Barclay family and Philip Green and his firm, January Investments Ltd (S)

headline: Shares of 3Com Plunge for a Second Day
abstract: Shares of 3Com Corp fall 8.5 percent, off a second day, amid concern about falling prices on Palm Pilot hand-held computer; company cut by 19 percent price of its most popular Palm Pilot device (S)

headline: Oil Executives Work the Room at OPEC Meeting
abstract: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meeting draws scores of oil industry executive and analysts to Vienna in hopes of audience with oil minister; American executives are able to see Libyans, Iranians and Iraqis discreetly in city, without stirring United States ire for skirting sanctions; photo (M)

headline: Waiting for Small Caps? Bring a Good Book
abstract: Interview with Prudential Securities small-cap research director Claudia E Mott, who comments on their small returns when compared with larger cousins; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Natural gas rises to six-week high as cool weather lifts demand amid falling inventories; graph; chart; table (S)

headline: Living for the Weekend
abstract: Filene's Basement corp division Aisle 3, bucking trend toward longer retail hours, opens three stores that will be open only on Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays (S)

headline: New Rival Arrives, but Dollar Is Still the World's Champion
abstract: Euro--new European currency--has positive debut in foreign exchange dealings; but it is still unclear how euro will fare against the dollar this year and what kind of challenge it will make over time against US currency; in afternoon trading, euro costs $1.18060, up from $1.17400 value of old European currency unit--the ecu--on Dec 31; graph (M)

headline: PROVIDIAN SAYS IT WILL OPEN 2 MORE CREDIT CARD CENTERS
abstract: Providian Financial Corp will open new credit card operations centers in Oakland, Calif, and Arlington, Tex, creating 1,400 jobs by end of 1999 to handle rapid growth (S)

headline: Forget Golf, There Are Masterpieces to Make
abstract: Many people living in Leisure World retirement community in Laguna Hills, Calif, are unleashing their creative energies, painting, sculpting, throwing pots, writing poetry, stories and plays, acting, taking photographs and learning to use computers to construct digital images; photo (M)

headline: Venezuelan Leader Plans to Cut Spending to Pare Deficit
abstract: Venezuelan Pres Hugo Chavez says he will seek special authority from Congress to reduce Government spending and take other steps to cut deficit and repair economy; announcement is made against backdrop of Chavez's controversial plan for referendum on rewriting Constitution (M)

headline: Silicon Valley's Awesome Look at New Sony Toy
abstract: Sony Corp stages demonstration of its new Playstation II video game; while new video game is still more than a year away from store shelves, it is creating stir in Silicon Valley because because it is first machine to deliver graphics that until now could be produced only be supercomputers; game is perhaps most striking example yet of coming generation of powerful computer processors that are not designed for traditional computers; instead, they are engineered to to concentrate all their considerable power on performing highly specialized tasks (M)

headline: World Ills Are Obvious, the Cures Much Less So
abstract: Fourth and final article in series, Global Contagion: A Narrative, on global financial crisis; crisis that began 19 months ago in Thailand is knocking on gates of American heartland and could be landmark crisis of post-cold-war era; while simplest challenge is for US to sustain strong growth rates, broader task will be to prevent nationalistic catacylsms in worst-off countries, like Russia and Indonesia, and to contain political and security risks of explosive frustration if crisis bites further into places like China and Latin America; while economy has demonstrated tremendous flexibility and resilience, uncertainties arise because US stock market is 64 percent higher than in December 1996 when Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, warned against irrational exuberance; photos; chart (L)

headline: 2 Web Sites for All Women, In the Home or Out of It
abstract: Hearst Corp, which recently acquired 50 percent stake in Women.com Web site (www.women.com) is giving Women.com control over its own Homearts.com site in effort aimed a creating company whose combined Web sites will be formidable force in attracting women and advertisers who want to cater to them (S)

headline: Stage II Apparel in Deal
abstract: Stage II Apparel Corp will acquire Cross Colours brand from private group including Robert Greenberg for undisclosed amount of stock (S)

headline: REIT in $108 Million Deal
abstract: Health Care Property Investors Inc agrees to buy 19 medical office buildings for about $108 million from Boyer Co (S)

headline: Hospitals' Mixed Marriages Raise Eyebrows at the I.R.S.
abstract: THE Internal Revenue Service has been  aggressively auditing the tax-exempt status of the more than 20 not-for-profit hospital groups that have struck partnerships with for-profit chains like Columbia/HCA Healthcare and Tenet Healthcare.     At least two deals for such partnerships collapsed recently, clouding the prospects of three hospitals in northern Virginia and four in Alabama. Industry executives say the I.R.S. audits have chilled the outlook for similar joint ventures at a time when many hospitals are under financial pressure. Columbia/HCA and Tenet, the two biggest chains, are already selling dozens of hospitals as they try to bolster profits and investor confidence.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Chief Supports Aid for Social Security  Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the House Ways and Means Committee he supports the President's notion of putting almost two-thirds of the Federal budget surpluses over the next 15 years into Social Security reserves.    But Mr. Greenspan and some Republicans in Congress disagreed with the President's idea of having the Government invest part of the money in the stock market. Political pressures, Mr. Greenspan said, could lead to inefficient investments that would result in a lower rate of return for retirees and a lower standard of living for Americans. [Page A1.]

headline: TEXAS UTILITIES WINS BIDDING FOR AUSTRALIAN COMPANY
abstract: Texas Utilities Co wins bidding for Australian state-owned natural-gas and retail company with its offer of $1.02 billion; Texas Utilities will acquire retail business of Kinetik Energy and distribution business of Westar, which serve Melbourne area and are sold as one company through privatization auction by State of Victoria (S)

headline: In Kosovo's Furtive War, a Serb Just Disappears
abstract: Velika Hoca, Serbia, villagers bury Dobrivoje Savalic, Serbian farmer who was kidnapped on Feb 27 and handed back dead few days later; district around Serbian village has seen almost one killing each day in last two weeks; it is not clear who kidnappers were, but they were almost certainly ethnic Albanians; map; photo (M)

headline: Legal Scholars Support Case for Using Force
abstract: The NATO attack on Yugoslavia skirts the edge of international law, legal experts say. But there are few meaningful sanctions that could be imposed under international law, and legal principles are vague enough to provide justification for the bombing as a humanitarian act.    The central assertion of the Yugoslav Government, Russian officials and other critics of the attack is that NATO has illegally intervened in a sovereign nation's internal dispute. That argument rests on the United Nations charter, which prohibits the use of force except in self-defense, when a nation is threatened with aggression or when the Security Council authorizes a military operation for humanitarian or other reasons.

headline: INTERIM SERVICES IN $438 MILLION DEAL FOR NORRELL
abstract: Interim Services Inc to buy Norrell Corp for $438 million in stock and assumption of $115 million in debt (S)

headline: M.B.A. Magic Is a Fiction
abstract: Experts offer advice to a reader who took night classes to earn an MBA degree in market research only to find that prospective employers seem more interested in experience (M)

headline: Cable Lines to Give Local Phone Choice
abstract: AT&T and Time Warner have joined forces to sell local telephone service over Time Warner's millions of cable television lines. The venture could provide consumers with a major alternative to the regional Bells and GTE, which dominate that $100 billion business.    The companies said they would sell local phone service in one or two undisclosed markets this year. For Time Warner's 1.1 million subscribers in New York City, the deal could bring a widespread local phone alternative to Bell Atlantic in a few years.     Business Day, page C1.

headline: Bridging Goldman's Gender Gap
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co, breaking tradition of male dominance, is adding two women, Robin Neustein and Leslie Tortora, to management committee; both are central to strategy talks at firm (M)

headline: McGraw and National Geographic Team Up
abstract: McGraw-Hill Companies and National Geographic Society say they will join to produce science, social studies and geography books for grade school and high school students (S)

headline: Brazil's Economic Crisis Pits President Against Governors
abstract: Resistance to economic reform by group of powerful state governors creates dangerous impasse in Brazil's struggle to stabilize economy; latest crisis was touched off when Minas Gerais Gov Itamar Franco set unilateral 90-day moratorium on repayment of state's estimated $13.5 billion debt to Government; other opposition governors score Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso's austerity plan and seek to renegotiate their debt (M)

headline: Turkey and Greece Trade Words Over Kurd
abstract: Turkey and Greece trade harsh words as crisis over captured Kurdish guerrilla commander, Abdullah Ocalan, further sours already tense relations; Suleyman Demirel, Turkey's President, says Greece should be added to list of countries that support terrorism and harbor terrorists for allegedly protecting Ocalan after he fled to Kenya, where he was captured by Turkish commandos; Greece accuses Turkey of trying to use it as scapegoat for Kurdish problem, which it urges Turkey to solve quickly; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.63   4.86   5.47        3-month T-bills   4.40   4.40   5.08        6-month T-bills   4.40   4.39   5.05        10-yr. T-infl.   3.76   3.74   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.79   4.74   5.55        30-yr. T-bond   5.24   5.18   5.86        Telephone bd.   6.91   6.87   7.28        Municipal bds.   5.13   5.11   5.19          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Translating Your Skills
abstract: Michelle Cottle's Working column answers reader's inquiry about moving from teaching to corporate world (M)

headline: Time and Reader's Digest Said to Discuss Link
abstract: Reader's Digest Association and Time Warner Inc are in talks to combine Reader's Digest with number of Time Inc titles and direct marketing businesses; Time Inc chief executive Don Logan has held talks with Reader's Digest's new chief executive Thomas O Ryder, but deal is not expected to be announced soon, if at all; if agreement is reached, Time Warner would become partner of two foundations that together control 72 percent of Reader's Digest voting shares (M)

headline: A Ruling Favors Bottler of Coke
abstract: Federal judge denies request by B K Miller, a Maryland soft-drink distributor, for sanctions against Coca-Cola Enterprises in connection with documents the bottler filed in a lawsuit; Miller contends documents were fabricated, but jury will now decide that (S)

headline: Web Guide to Truly Bad Movies
abstract: Web site www.stomptokyo.com provides reviews of B movies shown on cable television or available in video stores as well as links to other sites exploring bad movies; photo (M)

headline: Hitachi Offers Bigger Notepad For the Screen-Tapping Crowd
abstract: Hitachi introduces HPW-600ET Handheld PC, which is is 6 inches long and nearly 9 inches wide, but surface area is taken up almost entirely by touch-sensitive screen; cost is $1,199; photo (S)

headline: A Joust With Inflation, Recession and Mountainous Foreign Debt
abstract: Brazil's struggle to get back on track after being hurt by global economic shocks is likely to slow economic output further in early 1999; what happens in Brazil will in some measure affect every economy in hemisphere as it succeeds or fails; photo (M)

headline: Share Prices Rebound, With Dow Climbing 103.16
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 103.16 points, or 1.12 percent, to 9,298.63; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 13.25 points, or 1.08 percent, to 1,237.28, while Nasdaq market rises 11.64 points, or five-tenths of a percent, to 2,260.55; graph; chart (M)s

headline: Virtual Jobs, Actual Layoffs
abstract: It's no secret that even in a robust economy, downsizing has become a permanent fixture. But in a study of layoffs over the last six years, Challenger, Gray & Christmas, the outplacement firm in Chicago, has found that the computer industry, considered a prime source of job growth, is also a leader in job loss.    The firm said that from 1993 through 1998, companies in more than 30 industries announced a combined 3.1 million layoffs; seven industries accounted for more than half the total. The computer industry ranked third in downsizing, outpointed only by aerospace and retailing.

headline: New Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: Black Anger at British Police Abuse Boils Over
abstract: Treatment of black and Asian minorities by police comes to forefront of Britain's consciousness as increasing number of people make public complaints; public has been galvanized by case of Carl Josephs, who successfully sued West Midlands police for racial harassment and exacerbated anger stemming from 1993 murder of 18-year-old black student, Stephen Lawrence in South London, for which group of white youths were never charged; Home Secretary Jack Straw says he will require police to hire more officers from minority groups, and Govt is poised to issue stinging report about race and police that is likely to result in sea change in British police culture; map; photo (M)

headline: Cadbury's Earnings Climb By 6% Despite Slower Sales
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes PLC reports 6 percent gain in 1998 earnings despite slower sales; company faces questions from analysts and shareholders about its plans and Wall Street seems unimpressed; earnings in 1998 rose to $980.3 million, and sales fell to $6.6 billion (M)

headline: DOW FINISHES DAY OVER 10,000 MARK FOR THE FIRST TIME
abstract: Stock prices rise sharply, with Dow Jones Industrial Average closing above 10,000-point level for first time; average gained 184.54 points, or 1.9 percent, to close at 10,006.78; has doubled since November 1995, and is up nearly 10-fold since 1982; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 27.37 points, or 2.1 percent, to 1,310.17; Nasdaq composite index jumps 73.67 points, or 3 percent, to 2,492.84; chronology of Dow's rise since 1907; graphs (L)

headline: RHODIA MAY JOIN BIDDING FOR ALBRIGHT & WILSON
abstract: Rhodia SA says it make make takeover bid for Albright & Wilson PLC, which on March 8 agreed to be acquired by Albemarle Corp (S)

headline: Hekou Journal; Hidden China, a Swarm of Pimps and Pickpockets
abstract: Article on Hekou, seedy Chinese town along border with Vietnam where iron-fisted Chinese control is nowhere to be seen and lawlessness abounds; pimps and pickpockets proliferate, gambling is done in open and heroin is readily available; map; photo (M)

headline: Russian Panel to Review Prosecutor's Scandal
abstract: As focus of Russia's latest political scandal shifts from corruption to sex, President Boris N Yeltsin appoints commission to investigate making and distribution of a videotape that shows embattled Prosecutor Gen, Yuri I Skuratov, in bed naked with two young women; Yeltsin, who is discharged from hospital after three weeks, holds meeting with Skuratov, who has mounted a challenge to Yeltsin by refusing to keep a promise to resign (M)

headline: A New State for Inuit: Frigid but Optimistic
abstract: Canada's Inuit Indians prepare to govern themselves in eastern 60 percent of what is now Northwest Territories, in new territory to be known as Nunavut; Iqaluit, frontier city, will become North America's newest capital on April 1; it has air of boom town, with three banks, two tanning salons and Chinese restaurant; construction crews work 10-hour days to finish commercial buildings, apartments and new Nunavut legislative building; Nunavut is 770,000 square miles of snow and ice, but just 25,000 residents; it is result of largest land-claim settlement in Canadian history; Inuit of Nunavut will be first indigenous people in Americas to govern themselves completely; Simon Awa, executive director of Nunavut Implementation Commission, says Inuit respect Canadian Constitution and Parliamentary system and will marry them with Inuit traditional knowledge and way of dealing with issues; photos; map (M)

headline: German Companies Adopt Fund For Slave Laborers Under Nazis
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder of Germany announces establishment of fund, projected to amount to $1.7 billion and financed by 12 German companies, to compensate Holocaust victims and end 'campaign being led against German industry and our country'; announcement seems aimed at halting wave of lawsuits in American courts against German companies that used slave labor and forced labor during World War II, but wording seems unlikely to calm controversy; appears comparable to response of Swiss officials who saw darkly orchestrated anti-Swiss movement in legal actions by Holocaust survivors against Swiss banks that ultimately led to $1.25 billion settlement; mingles firmness with remorse, reflecting ambivalent mood of Germany anxious to put past behind it, irritated by what some intellectuals see as polarization of Holocaust yet still conscious of its inescapable historical responsibilities; photo (M)

headline: Compaq Is Expected to Spin Off Part of Alta Vista
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp is expected to announce plans to sell or spin off part of its Alta Vista Web site in public offering; is thought to be looking to capitalize on rich valuations given to Internet-related companies selling shares in recent weeks (M)

headline: TECHNOLOGY; Decision Is Expected Today On Anti-Pornography Law
abstract: Judge Lowell A Reed Jr is expected to decide on Feb 1 whether to issue preliminary injunction blocking new Federal law meant to shield children from commercial pornography on World Wide Web; critics of law say it could force variety of Web site operators to choose between censorship and prison; backers say law is necessary to prevent commercial sites from making graphic sexual images available to all visitors, including children; Pres Clinton signed law in October; Judge Reed's restraining order will expire on Feb 2; plaintiff witnesses say they fear law is worded so broadly that it would sweep away more than pornography; Justice Dept, defending law, illustrates how readily available graphic pornography is on Internet; photo (M)

headline: Sales of High-End Chips Help Intel Beat Estimates
abstract: Intel Corp reports earnings of $2.1 billion in fourth quarter, up 18 percent from $1.7 billion fro year-earlier period; revenues rose 17 percent, to $7.6 billion, from $6.5 billion in fourth quarter of 1997 (M)

headline: Nash Finch Cutbacks
abstract: Nash Finch Co to close its distribution center in Appleton, Wis, in early March, eliminating 165 jobs (S)

headline: Private Sector; A 'Hound Dog' Hunts on Wall St.
abstract: Mel Farr, former Detroit Lions running back who has built nation's largest chain of black-owned auto dealerships, is trying to raise $45 million in private capital to take business into some of most blighted areas; Michigan-based company sells mostly to 'financially challenged' blacks with little or no credit; interview; photo (M)

headline: A Site for Venting
abstract: Daniel S Levine develops Web site (www.disgruntled.com) that combines news, feature, satire and commentary about darker side of world of work; invites users to visit pages to vent and tell their tales of horror, frustration, liberation and revenge; Levine photo (M)

headline: A Food Fight: Nabisco Is Seen As Hot Target
abstract: Several analysts expect breakup of RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp to make Nabisco food unit hot merger target; see Philip Morris Cos and Pepsico as possible bidders (M)

headline: MANAGEMENT TO ACQUIRE INTEGRATED CIRCUIT SYSTEMS
abstract: Integrated Circuit Systems Inc agrees to be acquired in management buyout valued at $257 million; investor group includes senior management, Bain Capital Inc and Bear, Stearns & Co; Integrated Circuit also agrees to sell its intellectual property and engineering hardware and software to 3Com Corp for $16 million in cash (S)

headline: CENTRAL PARKING SELLING 74 LOTS TO ADVANCE A PURCHASE
abstract: Central Parking Corp, nation's largest operator of parking lots, to sell 74 lots in 18 cities to settle a Justice Department suit challenging its proposed $585 million purchase of Allright Holdings Inc (S)

headline: In Court, Ousted Malaysian Talks of Political Intrigue
abstract: Interview with Anwar Ibrahim, former Deputy Prime Min of Malaysia, who was ousted five months ago and jailed on corruption and sex-related charges; depicts himself as victim of political conspiracy sanctioned by former mentor, Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Faces Teacher Crisis : Teacher Crisis Looms in U.S.
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Amid rising enrollments and a surge in teacher retirements, the United States is heading into a decade of teacher shortages that could severely test the mettle and ingenuity of the nation's schools, educators say. Shortages are so bad in parts of the United States, and particularly in some subject areas, that recruiters are acting almost like sports agents, offering bonuses and entering into low-key bidding wars.

headline: 2 Big Boston Banks In $16 Billion Union
abstract: Fleet Financial Group plans to acquire BankBoston for $16 billion in a stock deal that will create the eighth-largest bank in the country and the pre-eminent bank in New England.

headline: Youth Move at Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp is considering new brand name for its sporty cars and trucks for Japanese market, hoping to attract young car buyers (S)

headline: Where The Boys Are; Networks' Huge Bet On Football Provides Must-See TV for Men
abstract: Television networks' qualms about paying huge sums for right to broadcast National Football League games give way to growing conviction that football may soon be among their few sure sources of big audiences, especially male audiences, the most precious commodity for advertisers; ABC, CBS and Fox, which committed total of $12.8 billion in Jan 1998 to cover NFL games through 2005, have shown some growth in one category or another of male viewers for their regular prime-time shows this season, while NBC, which walked away from bidding, has lost fully a quarter of the male viewers who watched its shows last season; photos; drawing; table; graph (L)

headline: Stringing Holes Together, 5,599,663 of Them
abstract: Architects at Polshek Partnership designed sphere with millions of perforations for Rose Center at American Museum of Natural History; drawings were sent electronically to fabricator, and at factory, files were converted to program based on Autocad software; drawing (S)

headline: Media Talk; At Knight Ridder, The Chief Belies Tightfisted Image
abstract: Knight-Ridder, whose chief executive, P Anthony Ridder, is known for his relentless cost-cutting, spent huge amount of money moving its headquarters to San Jose, Calif, from Miami; company's proxy statement shows moving expenses were paid for 40 of 150 headquarters staff, that 40 also got bonuses to compensate for higher-priced housing in San Jose, and that Ridder himself got 'relocation bonus' as well as other payments for the move; photo (S)

headline: MOVIE GUIDE : La Nina de Tus Ojos
abstract: Directed by Fernando Trueba. Spain.

headline: Pakistan Denies Role in Plotting Bombings in India
abstract: Ashraf Qazi, Pakistani envoy in New Delhi, denies that Bangladeshi arrested and accused of plotting to bomb American consulates in Madras and Calcutta is Pakistani intelligence agent, as police charge; notes that US and Pakistan have good relationship; US counterrorism team will interview suspect, Sayed Abu Nasir (S)

headline: January Offered No Signs Of Slowdown in Economy
abstract: National Association of Realtors says resales of single-family homes rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, to annual record rate of 5.07 million, after rising 3.1 percent in December; last year's sales totaled 4.8 million; Commerce Department reports factory orders for durable goods rose 3.9 percent in January; level of orders, $203.425 billion, was highest on record; orders rose revised 3.4 percent in December; Labor Department says number of workers applying for state unemployment benefits fell by 5,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 293,000, after increasing 14,000, to 298,000, the week before; Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp says average rate on 30-year fixed mortgage rose 7 basis points, to 6.89 percent, this week; graph on durable goods orders (M)

headline: What's in a Fund Name? In Japan, a Dead Italian
abstract: A number of new Japanese mutual funds are named after Italian classical and Renaissance icons like Galileo, Marco Polo and Leonardo da Vinci (S)

headline: Prices Paid To Producers Up Sharply
abstract: Labor Department reports producer prices rose half a percent in January, largest increase in more than two years; core rate of producer prices, which excludes food and energy costs, dropped one-tenth of 1 percent, first decrease in that measure in seven months; department reports number of first-time claims filed for state unemployment benefits rose 4,000 last week, to seasonally adjusted 288,000; graph on producer prices (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Jones and S.& P. 500 Establish Record Highs  The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set new highs as oil prices soared, but concerns about technology-company earnings crimped gains in the Nasdaq composite index.

headline: ALBRIGHT DEBATES RIGHTS AND TRADE WITH THE CHINESE
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright moves to infuse troubled US-China relationship with new sense of direction during talks in Beijing; speaks sternly today to Chinese authorities about human rights while encouraging them to move forward and join World Trade Organization, in which membership is viewed by China as matter of national prestige; expresses US displeasure over crackdown against opposition groups to Pres Jiang Zemin and other senior officials; calls for release number of political prisoners; makes clear, despite criticism, that Clinton Administration is sticking to approach of separating human rights from trade issues; comments are latest in series of signals being sent by Washington in effort to prompt China to make serious efforts to open markets--thorny issue that faces huge obstacles; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Drug issues go from champs to chumps in a few short weeks.
