abstract: Drug stocks are down after soaring for most of 1998, and slide is expected to continue despite strong industry earnings; investors appear to be taking profits from drug holdings and moving them into less expensive sectors, and they appear to be leery about the industry's blockbuster drugs, which can hurt a stock at the slightest mention of bad news; instantaneous fortunes made in Internet stocks also seems to have dimmed the luster of long-term, consistent growth offered by drug stocks; graph (M)

headline: Microsoft and the Question of Monopoly
abstract: Richard L Schmalensee testifies as an expert witness for Microsoft Corp at its antitrust trial, and he is interrupted by a series of questions from Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson that suggest that Microsoft will have a difficult time proving to him that it does not have a monopoly in the market for personal computer operating systems; whether it does or not is not directly at issue in the trial, but Government's case would collapse if Microsoft can convince the court that it is not a monopoly (M)

headline: Private Sector; A Journalist's Juicy Reward
abstract: TheStreet.Com hedge fund manager, columnist and part owner James J Cramer declines to comment on publication in initial public offering prospectus of his annual salary, which currently stands at $250,000; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Admits Missile Misfire May Have Hit Iraq Civilians
abstract: American jets attack several air-defense sites in northern and southern Iraq; Pentagon says at least one missile misfired, and might have killed several civilians; Iraq claims 11 civilians dead and 59 wounded; photo; map; Gen Anthony C Zinni says jets attacked after four MIG fighters flew into southern no-flight zone to try to lure Americans into range of surface-to-air missiles; regrets civilian casualties, but blames Saddam Hussein for initiating exchanges (S)

headline: Roche Cleared For H.I.V. Test
abstract: Roche Holding AG wins US Food and Drug Administration clearance to sell new, more sensitive version of its Amplicor test, designed to measure amount of HIV in patient's blood (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST    ISRAEL: NETANYAHU ON PULLOUT  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said he would consider ''the possibility of a unilateral withdrawal'' from Lebanon if ''accompanied by necessary security measures.'' He rejected a suggestion by Foreign Minister Ariel Sharon that May elections be postponed in order to form a unity government dedicated to a pullout. Both men's remarks followed a campaign promise by the Labor Party candidate, Ehud Barak, to withdraw troops within a year if elected Prime Minister.   Deborah Sontag (NYT)

headline: EQUITABLE'S EARNINGS ROSE SLIGHTLY IN FOURTH QUARTER
abstract: The Equitable Companies Inc. earned after-tax fourth-quarter earnings of 74 cents a diluted share, compared with 73 cents a year earlier, a slight rise that came in part from growth in the company's insurance and asset management segments. The after-tax contribution of Equitable's insurance operations totaled $102.9 million, or 61.5 percent of the total quarterly earnings of $167.2 million. Earnings at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Equitable's investment banking arm, sank 32 percent from a year earlier. Equitable is based in New York.

headline: Netanyahu's Likud Mentor Says He'll Challenge Protege
abstract: Moshe Arens, Israel's former Defense and Foreign Minister and political godfather of Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, says he will challenge Netanyahu for leadership of Likud party in primaries, which will select Likud candidates for national elections on May 17; says party is in crisis, citing defections of some top-rank members; photo (M)

headline: Monterrey Journal; Beisbol, Si! But Can U.S. Players Drink the Water?
abstract: Major League baseball's first season opener to be played outside US or Canada is scheduled for Monterrey, Mexico, on April 4; game, between San Diego Padres and Colorado Rockies, has aroused great excitement in Monterrey, and Mexican fans hope it means that major leagues will one day have expansion team in Monterrey, Mexico's baseball capital; major league executives say only that game is part of their campaign to globalize baseball; map; photos (M)

headline: Evan Thomas 2d Dies at 78; Published Many Best Sellers
abstract: Evan Welling Thomas 2d, book editor who published dozens of books, including John F Kennedy's Profiles in Courage, dies at age of 78 (M)

headline: Hilfiger and Nintendo Get Marketing Honors
abstract: Promotion Marketing Association honors Wescott Marketing for promotion marketing campaign for Tommy Hilfiger Inc and Nintendo America, fete, New Orleans (S);

headline: U.N. Panel Seeks to Ease Suffering of Iraq's People
abstract: Panel of senior UN officials concludes that Iraq has gone from relative affluence to massive poverty since imposition of economic sanctions after Persian Gulf war in 1991 and recommends several steps to alleviate suffering of its people; does not recommend lifting of sanctions, but suggests easing them with specific modifications, which US says it might oppose (M)

headline: NEW CENTURY AND NORTHERN STATES PLAN MERGER
abstract: New Century Energies Inc and Northern States Power Co agree to $4.9 billion merger, creating company that would sell electricity and natural gas to 4.5 million customers in 12 states; New Century shareholders will own 54 percent of company; merger is expected to save company $1.1 billion in first 10 years (S)

headline: MORGAN STANLEY TO PURCHASE SPANISH BROKERAGE FIRM
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company, the third-largest United States brokerage firm, said it would buy Asesores Bursatiles, Spain's biggest independent broker, giving it $4.34 billion in managed funds in one of Europe's fastest-growing asset management markets. The purchase gives Morgan Stanley, based in New York, an entry into individual investor services in Europe, and the Spanish company's 420-branch private banking network could also help increase Morgan Stanley's share of securities underwriting for Spanish corporations. Financial terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Shares of Morgan Stanley fell $2.8125, to $85.75.

headline: Loud Knocks In the Night, And Orders To Get Out
abstract: About 50 Western journalists flee after Serbian Government orders all members of news media from NATO countries to leave; some take refuge in Skopje, Macedonia; some journalists and crews are roughed up; while atmosphere in Pristina, capital of Kosovo province, is reportedly more tense than elsewhere in country, other journalists also face harassment; two American reporters are held in Belgrade police station for 11 hours (M)

headline: Istanbul Journal; You Want a Black Olive Bagel? Come to Turkey
abstract: Tribeca, first bagel cafe in Istanbul, Turkey, is among many signs of growing American influence in country where citizens seem to crave everything American; serves American-style bagels, coffee and pastry, and 80 percent of its patrons are Turks; proprietors Rafi Karako and Hikmet Ongan comment; photo (M)

headline: Sales of Credit Card Accounts Are Hurting Many Consumers
abstract: Millions of Americans are facing little choice but to accept terms offered by credit card issuers as industry rapidly consolidates into fewer and larger hands; new owners of credit card business are free to impose whatever interest rate traffic will bear, subject only to handful of remaining state usury ceilings; can impose new rates on existing balances, shorten time for making payments without interest charges, eliminate grace periods for payments received few days late and raise penalties for late payments; about 32 million accounts were sold in 1998, or more than four times as many in 1996, with sales involving estimated 20 million consumers; big buyers have included Chase Manhattan, Bank of New York, Citibank, Fleet Financial, Banc One and other little-known companies; chart (M)

headline: U.S. Lawyer Questions Message in Microsoft Videotape
abstract: David Boies, Government's lead lawyer in trial of antitrust suit against Microsoft, questions another videotape demonstration, but this time challenge deals not with reliability or honesty of Microsoft's tape but with its message; at issue is new tape showing that Microsoft is allowing computer manufacturers to customize Windows desktop, computer screen that users see when turning on computer; with customizations, first screen shows manufacturers' promotions and advertisements ahead of Microsoft's; Boies shows that such customizations are in clear violation of Windows licensing agreements companies must sign; says Microsoft gave special permission for customization only weeks before Government filed suit against Microsoft, and that Microsoft could rescind permission if suit goes away (M)

headline: ADELPHIA IN DEAL FOR CABLE STAKE AND SHARES
abstract: Adelphia Communications Corp will pay $257.2 million in cash to FPL Group Inc for Adelphia shares held by FPL and FPL's one-third interest in Olympus Communications LP, partnership formed in 1995 to provide cable service in Florida (S)

headline: Amazon Surge May Reflect The New Math Of the Internet
abstract: Amazon.com, Internet bookseller which has yet to report profitable quarter since going public in May 1997, saw its share price soar by nearly 50 percent in first trading week of new year; stock price has climbed about 150 percent since beginning of December; Amazon.com now has market value of $25.4 billion; some analysts say unrestrained enthusiasm despite company's lack of profit may reflect investors' appreciation for Amazon.com's sales momentum and value of its dominant position as leading electronic bookseller; it comes as many investors seem to find shares of variety of Internet companies irresistible; some Internet bears see more greed than logic in meteoric rise of Amazon.com (M)

headline: Average Malaysians Ask:'What Crisis?'
abstract: ALOR GAJAH, Malaysiaâ€”  It has been 18 months since Haris Aziz and his family began hearing the words "economic crisis" and by now one might have expected them to be feeling the pinch.

headline: Pace to Acquire Green Advertising
abstract: Pace Communications Group is buying Green Advertising; Green will operate as Green Advertising division of Pace (S)

headline: Baiting the Hooks; How Internet Merchants Keep Customers Coming Back
abstract: Tina Kelley article discusses methods used by Web site designers to lure people in and transform them from surfers to loyal customers; says most obvious and perhaps most subtle technique is to give visitors feeling they are part of a community by offering advice, chat rooms and E-mail responses (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Behind Offer for Mirror Are Some Deep Pockets
abstract: George Soros and Deutsche Morgan Grenfell are reportedly behind Regional Independent Media PLC's bid to buy Mirror Group PLC; Mirror rejects $1.5 billion offer but says it plans to hold talks with the company (S)

headline: Year 2000 Status Report by Visa
abstract: Visa International Inc says that 99.4 percent of credit card terminals worldwide have been updated to accept cards with expiration dates beyond Dec 31; Visa spokeswoman Linda Elliot says Year 2000 may bring other problems for credit card users that are beyond card association's control (S)

headline: Olivetti Raises Hostile Bid For Big Rival
abstract: Olivetti SpA raises its hostile bid for Telecom Italia SpA by 15 percent, to 60.4 billion euros, or about $64.7 billion; sweetened bid comes same day that European Union's top antitrust regulator, Karel van Miert, expresses concern about measures Telecom Italia has proposed aimed at thwarting Olivetti's takeover attempt (M)

headline: Barclays Is Selling Unit
abstract: British bank Barclays PLC will sell Merck Finck & Co, private German bank, to Kredietbank SA Luxembourgeosie for 500 million marks ($278 million) (S)

headline: Patriot American Agrees To Investor Bailout Plan
abstract: Patriot American Hospitality Inc says it agreed to financial bailout plan led by investors Leon Black and Thomas H Lee, that its chairman-chief executive Paul Nussbaum has resigned and that it will convert from real estate investment trust into traditional corporation; group, which includes Black's Apollo Real Estate Advisors, Thomas H Lee Co, Beacon Capital Partners Inc and Rosen Consulting Group, will invest as much as $1 billion in Patriot and arrange $2.45 billion in loans to replace most of $3 billion in Patriot debt and obligations that would be due by end of 1999; company will also change its name to Wyndham International Inc, reflecting name of its main hotel chain, luxury Wyndham hotels; Nussbaum will be succeeded by James D Carreker, who oversees Patriot's hotel operations and developed its Wyndham chain (M)

headline: At Disney, The Video That Roared
abstract: Daniel Akst column questions Walt Disney Co's decision to recall millions of home video copies of The Rescuers, a 1977 animated film, into which a couple of frames of naked breasts had been inserted; notes that the offending frames cannot be detected in the normal playing of the film; says the millions of dollars that Disney is spending solely to protect its image could have paid for mammograms for the poor or some other worthwhile project; cartoon (M)

headline: The Year's Top Media Buys
abstract: Most Wanted 1998: The Annual Numbers     Seemingly absent from the 1998 box office list, which includes films that opened in 1998, is the all-time box office champion, ''Titanic.'' The Paramount release, which has earned $600 million since it opened on Dec. 19, 1997, captured the top spot for its album soundtrack and for video sales in 1998.      At the box office last year, the majority of the releases were aimed at children of all ages, with a multitude of explosions, goofy jokes, demolished cities and hurtling asteroids to go with the popcorn and soda. On 10 weekends, at least three $100 million films were playing in theaters.

headline: After the frenzy of Super Sunday, account activity takes center stage again.
abstract: In wake of Super Bowl Sunday, there have been developments affecting advertising accounts with billings estimated at more than $375 million involving various advertisers; specific advertising account activities discussed (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.75   4.88   5.40        3-month T-bills   4.38   4.35   5.02        6-month T-bills   4.41   4.38   5.03        10-yr. T-infl.   3.78   3.76   3.66        10-yr. T-note   4.94   4.87   5.61        30-yr. T-bond   5.35   5.29   5.92        Telephone bd.   7.01   6.89   7.17        Municipal bds.   5.15   5.14   5.20          Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Bridge  Information Systems Markets; The Bond Buyer

headline: Lucent to Buy Kenan for $1.45 Billion, but Is Quiet on Possible Acquisition of Ascend
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc will acquire Kenan Systems Corp for about $1.45 billion, but declines to talk about possible acquisition of Ascend Communications Inc; Kenan Sahin will become vice president at Lucent's Bell Labs research center and continue to run billing software business from Kenan's headquarters in Cambrdige, Mass (M)

headline: Riverside Bank to Be Sold
abstract: Associated Banc-Corp to buy Riverside Bank of Minneapolis for $89.1 million in stock (S)

headline: Quill vs. Computer
abstract: Letter from Josephine Colmenares comments on Mar 11 article on pens versus computers (S)

headline: MORE ON THE CONFLICT
abstract: POWERLESS MONITORS -- For the 1,400 members of the Kosovo Verification Mission evacuated to Macedonia, these are days of frustration and guilt over the fate of 1,500 local staff members left behind. Page A9.

headline: Computer Problems Disrupt the Nasdaq
abstract: Computer equipment failure disrupts trading on Nasdaq stock market for nearly 90 minutes, forcing market makers to their phones and leaving day traders frustrated (S)3

headline: It Beats Hanging Out at the Cooler
abstract: Playfair Inc founder Matt Weinstein signs up hundreds of companies to participate in fourth annual International Fun at Work Day on April 1; some events described (S)

headline: New Money, New Sign. But How to Type It?
abstract: Problem of keyboard symbol for new euro currency noted; new Windows keyboards sold in Europe will include symbol; photo (S)

headline: Tiffany Holder To Sell Stake
abstract: Tiffany & Co says its largest shareholder, Mitsukoshi Ltd, plans to sell its 12 percent stake in public offering; sale would raise about $243 million; Tiffany says sales at US stores open at least a year rose 12 percent for holiday period from Nov 1 through Dec 31 (S)

headline: COLUMBIA/HCA TO SELL HOSPITAL ASSETS TO NET $65 MILLION
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp will sell its half of joint operation of three hospitals in Cleveland and fourth in Canton, Ohio; Columbia/HCA operates hospitals with Sisters of Charity of St Augustine Health System through Caritas Healthcare Partnership and Canton Healthcare Partnership; its stake will be purchased by sisters and Cleveland-based University Hospitals Health System; company is also selling its portion of Ohio Health Choice; Columbia/HCA, which is under Federal investigation into its Medicare billing practices; will net about $65 million from transaction (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: PEERS' VOTING RIGHTS -- Prime Minister Tony Blair's Government submitted to Parliament legislation aimed at fulfilling his promise to eliminate the voting rights of 750 hereditary peers, members of the House of Lords who gained their seats by the circumstances of birth. Some 500 life peers would remain in a transitional assembly while a proposed Royal Commission produced recommendations due Dec. 31 for longer-term reform of the chamber.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil prices rise 2.8 percent after important Royal Dutch/Shell terminal in Nigeria is closed by protesters demanding greater share in revenue; crude oil for February delivery rises 37 cents, to $13.44 a barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Ericsson and Qualcomm Settle Dispute
abstract: Ericsson AB, world's third-largest mobile telephone maker, and Qualcomm Inc, American rival, agree to share access to each other's technology in market that is expected to add 700 million cellular phone users over next five years; this ends two-year patent dispute; Ericsson will buy Qualcomm unit that makes cellular equipment based on code division multiple access technology, which will be basis for future broadband technology that lets users get real-time news and hold video conferences on the go; Qualcomm will receive royalties and access to some of Ericsson's patents on phone technology; photo (M)

headline: Behind the Tour de France, and Beyond
abstract: Ian Austen article on evaluates The Tour Saga, tracing history of Tourde France, available on CD-ROM from World Media Live (S)

headline: Those Vanishing References
abstract: David J Flores letter on Feb 21 article questions practicality of training managers to provide truthful job references1

headline: Shake-Up at BMW May Prompt Renewed Interest Among Suitors
abstract: Recent removal of two top executives at BMW AG will prompt renewed interest by other auto makers in buying German maker of sporty coupes and sedans; it remains unclear whether controlling Quandt family wants to sell (M)

headline: French Are Gearing Up to Join In Dousing the Flames of Kosovo
abstract: France, while eager to avoid getting dragged into fighting in Kosovo, has lined up behind threat of American-led NATO bombing to force Serbia to withdraw military and police units from province and negotiate with rebels; will send aircraft carrier to Adriatic Sea in preparation for strike and will have 40 fighter planes in Italy ready to fly NATO missions; French officials doubt bombing alone would force Pres Slobodan Milosevic to restore Kosovo's autonomy; opposes rebel goal of full independence (M)

headline: Lycos Deal Meets the New Internet Math
abstract: Events yesterday provided further proof that Internet investors prefer fantasy to reality.    That proof came when Lycos Inc., the Internet portal service, said it would merge with the electronic shopping units of USA Networks Inc., including the Home Shopping Network, Ticketmaster and the partly independent Ticketmaster Online-Citysearch.

headline: America Online Fills Job
abstract: America Online Inc says Marc Andreessen, co-founder of Netscape Communications Corp, will become America Online's chief technology officer upon close of its acquisition of Netscape (S)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : The Grass Is Never Greener
abstract: Americans spend at least as much on lawn care â€” an estimated total of $30 billion a year â€” as they do on books. Lawns occupy more land than any other crop, including wheat and corn.

headline: Mitsubishi Seeking Links To Foreign Car Makers
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp is seeking alliances with foreign car companies that could lead to sale of a stake in company (S)

headline: U.S. Official Says Politics Didn't Halt Mexico Case
abstract: Customs official John E Hensley, in letter to Congressional subcommittee head John L Mica, says that major inquiry into money laundering by Mexican banks was stopped only after undercover agents had been unable to proceed in talks with corrupt bankers to move over $1 billion that was said to belong to Mexican Defense Min Enrique Cervantes and other officials; Hensley and Customs Comr Raymond W Kelly deny that operation was closed for political reasons (M)

headline: A Giant's Generosity
abstract: Marc Beauchamp letter on Jan 21 article hails as corporate philanthropy Microsoft Corp's decision to publish Encarta Africana (S)

headline: Gateway Plans to Offer Free Net Service
abstract: Gateway 2000 Inc begins offering customers one year of free Internet service when they buy machines costing more than $1,000; buyers will get 150 free hours of Internet use a month through gateway.net, company's one-line service; each hour beyond that will cost $1.50; Gateway also says it is buying 20 percent stake in NECX, closely held on-line seller of computers and other electronic products, for about $21 million; companies plan to start Internet site called Spotshop.com to sell Gateway products (S)3

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: GULF WAR ILLNESSES -- A study of more than 8,000 British troops who served in the Persian Gulf war has found that they are more than twice as likely to suffer ill-health as troops who stayed home or served in Bosnia. The study, published in the medical journal The Lancet, says the veterans complained of chronic fatigue, hair loss, rashes, memory loss and nervous-system disorders.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: POLITICAL TARGET DATE -- Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders of the Northern Ireland Assembly set Feb. 15 as the target for agreement on new governmental bodies that would give Catholics more political power in the Protestant-dominated province of Ulster. But in approving an agenda, First Minister David Trimble, a Protestant, and his Catholic deputy, Seamus Mallon, avoided the issue blocking the peace effort: disarmament of the I.R.A.   James F. Clarity (NYT)

headline: U.S. READY TO EASE SOME RESTRICTIONS IN POLICY ON CUBA
abstract: Senior American officials say US is ready to let more people and more money flow to Cuba, but they reject fundamental review of US policy toward Cuba; moves will let Cuban citizens receive millions more dollars from American friends and family members, allow them to buy more American food and medicine, permit more direct flights between two countries, renew direct mail service from US and let Baltimore Orioles and Cuban national baseball team play ball in March; Sec of State Madeleine K Albright formally recommends steps to Pres Clinton, and White House is expected to announce them on Jan 5; Administration officials say forthcoming report from Council on Foreign Relations helped to shape their new proposals (M)

headline: Expanded Roles For Two Agencies
abstract: Clairol division of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co reassigns Nice 'n Easy hair color brand to Kaplan Thaler Group from Intuition Group, unit of WPP Group PLC; Bacardi-Martini USA, unit of Bacardi Ltd, awards Amster Yard creative and strategic portions of its accounts for Bombay Original gin and Bombay Sapphire gin, which had been at Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners; billings estimated at $10 million (S)

headline: Too Much Ado About Giving References
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin article says employers may be overly concerned that giving a detailed reference for a present or former employee will expose them to a lawsuit from the employee; a study of Federal and state court records nationwide from 1965 to 1970 and 1985 to 1990 has turned up only 16 defamation cases arising from references checks, and plaintiffs prevailed in only 4 of those; a reference might even risk a lawsuit by the new employer by withholding certain information about the applicant; cartoon (M)

headline: DataBank: December 28-31; The Nasdaq, the Bull's New Corral
abstract: Comment on stock index showings at end of 1998; graphs

headline: Royal Ahold to Sell Securities in U.S.
abstract: Royal Ahold NV and its affiliate file with Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as much as $2.09 billion of securities (S)

headline: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES TO CUT PRODUCTION AT PAPER MILL
abstract: Willamette Industries to cut production at paper mill in Kingsport, Tenn, and dismiss 150 workers at the site (S)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Film Confronts a History Few Turks Can Agree On
abstract: Turkish filmmaker Reis Celik has produced film about three college dropouts who tried to set off Marxist revolution in Turkey, but who were captured and hanged in 1972; film, Goodbye Tomorrow, focuses on most prominent of three, Deniz Gezmis; since film's release, debates over Gezmis, leftist movement and death penalty have come to surface in Istanbul; photos (M)

headline: Nuclear Lapses Known in '96, Aides Now Say
abstract: Senior Clinton Administration aide ordered late in 1996 that security measures at nation's nuclear weapons laboratories be quickly strengthened, months earlier than previously acknowledged, but orders were largely ignored or delayed; Deputy Energy Sec Charles B Curtis ordered that series of security measures be carried out on strict timetable, but measures were not taken despite warning in department's annual security review for year that department was at greater risk of becoming victim of espionage than at any time in its history; officials say lapses occurred mostly during transitional period, during which Federico Pena became Energy Sec in 1997 and Curtis left office month later (M)

headline: CENDANT SETTLES LAWSUIT BY INVESTORS FOR $350 MILLION
abstract: The Cendant Corporation, a franchiser and direct marketer, agreed yesterday to settle a class-action lawsuit by investors for $350 million. Cendant, based in Parsippany, N.J., agreed to raise by $350 million the market value of securities it issued last year to help finance a bid to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc. Plaintiffs contended that the company's executives had misled investors by failing to disclose accounting fraud in April that resulted in a drop in Cendant's share price. The accounting troubles also caused the $3.1 billion purchase of American Bankers Insurance to fall through. Cendant stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $19.9375.

headline: E-Mail and a Closer Family
abstract: Letter from Sister Mary Elizabeth comments on Jan 14 article on E-mail addresses (S)

headline: Japan Says Its Economy Shrank For Record 5th Straight Quarter
abstract: Japanese Government reports economy shrank in fourth quarter at annual rate of 3.2 percent, extending economic contraction to record five straight quarters; for 1998 as a whole, economy contracted by 2.8 percent, first annual decline in a quarter-century (M)

headline: Fed Report and Housing Data Are Strong
abstract: Federal Reserve's latest reading on nation's economy suggests current expansion, already at peacetime record, will persevere in 1999 while inflation remains at bay; Fed's regional outlook, known as beige book, is based on reports from Fed's 12 district banks; Fed says many retailers resorted to more drastic discounting than usual during holidays and that labor shortages persist in most parts of country, with some regions reporting heightened wage pressures; Commerce Department says housing starts rose in December as builders enjoyed busiest year for new-home construction in more than a decade; starts rose 3.5 percent to seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.720 million houses; 1.616 million homes were started in 1998, most since 1.121 million in 1987; graph (M)

headline: DEUTSCHE BANK SEES NO ROADBLOCKS TO BANKERS TRUST
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG chief executive Rolf Breuer says he is confident that his bank's acquisition of Bankers Trust Corp will be completed as planned this year (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of The Right Thing column Feb 21, about risks of being sued over job reference

headline: Swiss Truth-Teller, or Lying Traitor?
abstract: Group of Swiss citizens files charges of treason against Jean Ziegler, professor at University of Geneva and author of book The Swiss, the Gold and the Dead, which charged that Switzerland helped finance Third Reich and prolonged World War II by purchasing Nazi gold, withholding funds in Jewish bank accounts and turning away tens of thousands of Jewish refugees; photo (M)

headline: MCI Won't Make Bid for Airtouch
abstract: MCI Worldcom Inc says it will not make bid for Airtouch Communications Inc (S)

headline: Mobile Phone Group to Sell British Venture
abstract: Cable and Wireless PLC and Mediaone Group seek buyer for One 2 One Ltd, British mobile-phone venture; weigh other options (M)

headline: Yeltsin Wants To Stay Out Of Warfare In Yugoslavia
abstract: Pres Boris N Yeltsin, in speech to Russia's Parliament on state of nation, says country 'will not allow itself to be drawn into military conflict' in Yugoslavia and condemns NATO air strikes; calls on Cabinet, which he credits with having stopped economic downturn, to move ahead with economic program; blames Parliament's Communist-led lower house for Russia's financial collapse last summer; says it sent 'bad signal to investors' in rejecting Government's fiscal program; photo (M)

headline: Patents; Two men have developed a magnetic videotape that records both analog and digital signals.
abstract: Patent is granted to Christopher Strolle and Jung Wan Ko for magnetic tape that can record both analog and digital signals; John Cort Severns receives patent for compound that can be added to conventional clothing dryer to make clothes resistant to sun fading (M)

headline: BROWN & SHARPE TO CLOSE PLANTS IN BRITAIN, REPORT LOSS
abstract: Brown & Sharpe Manufacturing Co will take pretax first-quarter charge of about $20 million to close three British plants and dismiss 230 workers, mostly in Britain, to cut costs; also plans to restructure some custom-measurement businesses (S)

headline: State Dept. Has Final Say On Exports Of Satellites
abstract: State Department tells Congress that Commerce Department will have a voice, but not a vote, in approving export of American-made satellites; Congress last year shifted authority from Commerce to State over Pres Clinton's objections, and Republicans have warned him not to try to undermine law (S)

headline: Renault Executive Seen in Nissan Post
abstract: Renault SA, which seeks 35 stake in Nissan Motor Co, says Carlos Ghosn, its executive vice president noted for cost cutting, is most likely candidate to be Nissan Motor Co chief operating officer (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Trading on E*Trade's Success; Chief Has Aggressive Plans to Expand Internet Broker
abstract: Market Place column examines success of E*Trade, on-line brokerage business that rivals some conventional firms, and outlines aggressive plans for future of its chief executive, Christos M Cotsakos; Cotsakos wants company to become digital financial media company that will offer financial transactions and other services over Internet, cable television and even wireless hand-held devices; notes that Cotsakos, by fighting on so many fronts, risks giving up ground that E*Trade already won in brokerage business, where competition is growing more intense; photos; charts (M)

headline: E*Trade Cut Option Price Just Before Stock Surged
abstract: E*Trade Group Inc., the No. 2 on-line broker, reduced the exercise price on employee stock options two weeks after its stock traded at a 21-month low and began a three-month surge that increased its price sixfold.    On Oct. 22, the company told employees they could trade in options carrying higher exercise prices for new ones at that day's closing price of $17, according to the company's annual report, filed this week with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Electronic Serial Numbers Raise Privacy Concerns  From computers to cellular phones to home electronics, everyday devices and software programs are increasingly embedding telltale identifying numbers that enable them to interact. That trend is generating a dispute pitting security interests and convenience against privacy concerns.    Privacy groups argue that the merger of computers and the Internet has brought the specter of a new surveillance society. But a growing alliance of computer industry executives, engineers, law enforcement officials and scholars contend that absolute anonymity is not only increasingly difficult to obtain technically but is also a potential threat to democratic order because of the possibility of electronic crime and terrorism. ''You already have zero privacy -- get over it,'' Scott McNealy, the chairman and chief executive of Sun Microsystems, said recently. [Page A1.]

headline: Old Enmities Puncture Baseball Detente in Cuba
abstract: Baltimore Orioles are set to play exhibition game in Havana against team of Cuban all-stars during particularly chilly period in cold war relationship between Cuba and United States; Cuba is target of international condemnation over its new curbs on growing internal dissent; photo (M)

headline: Feeling Cyberwheels Rumble on the Track
abstract: J C Herz column assesses new computer driving games from Microsoft and Electronic Arts, which have steering wheels that deliver tactile feedback; drawing (M)

headline: U.S. ISSUES APPEAL TO SERBS TO HALT ATTACK IN KOSOVO
abstract: Special US envoy Richard C Holbrooke, under orders not to let Serbia delay NATO action while Kosovo burns, meets with Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic in Belgrade in last-ditch effort to negotiate at least cease-fire; says little was achieved in more than three hours of talks with Milosevic; says heightened military activities in Kosovo make it extremely difficult to pursue peace; senior NATO official says Serbian forces have destroyed three of Kosovo Liberation Army's seven reigonal headquarters in past three days, adding to urgency of Holbrooke mission; Serb forces burn villages and drive civilians from homes in Kosovo, whose population is predominantly ethnic Albanians; Pres Clinton warns military action could be imminent if Milosevic continues to choose agression over peace; says 30,000 more Albanians have been displaced from homes in last few days; says Milosevic will not be allowed to continue aggression with impunity since America's security interests must include Europe's freedom and security; photo (M)

headline: A Price Not Paid in Money
abstract: A FEW years ago, my wife, Christine, and some colleagues had an emergency at work. One man suggested an outrageously expensive solution. My wife said that there must be a cheaper way. He shook his head, saying, ''Money is cheap; it's time that's expensive.''    Which means most of us are very poor. If anything is universal among the butchers, bakers and automobile makers, it is that they are all spending incredible amounts of time at work, which is leaving everyone with little for the things that really count.

headline: Renault Truck Unit Seeks Scania Alliance
abstract: RVI, Renault SA's truck unit, seeks alliance with Scania AB to create world's second-largest truck maker; says deal would probably stop short of full acquisition; deal would hamper Volvo AB plan to acquire Scania (M)

headline: Clinton to Declare He'll Send G.I.'s to Kosovo if Pact Is Set
abstract: Clinton Administration says Pres Clinton will announce he will send American troops to Kosovo as part of peacekeeping force to be formed if warring parties reach accord; Pentagon is reportedly satisifed with military section of proposed accord and wants to move quickly to prepare eventual deployment; commitment, sought by European allies, would strengthen State Sec Madeleine K Albright's hand at peace talks (M)

abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               Prime rate   7.75   7.75   8.50        Discount rate   4.50   4.50   5.00        Federal funds   4.88   4.79   5.75        3-month T-bills   4.36   4.36   5.02        6-month T-bills   4.35   4.35   4.95        10-yr. headline: A Haughty Blast From Communism's Past
abstract: Italian Prime Min Massimo D'Alema will hold his first official meeting with Pres Clinton in Washingon on March 5; D'Alema, former Communist, has recast himself as moderate; photo (M)

headline: Moscow Court Backs Treason Charge for Atom-Waste Exposer
abstract: Russia's highest court refuses to drop treason charges against Aleksandr Nikitin, retired officer who helped prepare report on Soviet nuclear submarine accidents for Bellona, Norwegian environmental organization that focuses on northwestern Russia, where submarine accidents, radioactive storage sites and ocean dumping of nuclear waste have prompted fears of nuclear pollution (M)

headline: The Japanese Intervene To Drive Down A Surging Yen
abstract: Japanese central bank intervenes in currency markets, selling yen for dollars and sending currency down 3 percent, its biggest one-day loss in more than three years; intervention is acknowledgment by Japan that rising value of yen, up 31 percent since August, is making its faltering effort to turn economy around even more difficult; strong yen is damaging because it makes Japanese exports, possible engine of recovery, much more expensive and less competitive abroad; graph; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Wheat prices surge on futures markets on speculation that United States will clear way for $500 million sale of crops to Iran; graph (S)

headline: JURY ORDERS DAYTON SUPERIOR UNIT TO PAY $36.4 MILLION
abstract: Federal jury orders Symons Corp, Dayton Superior Corp unit, to pay $36.4 million in damages to EFCO Corp, maker of forms for concrete construction, for false advertising and other misdeeds; misdeeds occurred before Dayton acquired Symons in 1997 (S)

headline: Pocket Paperbacks Are Losing Readers To Hardcover Sales
abstract: Purse-sized, mass-market paperback books are losing ground to discounted hardcovers and larger and more expensive quality trade paperbacks; $1.5 billion market for paperbacks remains profitable, but sales in United States have declined by almost 9 percent in last four years, to 484 million copies sold in 1998, which is three times percentage loss in consumer books over all; Book Industry Study Group, publishers' research arm, projects continued slight annual declines for paperback market; photo (M)

headline: 'Quality Time' on Two Fronts
abstract: Judith Abranovich letter supports Harvard economist Juliet B Schor, quoted in February 28 article, on adverse impact on children whose parents substitute themselves with toys and videos (S)

headline: Vice President For Siberia
abstract: Your boss offers you a promising new assignment with an exalted title, describing the job as a big step ahead. Your immediate response is to jump at the chance. But then -- maybe before taking the new job, maybe after -- you realize you are being moved over, not up. How did you discover that your promotion was no promotion? And what did you do next? Send your stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Palestinians About to Get an Area Code of Their Own
abstract: International Telecommunications Union, United Nations affiliate, announces that new area code has been reserved for Palestinian National Authority territory in West Bank and Gaza; action is taken over Israeli objections (M)

headline: About the Tables
abstract: Editors' Note: New York Times is making its daily mutual funds table more concise to accommodate growth in number of mutual funds; changes noted (S)

headline: Shares End Day Mixed, With Blue Chips Struggling a Bit
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 8.26 points, or almost one-tenth of 1 percent, to 9,544.42; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 0.96 point, or nearly one-tenth of a percent, to 1,271.18; Nasdaq composite index rises 34.34 points, or 1.5 percent, to 2,376.35; TheStreet.com's Internet index gains 23.55 points, or 4.8 percent, to 514.53; graph; chart (M)

headline: Amex Chairman Named Chief of Thermo Electron
abstract: Richard F Syron, chairman of American Stock Exchange, will become chief executive of Thermo Electron on June 1; Syron has served on board of Thermo Electron since September 1997; he will replace company's founder, George N Hatsopoulos, who will remain as nonexecutive chairman; photo (M)

headline: China Tries To Fend Off U.N. Censure Over Rights
abstract: China, even before start of this year's meetings of United Nations Human Rights Commission, begins vigorous campaign to head off possible censure of its human rights record (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN, SPAIN: GIBRALTAR DISPUTE -- A dispute over fishing rights around Gibraltar has intensified, with Spain threatening to stop honoring Gibraltar drivers' licenses and to ban aircraft flying to and from the British colony from Spanish airspace. Members of Parliament called for the Royal Navy to intervene, and Downing Street criticized Spain for its ''unacceptable threatening behavior.''   Sarah Lyall (NYT)    SPAIN, TURKEY: A PLEA ON KURDS -- Prime Minister Jose Maria Aznar has urged Basque nationalists to reverse a decision to invite the self-styled Kurdish parliament in  exile to meet next July in the Basque parliament chamber. Turkey says the 65-member group is linked to separatist rebels, and Spanish businessmen are concerned that a diplomatic wrangle could hurt exports.   (NYT)

headline: Arthur Raymond, DC-3 Maker, Dies at 99
abstract: Arthur E Raymond, leader of team that designed DC-3 airplane, dies two days short of his 100th birthday; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall St. Firms Nimbly Handle A Hard Quarter
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc beat estimates for their fourth-quarter earnings; Morgan Stanley says net income for quarter ended Nov 30 rose 51 percent, to $1.2 billion compared with $810 million in year-earlier period; Lehman had net income of $74 million in quarter, down 60 percent from $185 million in period a year earlier (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Issue du Jour at Microsoft Trial: Are Consumers Harmed?
abstract: Issue du Jour at Microsoft Trial: Are Consumers Harmed?**Massachusetts Institute of Technology economist Franklin M Fisher, economist testifying for Government, concedes that there is scant evidence consumers had been harmed by practices that are central to Justice Department's antitrust case against Microsoft Corp; he argues that real problem lies in future because Microsoft's monopoly in operating systems makes it de facto gatekeeper on new technology in personal compuer market (M)

headline: UGI STOCK PLUNGES AFTER OFFER FOR UNISOURCE
abstract: Shares of UGI Corp plunge after company announces it will buy Unisource Worldwide Inc; UGI will issue $815 million in stock and assume $710 million in debt to buy Unisource; UGI also says it will sell its UGI Utilities Inc unit, valued at more than $220 million, cut its dividend by 49 percent, and buy back as much as 20 percent of its common stock (S)

headline: New Owners of Barney's Lack Experience
abstract: When Barney's Inc., the high-end retailer whose Barneys New York stores turned basic black pants into a uniform of Manhattan chic, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in early 1996, it did not take long for two types of investors to swoop in.    There were other retailers, who were itching to buy the prestigious name. Saks Fifth Avenue offered $290 million in 1997 for its archrival. Dickson Poon, a Hong Kong entrepreneur whose Dickson Concepts also owns Britain's Harvey Nichols department store, bid $280 million. Last year, the DFS Group, no stranger to luxury goods through its many airport duty-free shops, also flirted with the company, valuing it roughly the same as Mr. Poon.

headline: Chocolate addicts, beware. DDB Needham's new campaign for Hershey is coming on strong.
abstract: Advertising column describes aggressive campaign to market new products from Hershey Foods Corp, including Reese's Bites and 'bites' of its other winning chocolate candies; company says bites are for 'mindless munching'; campaign was created by DDB Needham Worldwide; Hershey is trying to improve on sales of chocolate candy last year, which were flat at $3.2 billion even as sales of nonchocolate candy increased 32 percent (M)

headline: Pope Urges Bishops to Minister to the Rich
abstract: Pope John Paul II delivers Apostolic Exhortation to Bishops of North and South America during visit to Mexico City, urging them to take better care of poor while also instructing them to minister to rich; issues warning against increasing secularization of society; lashes out at inequities of unbridled free-market system; photo (M)

headline: Showtime to Give Web a Whirl With a New Animated Series
abstract: Showtime Networks' new animated series will be seen exclusively on World Wide Web; show, Whirlgirl, is about a 21st-century superheroine (S)

headline: Intuit's Earnings Show Strong Increase
abstract: Intuit Inc says profit from operations in fiscal second quarter was $84.8 million, up from $47 million in year-earlier period; revenue rose 46 percent, to $346 million from $237.5 million; Intuit says it plans to sell its 9.9 percent stake in Internet search directory Excite Inc, which could generate more than $500 million; Intuit has already sold 450,000 shares since At Home Corp offered to buy Excite last month (M)

headline: A Quick Fix for the Blahs of Winter
abstract: Michelle Slatalla (User's Guide) column on using her computer at home for short periods of time as way to defeat her winter doldrums (M)

headline: Siemens to Spin Off Semiconductor Division
abstract: Siemens AG says it will spin off its semiconductor division on April 1 under new name, Infineon Technologies AG; new company will employ 25,000 people in its headquarters in Munich (S)

headline: In Yugoslavia, Economy Is Already Limp
abstract: NATO air strikes against Serbia are unlikely to cause great harm to Yugoslav economy already battered by civil war and sanctions first imposed in 1992; Yugoslavia's currency has lost more than half its value in year since Kosovo conflict began (M)

headline: Spain's Vanguard Designers Turn to Distant Cultures for Inspiration
abstract: MADRIDâ€”  What do the American literary icon Paul Bowles, the late Spanish artist Joan Miro and an icy national park called Torre del Paine in southern Chile have in common?

headline: Monsanto Visionary in a Cubicle; Could His Company's Special Culture Survive a Merger?
abstract: Monsanto Corp, life sciences company with nontraditional approach to corporate life, is said to be in merger talks with DuPont, much larger and more traditional chemicals and life sciences company; Monsanto chief executive Robert B Shapiro has been searching for a way for Monsanto to be acquired by DuPont and still retain its special character and habits, with its own compensation and incentive programs, and possibly its own stock; corporate culture is important to Monsanto as it slowly transforms itself from chemicals concern to what is called life sciences company, making everything from arthritis drugs to genetically modified crops; charts; photos (M)

headline: REGULATION COULD DELAY THE PURCHASE OF BANKERS TRUST
abstract: Deutsche Bank A.G.'s planned $10.1 billion acquisition of the Bankers Trust Corporation could be derailed if regulators in the United States delay approval, Rolf Breuer, chief executive of Deutsche, said. He commented to a German TV station on Monday after the bank, Jewish leaders, and American and German Government officials met in Washington to try to settle compensation claims by victims of the Nazi Holocaust and their heirs. The acquisition by Bankers Trust, based in New York, by Deutsche, Germany's largest bank, requires the approval of banking regulators in the United States Government and in New York State.

headline: State Farm Car Profit Falls
abstract: State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Co says 1998 profit from its car insurance business fell 56 percent, to $1.1 billion, as it paid more dividends and faced higher losses on policies; says its homeowners insurance unit lost money and that life insurance profut rose (S)

headline: Two Prominent Law Firms Call Off a Proposed Merger
abstract: Prominent New York law firms White & Case and Brown & Wood call off their proposed merger after at least four months of talks, saying move is 'impractical' (M)

headline: The Deal Still Rules
abstract: Merger boom has been true market mania of 1990's, bigger, broader and more significant for investors and economy than Internet hoopla; broadening of stock ownership by average Americans and pervasiveness of mergers in nearly every industry have left few Americans unaffected by today's merger wave; $7.1 trillion in deals have been announced worldwide since boom began in Jan 1994; 50 biggest American companies at start of 1994 have since been involved in 4,190 mergers or acquisitions, six have disappeared through mergers and three more are slated to vanish; wide range of investors now trade merger stocks actively, not just sophisticated institutions; graphs; photos (M)

headline: More Details On Holbrooke As Senators Review Files
abstract: Senate Foreign Relations Committee is weighing Pres Clinton's nomination of Richard C Holbrooke to be chief delegate to United Nations; Congressional officials from both parties expect Holbrooke to be confirmed by Senate, but panel's Republican leadership has first vowed to investigate variety of conflict-of-interest allegations made against veteran diplomat; one matter involves Holbrooke's opening of job negotiations with large investment bank only months after he intervened, as State Dept official, to help bank win consulting contract; investigators find no evidence that Holbrooke saw bank as potential employer at that time (M)

headline: Media Buyers Worry About the Timing at Talk
abstract: Media buyers express concern about Miramax Films's Talk magazine's late start in selling advertising pages; writers express surprise that magazine, set for Aug launch, offers lower-than-expected salaries; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Drop Sharply After Positive Economic Reports
abstract: US Treasury bond prices post biggest drop in almost three months; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 1 18/32, to 101 1/32; yield rises to 5.18 percent from 5.08 percent; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: More Foreign Papers
abstract: Letter from Larry Burnagiel says Mar 4 article on foreign news on Web failed to mention media links by Editor & Publisher, newspaper industry's own trade journal (S)

headline: VW Shares Tumble On Profit Warning
abstract: Car shares decline across Europe after Volkswagen warns it will be 'difficult' to raise 1999 profit; says 1998 earnings climbed 65 percent, but slowing fourth-quarter sales led to lower-than-expected 1998 earnings per share of 9.5 marks; investors had expected popularity of VW's new models to overcome slowing worldwide sales growth; Volswagen shares fall 6.25 percent; other car shares that fell include Bayerische Motoren Werke AG, down 3.46 percent, PSA Peugeot Citroen, down 2.27 percent, and Fiat SpA, down 1.91 percent (S)

headline: LVMH Raises Its Stake in Gucci to 26.7%
abstract: LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton SA says it raised its stake in Gucci Group NV to 26.7 percent, strengthening its influence over the Italian company and providing platform from which to make eventual takeover offer; LVMH says it does not plan takeover bid for Gucci 'under present conditions' (S)

headline: Ford and Chrysler Beat Sales Forecasts
abstract: DaimlerChrysler AG and Ford Motor Co beat analysts' December sales figures; Ford says sales of domestic car and light-truck rose 6.1 percent, well above prediction of rise of six-tenths of a percent; Chrysler car and light-truck sales rose 6.9 percent, surpassing forecast of 5 percent (S)

headline: Starcom Creates Executive Positions
abstract: Starcom Media Services, unit of Leo Burnett Co, is creating four top management positions for its American operations; changes will help free Jack Klues, chairman, and Bob Brennan, president, to develop global expansion plans; new positions will be held by Renetta McCann, John Muszynski, Mary Ann Foxley and Kathy Ring (S)

headline: The View From the Outside: Levi's Needs More Than a Patch
abstract: IT'S hard to think of a more iconic product than Levi's jeans. Or of an iconic company that has been stuck in a slump as long as has Levi Strauss & Company, the privately held San Francisco clothing maker that has been losing market share to upstart brands and private labels.    Last week, Levi's announced that it would lay off 5,900 workers, close 11 plants and shift manufacturing overseas to cut costs.

headline: Keychain Pager Is Aimed At the Playground Crowd
abstract: Playmates Toys releases just-for-children pager called Friend.link which can send E-mail-style messages via radio waves to other Friend.links within 25 feet; target age for device is 8 through 13; photo (S)

headline: An Overseas Stake In the American Dream
abstract: Last May, Israel declared its currency, the shekel, freely convertible, making it easier for citizens to own foreign bank accounts and invest overseas. One unexpected result: Israelis with spare cash are snapping up property in America.    Land is something of an obsession in Israel, where desirable real estate is scarce enough to be very expensive. So when the shekel became convertible, Israeli real estate companies leapt into action, setting up consortiums to buy New York apartment buildings that look like bargains by Israeli standards.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- Pluralism Under Golden Arches; From Abroad, McDonald's Finds Value in Local Control
abstract: In Austria, Indonesia and South Korea, McDonald's sells Big Macs and Happy Meals. But its Vienna franchises also contain ''McCafes,'' which offer coffee blended for local tastes. In Jakarta, the McDonald's menu includes rice as well as french fries. And in Seoul, the burger chain sells roast pork on a bun with a garlicky soy sauce.    That combination of a globally recognized brand with a flexible menu that caters to local palates has helped McDonald's navigate the global economic turbulence that has knocked most of the other big corporations operating around the world way off course.    For the 15th consecutive year, the McDonald's Corporation has achieved solid growth in its international division, which now accounts for nearly 60 percent of corporate profits. No other American multinational has enjoyed such consistent success abroad, particularly lately amid the dizzying plunges in local currencies and economic activity in much of Asia and Latin America. McDonald's says a large part of the reason it has done so well is that its operations overseas are run by local residents who are attuned to changing economic conditions and consumer tastes.
